Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers such that $a b c = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\left(1+\frac{a}{b}\right)\left(1+\frac{b}{c}\right)\left(1+\frac{c}{a}\right) \geq C(1 + a + b + c)
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{a}{c}+\frac{b}{a}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}+\frac{c}{b} \geq 2(a+b+c)
$$

Furthermore
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{a}{c}+1=\frac{a}{b}+\frac{a}{c}+a b c \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a^{3}}=3 a
$$

Analogously
$$
\frac{b}{a}+\frac{b}{c}+1 \geq 3 b \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c}{a}+\frac{c}{b}+1 \geq 3 c
$$

So
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{a}{c}+\frac{b}{a}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}+\frac{c}{b}+3 \geq 3(a+b+c) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

It is enough to show that $a+b+c \geq 3$.
We have $a+b+c \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a b c}=3$, and finally from (1) we obtain
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{a}{c}+\frac{b}{a}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}+\frac{c}{b}+3 \geq 2(a+b+c)+(a+b+c) \geq 2(a+b+c)+3
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{a}{c}+\frac{b}{a}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}+\frac{c}{b} \geq 2(a+b+c)
$$

Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{b}{(c+a)^{2}}+\frac{c}{(a+b)^{2}} \geq \frac{C}{a+b+c}
$$
solution: Without loss of generality we may assume that $a+b+c=1$. Now, consider the function $f:(0,1) \rightarrow(0, \infty), f(x)=\frac{x}{(1-x)^{2}}$. A short computation of derivatives shows that $f$ is convex. Thus, we may apply Jensen's Inequality and the conclusion follows.

We rewrite the inequality as

$$
(a+b+c)\left(\frac{a}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{b}{(c+a)^{2}}+\frac{c}{(a+b)^{2}}\right) \geq \frac{9}{4}
$$

Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality we get

$$
(a+b+c)\left(\frac{a}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{b}{(c+a)^{2}}+\frac{c}{(a+b)^{2}}\right) \geq\left(\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}\right)^{2}
$$

It remains to prove that

$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b} \geq \frac{3}{2}
$$

which is well-known.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers such that $ab + bc + ca = 1$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{a+b}+\frac{1}{b+c}+\frac{1}{c+a}-\frac{1}{a+b+c} \geq C.
$$

Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^4 + b^4 + c^4 = 3$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1}{4-ab} + \frac{1}{4-bc} + \frac{1}{4-ca} \leq C
$$
solution:
After clearing denominators the given inequality becomes
$$
48-8 \sum_{\text {sym }} a b+a b c \sum_{\text {sym }} a \leq 64-16 \sum_{\text {sym }} a b+4 a b c \sum_{\text {sym }} a-a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
16+3 a b c(a+b+c) \geq a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}+8(a b+b c+c a) . \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Applying Schur's inequality we have that
$\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+3 a b c\right)(a+b+c) \geq(a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)+c a(c+a))(a+b+c)$, and since $a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}=3$ we deduce
$$
\begin{equation*}
3+3 a b c(a+b+c) \geq(a b+a c)^{2}+(a c+b c)^{2}+(b c+a b)^{2} . \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\begin{equation*}
(a b+a c)^{2}+(a c+b c)^{2}+(b c+a b)^{2}+12 \geq 8(a b+b c+c a) \tag{3}
\end{equation*}
$$

Now from (2) and (3) we deduce
$$
\begin{equation*}
15+3 a b c(a+b+c) \geq 8(a b+b c+c a) \tag{4}
\end{equation*}
$$

Once more we apply $A M \geq G M$, and we get
$$
3=a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{4}}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad 1 \geq a b c
$$
or
$$
\begin{equation*}
1 \geq a^{2} b^{2} c^{2} \tag{5}
\end{equation*}
$$

Finally using (4) and (5) we get inequality (1).
Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$.,Let $x=a b, y=b c$ and $z=a c$. The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{1-x}{4-x}+\frac{1-y}{4-y}+\frac{1-z}{4-z} \geq 0
$$
or
$$
\frac{1-x^{2}}{4+3 x-x^{2}}+\frac{1-y^{2}}{4+3 y-y^{2}}+\frac{1-z^{2}}{4+3 z+z^{2}} \geq 0
$$

Notice that
$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=(a b)^{2}+(b c)^{2}+(c a)^{2} \leq a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}=3
$$

Assume that $x \geq y \geq z$. Then clearly
$$
1-x^{2} \leq 1-y^{2} \leq 1-z^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{4+3 x-x^{2}} \leq \frac{1}{4+3 y-y^{2}} \leq \frac{1}{4+3 z+z^{2}}
$$

Therefore by Chebishev's inequality we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3\left(\frac{1-x^{2}}{4+3 x-x^{2}}+\frac{1-y^{2}}{4+3 y-y^{2}}+\frac{1-z^{2}}{4+3 z+z^{2}}\right) \\
& \quad \geq\left(1-x^{2}+1-y^{2}+1-z^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4+3 x-x^{2}}+\frac{1}{4+3 y-y^{2}}+\frac{1}{4+3 z+z^{2}}\right) \\
& \quad \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$ such that $x + y + z = xyz$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
(x-1)(y-1)(z-1) \leq C.
$$
solution:
Because of $x<x y z \Rightarrow y z>1$ (and the similar relations $x z>1, x y>1$ ) at most one of the three numbers can be less than 1 . In any of these cases $(x \leq 1, y \geq 1$, $z \geq 1$ or the similar ones) the inequality to prove is clear. The only case we still have to analyse is that when $x \geq 1, y \geq 1$ and $z \geq 1$.

In this situation denote

$$
x-1=a, y-1=b, z-1=c
$$

Then $a, b, c$ are nonnegative real numbers and, because

$$
x=a+1, y=b+1, z=c+1
$$

they satisfy

$$
a+1+b+1+c+1=(a+1)(b+1)(c+1)
$$

which means

$$
a b c+a b+a c+b c=2
$$

Now let $x=\sqrt[3]{a b c}$; we have

$$
a b+a c+b c \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a b a c b c}=3 x^{2}
$$

that's why we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{3}+3 x^{2} \leq 2 \Leftrightarrow(x+1)\left(x^{2}+2 x-2\right) \leq 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(x+1)(x+1+\sqrt{3})(x+1-\sqrt{3}) \leq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

For $x \geq 0$, this yields

$$
\sqrt[3]{a b c}=x \leq \sqrt{3}-1
$$

or, equivalently

$$
a b c \leq(\sqrt{3}-1)^{3}
$$

which is exactly

$$
(x-1)(y-1)(z-1) \leq 6 \sqrt{3}-10 .
$$

The proof is complete.,Like in the first solution (and due to the symmetry) we may suppose that $x \geq 1$, $y \geq 1$; we can even assume that $x>1, y>1$ (for $x=1$ the inequality is plain). Then we get $x y>1$ and from the given condition we have

$$
z=\frac{x+y}{x y-1}
$$

The relation to prove is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (x-1)(y-1)(z-1) \leq 6 \sqrt{3}-10 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow 2 x y z-(x y+x z+y z) \leq 6 \sqrt{3}-9
\end{aligned}
$$

or, with this expression of $z$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
2 x y \frac{x+y}{x y-1}-x y-(x+y) \frac{x+y}{x y-1} \leq 6 \sqrt{3}-9 \Leftrightarrow \\
\Leftrightarrow(x y-x-y)^{2}+(6 \sqrt{3}-10) x y \leq 6 \sqrt{3}-9,
\end{gathered}
$$

after some calculations.
Now, we put $x=a+1, y=b+1$ and transform this into

$$
a^{2} b^{2}+(6 \sqrt{3}-10)(a+b+a b)-2 a b \geq 0
$$

But

$$
a+b \geq 2 \sqrt{a b}
$$

and $6 \sqrt{3}-10>0$, so it suffices to show that

$$
a^{2} b^{2}+(6 \sqrt{3}-10)(2 \sqrt{a b}+a b)-2 a b \geq 0
$$

The substitution $t=\sqrt{a b} \geq 0$ reduces this inequality to

$$
t^{4}+(6 \sqrt{3}-12) t^{2}+2(6 \sqrt{3}-10) t \geq 0
$$

or

$$
t^{3}+(6 \sqrt{3}-12) t+2(6 \sqrt{3}-10) \geq 0
$$

The derivative of the function

$$
f(t)=t^{3}+(6 \sqrt{3}-12) t+2(6 \sqrt{3}-10), t \geq 0
$$

is

$$
f^{\prime}(t)=3\left(t^{2}-(\sqrt{3}-1)^{2}\right)
$$

and has only one positive zero. It is $\sqrt{3}-1$ and it's easy to see that this is a minimum point for $f$ in the interval $[0, \infty)$. Consequently

$$
f(t) \geq f(\sqrt{3}-1)=0
$$

and we are done.
A final observation: in fact we have

$$
f(t)=(t-\sqrt{3}+1)^{2}(t+2 \sqrt{3}-2)
$$

which shows that $f(t) \geq 0$ for $t \geq 0$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$.  Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:

$$
\frac{abc}{(1+a)(a+b)(b+c)(c+16)} \leq C.
$$
solution:
By Hlder's inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
(1+a)(a+b)(b+c)(c+16) & \geq(\sqrt[4]{1 \cdot a \cdot b \cdot c}+\sqrt[4]{a \cdot b \cdot c \cdot 16})^{4} \\
& =(3 \sqrt[4]{a b c})^{4}=81 a b c
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{1}{a}=\frac{a}{b}=\frac{b}{c}=\frac{c}{16}$, i.e. $a=2, b=4, c=8$.

Theorem 54.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n} ; m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}$ be three sequences of positive real numbers and let $p>1$. Then
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be the angles of a triangle and let $t$ be a real number. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ and $t$:
$$
\cos \alpha + t(\cos \beta + \cos \gamma) \leq 1 + C
$$
solution:
For any three real numbers $\beta, \gamma, t$, the following inequality holds:
$$
(\cos \beta+\cos \gamma-t)^{2}+(\sin \beta-\sin \gamma)^{2} \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
-\cos (\beta+\gamma)+t(\cos \beta+\cos \gamma) \leq 1+\frac{t^{2}}{2}
$$

Since $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$ we have
$$
\cos \alpha+t(\cos \beta+\cos \gamma) \leq 1+\frac{t^{2}}{2}
$$

Equality occurs iff $0<t<2, \cos \alpha=1-\frac{t^{2}}{2}, \cos \beta=\cos \gamma$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $xyz = 1$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\frac{1}{(x+1)^{2}+y^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{(y+1)^{2}+z^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{(z+1)^{2}+x^{2}+1} \leq C.
$$
solution:
We have
$$
\frac{1}{(x+1)^{2}+y^{2}+1}=\frac{1}{2+x^{2}+y^{2}+2 x} \leq \frac{1}{2(1+x+x y)}
$$

Similarly
$$
\frac{1}{(y+1)^{2}+z^{2}+1} \leq \frac{1}{2(1+y+y z)} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{(z+1)^{2}+x^{2}+1} \leq \frac{1}{2(1+z+z x)}
$$

So we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{(x+1)^{2}+y^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{(y+1)^{2}+z^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{(z+1)^{2}+x^{2}+1} \\
& \quad \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{1+x+x y}+\frac{1}{1+y+y z}+\frac{1}{1+z+z x}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We'll show that
$$
\frac{1}{1+x+x y}+\frac{1}{1+y+y z}+\frac{1}{1+z+z x}=1
$$
from which we'll deduce the required result.
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{1+x+x y}+\frac{1}{1+y+y z}+\frac{1}{1+z+z x} \\
& =\frac{x y z}{x y z+x+x y}+\frac{1}{1+y+y z}+\frac{1}{1+z+z x} \\
& =\frac{y z}{y z+1+y}+\frac{1}{1+y+y z}+\frac{y}{y+y z+1} \\
& =\frac{1+y+y z}{1+y+y z}=1
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x + y + z = 3$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\sqrt{x} + \sqrt{y} + \sqrt{z} \geq C(xy + yz + zx)
$$
solution:
Rewrite the inequality in the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{2}+2 \sqrt{x}+y^{2} & +2 \sqrt{y}+z^{2}+2 \sqrt{z} \geq x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+2 x y+2 y z+2 z x \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow x^{2}+2 \sqrt{x}+y^{2}+2 \sqrt{y}+z^{2}+2 \sqrt{z} \geq 9
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, from the AM-GM Inequality, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
x^{2}+2 \sqrt{x}=x^{2}+\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{x^{2} \cdot x}=3 x \\
y^{2}+2 \sqrt{y} \geq 3 y, z^{2}+2 \sqrt{z} \geq 3 z
\end{gathered}
$$

hence

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+2(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{z}) \geq 3(x+y+z) \geq 9
$$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $x, y$ be positive real numbers. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
x^{y}+y^{x} \geq C
$$
solution:
We'll show that for every real number $a, b \in(0,1)$ we have
$$
a^{b} \geq \frac{a}{a+b-a b}
$$

By Bernoulli's inequality we have
$$
a^{1-b}=(1+a-1)^{1-b} \leq 1+(a-1)(1-b)=a+b-a b,
$$
i.e.
$$
a^{b} \geq \frac{a}{a+b-a b}
$$

If $x \geq 1$ or $y \geq 1$ then the given inequality clearly holds.
So let $0<x, y<1$.
By the previous inequality we have
$$
x^{y}+y^{x} \geq \frac{x}{x+y-x y}+\frac{y}{x+y-x y}=\frac{x+y}{x+y-x y}>\frac{x+y}{x+y}=1
$$

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

problem:
Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $x y z \geq 1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{x^{5}-x^{2}}{x^{5}+y^{2}+z^{2}}+\frac{y^{5}-y^{2}}{y^{5}+z^{2}+x^{2}}+\frac{z^{5}-z^{2}}{z^{5}+x^{2}+y^{2}} \geq C
$$

Theorem 78.Theorem:
Consider the expression $S=S_{a}(b-c)^{2}+$ $S_{b}(a-c)^{2}+S_{c}(a-b)^{2}$, where $S_{a}, S_{b}, S_{c}$ are functions of $a, b, c$.
$1^{\circ}$ If $S_{a}, S_{b}, S_{c} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$2^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$ and $S_{b}, S_{b}+S_{a}, S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$3^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$ and $S_{a}, S_{c}, S_{a}+2 S_{b}, S_{c}+2 S_{b} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$4^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ and $S_{b}, S_{c}, a^{2} S_{b}+b^{2} S_{a} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$5^{\circ}$ If $S_{a}+S_{b} \geq 0$ or $S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0$ or $S_{c}+S_{a} \geq 0\left(S_{a}+S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0\right)$ and $S_{a} S_{b}+S_{b} S_{c}+S_{c} S_{a} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.

problem:
For a given $n > 2$, find the maximal value of the constant $C$ such that for any $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n > 0$ satisfying $x_1^2 + x_2^2 + \cdots + x_n^2 = 1$, the following inequality holds:
$$
(1-x_1)(1-x_2) \ldots (1-x_n) \geq C x_1 x_2 \ldots x_n
$$
solution:
We will prove that this constant is $(\sqrt{n}-1)^{n}$. Indeed, let $a_{i}=x_{i}^{2}$. We must find the minimal value of the expression

$$
\frac{\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1-\sqrt{a_{i}}\right)}{\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{a_{i}}}
$$

when $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=1$. Let us observe that proving that this minimum is $(\sqrt{n}-1)^{n}$ reduces to proving that

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1-a_{i}\right) \geq(\sqrt{n}-1)^{n} \cdot \prod_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{a_{i}} \cdot \prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+\sqrt{a_{i}}\right)
$$

But from the result proved in the solution of the problem 121, we find that

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1-a_{i}\right)^{2} \geq\left(\frac{(n-1)^{2}}{n}\right)^{n} \prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}
$$

So, it is enough to prove that

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+\sqrt{a_{i}}\right) \leq\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\right)^{n}
$$

But this is an easy task, because from the AM-GM Inequality we get

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+\sqrt{a_{i}}\right) \leq\left(1+\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{a_{i}}}{n}\right)^{n} \leq\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\right)^{n}
$$

the last one being a simple consequence of the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle, and let $s$ be the semi-perimeter of the triangle. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a b c < a^{2}(s-a) + b^{2}(s-a) + c^{2}(s-a) \leq C a b c
$$
solution:
Since
$$
\begin{aligned}
2\left(a^{2}(s-a)+b^{2}(s-a)+c^{2}(s-a)\right)= & a^{2} b+a^{2} c+b^{2} a+b^{2} c+c^{2} a+c^{2} b \\
& -\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
and
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (b+c-a)(c+a-b)(a+b-c) \\
& \quad=a^{2} b+a^{2} c+b^{2} a+b^{2} c+c^{2} a+c^{2} b-\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)-2 a b c
\end{aligned}
$$
we have
$2\left(a^{2}(s-a)+b^{2}(s-a)+c^{2}(s-a)\right)=(b+c-a)(c+a-b)(a+b-c)+2 a b c$.
Hence
$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{2}(s-a)+b^{2}(s-a)+c^{2}(s-a) & =\frac{(b+c-a)(c+a-b)(a+b-c)}{2}+a b c \\
& >a b c
\end{aligned}
$$

Recalling the well-known inequality
$$
(b+c-a)(c+a-b)(a+b-c) \leq a b c
$$
we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{2}(s-a)+b^{2}(s-a)+c^{2}(s-a) & =\frac{(b+c-a)(c+a-b)(a+b-c)}{2}+a b c \\
& \leq \frac{3}{2} a b c
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality holds if and only if the triangle is equilateral.

problem:
Let $a, b$ be real numbers such that $9a^2 + 8ab + 7b^2 \leq 6$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
7a + 5b + 12ab \leq C
$$
solution:
By the inequality $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
7 a+5 b+12 a b & \leq 7\left(a^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\right)+5\left(a^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\right)+12 a b \\
& =7 a^{2}+5 b^{2}+12 a b+3 \\
& =9 a^{2}+8 a b+7 b^{2}-2 a^{2}+4 a b-2 b^{2}+3 \\
& =9 a^{2}+8 a b+7 b^{2}-2(a-b)^{2}+3 \leq 6+3=9
\end{aligned}
$$
as required. Equality holds iff $a=b=1 / 2$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
C+\left(2+\frac{a^{2}}{b c}\right)\left(2+\frac{b^{2}}{c a}\right)\left(2+\frac{c^{2}}{a b}\right) \geq 6(a+b+c)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 a b c\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+3 a b c-a^{2} b-a^{2} c-b^{2} a-b^{2} c-c^{2} a-c^{2} b\right) \\
& \quad+\left(a^{3} b^{3}+b^{3} c^{3}+c^{3} a^{3}+3 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}-a b^{3} c^{2}-a b^{2} c^{3}-a^{2} b^{1} c^{3}-a^{3} b^{1} c^{2}\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
which is true due to Schur's inequality, for variables $a, b, c$ and $a b, b c, c a$.

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b$:
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a} \geq C
$$
solution:
From the obvious inequality $(a-b)^{2} \geq 0$ we have
$a^{2}-2 a b+b^{2} \geq 0 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad a^{2}+b^{2} \geq 2 a b \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{a b} \geq 2 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a} \geq 2$.
Equality occurs if and only if $a-b=0$, i.e. $a=b$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$ be real numbers. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\sqrt{x(y+z)}+\sqrt{y(z+x)}+\sqrt{z(x+y)} \geq C \sqrt{\frac{(x+y)(y+z)(z+x)}{x+y+z}}
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\sqrt{\frac{x(x+y+z)}{(x+y)(x+z)}}+\sqrt{\frac{y(x+y+z)}{(y+z)(y+x)}}+\sqrt{\frac{z(x+y+z)}{(z+x)(z+y)}} \geq 2
$$

According to Case 10, it suffices to show that
$$
\cos \frac{\alpha}{2}+\cos \frac{\beta}{2}+\cos \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq 2
$$
where $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle, i.e. $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$ and $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$. Due to Case 1, it remains to prove that
$$
\sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma \geq 2
$$
where $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of an acute triangle, i.e. $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi / 2)$ and $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$.

Since $\alpha \in(0, \pi / 2]$ it follows that $0<\sin \alpha \leq 1$, i.e. $\sin \alpha \geq \sin ^{2} \alpha$, and equality occurs if and only if $\alpha=\pi / 2$.

Similarly for $\beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi / 2]$ we conclude that
$$
\sin \beta \geq \sin ^{2} \beta \quad \text { and } \quad \sin \gamma \geq \sin ^{2} \gamma
$$

Thus we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma \\
& \quad \geq \sin ^{2} \alpha+\sin ^{2} \beta+\sin ^{2} \gamma \\
& \quad=\frac{1-\cos 2 \alpha}{2}+\frac{1-\cos 2 \beta}{2}+\sin ^{2} \gamma=1-\frac{1}{2}(\cos 2 \alpha+\cos 2 \beta)+\sin ^{2} \gamma \\
& \quad=1-\frac{1}{2} 2 \cos (\alpha+\beta) \cos (\alpha-\beta)+1-\cos ^{2} \gamma \\
& \quad=2-\cos (\pi-\gamma) \cos (\alpha-\beta)-\cos ^{2} \gamma=2+\cos \gamma \cos (\alpha-\beta)-\cos ^{2} \gamma \\
& \quad=2+\cos \gamma(\cos (\alpha-\beta)-\cos \gamma)=2+\cos \gamma[\cos (\alpha-\beta)-\cos (\pi-(\alpha+\beta))] \\
& \quad=2+\cos \gamma(\cos (\alpha-\beta)+\cos (\alpha+\beta))=2+2 \cos \gamma \cos \alpha \cos \beta>2
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 45.Theorem:
Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$. Then $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle if and only if
$$
\sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\beta}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\gamma}{2}+2 \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\gamma}{2}=1
$$

problem:
Consider the pairwise distinct integers $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$, $n \geq 0$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all pairwise distinct integers $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$:
$$
x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\cdots+x_{n}^{2} \geq x_{1} x_{2}+x_{2} x_{3}+\cdots+x_{n} x_{1}+C
$$
solution:
The inequality can be rewritten as

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}-x_{i+1}\right)^{2} \geq 2(2 n-3)
$$

Let $x_{m}=\min \left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}$ and $x_{M}=\max \left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}$. Suppose without loss of generality that $m<M$. Let

$$
S_{1}=\left(x_{m}-x_{m+1}\right)^{2}+\cdots+\left(x_{M-1}-x_{M}\right)^{2}
$$

and

$$
S_{2}=\left(x_{M}-x_{M+1}\right)^{2}+\cdots+\left(x_{n}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}+\cdots+\left(x_{m-1}-x_{m}\right)^{2}
$$

The inequality $\sum_{i=1}^{k} a_{i}^{2} \geq \frac{1}{k}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k} a_{i}\right)^{2}$ (which follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality) implies that

$$
S_{1} \geq \frac{\left(x_{M}-x_{m}\right)^{2}}{M-m}
$$

and

$$
S_{2} \geq \frac{\left(x_{M}-x_{m}\right)^{2}}{n-(M-m)}
$$

So

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}-x_{i+1}\right)^{2} & =S_{1}+S_{2} \geq\left(x_{M}-x_{m}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{1}{M-m}+\frac{1}{n-(M-m)}\right) \geq \\
& \geq(n-1)^{2} \frac{4}{n}=4 n-8+\frac{4}{n}>4 n-8
\end{aligned}
$$

But

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}-x_{i+1}\right)^{2} \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}-x_{i+1}=0 \bmod 2
$$

so

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}-x_{i+1}\right)^{2} \geq 4 n-6
$$

and the problem is solved.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $abc = 1$. Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{a^{3}(b+c)}+\frac{1}{b^{3}(c+a)}+\frac{1}{c^{3}(a+b)} \geq C.
$$
solution:
If we divide both sides by $(a b c)^{4 / 3}=1$, and after clearing the denominators, the given inequality will be equivalent to
$$
2 T\left[\frac{16}{3}, \frac{13}{3}, \frac{7}{3}\right]+T\left[\frac{16}{3}, \frac{16}{3}, \frac{4}{3}\right]+T\left[\frac{13}{3}, \frac{13}{3}, \frac{10}{3}\right] \geq 3 T[5,4,3]+T[4,4,4]
$$

Now according to Muirhead's inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 T\left[\frac{16}{3}, \frac{13}{3}, \frac{7}{3}\right] \geq 2 T[5,4,3], \quad T\left[\frac{16}{3}, \frac{16}{3}, \frac{4}{3}\right] \geq T[5,4,3] \\
& T\left[\frac{13}{3}, \frac{13}{3}, \frac{10}{3}\right] \geq T[4,4,4] .
\end{aligned}
$$

If we add the last three inequalities we obtain the required result.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b + b c + c a = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\left(a^{2}+a b+b^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}+b c+c^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}+c a+a^{2}\right) \geq C
$$

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b$ and $c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle, and $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be its angles (in radians), respectively. Let $s$ be the semi-perimeter of the triangle. Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all triangles:
$$
\frac{b+c}{\alpha}+\frac{c+a}{\beta}+\frac{a+b}{\gamma} \geq C s.
$$

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\sqrt{\frac{a}{b+c}}+\sqrt{\frac{b}{c+a}}+\sqrt{\frac{c}{a+b}} > C
$$
solution:
We'll show that $\sqrt{\frac{x}{y+z}} \geq \frac{2 x}{x+y+z}$, for every $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$.
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sqrt{\frac{x}{y+z}} \geq \frac{2 x}{x+y+z} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{x}{y+z} \geq\left(\frac{2 x}{x+y+z}\right)^{2} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad(x+y+z)^{2} \geq 4 x(y+z) \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(y+z-x)^{2} \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
with equality iff $x=y+z$.
Now we easily obtain
$$
\sqrt{\frac{a}{b+c}}+\sqrt{\frac{b}{c+a}}+\sqrt{\frac{c}{a+b}} \geq \frac{2(a+b+c)}{a+b+c}=2
$$
with equality if and only if $a=b+c, b=a+c, c=a+b$, i.e. $a=b=c=0$, which is impossible.

So we have strict inequality, i.e. $\sqrt{\frac{a}{b+c}}+\sqrt{\frac{b}{c+a}}+\sqrt{\frac{c}{a+b}}>2$, as required.

Theorem 11.Theorem:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Given a function $f$ of $n$ variables, define the cyclic sum of variables $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{c y c} f\left(x_{1}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+f\left(x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}, x_{1}\right) \\
+\ldots+f\left(a_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n-1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be real numbers such that $\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+b^{2}\right)\left(1+c^{2}\right)\left(1+d^{2}\right)=16$. Determine the minimal constant $C_1$ and maximal constant $C_2$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:

$$
-C_2 \leq a b+b c+c d+d a+a c+b d-a b c d \leq C_1
$$
solution:
Let us write the condition in the form $16=\prod(i+a) \cdot \prod(a-i)$. Using symmetric sums, we can write this as follows
$16=\left(1-i \sum a-\sum a b+i \sum a b c+a b c d\right)\left(1+i \sum a-\sum a b-i \sum a b c+a b c d\right)$. So, we have the identity $16=\left(1-\sum a b+a b c d\right)^{2}+\left(\sum a-\sum a b c\right)^{2}$. This means that $\left|1-\sum a b+a b c d\right| \leq 4$ and from here the conclusion follows.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $ab + bc + ca + abc = 4$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} \geq C(a + b + c)
$$
solution:
Since $a b+b c+c a+a b c=4$ there exist real numbers $x, y, z$ such that
$$
a=\frac{2 x}{y+z}, \quad b=\frac{2 y}{z+x}, \quad c=\frac{2 z}{x+y}
$$
and the given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{x+y}{z}+\frac{z+x}{y}+\frac{y+z}{x} \geq 4\left(\frac{x}{y+z}+\frac{y}{z+x}+\frac{z}{x+y}\right) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Inequality (1) is homogenous, so we may assume that $x+y+z=1, x y+y z+$ $z x=u, x y z=v$.

After some algebraic transformations we find that inequality (1) can be rewritten as follows
$$
9 v^{2}+4(1-u) v-v^{2} \geq 0
$$

So, according to the $A B C$ theorem, we need to consider just two cases:
If $z=0$ then inequality (1) is trivially correct.
If $y=z=1$ (we can do this because of the homogenous property) inequality (1) becomes
$$
2(x+1)+\frac{2}{x} \geq 4\left(\frac{x}{2}+\frac{2}{x+1}\right) \text { i.e. } \quad 2(x-1)^{2} \geq 0
$$
which is obvious.

Theorem 77.Theorem: If the function $f(a b c, a b+b c+c a, a+b+c)$ is a concave function then it achieves it's maximum and minimum values on $\mathbb{R}$ when $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$, and on $\mathbb{R}^{+}$when $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$ or $a b c=0$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z \geq 2$ be real numbers. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z \geq 2$:
$$
\left(y^{3}+x\right)\left(z^{3}+y\right)\left(x^{3}+z\right) \geq C x y z
$$
solution:
We have
$$
y^{3}+x \geq 4 y+x=y+y+y+y+x \geq 5 \sqrt[5]{y^{4} x}
$$

Analogously
$$
z^{3}+y \geq 5 \sqrt[5]{z^{4} y} \quad \text { and } \quad x^{3}+z \geq 5 \sqrt[5]{x^{4} z}
$$

Multiplying the last three inequalities gives us the required inequality.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$ such that $(x+y+z)^{3}=32 x y z$. Determine the minimum constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\frac{x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}}{(x+y+z)^{4}} \leq C.
$$
solution:
We may of course assume that $x+y+z=4$ and $x y z=2$. Thus, we have to find the
extremal values of $\frac{x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}}{4^{4}}$. Now, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4} & =\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2}-2 \sum x^{2} y^{2}= \\
& =\left(16-2 \sum x y\right)^{2}-2\left(\sum x y\right)^{2}+4 x y z(x+y+z)= \\
& =2 a^{2}-64 a+288
\end{aligned}
$$

where $a=x y+y z+z x$. Because $y+z=4-x$ and $y z=\frac{2}{x}$, we must have $(4-x)^{2} \geq \frac{8}{x}$, which implies that $3-\sqrt{5} \leq x \leq 2$. Due to symmetry, we have $x, y, z \in[3-\sqrt{5}, 2]$. This means that $(x-2)(y-2)(z-2) \leq 0$ and also

$$
(x-3+\sqrt{5})(y-3+\sqrt{5})(z-3+\sqrt{5}) \geq 0
$$

Clearing paranthesis, we deduce that

$$
a \in\left[5, \frac{5 \sqrt{5}-1}{2}\right]
$$

But because $\frac{x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}}{4^{4}}=\frac{(a-16)^{2}-112}{128}$, we find that the extremal values of the expression are $\frac{383-165 \sqrt{5}}{256}, \frac{9}{128}$, attained for the triples $\left(3-\sqrt{5}, \frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}, \frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right)$, respectively $(2,1,1)$.,As in the above solution, we must find the extremal values of $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}$ when $x+y+z=1, x y z=\frac{1}{32}$, because after that the extremal values of the expression $x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}$ can be immediately found. Let us make the substitution $x=\frac{a}{4}, y=$ $\frac{b}{4}, z=\frac{c}{2}$, where $a b c=1, a+b+2 c=4$. Then $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+4 c^{2}}{16}$ and so we must find the extremal values of $a^{2}+b^{2}+4 c^{2}$. Now, $a^{2}+b^{2}+4 c^{2}=(4-2 c)^{2}-\frac{2}{c}+4 c^{2}$ and the problem reduces to finding the maximum and minimum of $4 c^{2}-8 c-\frac{1}{c}$ where there are positive numbers $a, b, c$ such that $a b c=1, a+b+2 c=4$. Of course, this comes down to $(4-2 c)^{2} \geq \frac{4}{c}$, or to $c \in\left[\frac{3-\sqrt{5}}{2}, 1\right]$. But this reduces to the study of the function $f(x)=4 x^{2}-8 x-\frac{1}{x}$ defined for $\left[\frac{3-\sqrt{5}}{2}, 1\right]$, which is an easy task.

problem:
Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $x y z=1$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\frac{1}{(1+x)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(1+y)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(1+z)^{2}}+\frac{2}{(1+x)(1+y)(1+z)} \geq C
$$
solution:
Let $x+y+z=p, x y+y z+z x=q$ and $x y z=r=1$.
The given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{align*}
& (1+x)^{2}(1+y)^{2}+(1+y)^{2}(1+z)^{2}+(1+z)^{2}(1+x)^{2}+2(1+x)(1+y)(1+z) \\
& \quad \geq(1+x)^{2}(1+y)^{2}(1+z)^{2} \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

We have
$$
(1+x)(1+y)(1+z)=1+p+q+r=2+p+q
$$
and
$$
\begin{aligned}
(1 & +x)^{2}(1+y)^{2}+(1+y)^{2}(1+z)^{2}+(1+z)^{2}(1+x)^{2} \\
\quad & =(3+2 p+q)^{2}-2(3+p)(1+p+q+r) \\
& =(3+2 p+q)^{2}-2(3+p)(2+p+q)
\end{aligned}
$$

So inequality (1) becomes
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (3+2 p+q)^{2}-2(3+p)(2+p+q)+2(2+p+q) \geq(2+p+q)^{2} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad p^{2} \geq 2 q+3
\end{aligned}
$$

According to $q^{3} \geq 27 r^{2}=27$ , it follows that
$$
\begin{equation*}
q \geq 3 \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

By $p^{2} \geq 3 q$, we obtain
$$
p^{2} \geq 3 q=2 q+q \stackrel{(2)}{\geq} 2 q+3
$$
as required.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $abc = 1$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
1 + \frac{C}{a+b+c} \geq \frac{6}{ab+bc+ca}
$$
solution:
Let $x=\frac{1}{a}, y=\frac{1}{b}, z=\frac{1}{c}$. Then clearly $x y z=1$.
The given inequality becomes
$$
1+\frac{3}{x y+y z+z x} \geq \frac{6}{x+y+z}
$$

Using the well-known inequality $(x+y+z)^{2} \geq 3(x y+y z+z x)$ we deduce
$$
1+\frac{3}{x y+y z+z x} \geq 1+\frac{9}{(x+y+z)^{2}}
$$

So it's enough to prove that
$$
1+\frac{9}{(x+y+z)^{2}} \geq \frac{6}{x+y+z}
$$

The last inequality is equivalent to $\left(1-\frac{3}{x+y+z}\right)^{2} \geq 0$, and clearly holds.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\left(a^{5}-a^{2}+3\right)\left(b^{5}-b^{2}+3\right)\left(c^{5}-c^{2}+3\right) \geq C(a+b+c)^{3}
$$
solution:
For every positive real number $x$, we have that $x^{2}-1$ and $x^{3}-1$ have the same signs, and because of this $x^{5}-x^{3}-x^{2}+1=\left(x^{2}-1\right)\left(x^{3}-1\right) \geq 0$, i.e. we obtain
$$
x^{5}-x^{2}+3 \geq x^{3}+2
$$

Now we get
$$
\left(a^{5}-a^{2}+3\right)\left(b^{5}-b^{2}+3\right)\left(c^{5}-c^{2}+3\right) \geq\left(a^{3}+2\right)\left(b^{3}+2\right)\left(c^{3}+2\right)
$$

So it is enough to show that
$$
\begin{equation*}
\left(a^{3}+2\right)\left(b^{3}+2\right)\left(c^{3}+2\right) \geq(a+b+c)^{3} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

After a little algebra we obtain that (1) is equivalent to
$$
\begin{gather*}
a^{3} b^{3} c^{3}+3\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)+2\left(a^{3} b^{3}+b^{3} c^{3}+c^{3} a^{3}\right)+8 \\
\quad \geq 3\left(a^{2} b+b^{2} a+b^{2} c+c^{2} b+c^{2} a+a^{2} c\right)+6 a b c \tag{2}
\end{gather*}
$$

Using $A M \geq G M$ we can easily obtain the following inequalities
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a^{3}+a^{3} b^{3}+1 \geq 3 a^{2} b, \quad a^{3}+a^{3} c^{3}+1 \geq 3 a^{2} c, \quad b^{3}+a^{3} b^{3}+1 \geq 3 b^{2} a, \\
& b^{3}+b^{3} c^{3}+1 \geq 3 b^{2} c, \quad c^{3}+c^{3} a^{3}+1 \geq 3 c^{2} a, \quad c^{3}+c^{3} b^{3}+1 \geq 3 c^{2} b, \\
& a^{3} b^{3} c^{3}+a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+1+1 \geq 6 a b c .
\end{aligned}
$$

After adding the previous inequalities we obtain inequality (2), as desired.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers such that $a_{1} + a_{2} + \ldots + a_{n} = 1$ and $a_{i} < \frac{1}{n-1}$ for all $i$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}}{1-(n-1) a_{i}}} \geq C
$$
solution:
We will prove that the minimal value is $\frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{n-3}}}$. Indeed, using Suranyi's Inequality, we find that

$$
(n-1) \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}+n a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n} \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1} \Rightarrow n a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n} \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1}\left(1-(n-1) a_{i}\right)
$$

Now, let us observe that

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{n-1}\left(1-(n-1) a_{k}\right)=\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{\left(\sqrt[3]{a_{k}^{n-1}}\right)^{3}}{\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{1-(n-1) a_{k}}}\right)^{2}}
$$

and so, by an immediate application of Hlder Inequality, we have

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1}\left(1-(n-1) a_{i}\right) \geq \frac{\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{\frac{n-1}{3}}\right)^{3}}{\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{1}{1-(n-1) a_{k}}}\right)^{2}}
$$

But for $n>3$, we can apply Jensen's Inequality to deduce that

$$
\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{\frac{n-1}{3}}}{n} \geq\left(\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}}{n}\right)^{\frac{n-1}{3}}=\frac{1}{n^{\frac{n-1}{3}}}
$$

Thus, combining all these inequalities, we have proved the inequality for $n>3$. For $n=3$ it reduces to proving that

$$
\sum \sqrt{\frac{a b c}{b+c-a}} \geq \sum a
$$

which was proved in the solution of the problem 107.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

Theorem 19.Theorem:
For any nonnegative real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$

$$
(n-1) \sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{n}+n \prod_{k=1}^{n} a_{k} \geq\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}\right) \cdot\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{n-1}\right)
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be non-negative real numbers such that $a + b + c + d = 4$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
C + 2abcd \geq 3(ab + ac + ad + bc + bd + cd)
$$
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c \geq d$.
Let us denote
$$
f(a, b, c, d)=3(a b+a c+a d+b c+b d+c d)-2 a b c d
$$

We have
$$
\begin{align*}
& f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right)-f(a, b, c, d) \\
& =3\left(\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right) b+\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right) d+\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right) b+b d+\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right) d\right) \\
& -2 b d\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}-(3(a b+a c+a d+b c+b d+c d)-2 a b c d) \\
& =3\left(\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}-a c\right)-2 b d\left(\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}-a c\right) \\
& =\left(\frac{a-c}{2}\right)^{2}(3-2 b d) \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

Also $2 \sqrt{b d} \leq b+d \leq \frac{1}{2}(a+b+c+d)=2$, from which it follows that $b d \leq 1$.
By (1) and the last conclusion we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right)-f(a, b, c, d) & =\left(\frac{a-c}{2}\right)^{2}(3-2 b d) \\
& \geq\left(\frac{a-c}{2}\right)^{2}(3-2) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e. it follows that
$$
f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right) \geq f(a, b, c, d)
$$

By the SMV theorem it follows that we only need to prove the inequality $f(a, b, c, d) \leq 16$, in the case when $a=b=c=t \geq d$, i.e. we need to prove that $f(t, t, t, d) \leq 16$, when $3 t+d=4$.

Clearly $3 t \leq 4$.
Thus we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(t, t, t, d) \leq 16 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 9\left(t^{2}+d t\right)-2 t^{3} d-16 \leq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Leftrightarrow \quad 9 t^{2}+9 t(4-3 t)-2 t^{3}(4-3 t)-16 \leq 0 \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad 2(3 t-4)(t-1)^{2}(t+2) \leq 0, \quad \text { which is true. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=d=1$ or $a=b=c=4 / 3, d=0$ (up to permutation).

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\sqrt{\frac{a+b}{c}}+\sqrt{\frac{b+c}{a}}+\sqrt{\frac{c+a}{b}} \geq C
$$

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $a x + b y + c z = x y z$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\sqrt{a+b} + \sqrt{b+c} + \sqrt{c+a} < C(x + y + z)
$$
solution:
We have $\frac{a}{y z}+\frac{b}{x z}+\frac{c}{x y}=1$.
Let
$$
u=\frac{a}{y z}, \quad v=\frac{b}{x z}, \quad w=\frac{c}{x y}
$$

We need to show that
$$
\sqrt{z(y u+x v)}+\sqrt{x(z v+y w)}+\sqrt{y(x w+z u)}<x+y+z
$$
where $u+v+w=1$.
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (\sqrt{z(y u+x v)}+\sqrt{x(z v+y w)}+\sqrt{y(x w+z u)})^{2} \\
& \quad \leq(x+y+z)(y u+x v+z v+y w+x w+z u)
\end{aligned}
$$

Also we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
y u+x v+z v+y w+x w+z u & =x(1-u)+y(1-v)+z(1-w) \\
& =x+y+z-(x u+y v+z w)<x+y+z
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we obtain
$$
(\sqrt{z(y u+x v)}+\sqrt{x(z v+y w)}+\sqrt{y(x w+z u)})^{2}<(x+y+z)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\sqrt{z(y u+x v)}+\sqrt{x(z v+y w)}+\sqrt{y(x w+z u)}<x+y+z
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Find the smallest constant $C$ such that for all real numbers $x$ and $y$, the following inequality holds:
$$
3(x+y+1)^{2}+C \geq 3 x y
$$
solution:
Observe that for any real numbers $a$ and $b$ we have
$$
a^{2}+a b+b^{2}=\left(a+\frac{b}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{3 b^{2}}{4} \geq 0
$$
with equality if and only if $a=b=0$.
Let $x, y$ be real numbers. Then according to the above inequality we have
$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(x+\frac{2}{3}\right)^{2}+\left(x+\frac{2}{3}\right)\left(y+\frac{2}{3}\right)+\left(y+\frac{2}{3}\right)^{2} \geq 0, \quad \text { i.e. } \\
3 x^{2}+3 y^{2}+3 x y+6 x+6 y+4 \geq 0
\end{gathered}
$$
which is equivalent to
$$
3(x+y+1)^{2}+1 \geq 3 x y
$$

Equality occurs iff $x+\frac{2}{3}=y+\frac{2}{3}=0$, i.e. $x=y=-\frac{2}{3}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{b}+\frac{b^{2}}{c}+\frac{c^{2}}{a} \geq C(a+b+c)
$$
solution:
Observe that
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{a^{2}}{b}+\frac{b^{2}}{c}+\frac{c^{2}}{a}=\frac{a^{2}-a b+b^{2}}{b}+\frac{b^{2}-b c+c^{2}}{c}+\frac{c^{2}-c a+a^{2}}{a} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since for any $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$, we have $x^{2}-x y+y^{2} \geq x y$, by (1) we get
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{b}+\frac{b^{2}}{c}+\frac{c^{2}}{a} \geq \frac{a b}{b}+\frac{b c}{c}+\frac{c a}{a}=a+b+c
$$,From $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{b}+b \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}}{b} \cdot b}=2 a
$$

Analogously we get
$$
\frac{b^{2}}{c}+c \geq 2 b \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c^{2}}{a}+a \geq 2 c
$$

After adding these three inequalities we obtain
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{b}+\frac{b^{2}}{c}+\frac{c^{2}}{a}+(a+b+c) \geq 2(a+b+c)
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{b}+\frac{b^{2}}{c}+\frac{c^{2}}{a} \geq a+b+c
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c$.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$, and $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be the angles of a given triangle such that $\alpha + \beta + \gamma = \pi$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$:
$$
\cot ^{n} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\cot ^{n} \frac{\beta}{2}+\cot ^{n} \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq C.
$$
solution:
We use the identity
$$
\cot \frac{\alpha}{2}+\cot \frac{\beta}{2}+\cot \frac{\gamma}{2}=\cot \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\gamma}{2} .
$$

Since $\frac{\alpha}{2}, \frac{\beta}{2}, \frac{\gamma}{2} \in(0, \pi / 2)$ it follows that $\cot \frac{\alpha}{2}, \cot \frac{\beta}{2}, \cot \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq 0$.
Applying $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\cot \frac{\alpha}{2}+\cot \frac{\beta}{2}+\cot \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\cot \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\gamma}{2}}
$$
or
$$
\cot \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\cot \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\gamma}{2}}
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\cot \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq 3^{3 / 2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Furthermore, using the power mean inequality we get
$$
\cot ^{n} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\cot ^{n} \frac{\beta}{2}+\cot ^{n} \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq 3\left(\cot \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \cot \frac{\gamma}{2}\right)^{n / 3} .
$$

Now from the previous inequality and (1) we obtain
$$
\cot ^{n} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\cot ^{n} \frac{\beta}{2}+\cot ^{n} \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq 3^{\frac{n+2}{2}}
$$

Equality occurs iff $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=\pi / 3$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Find the minimal constant $C$ such that for all real numbers $x$, $y$, and $z$, the following inequality holds:
$$
x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{2}+C \geq 2 x\left(x y^{2}-x+z+1\right)
$$
solution:
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{4} & +y^{4}+z^{2}+1-2 x\left(x y^{2}-x+z+1\right) \\
& =\left(x^{4}-2 x^{2} y^{2}+x^{4}\right)+\left(z^{2}-2 x z+x^{2}\right)+\left(x^{2}-2 x+1\right) \\
& =\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)^{2}+(x-z)^{2}+(x-1)^{2} \geq 0,
\end{aligned}
$$
from which we get the desired inequality.
Equality occurs if and only if $x=y=z=1$ or $x=z=1, y=-1$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers such that $abcd = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:
$$
\left(1 + a^2\right)\left(1 + b^2\right)\left(1 + c^2\right)\left(1 + d^2\right) \geq C(a + b + c + d)^2
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 2$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \geq C(a \sqrt{b+c}+b \sqrt{c+a}+c \sqrt{a+b})

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$

& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c=3$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a b c+\frac{12}{a b+b c+a c} \geq C
$$
solution:
Recalling the well-known inequality $a b c \geq(b+c-a)(c+a-b)(a+$ $b-c)$ we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
a b c & \geq(3-2 a)(3-2 b)(3-2 c) \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad a b c \geq 27-18(a+b+c)+12(a b+b c+c a)-8 a b c \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad 3 a b c \geq 4(a b+b c+c a)-9 \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad a b c \geq \frac{4(a b+b c+c a)}{3}-3 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore we have
$$
a b c+\frac{12}{a b+b c+a c} \geq \frac{4(a b+b c+c a)}{3}+\frac{12}{a b+b c+a c}-3 \geq 8-3=5
$$
where the last inequality follows since $A M \geq G M$.

problem:

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c + d = 4$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:
$$
a^{2} b c + b^{2} c d + c^{2} d a + d^{2} a b \leq C.
$$
solution:
Let $(x, y, z, t)$ be a permutation of $(a, b, c, d)$ such that $x \geq y \geq z \geq t$. Then clearly $x y z \geq x y t \geq x z t \geq y z t$.

By the rearrangement inequality we obtain
$$
\begin{equation*}
x \cdot x y z+y \cdot x y t+z \cdot x z t+t \cdot y z t \geq a^{2} b c+b^{2} c d+c^{2} d a+d^{2} a b \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since $A M \geq G M$ we deduce
$$
\begin{equation*}
x \cdot x y z+y \cdot x y t+z \cdot x z t+t \cdot y z t=(x y+z t)(x z+y t) \leq \frac{(x y+x z+y t+z t)^{2}}{4} \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since
$$
x y+x z+y t+z t=(x+z)(y+t) \leq \frac{(x+y+z+t)^{2}}{4}=4
$$
by (2) we deduce that
$$
x \cdot x y z+y \cdot x y t+z \cdot x z t+t \cdot y z t \leq 4
$$

Finally by (1) we obtain
$$
a^{2} b c+b^{2} c d+c^{2} d a+d^{2} a b \leq 4
$$
and we are done.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c=d=1$ or $a=2, b=c=1, d=0$ (up to permutation).

Theorem 37.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers and let $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a permutation of $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$. Then
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \geq a_{1} x_{1}+a_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} x_{n}
$$

problem:
Find the smallest constant $C$ such that for all positive real numbers $a$ and $b$, the following inequality holds:
$$
\sqrt[3]{a}+\sqrt[3]{b} \leq C \sqrt[3]{a+b}
$$
solution:
Consider the function $f(x)=\sqrt[3]{x}$.
We have $f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{3} x^{-\frac{2}{3}}$ and $f^{\prime \prime}(x)=-\frac{2}{9} x^{-\frac{5}{3}}<0$, for any $x \in(0, \infty)$. Thus $f(x)$ is concave on the interval $(0, \infty)$.

By Jensen's inequality we deduce
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{2} f(a)+\frac{1}{2} f(b) \leq f\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{\sqrt[3]{a}+\sqrt[3]{b}}{2} \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{a+b}{2}} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \sqrt[3]{a}+\sqrt[3]{b} \leq \frac{2}{\sqrt[3]{2}} \sqrt[3]{a+b}=\sqrt[3]{4} \cdot \sqrt[3]{a+b}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $k_{\min }=\sqrt[3]{4}$, and for instance we reach this value for $a=b$.

problem:

$$
\frac{1}{8 a b+1}+\frac{1}{8 b c+1}+\frac{1}{8 c a+1} \geq C
$$

Theorem 72.Theorem:
Let $x, y, z \geq 0$, and $p=x+y+z, q=x y+y z+z x, r=x y z$.
Then we have the following inequalities:
$$
\begin{array}{ll}
N_{3}: p q-9 r \geq 0, & N_{9}: p^{4}+3 q^{2} \geq 4 p^{2} q \\
N_{4}: p^{2} \geq 3 q, & N_{10}: 2 p^{3}+9 r^{2} \geq 7 p q r \\
N_{5}: p^{3} \geq 27 r, & N_{11}: p^{2} q+3 p r \geq 4 q^{2} \\
N_{6}: q^{3} \geq 27 r^{2}, & N_{12}: q^{3}+9 r^{2} \geq 4 p q r \\
N_{7}: q^{2} \geq 3 p r, & N_{13}: p q^{2} \geq 2 p^{2} r+3 q r \\
N_{8}: 2 p^{3}+9 r \geq 7 p q, &
\end{array}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 a b c+C \geq(1+a)(1+b)(1+c)
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b c+2 \geq a+b+c+a b+b c+a c
$$

Recall the Turkevicius inequality:
For any positive real numbers $x, y, z, t$ we have
$$
x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}+t^{4}+2 x y z t \geq x^{2} y^{2}+y^{2} z^{2}+z^{2} t^{2}+t^{2} x^{2}+x^{2} z^{2}+y^{2} t^{2}
$$

If we set $a=x^{2}, b=y^{2}, c=z^{2}, t=1$ we deduce
$$
\begin{equation*}
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 \sqrt{a b c}+1 \geq a+b+c+a b+b c+a c \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\begin{equation*}
2\sqrt{a b c} \leq a b c+1 \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

From (1) and (2) we obtain
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b c+2 \geq a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 \sqrt{a b c}+1 \geq a+b+c+a b+b c+a c
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a+b+c=1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1-2 a b}{c}+\frac{1-2 b c}{a}+\frac{1-2 c a}{b} \geq C
$$
solution:
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1-2 a b}{c}+\frac{1-2 b c}{a}+\frac{1-2 c a}{b} \\
& =\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}-2 a b}{c}+\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}-2 b c}{a}+\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}-2 c a}{b}
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{align*}
= & \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 b c+2 a c}{c}+\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 a c+2 a b}{a} \\
& +\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 a b+2 b c}{b} \\
= & \left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)+4(a+b+c) \\
= & \left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)+4 \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

By $Q M \geq A M$ we get
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{3}=\frac{1}{3} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \geq \frac{9}{a+b+c}=9
$$

Finally, from previous inequalities and (1) we obtain
$$
\frac{1-2 a b}{c}+\frac{1-2 b c}{a}+\frac{1-2 c a}{b}=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)+4 \geq \frac{9}{3}+4=7
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a-b}{b+c}+\frac{b-c}{c+d}+\frac{c-d}{d+a}+\frac{d-a}{a+b} \geq C
$$
solution:
Applying $A M \geq H M$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a-b}{b+c}+\frac{b-c}{c+d}+\frac{c-d}{d+a}+\frac{d-a}{a+b} \\
& \quad=\frac{a+c}{b+c}+\frac{b+d}{c+d}+\frac{c+a}{d+a}+\frac{d+b}{a+b}-4 \\
& \quad=(a+c)\left(\frac{1}{b+c}+\frac{1}{d+a}\right)+(b+d)\left(\frac{1}{c+d}+\frac{1}{a+b}\right)-4 \\
& \quad \geq \frac{4(a+c)}{a+b+c+d}+\frac{4(b+d)}{a+b+c+d}-4=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}_0$:
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+C(a+b+c)+9 a b c \geq 8(a b+b c+c a)
$$
solution:
We'll use Schur's inequality, i.e. for all $a, b, c \geq 0$ we have
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+a b c(a+b+c) \geq a b\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)+b c\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+c a\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right)
$$

By $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
4(a+b+c)+\frac{4(a b+b c+c a)^{2}}{(a+b+c)} \geq 8(a b+b c+c a)
$$

So it suffices to prove that
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+9 a b c \geq \frac{4(a b+b c+c a)^{2}}{(a+b+c)}
$$

The previous inequality is equivalent to
$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{4} & +b^{4}+c^{4}+a b c(a+b+c)+a b\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)+b c\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+c a\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right) \\
& \geq 4\left(a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying Schur's inequality and $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{4} & +b^{4}+c^{4}+a b c(a+b+c)+a b\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)+b c\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+c a\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right) \\
& \geq 2\left(a b\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)+b c\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+c a\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right)\right) \\
& \geq 2(a b(2 a b)+b c(2 b c)+c a(2 c a))=4\left(a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$ or $a=b=2, c=0$ (up to permutation).

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, x, y, z$ be positive real numbers, and let $a + b = 3$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, x, y, z$:
$$
\frac{x}{a y+b z}+\frac{y}{a z+b x}+\frac{z}{a x+b y} \geq C.
$$
solution:
We'll show that
$$
\frac{x}{a y+b z}+\frac{y}{a z+b x}+\frac{z}{a x+b y} \geq \frac{3}{a+b}
$$
and combining with $a+b=3$ will give us the required inequality.
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x}{a y+b z}+\frac{y}{a z+b x}+\frac{z}{a x+b y} \\
& \quad=\frac{x^{2}}{a x y+b x z}+\frac{y^{2}}{a y z+b x y}+\frac{z^{2}}{a x z+b y z} \geq \frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{(a+b)(x y+y z+z x)} \\
& \quad \geq \frac{3}{a+b}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $p \geq 1$ be an arbitrary real number. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that for any positive integer $n$, the following inequality holds:
$$
1^{p}+2^{p}+\cdots+n^{p} \geq n \cdot\left(\frac{n+1}{C}\right)^{p}
$$
solution:
If $p=1$ then the given inequality is true, i.e. it becomes equality.
So let $p>1$.
We take $x_{1}=1, x_{2}=2, \ldots, x_{n}=n$ and $y_{1}=n, y_{2}=n-1, \ldots, y_{n}=1$.
By Minkowski's inequality we have
$$
\left((1+n)^{p}+(1+n)^{p}+\cdots+(1+n)^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}} \leq 2\left(1^{p}+2^{p}+\cdots+n^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$
i.e.
$$
n(1+n)^{p} \leq 2^{p}\left(1^{p}+2^{p}+\cdots+n^{p}\right)
$$
or
$$
1^{p}+2^{p}+\cdots+n^{p} \geq n \cdot\left(\frac{n+1}{2}\right)^{p}
$$
as required.
Equality occurs iff $n=1$. (Why?)

Theorem 54.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n} ; m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}$ be three sequences of positive real numbers and let $p>1$. Then
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 9$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
2(a+b+c) - abc \leq C
$$
solution:
Of course, we have $|a|,|b|,|c| \leq 3$ and $|a+b+c|,|a b c| \leq 3 \sqrt{3}$. Also, we may assume of course that $a, b, c$ are non-zero and that $a \leq b \leq c$. If $c<0$ then we have $2(a+b+c)-a b c<-a b c \leq 3 \sqrt{3}<10$. Also, if $a \leq b<0<c$ then we have $2(a+b+c)<$ $2 c \leq 6<10+a b c$ because $a b c>0$. If $a<0<b \leq c$, using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality we find that $2 b+2 c-a \leq 9$. Thus, $2(a+b+c)=2 b+2 c-a+3 a \leq 9+3 a$ and it remains to prove that $3 a-1 \leq a b c$. But $a<0$ and $2 b c \leq 9-a^{2}$, so that it remains to show that $\frac{9 a-a^{3}}{2} \geq 3 a-1 \Leftrightarrow(a+1)^{2}(a-2) \leq 0$, which follows. So, we just have to threat the case $0<a \leq b \leq c$. In this case we have $2 b+2 c+a \leq 9$ and $2(a+b+c) \leq 9+a$. So, we need to prove that $a \leq 1+a b c$. This is clear if $a<1$ and if $a>1$ we have $b, c>1$ and the inequality is again. Thus, the problem is solved.,Because $\max \{a, b, c\} \leq 3$ and $|a b c| \leq 10$, it is enough to consider only the cases when $a, b, c \geq 0$ or exactly of the three numbers is negative. First, we will suppose that $a, b, c$ are nonnegative. If $a b c \geq 1$, then we are done, because

$$
2(a+b+c)-a b c \leq 2 \sqrt{3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}-1<10
$$

Otherwise, we may assume that $a<1$. In this case we have

$$
2(a+b+c)-a b c \leq 2\left(a+2 \sqrt{\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}}{2}}\right)=2 a+2 \sqrt{18-2 a^{2}} \leq 10
$$

Now, assume that not all three numbers are nonnegative and let $c<0$.
Thus, the problem reduces to proving that for any nonnegative $x, y, z$ whose sum of squares is 9 we have $4(x+y-z)+2 x y z \leq 20$. But we can write this as $(x-2)^{2}+(y-2)^{2}+(z-1)^{2} \geq 2 x y z-6 z-2$. Because $2 x y z-6 z-2 \leq x\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)-6 z-2=$ $-z^{3}+3 z-2=-(z-1)^{2}(z+2) \leq 0$, the inequality follows.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{8 a b c+(a+b-c)^{3}}+\frac{1}{8 a b c+(b+c-a)^{3}}+\frac{1}{8 a b c+(c+a-b)^{3}} \leq \frac{C}{abc}.
$$

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1}{a^3 + 2} + \frac{1}{b^3 + 2} + \frac{1}{c^3 + 2} \geq C
$$
solution:
We have
$$
\frac{1}{a^{3}+2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{a^{3}}{a^{3}+2}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{a^{3}}{a^{3}+1+1}\right) \geq \frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{a^{3}}{3 a}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{a^{2}}{3}\right)
$$

Therefore
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{a^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{b^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{c^{3}+2} & \geq \frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{a^{2}}{3}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{b^{2}}{3}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{c^{2}}{3}\right) \\
& =\frac{3}{2}-\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{6}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b}+\frac{b^{3}}{c}+\frac{c^{3}}{a} \geq C(a b+b c+c a)
$$
solution:
Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b}+\frac{b^{3}}{c}+b c \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{a^{3}}{b} \cdot \frac{b^{3}}{c} \cdot b c}=3 a b
$$

Analogously we have
$$
\frac{b^{3}}{c}+\frac{c^{3}}{a}+c a \geq 3 b c \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c^{3}}{a}+\frac{a^{3}}{b}+a b \geq 3 c a
$$

Adding these three inequalities we obtain
$$
2\left(\frac{a^{3}}{b}+\frac{b^{3}}{c}+\frac{c^{3}}{a}\right)+a b+b c+c a \geq 3(a b+b c+c a)
$$
from which follows the desired inequality. Equality holds iff $a=b=c$.
