problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a + b + c = 1$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} + 48(ab + bc + ca) \geq C.
$$
solution:
Setting $a b+b c+c a=\frac{1-q^{2}}{3} \geq 0, q \geq 0$, it follows that $q \in[0,1]$.
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}+48(a b+b c+c a) & =\frac{a b+b c+c a}{a b c}+48(a b+b c+c a) \\
& =\frac{1-q^{2}}{3 r}+16\left(1-q^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

So it suffices to show that
$$
\frac{1-q^{2}}{3 r}+16\left(1-q^{2}\right) \geq 25
$$

Due to Theorem 

Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a+b+c=1$ and let
$$
a b+b c+c a=\frac{1-q^{2}}{3} \quad(q \geq 0)
$$

Then we have the following inequalities
$$
\frac{(1+q)^{2}(1-2 q)}{27} \leq a b c \leq \frac{(1-q)^{2}(1+2 q)}{27}
$$

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1-q^{2}}{3 r}+16\left(1-q^{2}\right) & \geq 27 \frac{1-q^{2}}{3(1-q)^{2}(1+2 q)}+16\left(1-q^{2}\right) \\
& =9 \frac{1+q}{(1-q)(1+2 q)}+16\left(1-q^{2}\right) \\
& =\frac{2 q^{2}(4 q-1)^{2}}{(1-q)(1+2 q)}+25 \geq 25
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $(a, b, c)=(1 / 3,1 / 3,1 / 3)$ or $(a, b, c)=(1 / 2,1 / 4$, $1 / 4$ ) (up to permutation).

Theorem 73.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a+b+c=1$ and let
$$
a b+b c+c a=\frac{1-q^{2}}{3} \quad(q \geq 0)
$$

Then we have the following inequalities
$$
\frac{(1+q)^{2}(1-2 q)}{27} \leq a b c \leq \frac{(1-q)^{2}(1+2 q)}{27}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^2 b^2 + b^2 c^2 + c^2 a^2 \leq C(a+b+c).
$$
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \leq b \leq c$. Then clearly $a \leq 1$ and $b^{2}+c^{2} \geq 2$, from which it follows that $b+c \geq \sqrt{2}$.

Let $f(a, b, c)=a+b+c-a^{2} b^{2}-b^{2} c^{2}-c^{2} a^{2}$. Then we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(a, b, c)-f\left(a, \sqrt{\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}}{2}}, \sqrt{\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}}{2}}\right) \\
& \quad=(b-c)^{2}\left(\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{4}-\frac{1}{b+c+\sqrt{2\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}}\right) \geq\left(\frac{2}{4}-\frac{1}{2+\sqrt{2}}\right)(b-c)^{2} \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus
$$
f(a, b, c) \geq f\left(a, \sqrt{\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}}{2}}, \sqrt{\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}}{2}}\right)
$$

By the SMV theorem it suffices to prove that $f(a, t, t) \geq 0$, when $a^{2}+2 t^{2}=3$.
We have
$$
\begin{align*}
& f(a, t, t) \geq 0 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad a+\sqrt{2\left(3-a^{2}\right)} \geq a^{2}\left(3-a^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{4}\left(3-a^{2}\right)^{2} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-1)^{2}\left(\frac{3}{4}(a+1)^{2}-\frac{3}{3-a+\sqrt{2\left(3-a^{2}\right)}}\right) \geq 0 \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

Since $a \leq 1$ it follows that
$$
\frac{3}{3-a+\sqrt{2\left(3-a^{2}\right)}} \leq \frac{3}{4} \leq \frac{3}{4}(a+1)^{2}
$$

Therefore inequality (1) is true, and we are done.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers such that $a+b+c \leq \frac{3}{2}$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a+b+c+\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \geq C
$$
solution:
If we use $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
A=a+b+c+\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \geq 6 \sqrt[6]{a b c \cdot \frac{1}{a b c}}=6
$$
with equality if and only if $a=b=c=1$.
But then $a+b+c=3>\frac{3}{2}$, a contradiction.
Since $A$ is a symmetrical expression on $a, b$ and $c$ we estimate that $\min A$ occurs at $a=b=c$, i.e. at $a=b=c=1 / 2$.

Therefore for a point of incidence we have $\frac{1}{\alpha a}=\frac{1}{\alpha b}=\frac{1}{\alpha c}=a=b=c=1 / 2$, and it follows that $\alpha=\frac{1}{a^{2}}=4$.

Now we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & =a+b+c+\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}=\left(a+b+c+\frac{1}{4 a}+\frac{1}{4 b}+\frac{1}{4 c}\right)+\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right) \\
& \geq 6 \sqrt[6]{a b c \cdot \frac{1}{(4 a)(4 b)(4 c)}}+\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)=3+\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right) \\
& \geq 3+\frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{9}{a+b+c} \geq 3+\frac{27}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{3 / 2}=\frac{15}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

So $\min A=\frac{15}{2}$, for $a=b=c=1 / 2$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + abc = 4$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
0 \leq ab + bc + ca - abc \leq C.
$$
solution:
The lower bound is not difficult. Indeed, we have $a b+b c+c a \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}$ and thus it is enough to prove that $a b c \leq 3 \sqrt[3]{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}$, which follows from the fact that $a b c \leq 4$. The upper bound instead is hard. Let us first observe that there are two numbers among the three ones, which are both greater or equal than 1 or smaller than or equal to 1 . Let them be b and c . Then we have

$$
4 \geq 2 b c+a^{2}+a b c \Rightarrow(2-a)(2+a) \geq b c(2+a) \Rightarrow b c \leq 2-a
$$

Thus, $a b+b c+c a-a b c \leq a b+2-a+a c-a b c$ and it is enough to prove the inequality $a b+2-a+a c-a b c \leq 2 \Leftrightarrow b+c-b c \leq 1 \Leftrightarrow(b-1)(c-1) \geq 0$, which is true due to our choice.,We won't prove again the lower part, since this is an easy problem. Let us concentrate on the upper bound. Let $a \geq b \geq c$ and let $a=x+y, b=x-y$. The hypothesis becomes $x^{2}(2+c)+y^{2}(2-c)=4-c^{2}$ and we have to prove that $\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)(1-c) \leq 2(1-x c)$. Since $y^{2}=2+c-\frac{2+c}{2-c} x^{2}$, the problem asks to prove the inequality $\frac{4 x^{2}-\left(4-c^{2}\right)}{2-c}(1-c) \leq 2(1-c x)$. Of course, we have $c \leq 1$ and $0 \leq y^{2}=2+c-\frac{2+c}{2-c} x^{2} \Rightarrow x^{2} \leq 2-c \Rightarrow x \leq \sqrt{2-c}$ (we have used the fact that $a \geq b \Rightarrow y \geq 0$ and $b \geq 0 \Rightarrow x \geq y \geq 0$ ). Now, consider the function $f:[0, \sqrt{2-c}] \rightarrow R, f(x)=2(1-c x)-\frac{\overline{4 x^{2}}-\left(4-c^{2}\right)}{2-c}(1-c)$. We have $f^{\prime}(x)=-2 c-8 x \cdot \frac{1-c}{2-c} \leq 0$ and thus f is decreasing and $f(x) \geq f(\sqrt{2-c})$. So, we have to prove that
$f(\sqrt{2-c}) \geq 0 \Leftrightarrow 2(1-c \sqrt{2-c}) \geq(2-c)(1-c) \Leftrightarrow 3 \geq c+2 \sqrt{2-c} \Leftrightarrow(1-\sqrt{2-c})^{2} \geq 0$ clearly true. Thus, the problem is solved.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{2}+a b+b^{2}}+\frac{b^{3}}{b^{2}+b c+c^{2}}+\frac{c^{3}}{c^{2}+c a+a^{2}} \geq C \cdot \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a+b+c}
$$
solution:
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & =\frac{a^{3}}{a^{2}+a b+b^{2}}+\frac{b^{3}}{b^{2}+b c+c^{2}}+\frac{c^{3}}{c^{2}+c a+a^{2}} \\
& =\frac{a^{4}}{a\left(a^{2}+a b+b^{2}\right)}+\frac{b^{4}}{b\left(b^{2}+b c+c^{2}\right)}+\frac{c^{4}}{c\left(c^{2}+c a+a^{2}\right)} \\
& \geq \frac{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}}{\left(a\left(a^{2}+a b+b^{2}\right)+b\left(b^{2}+b c+c^{2}\right)+c\left(c^{2}+c a+a^{2}\right)\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

So it suffices to prove that
$(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \geq a\left(a^{2}+a b+b^{2}\right)+b\left(b^{2}+b c+c^{2}\right)+c\left(c^{2}+c a+a^{2}\right)$,
which is true.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers such that $a + b + c = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\left(a + \frac{1}{a}\right)^2 + \left(b + \frac{1}{b}\right)^2 + \left(c + \frac{1}{c}\right)^2 \geq C.
$$

Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
(x y+y z+z x)\left(\frac{1}{(x+y)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(y+z)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(z+x)^{2}}\right) \geq C.
$$
solution:
With the substitution $x+y=c, y+z=a, z+x=b$, the inequality becomes after some easy computations

$$
\sum\left(\frac{2}{a b}-\frac{1}{c^{2}}\right)(a-b)^{2} \geq 0
$$

Let $a \geq b \geq c$. If $2 c^{2} \geq a b$, each term in the above expression is positive and we are done. So, let $2 c^{2}<a b$. First, we prove that $2 b^{2} \geq a c, 2 a^{2} \geq b c$. Suppose that $2 b^{2}<a c$. Then $(b+c)^{2} \leq 2\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)<a(b+c)$ and so $b+c<a$, false. Clearly, we can write the inequality like that

$$
\left(\frac{2}{a c}-\frac{1}{b^{2}}\right)(a-c)^{2}+\left(\frac{2}{b c}-\frac{1}{a^{2}}\right)(b-c)^{2} \geq\left(\frac{1}{c^{2}}-\frac{2}{a b}\right)(a-b)^{2}
$$

We can immediately see that the inequality $(a-c)^{2} \geq(a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}$ holds and thus if suffices to prove that

$$
\left(\frac{2}{a c}+\frac{2}{b c}-\frac{1}{a^{2}}-\frac{1}{b^{2}}\right)(b-c)^{2} \geq\left(\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}-\frac{2}{a b}-\frac{2}{a c}\right)(a-b)^{2}
$$

But it is clear that $\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}-\frac{2}{a b}-\frac{2}{a c}<\left(\frac{1}{b}-\frac{1}{c}\right)^{2}$ and so the right hand side is at most $\frac{(a-b)^{2}(b-c)^{2}}{b^{2} c^{2}}$. Also, it is easy to see that

$$
\frac{2}{a c}+\frac{2}{b c}-\frac{1}{a^{2}}-\frac{1}{b^{2}} \geq \frac{1}{a c}+\frac{1}{b c}>\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{b^{2} c^{2}}
$$

which shows that the left hand side is at least $\frac{(a-b)^{2}(b-c)^{2}}{b^{2} c^{2}}$ and this ends the solution.

Since the inequality is homogenous, we may assume that $x y+y z+z x=3$. Also, we make the substitution $x+y+z=3 a$. From $(x+y+z)^{2} \geq 3(x y+y z+z x)$, we get $a \geq 1$. Now we write the inequality as follows

$$
\begin{gather*}
\frac{1}{(3 a-z)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(3 a-y)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(3 a-x)^{2}} \geq \frac{3}{4} \\
4\left[(x y+3 a z)^{2}+(y z+3 a x)^{2}+(z x+3 a y)^{2}\right] \geq 3(9 a-x y z)^{2} \\
4\left(27 a^{4}-18 a^{2}+3+4 a x y z\right) \geq(9 a-x y z)^{2} \\
3\left(12 a^{2}-1\right)\left(3 a^{2}-4\right)+x y z(34 a-x y z) \geq 0 \tag{1}
\end{gather*}
$$

$$
\begin{equation*}
12\left(3 a^{2}-1\right)^{2}+208 a^{2} \geq(17 a-x y z)^{2} \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

We have two cases.
i) Case $3 a^{2}-4 \geq 0$. Since

$$
34 a-x y z=\frac{1}{9}[34(x+y+z)(x y+y z+z x)-9 x y z]>0
$$

the inequality (1) is true.
ii) Case $3 a^{2}-4<0$. From Schur's Inequality

$$
(x+y+z)^{3}-4(x+y+z)(x y+y z+z x)+9 x y z \geq 0
$$

it follows that $3 a^{3}-4 a+x y z \geq 0$. Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 12\left(3 a^{2}-1\right)^{2}+208 a^{2}-(17 a-x y z)^{2} \geq 12\left(3 a^{2}-1\right)^{2}+208 a^{2}-a^{2}\left(3 a^{2}+13\right)^{2}= \\
& =3\left(4-11 a^{2}+10 a^{4}-3 a^{6}\right)=3\left(1-a^{2}\right)^{2}\left(4-3 a^{2}\right)^{2} \geq 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ with $a+b+c=1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
5\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \leq 6\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)+C
$$
solution:
Because $a+b+c=1$, we have $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}=3 a b c+a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-a b-b c-c a$. The inequality becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
5\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) & \leq 18 a b c+6\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)-6(a b+b c+c a)+1 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow 18 a b c+1-2(a b+b c+c a)+1 \geq 6(a b+b c+c a) \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow 8(a b+b c+c a) \leq 2+18 a b c \Leftrightarrow 4(a b+b c+c a) \leq 1+9 a b c \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(1-2 a)(1-2 b)(1-2 c) \leq a b c \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(b+c-a)(c+a-b)(a+b-c) \leq a b c
\end{aligned}
$$

which is equivalent to Schur's Inequality.

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ such that $abc = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1+ab}{1+a}+\frac{1+bc}{1+b}+\frac{1+ac}{1+a} \geq C
$$
solution:
Since $a b c=1$ we have
$$
\frac{1+a b}{1+a}=\frac{a b c+a b}{1+a}=\frac{a b(c+1)}{a+1}
$$
and similarly
$$
\frac{1+b c}{1+b}=\frac{b c(a+1)}{b+1} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1+c a}{1+c}=\frac{c a(b+1)}{c+1}
$$

Now by $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1+a b}{1+a}+\frac{1+b c}{1+b}+\frac{1+c a}{1+c} & =\frac{a b(c+1)}{a+1}+\frac{b c(a+1)}{b+1}+\frac{c a(b+1)}{c+1} \\
& \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{a b(c+1)}{a+1} \cdot \frac{b c(a+1)}{b+1} \cdot \frac{c a(b+1)}{c+1}} \\
& =3 \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}}=3
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers, with $a, b, c \in(0,1)$ such that $a b+b c+c a=1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a}{1-a^{2}}+\frac{b}{1-b^{2}}+\frac{c}{1-c^{2}} \geq C\left(\frac{1-a^{2}}{a}+\frac{1-b^{2}}{b}+\frac{1-c^{2}}{c}\right)
$$
solution:
It is known that in every triangle $A B C$ the following identity holds $\sum \tan \frac{A}{2} \tan \frac{B}{2}=1$ and because $\tan$ is bijective on $\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$ we can set $a=\tan \frac{A}{2}, b=$ $\tan \frac{B}{2}, c=\tan \frac{C}{2}$. The condition $a, b, c \in(0,1)$ tells us that the triangle $A B C$ is acute-angled. With this substitution, the inequality becomes

$$
\sum \frac{2 \tan \frac{A}{2}}{1-\tan ^{2} \frac{A}{2}} \geq 3 \sum \frac{1-\tan ^{2} \frac{A}{2}}{2 \tan \frac{A}{2}} \Leftrightarrow \sum \tan A \geq 3 \sum \frac{1}{\tan A} \Leftrightarrow
$$

$\Leftrightarrow \tan A \tan B \tan C(\tan A+\tan B+\tan C) \geq 3(\tan A \tan B+\tan B \tan C+\tan C \tan A) \Leftrightarrow$

$$
\Leftrightarrow(\tan A+\tan B+\tan C)^{2} \geq 3(\tan A \tan B+\tan B \tan C+\tan C \tan A)
$$

clearly true because $\tan A, \tan B, \tan C>0$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a + x = b + y = c + z = 1$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, x, y, z$:
$$
(a b c + x y z)\left(\frac{1}{a y} + \frac{1}{b z} + \frac{1}{c x}\right) \geq C.
$$
solution:
We have
$$
a b c+x y z=a b c+(1-a)(1-b)(1-c)=(1-b)(1-c)+a c+a b-a
$$

So
$$
\frac{a b c+x y z}{a(1-b)}=\frac{1-c}{a}+\frac{c}{1-b}-1
$$
and analogously we obtain $\frac{a b c+x y z}{b(1-c)}$ and $\frac{a b c+x y z}{c(1-a)}$.
Hence
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (a b c+x y z)\left(\frac{1}{a y}+\frac{1}{b z}+\frac{1}{c x}\right) \\
& \quad=\frac{a}{1-c}+\frac{b}{1-a}+\frac{c}{1-b}+\frac{1-c}{a}+\frac{1-b}{c}+\frac{1-a}{b}-3 \geq 6-3=3
\end{aligned}
$$

problem:
Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ be positive real numbers such that
$$
\frac{1}{1+x_{1}}+\frac{1}{1+x_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{1+x_{n}}=1.
$$

Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$:
$$
\frac{\sqrt{x_{1}}+\sqrt{x_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{x_{n}}}{C} \geq \frac{1}{\sqrt{x_{1}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{x_{2}}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{\sqrt{x_{n}}}.
$$
solution:
Let $\frac{1}{1+x_{i}}=a_{i}$, for $i=1,2, \ldots, n$.
Clearly $\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}=1$ and the given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{1-a_{i}}{a_{i}}} \geq(n-1) \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{a_{i}}{1-a_{i}}} \Leftrightarrow \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{1}{a_{i}\left(1-a_{i}\right)}} \geq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{a_{i}}{1-a_{i}}} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad n \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{a_{i}}{1-a_{i}}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{1}{a_{i}\left(1-a_{i}\right)}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The last inequality is true according to Chebishev's inequality applied to the sequences
$$
\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{a_{1}\left(1-a_{1}\right)}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{a_{2}\left(1-a_{2}\right)}}, \ldots, \frac{1}{\sqrt{a_{n}\left(1-a_{n}\right)}}\right)
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{a^{2}+b c}+\frac{(c+a)^{2}}{b^{2}+c a}+\frac{(a+b)^{2}}{c^{2}+a b} \geq C
$$
solution:
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{(b+c)^{2}}{a^{2}+b c}-2+\frac{(c+a)^{2}}{b^{2}+c a}-2+\frac{(a+b)^{2}}{c^{2}+a b}-2 \geq 0 \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{b^{2}+c^{2}-2 a^{2}}{a^{2}+b c}+\frac{c^{2}+a^{2}-2 b^{2}}{b^{2}+c a}+\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-2 c^{2}}{c^{2}+a b} \geq 0 \\
& \Leftrightarrow\left(\frac{b^{2}-a^{2}}{a^{2}+b c}+\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{b^{2}+c a}\right)+\left(\frac{c^{2}-a^{2}}{a^{2}+b c}+\frac{a^{2}-c^{2}}{c^{2}+a b}\right) \\
& +\left(\frac{c^{2}-b^{2}}{b^{2}+c a}+\frac{b^{2}-c^{2}}{c^{2}+a b}\right) \geq 0 \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{(b-a)^{2}(a+b)(a+b-c)}{\left(a^{2}+b c\right)\left(b^{2}+c a\right)}+\frac{(c-a)^{2}(c+a)(c+a-b)}{\left(a^{2}+b c\right)\left(c^{2}+a b\right)} \\
& +\frac{(b-c)^{2}(b+c)(b+c-a)}{\left(b^{2}+c a\right)\left(c^{2}+a b\right)} \geq 0,
\end{aligned}
$$
which is clearly true.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a \sqrt{b c} + b \sqrt{c a} + c \sqrt{a b} \geq 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a + b + c \geq C
$$

Let $a, b, c$ be the side lengths, and $h_{a}, h_{b}, h_{c}$ be the lengths of the altitudes (respectively) of a given triangle. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all triangles:
$$
\frac{h_{a}+h_{b}+h_{c}}{a+b+c} \leq C.
$$

Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $abc \geq 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \geq C(a b+b c+c a)
$$
solution:
By Chebishev's inequality it is easy to obtain
$$
\begin{equation*}
3\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right) \geq(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Now by $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
a+b+c \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a b c} \geq 3
$$
and clearly
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq a b+b c+c a
$$

So by (1) we obtain
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \geq \frac{(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}{3} \geq \frac{3(a b+b c+c a)}{3}=a b+b c+c a
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 2$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
x + y + z \leq x y z + C
$$
solution:
If one of $x, y, z$ is negative, let us say $x$ then

$$
2+x y z-x-y-z=(2-y-z)-x(1-y z) \geq 0
$$

because $y+z \leq \sqrt{2\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)} \leq 2$ and $z y \leq \frac{z^{2}+y^{2}}{2} \leq 1$. So we may assume that $0<x \leq y \leq z$. If $z \leq 1$ then

$$
2+x y z-x-y-z=(1-z)(1-x y)+(1-x)(1-y) \geq 0
$$

Now, if $z>1$ we have

$$
z+(x+y) \leq \sqrt{2\left(z^{2}+(x+y)^{2}\right)}=2 \sqrt{1+x y} \leq 2+x y \leq 2+x y z
$$

This ends the proof.

Using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality, we find that

$$
x+y+z-x y z=x(1-y z)+y+z \leq \sqrt{\left(x^{2}+(y+z)^{2}\right) \cdot\left(1+(1-y z)^{2}\right)}
$$

So, it is enough to prove that this last quantity is at most 2 , which is equivalent to the inequality $(2+2 y z)\left(2-2 y z+(y z)^{2}\right) \leq 4 \Leftrightarrow 2(y z)^{3} \leq 2(y z)^{2}$, which is clearly true, because $2 \geq y^{2}+z^{2} \geq 2 y z$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers which satisfy the condition

$$
x y+x z+y z+2 x y z=1
$$

Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
x+y+z \geq C
$$
solution:
Denote also $s=x+y+z$; the following inequalities are well-known

$$
(x+y+z)^{2} \geq 3(x y+x z+y z)
$$

and

$$
(x+y+z)^{3} \geq 27 x y z
$$

then we have $2 s^{3} \geq 54 x y z=27-27(x y+x z+y z) \geq 27-9 s^{2}$, i. e.

$$
2 s^{3}+9 s^{2}-27 \geq 0 \Leftrightarrow(2 s-3)(s+3)^{2} \geq 0
$$

where from $2 s-3 \geq 0 \Leftrightarrow s \geq \frac{3}{2}$.
Or, because $p \leq \frac{1}{8}$, we have

$$
s^{2} \geq 3 q=3(1-2 p) \geq 3\left(1-\frac{2}{8}\right)=\frac{9}{4}
$$

if we put $q=x y+x z+y z, p=x y z$.
Now, one can see the following is also true

$$
q=x y+x z+y z \geq \frac{3}{4}
$$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $x, y \geq 0$ be real numbers such that $y(y+1) \leq (x+1)^2$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
y(y-1) \leq C x^2.
$$
solution:
If $0 \leq y \leq 1$, then $y(y-1) \leq 0 \leq x^{2}$.
Suppose that $y>1$.
If $x+\frac{1}{2} \leq y$, then
$$
y(y-1)=y(y+1)-2 y \leq(x+1)^{2}-2\left(x+\frac{1}{2}\right)=x^{2} .
$$

If $x+\frac{1}{2}>y$ then we have $x>y-\frac{1}{2}>0$, i.e.
$$
x^{2}>\left(y-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}=y(y-1)+\frac{1}{4}>y(y-1)
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers such that $ab + bc + ca = 1$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a}{1+a^{2}}+\frac{b}{1+b^{2}}+\frac{c}{1+c^{2}} \leq C
$$
solution:
Since $a b+b c+c a=1$ we take:
$$
a=\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}, \quad b=\tan \frac{\beta}{2}, \quad c=\tan \frac{\gamma}{2}
$$
where $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$ and $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$.
So we have
$$
\frac{a}{1+a^{2}}+\frac{b}{1+b^{2}}+\frac{c}{1+c^{2}}=\frac{1}{2}(\sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma)
$$
and the given inequality becomes
$$
\frac{1}{2}(\sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma) \leq \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{4}
$$
i.e.
$$
\sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma \leq \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2}
$$
which is true according to $N_{1}$.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1 / \sqrt{3}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the maximal positive number $C$ such that the inequality below holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{(b+c-a)^{2}}{(b+c)^{2}+a^{2}}+\frac{(c+a-b)^{2}}{(c+a)^{2}+b^{2}}+\frac{(a+b-c)^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}+c^{2}} \geq C
$$
solution:
Of course, we may take $a+b+c=2$. The inequality becomes

$$
\sum \frac{4(1-a)^{2}}{2+2(1-a)^{2}} \geq \frac{3}{5} \Leftrightarrow \sum \frac{1}{1+(1-a)^{2}} \leq \frac{27}{10}
$$

But with the substitution $1-a=x, 1-b=y, 1-c=z$, the inequality reduces to that from problem 47.

Let $x=\frac{b+c}{a}, y=\frac{c+a}{b}, z=\frac{a+b}{c}$. The inequality can be written

$$
\sum \frac{(x-1)^{2}}{x^{2}+1} \geq \frac{3}{5}
$$

Using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality, we find that

$$
\sum \frac{(x-1)^{2}}{x^{2}+1} \geq \frac{(x+y+z-3)^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+3}
$$

and so it is enough to prove that

$$
\frac{(x+y+z-3)^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+3} \geq \frac{3}{5} \Leftrightarrow\left(\sum x\right)^{2}-15 \sum x+3 \sum x y+18 \geq 0
$$

But from Schur's Inequality, after some computations, we deduce that $\sum x y \geq 2 \sum x$. Thus, we have

$$
\left(\sum x\right)^{2}-15 \sum x+3 \sum x y+18 \geq\left(\sum x\right)^{2}-9 \sum x+18 \geq 0
$$

the last one being clearly true since $\sum x \geq 6$.

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} \geq 0$ and $a_{n}$ is the least among the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, then find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$:
$$
a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}-n a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n} \geq C\left(\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n-1}}{n-1}-a_{n}\right)^{n}
$$
solution:
Let $a_{i}-a_{n}=x_{i} \geq 0$ for $i \in\{1,2, \ldots, n-1\}$. Now, let us look at

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}-n \cdot \prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}-(n-1)\left(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} a_{i}}{n-1}-a_{n}\right)^{n}
$$

as a polynomial in $a=a_{n}$. It is in fact

$$
a^{n}+\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\left(a+x_{i}\right)^{n}-n a \prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\left(a+x_{i}\right)-(n-1)\left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n-1}}{n-1}\right)^{n}
$$

We will prove that the coefficient of $a^{k}$ is nonnegative for all $k \in\{0,1, \ldots, n-1\}$, because clearly the degree of this polynomial is at most $n-1$. For $k=0$, this follows from the convexity of the function $f(x)=x^{n}$

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} x_{i}^{n} \geq(n-1)\left(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} x_{i}}{n-1}\right)^{n}
$$

For $k>0$, the coefficient of $a^{k}$ is

$$
\binom{n}{k} \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} x_{i}^{n-k}-n \sum_{1 \leq i_{1}<\cdots<i_{n-k} \leq n-1} x_{i_{1}} x_{i_{2}} \ldots x_{i_{n-k}}
$$

Let us prove that this is nonnegative. From the AM-GM Inequality we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
n \sum_{1 \leq i_{1}<i_{2}<\cdots<i_{n-k} \leq n-1} x_{i_{1}} x_{i_{2}} \ldots x_{i_{n-k}} \leq \\
\frac{n}{n-k} \sum_{1 \leq i_{1}<i_{2}<\cdots<i_{n-k} \leq n-1}\left(x_{i_{1}}^{n-k}+x_{i_{2}}^{n-k}+\cdots+x_{i_{n-k}}^{n-k}\right)=\frac{k}{n-1} \cdot\binom{n}{k} \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} x_{i}^{n-k}
\end{gathered}
$$

which is clearly smaller than $\binom{n}{k} \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} x_{i}^{n-k}$. This shows that each coefficient of the polynomial is nonnegative and so this polynomial takes nonnegative values when restricted to nonnegative numbers.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers which satisfy the condition
$$
x y + x z + y z + 2 x y z = 1.
$$
Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1}{x} + \frac{1}{y} + \frac{1}{z} \geq C(x + y + z).
$$
solution:
The three numbers $x, y, z$ cannot be all less than $\frac{1}{2}$, because, in this case we get the contradiction

$$
x y+x z+y z+2 x y z<\frac{3}{4}+2 \cdot \frac{1}{8}=1
$$

because of symmetry we may assume then that $z \geq \frac{1}{2}$.
We have $1=(2 z+1) x y+z(x+y) \geq(2 z+1) x y+2 z \sqrt{x y}$, which can also be written in the form $((2 z+1) \sqrt{x y}-1)(\sqrt{x y}+1) \leq 0$; and this one yields the inequality

$$
x y \leq \frac{1}{(2 z+1)^{2}}
$$

We also have $1=(2 z+1) x y+z(x+y) \leq(2 z+1) \frac{(x+y)^{2}}{4}+z(x+y)$, consequently $((2 z+1)(x+y)-2)(x+y+2) \geq 0$, which shows us that

$$
x+y \geq \frac{2}{2 z+1}
$$

The inequality to be proved

$$
\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z} \geq 4(x+y+z)
$$

can be also rearranged as

$$
(x+y)\left(\frac{1}{x y}-4\right) \geq \frac{4 z^{2}-1}{z}=\frac{(2 z-1)(2 z+1)}{z}
$$

From the above calculations we infer that

$$
(x+y)\left(\frac{1}{x y}-4\right) \geq \frac{2}{2 z+1}\left((2 z+1)^{2}-4\right)=\frac{2(2 z-1)(2 z+3)}{2 z+1}
$$

(the assumption $z \geq \frac{1}{2}$ allows the multiplication of the inequalities side by side), and this means that the problem would be solved if we proved

$$
\frac{2(2 z+3)}{2 z+1} \geq \frac{2 z+1}{z} \Leftrightarrow 4 z^{2}+6 z \geq 4 z^{2}+4 z+1
$$

but this follows for $z \geq \frac{1}{2}$ and we are done.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $abc = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a}{(a+1)(b+1)}+\frac{b}{(b+1)(c+1)}+\frac{c}{(c+1)(a+1)} \geq C
$$
solution:
After expanding we get
$$
a b+a c+b c+a+b+c \geq 3(a b c+1)
$$
i.e.
$$
a b+a c+b c+a+b+c \geq 6
$$

Since
$$
\begin{aligned}
a b+a c+b c+a+b+c & =\frac{1}{c}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{a}+a+b+c \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{a}+a\right)+\left(\frac{1}{b}+b\right)+\left(\frac{1}{c}+c\right) \geq 2+2+2=6
\end{aligned}
$$
we are done.
Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{1}{a}+a=\frac{1}{b}+b=\frac{1}{c}+c=1$, i.e. $a=b=c=1$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c+d=4$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:
$$
\frac{1}{11+a^{2}}+\frac{1}{11+b^{2}}+\frac{1}{11+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{11+d^{2}} \leq C.
$$
solution:
Rewrite the given inequality as follows
$$
\frac{1}{11+a^{2}}-\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{11+b^{2}}-\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{11+c^{2}}-\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{11+d^{2}}-\frac{1}{12} \leq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a^{2}-1}{11+a^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}-1}{11+b^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}-1}{11+c^{2}}+\frac{d^{2}-1}{11+d^{2}} \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
(a-1) \frac{a+1}{11+a^{2}}+(b-1) \frac{b+1}{11+b^{2}}+(c-1) \frac{c+1}{11+c^{2}}+(d-1) \frac{d+1}{11+d^{2}} \geq 0 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c \geq d$.
Then we have
$a-1 \geq b-1 \geq c-1 \geq d-1 \quad$ and $\quad \frac{a+1}{11+a^{2}} \geq \frac{b+1}{11+b^{2}} \geq \frac{c+1}{11+c^{2}} \geq \frac{d+1}{11+d^{2}}$.
Now inequality (1) is a direct consequences of Chebishev's inequality.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=d=1$.

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c+1=4abc$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequalities hold simultaneously for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \geq C 
$$

Theorem 83.Theorem: Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Then $$\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}\geq\frac{3}{2}$$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers such that $a^{2/3} + b^{2/3} + c^{2/3} = 3$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a^2 + b^2 + c^2 \geq C(a^{4/3} + b^{4/3} + c^{4/3}).
$$
solution:
After setting $a^{1 / 3}=x, b^{1 / 3}=y, c^{1 / 3}=z$ the initial condition becomes
$$
\begin{equation*}
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=3 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$
and the given inequality is equivalent to
$$
x^{6}+y^{6}+z^{6} \geq x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}
$$

Assume that $x^{2} \leq y^{2} \leq z^{2}$. Then it is clear that $x^{4} \leq y^{4} \leq z^{4}$.
Applying Chebishev's inequality we get
$$
\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\left(x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}\right) \leq 3\left(x^{6}+y^{6}+z^{6}\right)
$$
and using (1) we obtain $x^{6}+y^{6}+z^{6} \geq x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}$, as required.

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
For any $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n} \in (0,1)$ and for any permutation $\sigma$ of the set $\{1,2, \ldots, n\}$, determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{1-x_{i}} \geq\left(C+\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}}{n}\right) \cdot\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{1-x_{i} \cdot x_{\sigma(i)}}\right)
$$

Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a \geq b \geq c$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^{2} b(a-b)+b^{2} c(b-c)+c^{2} a(c-a) \geq C.
$$
solution:
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a^{2} b(a-b)+b^{2} c(b-c)+c^{2} a(c-a) \\
&= a^{2} b(a-b)+b^{2} c(b-c)+c^{2} a(c-a)-a b^{2}(a-b)-a b^{2}(b-c) \\
& \quad-a b^{2}(c-a)
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
= & \left(a^{2} b(a-b)-a b^{2}(a-b)\right)+\left(b^{2} c(b-c)-a b^{2}(b-c)\right) \\
& +\left(c^{2} a(c-a)-a b^{2}(c-a)\right) \\
= & a b(a-b)^{2}+\left(a b+a c-b^{2}\right)(a-c)(b-c)
\end{aligned}
$$

So we need to show that
$$
a b(a-b)^{2}+\left(a b+a c-b^{2}\right)(a-c)(b-c) \geq 0
$$
which clearly holds since $a \geq b \geq c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{b+c}{\sqrt{a}}+\frac{c+a}{\sqrt{b}}+\frac{a+b}{\sqrt{c}} \geq \sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c}+C
$$
solution:
By $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{b+c}{\sqrt{a}}+\frac{c+a}{\sqrt{b}}+\frac{a+b}{\sqrt{c}} \\
& \quad \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{b c}{a}}+2 \sqrt{\frac{c a}{b}}+2 \sqrt{\frac{a b}{c}} \\
& \quad=\left(\sqrt{\frac{b c}{a}}+\sqrt{\frac{c a}{b}}\right)+\left(\sqrt{\frac{c a}{b}}+\sqrt{\frac{a b}{c}}\right)+\left(\sqrt{\frac{a b}{c}}+\sqrt{\frac{b c}{a}}\right) \\
& \quad \geq 2(\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c}) \geq \sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c}+3 \sqrt[6]{a b c} \\
& \quad=\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c}+3
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $O$ be an arbitrary point in the interior of $\triangle ABC$. Let $x, y$, and $z$ be the distances from $O$ to the sides $BC, CA, AB$, respectively, and let $R$ be the circumradius of the triangle $\triangle ABC$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all points $O$ and all triangles $\triangle ABC$:
$$
\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{z} \leq C \sqrt{R}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{C a}{a^{2}+b c}+\frac{C b}{b^{2}+a c}+\frac{C c}{c^{2}+a b} \leq \frac{a}{b c}+\frac{b}{a c}+\frac{c}{a b} .
$$
solution:
Notice that $\frac{2 a}{a^{2}+b c} \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)$, which is equivalent to
$$
b(a-c)^{2}+c(a-b)^{2} \geq 0
$$

Also $\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{2 a}{b c}+\frac{b}{a c}+\frac{c}{a b}\right)$, which is equivalent to
$$
(a-b)^{2}+(a-c)^{2} \geq 0
$$

Hence
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{2 a}{a^{2}+b c} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{2 a}{b c}+\frac{b}{a c}+\frac{c}{a b}\right) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Analogously, we obtain
$$
\begin{align*}
& \frac{2 b}{b^{2}+a c} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{2 b}{a c}+\frac{c}{a b}+\frac{a}{b c}\right)  \tag{2}\\
& \frac{2 c}{c^{2}+a b} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{2 c}{a b}+\frac{a}{b c}+\frac{b}{a c}\right) \tag{3}
\end{align*}
$$

Adding (1), (2) and (3) we obtain the required inequality.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z \leq 1$ and $x + y + z = 1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraints:
$$
\frac{1}{1+x^{2}}+\frac{1}{1+y^{2}}+\frac{1}{1+z^{2}} \leq C
$$
solution:
Using the fact that $(4-3 t)(1-3 t)^{2} \geq 0$ for any $t \leq 1$, we find that

$$
\frac{1}{1+x^{2}} \leq \frac{27}{50}(2-x)
$$

Writing two similar expressions for $y$ and $z$ and adding them up, we find the desired inequality.

problem:
Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n} > 0$ be real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$:
$$
x_{1}^{x_{1}} x_{2}^{x_{2}} \cdots x_{n}^{x_{n}} \geq \left(x_{1} x_{2} \cdots x_{n}\right)^{C}
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a b + b c + c a = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{b}\right)^{2}+\left(b+\frac{1}{c}\right)^{2}+\left(c+\frac{1}{a}\right)^{2} \geq C
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a + b + c + d + abcd = 5$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:
$$
\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} + \frac{1}{d} \geq C.
$$
solution:
We'll use Lagrange's theorem.
Let
$f(a, b, c, d)=\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}+\frac{1}{d} \quad$ and $\quad g(a, b, c, d)=a+b+c+d+a b c d-5=0$.
We define
$$
L=f-\lambda g=\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}+\frac{1}{d}-\lambda(a+b+c+d+a b c d-5)
$$

For the first partial derivatives we get
$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\frac{\partial L}{\partial a}=-\frac{1}{a^{2}}-\lambda(1+b c d)=0, & \frac{\partial L}{\partial b}=-\frac{1}{b^{2}}-\lambda(1+a c d)=0 \\
\frac{\partial L}{\partial c}=-\frac{1}{c^{2}}-\lambda(1+a b d)=0, & \frac{\partial L}{\partial d}=-\frac{1}{d^{2}}-\lambda(1+a b c)=0
\end{array}
$$

So
$$
\lambda=-\frac{1}{a^{2}(1+b c d)}=-\frac{1}{b^{2}(1+a c d)}=-\frac{1}{c^{2}(1+a b d)}=-\frac{1}{d^{2}(1+a b c)}
$$

From the first two equations we deduce
$$
a^{2}(1+b c d)=b^{2}(1+a c d), \quad \text { i.e. } \quad(a-b)(a+b+a b c d)=0
$$

Since $a+b+a b c d>0$ we must have $a=b$.

Analogously we deduce that $a=c=d$, i.e. $a=b=c=d$.
Using $a+b+c+d+a b c d=5$ we get
$$
a^{4}+4 a-5=0 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-1)\left(a^{3}+a^{2}+a+5\right)=0
$$
and it follows that we must have $a=1$.
So $a=b=c=d=1$.
Finally we have $f(1,1,1,1)=1+1+1+1=4$, and we are done.

Theorem 80.Theorem: Let $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)$ be a continuous and differentiable function on $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{m}$, and let $g_{i}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)$ $=0, i=1,2, \ldots, k$, where $(k<m)$ are the conditions that must be satisfied. Then the maximum or minimum values of $f$ with the conditions $g_{i}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots\right.$, $\left.x_{m}\right)=0, i=1,2, \ldots, k$, occur at the bounds of the interval $I$ or occur at the points at which the partial derivatives (according to the variables $\left.x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)$ of the function $L=f-\sum_{i=1}^{k} \lambda_{i} g_{i}$, are all zero.

problem:
Let $X$ be an arbitrary interior point of a given regular $n$-gon with side-length $a$. Let $h_{1}, h_{2}, \ldots, h_{n}$ be the distances from $X$ to the sides of the $n$-gon. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all interior points $X$:
$$
\frac{1}{h_{1}}+\frac{1}{h_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{h_{n}} > C.
$$
solution:
Let $S$ be the area of the given $n$-gon, and let $r$ be the inradius of its inscribed circle.

Then $S=\frac{n a r}{2}$.
On the other hand, we have
$$
S=\frac{1}{2} a\left(h_{1}+h_{2}+\cdots+h_{n}\right)
$$

Applying $A M \geq H M$ we have
$$
\frac{n}{\frac{1}{h_{1}}+\frac{1}{h_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{h_{n}}} \leq \frac{h_{1}+h_{2}+\cdots+h_{n}}{n}=\frac{2 S}{n a}=r
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{h_{1}}+\frac{1}{h_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{h_{n}} \geq \frac{n}{r} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

The perimeter of the $n$-gon is larger than the perimeter of its inscribed circle, so we have
$$
n a>2 \pi r, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \frac{n}{r}>\frac{2 \pi}{a}
$$

Now by (1) we obtain
$$
\frac{1}{h_{1}}+\frac{1}{h_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{h_{n}} \geq \frac{n}{r}>\frac{2 \pi}{a}
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Prove that for any $x, y$ in the interval $[0,1]$, determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds:
$$
\sqrt{1+x^{2}}+\sqrt{1+y^{2}}+\sqrt{(1-x)^{2}+(1-y)^{2}} \geq C(1-x y)
$$
solution:
Let the function $F:[0,1]^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, F(x, y)=\sqrt{1+x^{2}}+\sqrt{1+y^{2}}+$ $\sqrt{(1-x)^{2}+(1-y)^{2}}-(1+\sqrt{5})(1-x y)$. It is clear that $F$ is symmetric in $x$ and $y$ and also the convexity of the function $x \rightarrow \sqrt{1+x^{2}}$ shows that $F(x, 0) \geq 0$ for all $x$. Now, suppose we fix $y$ and consider $F$ as a function in $x$. It's derivatives are

$$
f^{\prime}(x)=(1+\sqrt{5}) y+\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}}-\frac{1-x}{\sqrt{(1-x)^{2}+(1-y)^{2}}}
$$

and

$$
f^{\prime \prime}(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{3}}}+\frac{(1-y)^{2}}{\sqrt{\left((1-x)^{2}+(1-y)^{2}\right)^{3}}}
$$

Thus, $f$ is convex and its derivative is increasing. Now, let

$$
r=\sqrt{1-\frac{6 \sqrt{3}}{(1+\sqrt{5})^{2}}}, c=1+\sqrt{5}
$$

The first case we will discuss is $y \geq \frac{1}{4}$. It is easy to see that in this case we have $c y>$ $\frac{1}{\sqrt{y^{2}-2 y+2}}$ (the derivative of the function $y \rightarrow y^{2} c^{2}\left(y^{2}-2 y+2\right)-1$ is positive) and so $f^{\prime}(0)>0$. Because $f^{\prime}$ is increasing, we have $f^{\prime}(x)>0$ and so $f$ is increasing with $f(0)=F(0, y)=F(y, 0) \geq 0$. Thus, in this case the inequality is proved.

Due to case 1 and to symmetry, it remains to show that the inequality holds in the cases $x \in\left[0, \frac{1}{4}\right], y \in[0, r]$ and $x \in\left[r, \frac{1}{4}\right], y \in\left[r, \frac{1}{4}\right]$.

In the first case we deduce immediately that

$$
f^{\prime}(x) \leq r(1+\sqrt{5})+\frac{x}{\sqrt{1+x^{2}}}-\frac{1-x}{\sqrt{1+(x-1)^{2}}}
$$

Thus, we have $f^{\prime}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)<0$, which shows that $f$ is decreasing on $\left[0, \frac{1}{4}\right]$. Because from the first case discussed we have $f\left(\frac{1}{4}\right) \geq 0$, we will have $F(x, y)=f(x) \geq 0$ for all points $(x, y)$ with $x \in\left[0, \frac{1}{4}\right], y \in[0, r]$.

Now, let us discuss the most important case, when $x \in\left[r, \frac{1}{4}\right], y \in\left[r, \frac{1}{4}\right]$. Let the points $O(0,0), A(1,0), B(1,1), C(0,1), M(1, y), N(x, 1)$. The triangle $O M N$ has perimeter

$$
\sqrt{1+x^{2}}+\sqrt{1+y^{2}}+\sqrt{(1-x)^{2}+(1-y)^{2}} \text { and area } \frac{1-x y}{2}
$$

But it is trivial to show that in any triangle with perimeter $P$ and area $S$ we have the inequality $S \leq \frac{P^{2}}{12 \sqrt{3}}$. Thus, we find that $\sqrt{1+x^{2}}+\sqrt{1+y^{2}}+\sqrt{(1-x)^{2}+(1-y)^{2}} \geq$ $\sqrt{6 \sqrt{3}} \sqrt{1-x y} \geq(1+\sqrt{5})(1-x y)$ due to the fact that $x y \geq r^{2}$. The proof is complete.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:

$$
\frac{xyz}{(1+3x)(x+8y)(y+9z)(z+6)} \leq C.
$$
solution:
First, we write the inequality in the following form

$$
(1+3 x)\left(1+\frac{8 y}{x}\right)\left(1+\frac{9 z}{y}\right)\left(1+\frac{6}{z}\right) \geq 7^{4}
$$

But this follows immediately from Huygens Inequality. We have equality for $x=2, y=\frac{3}{2}, z=1$.

Theorem 13.Theorem:
If $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ are positive real numbers with $p_{1}+p_{2}+\ldots+p_{n}=1$, then

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p_{i}} \geq \prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p_{i}}+\prod_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p_{i}}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b > 0$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b > 0$ and for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$:
$$
\left(1+\frac{a}{b}\right)^{n}+\left(1+\frac{b}{a}\right)^{n} \geq C.
$$

Let $a, b > 0$ be real numbers such that $a + b \leq 1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b$:
$$
ab + \frac{1}{ab} \geq C
$$
solution:
If we use $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
A=a b+\frac{1}{a b} \geq 2 \sqrt{a b \cdot \frac{1}{a b}}=2
$$
and equality occurs if and only if $a b=\frac{1}{a b}$, i.e. $a b=1$.
But then we have $a+b \geq 2 \sqrt{a b}=2$, contradicting $a+b \leq 1$.
If we take $x=\frac{1}{a b}$, then we have $x=\frac{1}{a b} \geq \frac{4}{(a+b)^{2}} \geq \frac{4}{1^{2}}=4$.
Thus we may consider an equivalent problem of the given problem:
Find the minimum of the function $A=x+\frac{1}{x}$, with $x \geq 4$.
Point of incidence is $x=4$.
So we have $\frac{x}{\alpha}=\frac{1}{x}$, from which it follows that $\alpha=x^{2}=16$.
Then we transform as follows
$$
A=x+\frac{1}{x}=\frac{x}{16}+\frac{1}{x}+\frac{15}{16} x \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{x}{16} \cdot \frac{1}{x}}+\frac{15}{16} x \geq 2 \cdot \frac{1}{4}+\frac{15}{16} \cdot 4=\frac{17}{4}
$$

Equality holds if and only if $x=4$, i.e. $a=b=1 / 2$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Consider positive real numbers $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ such that $x_{1} x_{2} \ldots x_{n}=1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1}{n-1+x_{1}}+\frac{1}{n-1+x_{2}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{n-1+x_{n}} \leq C
$$
solution:
Suppose the inequality is false for a certain system of $n$ numbers. Then we can find a number $k>1$ and $n$ numbers which add up to 1 , let them be $a_{i}$, such that $\frac{1}{n-1+x_{i}}=k a_{i}$. Then we have

$$
1=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{k a_{i}}-n+1\right)<\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{a_{i}}-n+1\right)
$$

We have used here the fact that $a_{i}<\frac{1}{n-1}$. Now, we write $1-(n-1) a_{k}=b_{k}$ and we find that $\sum_{k=1}^{n} b_{k}=1$ and also $\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(1-b_{k}\right)<(n-1)^{n} b_{1} \ldots b_{n}$. But this contradicts the fact that for each $j$ we have

$$
1-b_{j}=b_{1}+\cdots+b_{j-1}+b_{j+1}+\cdots+b_{n} \geq(n-1) \sqrt[n-1]{b_{1} \ldots b_{j-1} b_{j+1} \ldots b_{n}}
$$,Let us write the inequality in the form

$$
\frac{x_{1}}{n-1+x_{1}}+\frac{x_{2}}{n-1+x_{2}}+\ldots+\frac{x_{n}}{n-1+x_{n}} \geq 1
$$

This inequality follows by summing the following inequalities
$\frac{x_{1}}{n-1+x_{1}} \geq \frac{x_{1}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}}{x_{1}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}+x_{2}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}+\ldots+x_{n}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}}, \ldots, \frac{x_{n}}{n-1+x_{n}} \geq \frac{x_{n}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}}{x_{1}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}+x_{2}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}+\ldots+x_{n}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}}$,
The first from these inequalities is equivalent to

$$
x_{1}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}+x_{2}^{1-\frac{1}{n}}+\ldots+x_{n}^{1-\frac{1}{n}} \geq(n-1) x_{1}^{-\frac{1}{n}}
$$

and follows from the AM-GM Inequality.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d, e$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d, e \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+d}+\frac{c}{d+e}+\frac{d}{e+a}+\frac{e}{a+b} \geq C.
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1}=2$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1}{8 a^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{8 b^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{8 c^{2}+1} \geq C
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c = 1$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:

$$
\frac{a - b c}{a + b c} + \frac{b - c a}{b + c a} + \frac{c - a b}{c + a b} \leq C.
$$
solution:
Note that
$$
1-\frac{a-b c}{a+b c}=\frac{2 b c}{1-b-c+b c}=\frac{2 b c}{(1-b)(1-c)}=\frac{2 b c}{(c+a)(a+b)}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a-b c}{a+b c}=1-\frac{2 b c}{(c+a)(a+b)}
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\frac{b-c a}{b+c a}=1-\frac{2 c a}{(c+b)(b+a)} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c-a b}{c+a b}=1-\frac{2 a b}{(b+c)(c+a)}
$$

Now the given inequality becomes
$$
1-\frac{2 b c}{(c+a)(a+b)}+1-\frac{2 c a}{(c+b)(b+a)} 1-\frac{2 a b}{(b+c)(c+a)} \leq \frac{3}{2}
$$
or
$$
\frac{2 b c}{(c+a)(a+b)}+\frac{2 c a}{(c+b)(b+a)}+\frac{2 a b}{(b+c)(c+a)} \geq \frac{3}{2} .
$$

After expanding we get the equivalent form as follows
$$
4(b c(b+c)+c a(c+a)+a b(a+b)) \geq 3(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)
$$
i.e.
$$
a b+b c+a c \geq 9 a b c, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \geq 9
$$
which is true since
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \geq \frac{9}{a+b+c}=9 \quad(A M \geq H M)
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers such that $a + b + c = 2$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^{4} + b^{4} + c^{4} + C \cdot abc \geq a^{3} + b^{3} + c^{3}
$$
solution:
Applying Schur's inequality (fourth degree) we have that
$$
a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+a b c(a+b+c) \geq a^{3}(b+c)+b^{3}(c+a)+c^{3}(a+b)
$$
i.e.
$$
2\left(a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}\right)+a b c(a+b+c) \geq\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)(a+b+c)
$$
from which, using the initial condition, we obtain the result as required.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c=2 / 3$ or $a=b=1, c=0$ (over all permutations).

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \geq 0$ such that $a + b + c + d = 1$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^{4} + b^{4} + c^{4} + d^{4} + C a b c d \geq \frac{1}{27}
$$
solution:
Denote $f(a, b, c, d)=a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+d^{4}+\frac{148}{27} a b c d-\frac{1}{27}$.
Since the given inequality is symmetric we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c \geq d$. We have
$$
f(a, b, c, d)-f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right)=\left(\frac{7}{8}(a-c)^{2}+3 a c-\frac{37}{27} b d\right)(a-b)^{2}
$$

Since $a c \geq b d$ it follows that
$$
f(a, b, c, d)-f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right) \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
f(a, b, c, d) \geq f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right)
$$

According to the SMV theorem it suffices to show that
$$
f(t, t, t, d) \geq 0, \quad \text { where } t=\frac{1-d}{3}
$$

We have
$$
f(t, t, t, d)=\frac{(1-d)^{4}}{27}+d^{4}+\frac{148 d(1-d)^{3}}{729}-\frac{1}{27}=\frac{2 d(4 d-1)^{2}(19 d+20)}{729} \geq 0
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=d=1 / 4$ or $a=b=c=1 / 3, d=0$ (up to permutation).

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the largest positive number $C$ such that the inequality below holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a^{5}}{b^{3}}+\frac{b^{5}}{c^{3}}+\frac{c^{5}}{a^{3}} \geq C(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2})
$$
solution:
Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
2 \frac{a^{5}}{b^{3}}+3 b^{2}=\frac{a^{5}}{b^{3}}+\frac{a^{5}}{b^{3}}+b^{2}+b^{2}+b^{2} \geq 5 \sqrt[5]{\frac{a^{5}}{b^{3}} \cdot \frac{a^{5}}{b^{3}} \cdot b^{2} \cdot b^{2} \cdot b^{2}}=5 a^{2}
$$

Analogously we have
$$
2 \frac{b^{5}}{c^{3}}+3 c^{2} \geq 5 b^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad 2 \frac{c^{5}}{a^{3}}+3 a^{2} \geq 5 c^{2}
$$

Adding these three inequalities we obtain
$$
2\left(\frac{a^{5}}{b^{3}}+\frac{b^{5}}{c^{3}}+\frac{c^{5}}{a^{3}}\right)+3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \geq 5\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a^{5}}{b^{3}}+\frac{b^{5}}{c^{3}}+\frac{c^{5}}{a^{3}} \geq a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}
$$

Equality holds iff $a=b=c$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
C\left(a^{2}-a+1\right)\left(b^{2}-b+1\right)\left(c^{2}-c+1\right) \geq 1+a b c+(a b c)^{2}
$$
solution:
Since
$$
2\left(a^{2}-a+1\right)\left(b^{2}-b+1\right)=1+a^{2} b^{2}+(a-b)^{2}+(1-a)^{2}(1-b)^{2}
$$
we deduce that
$$
2\left(a^{2}-a+1\right)\left(b^{2}-b+1\right) \geq 1+a^{2} b^{2}
$$

It follows that
$$
3\left(a^{2}-a+1\right)\left(b^{2}-b+1\right)\left(c^{2}-c+1\right) \geq \frac{3}{2}\left(1+a^{2} b^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}-c+1\right)
$$
and it remains to prove that
$$
3\left(1+a^{2} b^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}-c+1\right) \geq 2\left(1+a b c+(a b c)^{2}\right)
$$
which is equivalent to the following quadratic in $c$
$$
\left(3+a^{2} b^{2}\right) c^{2}-\left(3+2 a b+3 a^{2} b^{2}\right) c+1+3 a^{2} b^{2} \geq 0
$$
and clearly the last inequality is true, since $3+a^{2} b^{2}>0$ and $D=-3(1-a b)^{4} \leq 0$.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 11.Theorem:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Given a function $f$ of $n$ variables, define the cyclic sum of variables $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{c y c} f\left(x_{1}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+f\left(x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}, x_{1}\right) \\
+\ldots+f\left(a_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n-1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a + b + c = 1$. Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}+\frac{b^{3}}{b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{c^{3}}{c^{2}+a^{2}} \geq C.
$$
solution:
Clearly we have
$$
\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2} \geq a b \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \frac{a b}{a^{2}+b^{2}} \leq \frac{1}{2}
$$

Therefore
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}=a-b \frac{a b}{a^{2}+b^{2}} \geq a-\frac{b}{2}
$$

Analogously
$$
\frac{b^{3}}{b^{2}+c^{2}} \geq b-\frac{c}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c^{3}}{c^{2}+a^{2}} \geq c-\frac{a}{2}
$$

After adding these and using $a+b+c=1$ we obtain
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}+\frac{b^{3}}{b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{c^{3}}{c^{2}+a^{2}} \geq a+b+c-\frac{a+b+c}{2}=\frac{a+b+c}{2}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq C P + (a-b)^{2} + (b-c)^{2} + (c-a)^{2}
$$
where $P = a + b + c$.
solution:
The given inequality can be rewritten as
$$
\begin{equation*}
2(a b+b c+c a) \geq 4 \sqrt{3} P+a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Using $\frac{a b \sin \gamma}{2}=\frac{a c \sin \beta}{2}=\frac{b c \sin \alpha}{2}=P$ it follows that
$$
a b=\frac{2 P}{\sin \gamma}, \quad a c=\frac{2 P}{\sin \beta}, \quad b c=\frac{2 P}{\sin \alpha}
$$

From
$$
\cot \alpha=\frac{\cos \alpha}{\sin \alpha}=\frac{\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}}{2 b c}}{\frac{a}{2 R}}=\frac{R}{a b c}\left(b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}\right)
$$
we get
$$
\cot \alpha+\cot \beta+\cot \gamma=\frac{R}{a b c}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)
$$
i.e.
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=4 P(\cot \alpha+\cot \beta+\cot \gamma)
$$
and inequality (1) becomes
$$
4 P\left(\frac{1}{\sin \alpha}+\frac{1}{\sin \gamma}+\frac{1}{\sin \beta}\right) \geq 4 \sqrt{3} P+4 P(\cot \alpha+\cot \beta+\cot \gamma)
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{align*}
& \left(\frac{1}{\sin \alpha}-\cot \alpha\right)+\left(\frac{1}{\sin \beta}-\cot \beta\right)+\left(\frac{1}{\sin \gamma}-\cot \gamma\right) \geq \sqrt{3} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{1-\cos \alpha}{\sin \alpha}+\frac{1-\cos \beta}{\sin \beta}+\frac{1-\cos \gamma}{\sin \gamma} \geq \sqrt{3} \tag{2}
\end{align*}
$$

But $1-\cos \alpha=2 \sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}$ and $\sin \alpha=2 \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\alpha}{2}$, so we have
$$
\frac{1-\cos \alpha}{\sin \alpha}=\frac{2 \sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}}{2 \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\alpha}{2}}=\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}
$$

Now inequality (2) is equivalent to
$$
\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}+\tan \frac{\beta}{2}+\tan \frac{\gamma}{2} \geq \sqrt{3}
$$
which is true, since $\tan x$ is convex on $(0, \pi / 2)$ (Jensen's inequality).,The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
2(a b+b c+c a)-\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \geq 4 \sqrt{3} P
$$

We'll use Ravi's substitutions, i.e. $a=x+y, b=y+z, c=z+x$, where $x, y, z>0$.
Then the previous inequality becomes
$$
x y+y z+z x \geq \sqrt{3 x y z(x+y+z)}
$$
which is true due to
$$
(x y+y z+z x)^{2}-3 x y z(x+y+z)=\frac{(x y-y z)^{2}+(y z-z x)^{2}+(z x-x y)^{2}}{2}
$$

Clearly equality holds iff $x=y=z$, i.e. iff $a=b=c$.

Theorem 82.Theorem: If a triangle in the plane has side lengths $a, b$ and $c$ and area $T$, then $$a^2+b^2+c^2 \geq (a-b)^2+(b-c)^2+(c-a)^2 + 4\sqrt{3}T$$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3abc$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a}{b^2 c^2} + \frac{b}{c^2 a^2} + \frac{c}{a^2 b^2} \geq \frac{C}{a+b+c}
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)(a+b+c) \geq 9 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}
$$

Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)(a+b+c) \geq\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Since $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=3 a b c$ we obtain
$$
\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)(a+b+c) \geq\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}=(3 a b c)^{2}=9 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}
$$

Equality holds if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c = 1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a}{\sqrt[3]{a+2b}} + \frac{b}{\sqrt[3]{b+2c}} + \frac{c}{\sqrt[3]{c+2a}} \geq C
$$
solution:
Let us denote
$$
A=\frac{a}{\sqrt[3]{a+2 b}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt[3]{b+2 c}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt[3]{c+2 a}}
$$
and
$$
B=a(a+2 b)+b(b+2 c)+c(c+2 a)=(a+b+c)^{2}=1
$$

By Hlder's inequality we have
$$
A^{3} B \geq(a+b+c)^{4}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad A^{3} \geq(a+b+c)^{2}=1
$$
from which it follows that $A \geq 1$.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Theorem 54.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n} ; m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}$ be three sequences of positive real numbers and let $p>1$. Then
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{1}{a(1+b)}+\frac{1}{b(1+c)}+\frac{1}{c(1+a)} \geq C \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{a b c}(1+\sqrt[3]{a b c})}
$$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Find the maximal constant $C$ such that for all real numbers $a, b, c$, the following inequality holds:
$$
\sqrt{a^{2}+(1-b)^{2}}+\sqrt{b^{2}+(1-c)^{2}}+\sqrt{c^{2}+(1-a)^{2}} \geq C
$$
solution:
Applying Minkowsky's Inequality to the left-hand side we have
$\sqrt{a^{2}+(1-b)^{2}}+\sqrt{b^{2}+(1-c)^{2}}+\sqrt{c^{2}+(1-a)^{2}} \geq \sqrt{(a+b+c)^{2}+(3-a-b-c)^{2}}$.
Denoting $a+b+c=x$ we get

$$
(a+b+c)^{2}+(3-a-b-c)^{2}=2\left(x-\frac{3}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{9}{2} \geq \frac{9}{2}
$$

and the conclusion follows

Theorem 15.Theorem:
For any real number $r \geq 1$ and any positive real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$

$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c = 1$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a \sqrt[3]{1+b-c} + b \sqrt[3]{1+c-a} + c \sqrt[3]{1+a-b} \leq C
$$
solution:
Note that $1+b-c=a+b+c+b-c=a+2 b \geq 0$.
Now by $G M \leq A M$ we have
$$
a \sqrt[3]{1+b-c} \leq a \frac{1+b-c+1+1}{3}=a+\frac{a(b-c)}{3}
$$

Similarly
$$
b \sqrt[3]{1+c-a} \leq b+\frac{b(c-a)}{3} \quad \text { and } \quad c \sqrt[3]{1+a-b} \leq c+\frac{c(a-b)}{3}
$$

Adding these three inequalities we get
$$
a \sqrt[3]{1+b-c}+b \sqrt[3]{1+c-a}+c \sqrt[3]{1+a-b} \leq a+b+c=1
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a+b+c=1$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{b}{(c+a)^{2}}+\frac{c}{(a+b)^{2}} \geq C.
$$

Theorem 83.Theorem: Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Then $$\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}\geq\frac{3}{2}$$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}_0$:
$$
2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+a b c+C \geq 5(a+b+c)
$$
solution:
We'll use Schur's inequality, i.e.
$$
x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}+3 x y z \geq x y(x+y)+y z(y+z)+z x(z+x), \quad \text { for all } x, y, z \geq 0
$$

By $A M \geq G M$ and $Q M \geq A M$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
6(2 & \left.\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+a b c+8-5(a+b+c)\right) \\
\quad & =12\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+6 a b c+48-30(a+b+c) \\
= & 12\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+3(2 a b c+1)+45-30(a+b+c) \\
\geq & 12\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+9 \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}}+45-5\left((a+b+c)^{2}+9\right) \\
= & \frac{9 a b c}{\sqrt[3]{a b c}}+3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)-6(a b+b c+c a) \\
& +2\left((a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}\right) \\
\geq & \frac{9 a b c}{\sqrt[3]{a b c}}+3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)-6(a b+b c+c a) \\
\geq & \frac{27 a b c}{a+b+c}+3(a+b+c)^{2}-12(a b+b c+c a) \\
= & \frac{3}{a+b+c}\left(9 a b c+(a+b+c)^{3}-4(a b+b c+c a)(a+b+c)\right) \\
= & \frac{3}{a+b+c}\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+3 a b c-a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)+c a(c+a)\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

And we are done. Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x + y + z = 1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\frac{z - xy}{x^2 + xy + y^2} + \frac{y - zx}{x^2 + xz + z^2} + \frac{x - yz}{y^2 + yz + z^2} \geq C
$$
solution:
Let $p=x+y+z=1, q=x y+y z+z x, r=x y z$.
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{2}+x y+y^{2} & =(x+y)^{2}-x y=(1-z)^{2}-x y=1-2 z+z^{2}-x y \\
& =1-z-z(1-z)-x y=1-z-z(x+y)-x y=1-z-q
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly we deduce that
$$
x^{2}+x z+z^{2}=1-y-q \quad \text { and } \quad y^{2}+y z+z^{2}=1-x-q
$$

According to the previous identities, $I_{3}$ and $I_{12}$, by using elementary algebraic transformations the given inequality becomes
$$
q^{3}+q^{2}-4 q+3 q r+4 r+1 \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
27 q^{3}+27 q^{2}-108 q+27 r(3 q+4)+27 \geq 0 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

By $N_{1}: p^{3}-4 p q+9 r \geq 0$, since $p=1$ we get
$$
\begin{equation*}
9 r \geq 4 q-1 \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

According to inequality (2) we obtain
$$
\begin{align*}
& 27 q^{3}+27 q^{2}-108 q+27 r(3 q+4)+27 \\
& \quad \geq 27 q^{3}+27 q^{2}-108 q+3(4 q-1)(3 q+4)+27 \\
& \quad=(3 q-1)\left(9 q^{2}+24 q-15\right) \tag{3}
\end{align*}
$$

Since $p=1$ due to $N_{1}: p^{2} \geq 3 q$ it follows that
$$
\begin{equation*}
q \leq \frac{1}{3} \tag{4}
\end{equation*}
$$

Finally by (3) and (4) we obtain
$$
27 q^{3}+27 q^{2}-108 q+27 r(3 q+4)+27 \geq(3 q-1)\left(9 q^{2}+24 q-15\right) \geq 0
$$
since $3 q-1 \leq 0$ and $9 q^{2}+24 q-15 \leq 9 \cdot \frac{1}{9}+24 \cdot \frac{1}{3}-15=-6$, as required.

Theorem 72.Theorem:
Let $x, y, z \geq 0$, and $p=x+y+z, q=x y+y z+z x, r=x y z$.
Then we have the following inequalities:
$$
\begin{array}{ll}
N_{3}: p q-9 r \geq 0, & N_{9}: p^{4}+3 q^{2} \geq 4 p^{2} q \\
N_{4}: p^{2} \geq 3 q, & N_{10}: 2 p^{3}+9 r^{2} \geq 7 p q r \\
N_{5}: p^{3} \geq 27 r, & N_{11}: p^{2} q+3 p r \geq 4 q^{2} \\
N_{6}: q^{3} \geq 27 r^{2}, & N_{12}: q^{3}+9 r^{2} \geq 4 p q r \\
N_{7}: q^{2} \geq 3 p r, & N_{13}: p q^{2} \geq 2 p^{2} r+3 q r \\
N_{8}: 2 p^{3}+9 r \geq 7 p q, &
\end{array}
$$

problem:
Let $x, y, z \geq 0$ be real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z \geq 0$:
$$
\sqrt{x^{2}+1}+\sqrt{y^{2}+1}+\sqrt{z^{2}+1} \geq \sqrt{C(x+y+z)}
$$

Let $a, b, c \geq 0$ be real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + abc = 4$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
ab + bc + ca - abc \leq C.
$$

Let $a, b, c \in [1, 2]$ be real numbers. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in [1, 2]$:
$$
(a+b+c)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right) \leq C
$$

Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $abc = 1$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\left(a-1+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b-1+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c-1+\frac{1}{a}\right) \leq C
$$
solution:
Since $a b c=1$, it is natural to take $a=\frac{x}{y}, b=\frac{y}{z}, c=\frac{z}{x}$ where $x, y, z>0$. Now the given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\frac{x}{y}-1+\frac{z}{y}\right)\left(\frac{y}{z}-1+\frac{x}{z}\right)\left(\frac{z}{x}-1+\frac{y}{x}\right) & \leq 1 \quad \text { i.e. } \\
(x+y-z)(z+x-y)(y+z-x) & \leq x y z
\end{aligned}
$$
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

problem:
Let $M$ be the centroid of the triangle $A B C$, and let $k$ be its circumscribed circle. Let $M A \cap k=\left\{A_{1}\right\}, M B \cap k=\left\{B_{1}\right\}$ and $M C \cap k=\left\{C_{1}\right\}$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all triangles $ABC$:
$$
\overline{M A}+\overline{M B}+\overline{M C} \leq C (\overline{M A_{1}}+\overline{M B_{1}}+\overline{M C_{1}}).
$$
solution:
Denote $\overline{B C}=a, \overline{A C}=b$ and $\overline{A B}=c$. Let $A^{\prime}, B^{\prime}$ and $C^{\prime}$ be the midpoints of the sides $B C, A C$ and $A B$, respectively.

Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \leq b \leq c$, and then we may easily conclude that $\overline{M C} \leq \overline{M B} \leq \overline{M A}$.

Also by the power of a point we have $\frac{3}{2} \overline{M A} \cdot \overline{A^{\prime} A_{1}}=\frac{1}{4} a^{2}$ from which it follows that
$$
\overline{A^{\prime} A_{1}}=\frac{a^{2}}{6 \overline{M A}}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \overline{M A_{1}}=\frac{1}{2} \overline{M A}+\overline{A^{\prime} A_{1}}=\frac{1}{2} \overline{M A}+\frac{a^{2}}{6 \overline{M A}}
$$

Analogously we obtain
$$
\overline{M B_{1}}=\frac{1}{2} \overline{M B}+\frac{b^{2}}{6 \overline{M B}} \quad \text { and } \quad \overline{M C_{1}}=\frac{1}{2} \overline{M C}+\frac{c^{2}}{6 \overline{M C}}
$$

So it suffices to prove the inequality
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{3 \overline{M A}}+\frac{b^{2}}{3 \overline{M B}}+\frac{c^{2}}{3 \overline{M C}} \geq \overline{M A}+\overline{M B}+\overline{M C}
$$

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a^{2}}{3 \overline{M A}}+\frac{b^{2}}{3 \overline{M B}}+\frac{c^{2}}{3 \overline{M C}} & =\frac{a^{2} \cdot 1}{3 \overline{M A}}+\frac{b^{2} \cdot 1}{3 \overline{M B}}+\frac{c^{2} \cdot 1}{3 \overline{M C}} \geq \frac{3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}{3(\overline{M A}+\overline{M B}+\overline{M C})} \\
& =\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{\overline{M A}+\overline{M B}+\overline{M C}} \geq \frac{3\left(\overline{M A}^{2}+\overline{M B}^{2}+\overline{M C}^{2}\right)}{\overline{M A}+\overline{M B}+\overline{M C}} \\
& \geq \overline{M A}+\overline{M B}+\overline{M C}
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.
