Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $0 < x < \frac{\pi}{2}$:
$$
\tan x > x + C x^3.
$$
solution:
Let $f(x)=\tan x, g(x)=x+\frac{x^{3}}{3}, x \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
Then $f(0)=0=g(0)$ and we have
$$
f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} x}=1+\tan ^{2} x>1+x^{2}=g^{\prime}(x), \quad \text { for all } x \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)
$$

Thus, due to Theorem 13.2, we get $f(x)>g(x)$, i.e. $\tan x>x+\frac{x^{3}}{3}$ for all $x \in$ $\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $xy + yz + zx + xyz = 4$. Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\sqrt{x+2}+\sqrt{y+2}+\sqrt{z+2} \geq C.
$$
solution:
Let us denote $x+2=a, y+2=b$ and $z+2=c$. Then the condition $x y+y z+z x+x y z=4$ becomes
$$
a b c=a b+b c+c a
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}=1
$$

By Hlder's inequality we have
$$
(\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c})^{2}\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right) \geq 3^{3}
$$
and since $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}=1$ we get
$$
(\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c})^{2} \geq 3^{3}
$$
i.e.
$$
\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c} \geq 3 \sqrt{3}
$$
as required.

Theorem 54.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n} ; m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}$ be three sequences of positive real numbers and let $p>1$. Then
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $n > 2$ and $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n} > 0$ such that
$$
\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k}\right)\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x_{k}}\right) = n^{2} + 1.
$$
Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$:
$$
\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k}^{2}\right) \cdot \left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x_{k}^{2}}\right) > n^{2} + C + \frac{2}{n(n-1)}.
$$
solution:
In this problem, a combination between identities and the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality is the way to proceed. So, let us start with the expression

$$
\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(\frac{x_{i}}{x_{j}}+\frac{x_{j}}{x_{i}}-2\right)^{2}
$$

We can immediately see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(\frac{x_{i}}{x_{j}}+\frac{x_{j}}{x_{i}}-2\right)^{2} & =\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(\frac{x_{i}^{2}}{x_{j}^{2}}+\frac{x_{j}^{2}}{x_{i}^{2}}-4 \cdot \frac{x_{i}}{x_{j}}-4 \cdot \frac{x_{j}}{x_{i}}+6\right)= \\
& =\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x_{i}^{2}}\right)-4\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x_{i}}\right)+3 n^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus we could find from the inequality

$$
\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(\frac{x_{i}}{x_{j}}+\frac{x_{j}}{x_{i}}-2\right)^{2} \geq 0
$$

that

$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x_{i}^{2}}\right) \geq n^{2}+4
$$

Unfortunately, this is not enough. So, let us try to minimize

$$
\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(\frac{x_{i}}{x_{j}}+\frac{x_{j}}{x_{i}}-2\right)^{2}
$$

This could be done using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality:

$$
\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(\frac{x_{i}}{x_{j}}+\frac{x_{j}}{x_{i}}-2\right)^{2} \geq \frac{\left(\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(\frac{x_{i}}{x_{j}}+\frac{x_{j}}{x_{i}}-2\right)\right)^{2}}{\binom{n}{2}}
$$

Because $\sum_{i \leq i<j \leq n}\left(\frac{x_{i}}{x_{j}}+\frac{x_{j}}{x_{i}}-2\right)=1$, we deduce that

$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x^{2}}\right) \geq n^{2}+4+\frac{2}{n(n-1)}
$$

which is what we wanted to prove. Of course, we should prove that we cannot have equality. But equality would imply that $x_{1}=x_{2}=\cdots=x_{n}$, which contradicts the assumption

$$
\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k}\right)\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x_{k}}\right)=n^{2}+1
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a + b + c = 3$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
2(a^2b^2 + b^2c^2 + c^2a^2) + C \leq 3(a^2 + b^2 + c^2)
$$

Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be the angles of a triangle. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$:
$$
\cos \alpha+\sqrt{2}(\cos \beta+\cos \gamma) \leq C
$$
solution:
Since $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos \alpha+\sqrt{2}(\cos \beta+\cos \gamma) & =\cos \alpha+2 \sqrt{2} \cos \frac{\beta+\gamma}{2} \cos \frac{\beta-\gamma}{2} \\
& =\cos \alpha+2 \sqrt{2} \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\beta-\gamma}{2} \\
& \leq \cos \alpha+2 \sqrt{2} \sin \frac{\alpha}{2}=2-2\left(\sin \frac{\alpha}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)^{2} \leq 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality holds if and only if $\alpha=\pi / 2, \beta=\gamma$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers such that $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1-a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{1-a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{1-a b}{7-3 a c} \geq C
$$
solution:
First we'll show that
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{7-3 a b}+\frac{1}{7-3 b c}+\frac{1}{7-3 c a} \leq \frac{1}{2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

By $A M \geq H M$ we have
$$
\frac{1}{7-3 a b}=\frac{1}{3(1-a b)+2+2} \leq \frac{1}{9}\left(\frac{1}{3(1-a b)}+1\right)
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\frac{1}{7-3 b c} \leq \frac{1}{9}\left(\frac{1}{3(1-b c)}+1\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{7-3 c a} \leq \frac{1}{9}\left(\frac{1}{3(1-c a)}+1\right)
$$

So it follows that
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{7-3 a b}+\frac{1}{7-3 b c}+\frac{1}{7-3 c a} \leq \frac{1}{27}\left(\frac{1}{1-a b}+\frac{1}{1-b c}+\frac{1}{1-c a}\right)+\frac{1}{3} \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Recalling the well-known Vasile Cirtoaje's inequality
$$
\frac{1}{1-a b}+\frac{1}{1-b c}+\frac{1}{1-c a} \leq \frac{9}{2}
$$
by (2) we obtain
$$
\frac{1}{7-3 a b}+\frac{1}{7-3 b c}+\frac{1}{7-3 c a} \leq \frac{1}{2}
$$

Since $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1$ we have $a, b, c \leq 1$ and then clearly
$$
7-3 a b, 7-3 a b, 7-3 a b>0
$$
so by $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{7-3 a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{7-3 a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{7-3 a b}{7-3 a c} \geq 3 \tag{3}
\end{equation*}
$$

Finally by (2) and (3) we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{3-3 a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{3-3 a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{3-3 a b}{7-3 a c} \\
& \quad=\left(\frac{7-3 a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{7-3 a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{7-3 a b}{7-3 a c}\right)-4\left(\frac{1}{7-3 a b}+\frac{1}{7-3 b c}+\frac{1}{7-3 c a}\right) \\
& \quad \geq 3-2=1
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{1-a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{1-a b}{7-3 a c}+\frac{1-a b}{7-3 a c} \geq \frac{1}{3}
$$
as required.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
For a given $n > 2$, find the minimal value of the constant $C$, such that if $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n > 0$ have product 1, then
$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+C x_1}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+C x_2}} + \cdots + \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+C x_n}} \leq n-1.
$$
solution:
We will prove that $k_{n}=\frac{2 n-1}{(n-1)^{2}}$. Taking $x_{1}=x_{2}=\cdots=x_{n}=1$, we find that $k_{n} \geq \frac{2 n-1}{(n-1)^{2}}$. So, it remains to show that

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{2 n-1}{(n-1)^{2}} x_{k}}} \leq n-1
$$

if $x_{1} \cdot x_{2} \cdots x_{n}=1$. Suppose this inequality doesn't hold for a certain system of $n$ numbers with product $1, x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}>0$. Thus, we can find a number $M>n-1$ and some numbers $a_{i}>0$ which add up to 1 , such that

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{2 n-1}{(n-1)^{2}} x_{k}}}=M a_{k}
$$

Thus, $a_{k}<\frac{1}{n-1}$ and we have

$$
1=\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left[\frac{(n-1)^{2}}{2 n-1}\left(\frac{1}{M^{2} a_{k}^{2}}-1\right)\right] \Rightarrow\left(\frac{2 n-1}{(n-1)^{2}}\right)^{n}<\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{(n-1)^{2} a_{k}^{2}}-1\right)
$$

Now, denote $1-(n-1) a_{k}=b_{k}>0$ and observe that $\sum_{k=1}^{n} b_{k}=1$. Also, the above inequality becomes

$$
(n-1)^{2 n} \prod_{k=1}^{n} b_{k} \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(2-b_{k}\right)>(2 n-1)^{n}\left(\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(1-b_{k}\right)\right)^{2}
$$

Because from the AM-GM Inequality we have

$$
\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(2-b_{k}\right) \leq\left(\frac{2 n-1}{n}\right)^{n}
$$

our assumption leads to

$$
\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(1-b_{k}\right)^{2}<\frac{(n-1)^{2 n}}{n^{n}} b_{1} b_{2} \ldots b_{n}
$$

So, it is enough to prove that for any positive numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ the inequality $\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{k-1}+a_{k+1}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{(n-1)^{2 n}}{n^{n}} a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{n}$ holds.

This strong inequality will be proved by induction. For $n=3$, it follows from the fact that

$$
\frac{\left(\prod(a+b)\right)^{2}}{a b c} \geq \frac{\left(\frac{8}{9} \cdot\left(\sum a\right) \cdot\left(\sum a b\right)\right)^{2}}{a b c} \geq \frac{64}{27}\left(\sum a\right)^{3}
$$

Suppose the inequality is true for all systems of $n$ numbers. Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n+1}$ be positive real numbers. Because the inequality is symmetric and homogeneous, we may assume that $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n+1}$ and also that $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=1$. Applying the inductive hypothesis we get the inequality

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1-a_{i}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{(n-1)^{2 n}}{n^{n}} a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}
$$

To prove the inductive step, we must prove that

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{n+1}+1-a_{i}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{n^{2 n+2}}{(n+1)^{n+1}} a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n} a_{n+1}\left(1+a_{n+1}\right)^{n+1}
$$

Thus, it is enough to prove the stronger inequality

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+\frac{a_{n+1}}{1-a_{i}}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{n^{3 n+2}}{(n-1)^{2 n} \cdot(n+1)^{n+1}} a_{n+1}\left(1+a_{n+1}\right)^{n+1}
$$

Now, using Huygens Inequality and the AM-GM Inequality, we find that

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+\frac{a_{n+1}}{1-a_{i}}\right)^{2} \geq\left(1+\frac{a_{n+1}}{\sqrt[n]{\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1-a_{i}\right)}}\right)^{2 n} \geq\left(1+\frac{n a_{n+1}}{n-1}\right)^{2 n}
$$

and so we are left with the inequality

$$
\left(1+\frac{n a_{n+1}}{n-1}\right)^{2 n} \geq \frac{n^{3 n+2}}{(n-1)^{2 n} \cdot(n+1)^{n+1}} a_{n+1}\left(1+a_{n+1}\right)^{n+1}
$$

if $a_{n+1} \geq \max \left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right\} \geq \frac{1}{n}$. So, we can put $\frac{n\left(1+a_{n+1}\right)}{n+1}=1+x$, where $x$ is nonnegative. So, the inequality becomes

$$
\left(1+\frac{x}{n(x+1)}\right)^{2 n} \geq \frac{1+(n+1) x}{(x+1)^{n-1}}
$$

Using Bernoulli Inequality, we find immediately that

$$
\left(1+\frac{x}{n(x+1)}\right)^{2 n} \geq \frac{3 x+1}{x+1}
$$

Also, $(1+x)^{n-1} \geq 1+(n-1) x$ and so it is enough to prove that

$$
\frac{3 x+1}{x+1} \geq \frac{1+(n+1) x}{1+(n-1) x}
$$

which is trivial.
So, we have reached a contradiction assuming the inequality doesn't hold for a certain system of $n$ numbers with product 1 , which shows that in fact the inequality is true for $k_{n}=\frac{2 n-1}{(n-1)^{2}}$ and that this is the value asked by the problem.

Theorem 13.Theorem:
If $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ are positive real numbers with $p_{1}+p_{2}+\ldots+p_{n}=1$, then

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p_{i}} \geq \prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p_{i}}+\prod_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p_{i}}
$$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b} \geq C
$$

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a b+b c+c a}+\frac{8 a b c}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)} \geq C
$$
solution:
Observe that
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-(a b+b c+c a)=\frac{1}{2}\left((a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}\right)
$$
and
$$
(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)-8 a b c=a(b-c)^{2}+b(c-a)^{2}+c(a-b)^{2}
$$

Inequality becomes
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a b+b c+c a}-1 \geq 1-\frac{8 a b c}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-(a b+b c+c a)}{a b+b c+c a} \geq \frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)-8 a b c}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{(a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}}{a b+b c+c a} \geq \frac{2 a(b-c)^{2}+2 b(c-a)^{2}+2 c(a-b)^{2}}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad(b-c)^{2}\left(\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{a b+b c+c a}-2 a\right) \\
& +(c-a)^{2}\left(\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{a b+b c+c a}-2 b\right) \\
& +(a-b)^{2}\left(\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{a b+b c+c a}-2 c\right) \geq 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let
$$
S_{a}=\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{a b+b c+c a}-2 a=b+c-a-\frac{a b c}{a b+b c+c a}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& S_{b}=\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{a b+b c+c a}-2 b=a+c-b-\frac{a b c}{a b+b c+c a} \\
& S_{c}=\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{a b+b c+c a}-2 c=a+b-c-\frac{a b c}{a b+b c+c a}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since inequality is symmetric, we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$.
Then clearly
$$
S_{b}, S_{c} \geq 0, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0
$$

According to $2^{\circ}$ , it suffices to show that $S_{b}+S_{a} \geq 0$.
We have
$$
S_{b}+S_{a}=2 c-2 \frac{a b c}{a b+b c+c a}=\frac{2 c^{2}(a+b)}{a b+b c+c a} \geq 0
$$
as required.

Theorem 78.Theorem:
Consider the expression $S=S_{a}(b-c)^{2}+$ $S_{b}(a-c)^{2}+S_{c}(a-b)^{2}$, where $S_{a}, S_{b}, S_{c}$ are functions of $a, b, c$.
$1^{\circ}$ If $S_{a}, S_{b}, S_{c} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$2^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$ and $S_{b}, S_{b}+S_{a}, S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$3^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$ and $S_{a}, S_{c}, S_{a}+2 S_{b}, S_{c}+2 S_{b} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$4^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ and $S_{b}, S_{c}, a^{2} S_{b}+b^{2} S_{a} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$5^{\circ}$ If $S_{a}+S_{b} \geq 0$ or $S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0$ or $S_{c}+S_{a} \geq 0\left(S_{a}+S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0\right)$ and $S_{a} S_{b}+S_{b} S_{c}+S_{c} S_{a} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = xyz$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
x + y + z \geq C
$$
solution:
Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
x y z=x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(x y z)^{2}}, \text { i.e. }(x y z)^{3} \geq 27(x y z)^{2}
$$
which implies
$$
x y z \geq 27
$$
By $A M \geq G M$ and $x y z \geq 27$ we get $x+y+z \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{x y z} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{27}=9$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \geq 0$ such that $a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4} \leq 2\left(a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}\right)$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \leq C(a b+b c+c a)
$$
solution:
The condition

$$
\sum a^{4} \leq 2 \sum a^{2} b^{2}
$$

is equivalent to

$$
(a+b+c)(a+b-c)(b+c-a)(c+a-b) \geq 0
$$

In any of the cases $a=b+c, b=c+a, c=a+b$, the inequality

$$
\sum a^{2} \leq 2 \sum a b
$$

is clear. So, suppose $a+b \neq c, b+c \neq a, c+a \neq b$. Because at most one of the numbers $b+c-a, c+a-b, a+b-c$ is negative and their product is nonnegative, all of them are positive. Thus, we may assume that

$$
a^{2}<a b+a c, b^{2}<b c+b a, c^{2}<c a+c b
$$

and the conclusion follows.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a^{2}+1}{b+c}+\frac{b^{2}+1}{c+a}+\frac{c^{2}+1}{a+b} \geq C
$$
solution:
For each $x \in \mathbb{R}$ we have $x^{2}+1 \geq 2 x$.
So we have
$$
\frac{a^{2}+1}{b+c}+\frac{b^{2}+1}{c+a}+\frac{c^{2}+1}{a+b} \geq \frac{2 a}{b+c}+\frac{2 b}{c+a}+\frac{2 c}{a+b}
$$

It's enough to prove that $\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b} \geq \frac{3}{2}$, which is Nesbitt's inequality.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 83.Theorem: Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Then $$\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}\geq\frac{3}{2}$$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Find the largest positive number $C$ such that the inequality below holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}-\sqrt{c}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c}-\sqrt{a}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}+\sqrt{a}-\sqrt{b}} \geq \frac{C}{a+b+c}(\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c})
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ and $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=3$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b+2 c}+\frac{b^{3}}{c+2 a}+\frac{c^{3}}{a+2 b} \geq C
$$
solution:
We'll prove that
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b+2 c}+\frac{b^{3}}{c+2 a}+\frac{c^{3}}{a+2 b} \geq \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}
$$
from which since $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=3$, we'll obtain the required result.
Applying $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\frac{9 a^{3}}{b+2 c}+a(b+2 c) \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{9 a^{3}}{b+2 c} \cdot a \cdot(b+2 c)}=6 a^{2}
$$

Analogously we deduce
$$
\frac{9 b^{3}}{c+2 a}+b(c+2 a) \geq 6 b^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{9 c^{3}}{a+2 b}+c(a+2 b) \geq 6 c^{2}
$$

Adding the last three inequalities we obtain
$$
9\left(\frac{a^{3}}{b+2 c}+\frac{b^{3}}{c+2 a}+\frac{c^{3}}{a+2 b}\right)+3(a b+b c+c a) \geq 6\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{a^{3}}{b+2 c}+\frac{b^{3}}{c+2 a}+\frac{c^{3}}{a+2 b} \geq \frac{6\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)-3(a b+b c+c a)}{9} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Using the well-known inequality
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq a b+b c+c a
$$
according to (1) we obtain
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b+2 c}+\frac{b^{3}}{c+2 a}+\frac{c^{3}}{a+2 b} \geq \frac{3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}{9}=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}=\frac{3}{3}=1
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c = 1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} + 2 \sqrt{3abc} \leq C
$$

Theorem 45.Theorem:
Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$. Then $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle if and only if
$$
\sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\beta}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\gamma}{2}+2 \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\gamma}{2}=1
$$

problem:
Let $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \geq 0$ such that $x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n = 1$ and $n > 2$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds:
$$
x_{1}^{2} x_{2} + x_{2}^{2} x_{3} + \cdots + x_{n-1}^{2} x_{n} + x_{n}^{2} x_{1} \leq C.
$$
solution:
First of all, it is clear that the maximum is at least $\frac{4}{27}$, because this value is attained for $x_{1}=\frac{1}{3}, x_{2}=\frac{2}{3}, x_{3}=\cdots=x_{n}=0$. Now, we will prove by induction that

$$
x_{1}^{2} x_{2}+x_{2}^{2} x_{3}+\cdots+x_{n-1}^{2} x_{n}+x_{n}^{2} x_{1} \leq \frac{4}{27}
$$

for all $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n-1}, x_{n} \geq 0$ which add up to 1 . Let us prove first the inductive step. Suppose the inequality is true for $n$ and we will prove it for $n+1$. We can of course assume that $x_{2}=\min \left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n+1}\right\}$. But this implies that

$$
x_{1}^{2} x_{2}+x_{2}^{2} x_{3}+\cdots+x_{n}^{2} x_{1} \leq\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2} x_{3}+x_{3}^{2} x_{4}+\cdots+x_{n-1}^{2} x_{n}+x_{n}^{2}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)
$$

But from the inductive hypothesis we have

$$
\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2} x_{3}+x_{3}^{2} x_{4}+\cdots+x_{n-1}^{2} x_{n}+x_{n}^{2}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right) \leq \frac{4}{27}
$$

and the inductive step is proved. Thus, it remains to prove that $a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a \leq \frac{4}{27}$ if $a+b+c=1$. We may of course assume that $a$ is the greatest among $a, b, c$. In this case the inequality $a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a \leq\left(a+\frac{c}{2}\right)^{2} \cdot\left(b+\frac{c}{2}\right)$ follows immediately from $a b c \geq b^{2} c, \frac{a^{2} c}{2} \geq \frac{a c^{2}}{2}$. Because

$$
1=\frac{a+\frac{c}{2}}{2}+\frac{a+\frac{c}{2}}{2}+b+\frac{c}{2} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{\left(b+\frac{c}{2}\right)\left(a+\frac{c}{2}\right)^{2}}{4}}
$$

we have proved that $a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a \leq \frac{4}{27}$ and this shows that the maximum is indeed $\frac{4}{27}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle, and let $s = \frac{a+b+c}{2}$ be the semiperimeter. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a^{3}(s-a)+b^{3}(s-b)+c^{3}(s-c) \leq Ca b c s.
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
a^{2}(a-b)(a-c)+b^{2}(b-c)(b-a)+c^{2}(c-a)(c-b) \geq 0
$$
which clearly holds by Schur's inequality.

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Find the maximal constant $C$ such that for any real number $x > 0$, the following inequality holds:
$$
x + \frac{1}{x} \geq C
$$
solution:
From the obvious inequality $(x-1)^{2} \geq 0$ we have
$$
x^{2}-2 x+1 \geq 0 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad x^{2}+1 \geq 2 x
$$
and since $x>0$ if we divide by $x$ we get the desired inequality. Equality occurs if and only if $x-1=0$, i.e. $x=1$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a}{b+2} + \frac{b}{c+2} + \frac{c}{a+2} \leq C
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
a b^{2}+b c^{2}+c a^{2} \leq 2+a b c
$$

We may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$ (since the inequality is cyclic we must also consider the case $c \geq b \geq a$, which is analogous).

Then we have $a(b-a)(b-c) \leq 0$ from which we have $a^{2} b+a b c \geq a b^{2}+c a^{2}$. Thus
$$
a b^{2}+b c^{2}+c a^{2} \leq a^{2} b+a b c+b c^{2}
$$

We'll show that
$$
a^{2} b+b c^{2} \leq 2
$$

We have
$$
a^{2} b+b c^{2} \leq 2 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad b\left(3-b^{2}\right) \leq 2 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(b-1)^{2}(b+2) \geq 0
$$
which is clearly true, and we are done.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$ or $a=0, b=1, c=\sqrt{2}$ (over all permutations).

Theorem 11.Theorem:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Given a function $f$ of $n$ variables, define the cyclic sum of variables $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{c y c} f\left(x_{1}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+f\left(x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}, x_{1}\right) \\
+\ldots+f\left(a_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n-1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $ab + bc + ca = 3$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a(b^2+c^2)}{a^2+bc} + \frac{b(c^2+a^2)}{b^2+ca} + \frac{c(a^2+b^2)}{c^2+ab} \geq C
$$
solution:
Let $x=a\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right), y=b\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right)$ and $z=c\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)$.
Then we have
$$
\frac{x}{y+z}(b+c)=\frac{a\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(b+c)}{b\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right)+c\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)}=\frac{a\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}{a^{2}+b c}
$$

Analogously we get
$$
\frac{y}{z+x}(c+a)=\frac{b\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right)}{b^{2}+c a} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{z}{x+y}(a+b)=\frac{c\left(a^{2}+a^{2}\right)}{c^{2}+a b}
$$

By Corollary 4.5 and the previous identities we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}{a^{2}+b c}+\frac{b\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right)}{b^{2}+c a}+\frac{c\left(a^{2}+a^{2}\right)}{c^{2}+a b} \\
& \quad=\frac{x}{y+z}(b+c)+\frac{y}{z+x}(c+a)+\frac{z}{x+y}(a+b) \geq \sqrt{3(a b+b c+c a)}=3
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 32.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c$ and $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers. Then
$$
\frac{x}{y+z}(b+c)+\frac{y}{z+x}(c+a)+\frac{z}{x+y}(a+b) \geq \sqrt{3(a b+b c+c a)}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$:
$$
\sqrt{a^{2}+(1-b)^{2}}+\sqrt{b^{2}+(1-c)^{2}}+\sqrt{c^{2}+(1-a)^{2}} \geq C
$$

Theorem 15.Theorem:
For any real number $r \geq 1$ and any positive real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$

$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+C a b c \geq a^{2} b+a^{2} c+b^{2} a+b^{2} c+c^{2} a+c^{2} b
$$
solution:
Since the given inequality is symmetric, without loss of generality we can assume that $a \geq b \geq c$.

After taking $x=\ln a, y=\ln b$ and $z=\ln c$ the given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{3 x}+e^{3 y}+e^{3 z}+e^{x+y+z}+e^{x+y+z}+e^{x+y+z} \\
& \quad \geq e^{2 x+y}+e^{2 x+z}+e^{2 y+x}+e^{2 y+z}+e^{2 z+x}+e^{2 z+y}
\end{aligned}
$$

The function $f(x)=e^{x}$ is convex on $\mathbb{R}$, so by Karamata's inequality it suffices to prove that the sequence $a=(3 x, 3 y, 3 z, x+y+z, x+y+z, x+y+z)$ majorizes the sequence $b=(2 x+y, 2 x+z, 2 y+x, 2 y+z, 2 z+x, 2 z+y)$.

Since $a \geq b \geq c$ it follows that $x \geq y \geq z$ and clearly $3 x \geq x+y+z \geq 3 z$.
If $x+y+z \geq 3 y$ (the case when $3 y \geq x+y+z$ is analogous) then we obtain the following inequalities
$$
\begin{aligned}
3 x & \geq x+y+z \geq 3 y \geq 3 z \\
2 x+y & \geq 2 x+z \geq 2 y+x \geq 2 z+x \geq 2 y+z \geq 2 z+y
\end{aligned}
$$
which means that $a \succ b$, and we are done.

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the side lengths, and $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be the respective angles (in radians) of a given triangle. Find the maximal $C_1$ and minimal $C_2$ such that the following inequality holds for all triangles:
$$
C_1 \leq \frac{a \alpha+b \beta+c \gamma}{a+b+c} < C_2
$$
solution:
First let's prove the left inequality.
We can assume that $a \geq b \geq c$ and then clearly $\alpha \geq \beta \geq \gamma$.
So we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (a-b)(\alpha-\beta)+(b-c)(\beta-\gamma)+(c-a)(\gamma-\alpha) \geq 0 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 2(a \alpha+b \beta+c \gamma) \geq(b+c) \alpha+(c+a) \beta+(a+b) \gamma
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
3(a \alpha+b \beta+c \gamma) \geq(a+b+c)(\alpha+\beta+\gamma)
$$

Hence
$$
\frac{a \alpha+b \beta+c \gamma}{a+b+c} \geq \frac{\alpha+\beta+\gamma}{3}=\frac{\pi}{3}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c$.
Let's consider the right inequality.
Since $a, b$ and $c$ are side lengths of a triangle we have $a+b+c>2 a, a+b+c>$ $2 b$ and $a+b+c>2 c$.

If we multiply these inequalities by $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$, respectively, we obtain
$$
(a+b+c)(\alpha+\beta+\gamma)>2(a \alpha+b \beta+c \gamma)
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a \alpha+b \beta+c \gamma}{a+b+c}<\frac{\alpha+\beta+\gamma}{2}=\frac{\pi}{2}
$$

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $x > 0$ be a real number. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x > 0$:
$$
x + \frac{1}{x} \geq C
$$
solution:
Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
x+\frac{1}{x} \geq 2 \sqrt{x \cdot \frac{1}{x}}=2
$$
with equality iff $x=\frac{1}{x}$, i.e. $x=1$.
Thus $\min \left\{x+\frac{1}{x}\right\}=2$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c=1$. Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:

$$
\frac{b \sqrt{c}}{a(\sqrt{3 c}+\sqrt{a b})}+\frac{c \sqrt{a}}{b(\sqrt{3 a}+\sqrt{b c})}+\frac{a \sqrt{b}}{c(\sqrt{3 b}+\sqrt{c a})} \geq C.
$$
solution:
Rewrite the inequality in the form

$$
\sum \frac{\sqrt{\frac{b c}{a}}}{\sqrt{\frac{3 c a}{b}}+a} \geq \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{4}
$$

With the substitution $x=\sqrt{\frac{b c}{a}}, y=\sqrt{\frac{c a}{b}}, z=\sqrt{\frac{a b}{c}}$ the condition $a+b+c=1$ becomes $x y+y z+z x=1$ and the inequality turns into

$$
\sum \frac{x}{\sqrt{3} y+y z} \geq \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{4}
$$

But, by applying the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality we obtain

$$
\sum \frac{x^{2}}{\sqrt{3} x y+x y z} \geq \frac{\left(\sum x\right)^{2}}{\sqrt{3}+3 x y z} \geq \frac{3 \sum x y}{\sqrt{3}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}=\frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{4}
$$

where we used the inequalities

$$
\left(\sum x\right)^{2} \geq 3\left(\sum x y\right) \text { and } x y z \leq \frac{1}{3 \sqrt{3}}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \geq 0$ be real numbers such that $a + b + c + d = 4$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:
$$
\left(1 + a^2\right)\left(1 + b^2\right)\left(1 + c^2\right)\left(1 + d^2\right) \geq C(1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c)(1 + d).
$$
solution:
Let
$f(a, b, c, d)=\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+b^{2}\right)\left(1+c^{2}\right)\left(1+d^{2}\right)-(1+a)(1+b)(1+c)(1+d)$,
and assume that $a \leq b \leq c \leq d$ (symmetry).
We'll show that
$$
f(a, b, c, d) \geq f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right)
$$

Clearly
$$
\begin{equation*}
a+c \leq 2 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$
so it follows that
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(a, b, c, d)-f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right) \\
& \quad=\left(1+b^{2}\right)\left(1+d^{2}\right)\left(\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+c^{2}\right)-\left(1+\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{2}\right) \\
& \quad+(1+b)(1+d)\left(\left(1+\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}-(1+a)(1+c)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since
$$
\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+c^{2}\right)-\left(1+\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{2}=(a-c)^{2}\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{(a+c)^{2}+4 a c}{16}\right) \geq 0
$$
(this inequality follows by (1)) and by $A M \geq G M$ it follows that
$$
(1+a)(1+c) \leq\left(1+\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}
$$

So
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(a, b, c, d)-f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right) \geq 0, \quad \text { i.e. } \\
& f(a, b, c, d) \geq f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

According to the SMV theorem it suffices to show that
$$
f(t, t, t, d) \geq 0
$$
where $3 t+d=4$ i.e. $d=4-3 t$.

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(t, t, t, d) & =\left(1+t^{2}\right)^{3}\left(1+(4-3 t)^{2}\right)-(1+t)^{3}(5-3 t) \\
& =9 t^{8}-24 t^{7}+44 t^{6}-72 t^{5}+81 t^{4}-68 t^{3}-54 t^{2}-36 t+12 \\
& =(t-1)^{2}\left(9 t^{6}-6 t^{5}+23 t^{4}-20 t^{3}+18 t^{2}-12 t+12\right) \\
& =(t-1)^{2}\left(t^{4}(3 t-1)^{2}+2 t^{4}+5 t^{2}(2 t-1)^{2}+10 t^{2}+3(t-2)^{2}\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality holds if and only if $a=b=c=d=1$.

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

\sqrt[4]{5 a^2 + 4(b + c) + 3} + \sqrt[4]{5 b^2 + 4(c + a) + 3} + \sqrt[4]{5 c^2 + 4(a + b) + 3} \leq C

Theorem 35.Theorem:

problem:
Let $a, b, c \geq 0$ such that $a + b + c = 3$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\left(a^{2}-a b+b^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}-b c+c^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}-c a+a^{2}\right) \leq C
$$
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c \geq 0$.
So it follows that
$$
0 \leq b^{2}-b c+c^{2} \leq b^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad 0 \leq c^{2}-c a+a^{2} \leq a^{2}
$$
i.e. we obtain
$$
\left(b^{2}-b c+c^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}-c a+a^{2}\right) \leq a^{2} b^{2}
$$

Now we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(a^{2}\right. & \left.-a b+b^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}-b c+c^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}-c a+a^{2}\right) \\
& \leq a^{2} b^{2}\left(a^{2}-a b+b^{2}\right) \\
& =\frac{4}{9} \cdot \frac{3 a b}{2} \cdot \frac{3 a b}{2} \cdot\left(a^{2}-a b+b^{2}\right) \leq \frac{4}{9} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{3 a b}{2}+\frac{3 a b}{2}+\left(a^{2}-a b+b^{2}\right)\right)\right)^{3} \\
& =\frac{4}{9}\left(\frac{(a+b)^{2}}{3}\right)^{3} \leq \frac{4}{9}\left(\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{3}\right)^{3}=\frac{4}{9}\left(\frac{3^{2}}{3}\right)^{3}=12
\end{aligned}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the smallest positive number $C$ such that the inequality below holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a b}{a+b+2 c}+\frac{b c}{b+c+2 a}+\frac{c a}{c+a+2 b} \leq C(a+b+c)
$$
solution:
Since $A M \geq H M$ we have
$$
\frac{a b}{a+b+2 c}=\frac{a b}{(a+c)+(b+c)} \leq \frac{a b}{4}\left(\frac{1}{a+c}+\frac{1}{b+c}\right)
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\frac{b c}{b+c+2 a} \leq \frac{b c}{4}\left(\frac{1}{a+b}+\frac{1}{a+c}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c a}{c+a+2 b} \leq \frac{c a}{4}\left(\frac{1}{a+b}+\frac{1}{b+c}\right)
$$

By adding these three inequalities we obtain the required inequality.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c \geq abc$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that at least two of the following inequalities hold for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{2}{a}+\frac{3}{b}+\frac{6}{c} \geq C, \quad \frac{2}{b}+\frac{3}{c}+\frac{6}{a} \geq C, \quad \frac{2}{c}+\frac{3}{a}+\frac{6}{b} \geq C
$$
solution:
Set $\frac{1}{a}=x, \frac{1}{b}=y, \frac{1}{c}=z$.
Then $x, y, z>0$ and the initial condition becomes $x y+y z+z x \geq 1$.
We need to prove that at least two of the following inequalities $2 x+3 y+6 z \geq$ $6,2 y+3 z+6 x \geq 6,2 z+3 x+6 y \geq 6$, hold.

Assume the contrary, i.e. we may assume that $2 x+3 y+6 z<6$ and $2 z+3 x+$ $6 y<6$.

Adding these inequalities we get $5 x+9 y+8 z<12$.
But we have $x \geq \frac{1-y z}{y+z}$.
Thus, $12>\frac{5-5 y z}{y+z}+9 y+8 z$, i.e.
$$
12(y+z)>5+9 y^{2}+8 z^{2}+12 y z \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(2 z-1)^{2}+(3 y+2 z-2)^{2}<0
$$
which is impossible, and the conclusion follows.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a}{b^2 + 1} + \frac{b}{c^2 + 1} + \frac{c}{a^2 + 1} \geq C (a \sqrt{a} + b \sqrt{b} + c \sqrt{c})^2
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequalities hold simultaneously for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a b^{2}}{a+b}+\frac{b c^{2}}{b+c}+\frac{c a^{2}}{c+a} \leq C (a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2})
$$
solution:
Since $A M \geq H M$ and from the well-known inequality
$$
a b+b c+c a \leq a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}
$$
we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a b^{2}}{a+b}+\frac{b c^{2}}{b+c}+\frac{c a^{2}}{c+a} & =\frac{1}{1 / b^{2}+1 / a b}+\frac{1}{1 / c^{2}+1 / b c}+\frac{1}{1 / a^{2}+1 / c a} \\
& \leq \frac{b^{2}+a b}{4}+\frac{c^{2}+b c}{4}+\frac{a^{2}+c a}{4} \\
& =\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a}{4} \\
& \leq \frac{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}{4}=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

It remains to show the left inequality.
Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\frac{a b^{2}}{a+b}+\frac{b c^{2}}{b+c}+\frac{c a^{2}}{c+a} \geq \frac{3 a b c}{\sqrt[3]{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}}
$$

Therefore it suffices to show that
$$
\frac{3 a b c}{\sqrt[3]{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}} \geq \frac{9 a b c}{2(a+b+c)}
$$
i.e.
$$
2(a+b+c) \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}
$$
which is true, since
$$
2(a+b+c)=(a+b)+(b+c)+(c+a) \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}
$$

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 9$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
2(a+b+c) - abc \leq C.
$$
solution:
Let $a+b+c=p, a b+b c+c a=\frac{1-q^{2}}{3}, a b c=r$.
Then using identity $1^{\circ}$, the condition can be rewritten as
$$
9=a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=\frac{p^{2}+2 q^{2}}{3}
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
p^{2}+2 q^{2}=27 
\end{equation*}
$$

We deduce
$$
\begin{aligned}
2(a+b+c)-a b c=2 p-r & \leq 2 p-\frac{(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{27} \\
& =\frac{54 p-p^{3}+3 p q^{2}+2 q^{3}}{27}
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{54 p-p\left(p^{2}+2 q^{2}\right)+5 p q^{2}+2 q^{3}}{27} \\
& \stackrel{(15.1)}{=} \frac{54 p-27 p+5 p q^{2}+2 q^{3}}{27} \\
& =\frac{27 p+5 p q^{2}+2 q^{3}}{27}=\frac{p\left(27+5 q^{2}\right)+2 q^{3}}{27} .
\end{aligned}
$$

So it remains to prove that
$$
\frac{p\left(27+5 q^{2}\right)+2 q^{3}}{27} \leq 10 \quad \text { or } \quad p\left(27+5 q^{2}\right) \leq 270-2 q^{3}
$$

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(270-2 q^{3}\right)^{2} \geq\left(p\left(27+5 q^{2}\right)\right)^{2} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 27(q-3)^{2}\left(2 q^{4}+12 q^{3}+49 q^{2}+146 q+219\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.
Equality occurs if and only if $(a, b, c)=(2,2,-1)$ (up to permutation).

Theorem 74.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a+b+$ $c=p$.
Let $a b+b c+c a=\frac{p^{2}-q^{2}}{3},(q \geq 0)$ and $a b c=r$.
Then
$$
\frac{(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{27} \leq r \leq \frac{(p-q)^{2}(p+2 q)}{27}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$.

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be different positive integers. Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a_{1}}{1^{2}}+\frac{a_{2}}{2^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{n^{2}} \geq C(1 + \frac{1}{2} + \cdots + \frac{1}{n}).
$$
solution:
Let $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a permutation of $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ such that $x_{1} \leq$ $x_{2} \leq \cdots \leq x_{n}$.

Then clearly $x_{i} \geq i$ for each $i=1,2, \ldots, n$ and $\frac{1}{1^{2}} \geq \frac{1}{2^{2}} \geq \cdots \geq \frac{1}{n^{2}}$.
By the rearrangement inequality and the previous conclusion we obtain
$$
\frac{a_{1}}{1^{2}}+\frac{a_{2}}{2^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{n^{2}} \geq \frac{x_{1}}{1^{2}}+\frac{x_{2}}{2^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{x_{n}}{n^{2}} \geq 1+\frac{2}{2^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{n}{n^{2}}=1+\frac{1}{2}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n}
$$

Theorem 37.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers and let $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a permutation of $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$. Then
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \geq a_{1} x_{1}+a_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} x_{n}
$$

problem:
Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $x + y + z = 3$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{z} \geq C (x y+y z+z x).
$$
solution:
We have
$$
3(x+y+z)=(x+y+z)^{2}=x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+2(x y+y z+z x)
$$

Hence it follows that
$$
x y+y z+z x=\frac{1}{2}\left(3 x-x^{2}+3 y-y^{2}+3 z-z^{2}\right)
$$

Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
\sqrt{x} & +\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{z}-(x y+y z+z x) \\
= & \sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{z}+\frac{1}{2}\left(x^{2}-3 x+y^{2}-3 y+z^{2}-3 z\right) \\
= & \frac{1}{2}\left(\left(x^{2}-3 x+2 \sqrt{x}\right)+\left(y^{2}-3 y+2 \sqrt{y}\right)+\left(z^{2}-3 z+2 \sqrt{z}\right)\right) \\
= & \frac{1}{2}\left(\sqrt{x}(\sqrt{x}-1)^{2}(\sqrt{x}+2)+\sqrt{y}(\sqrt{y}-1)^{2}(\sqrt{y}+2)\right. \\
& \left.+\sqrt{z}(\sqrt{z}-1)^{2}(\sqrt{z}+2)\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{z} \geq x y+y z+z x
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a+b+c-2 a b c \leq C
$$
solution:
Since $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1$ and $a^{2} \geq 0$ it follows that $b^{2}+c^{2} \leq 1$, i.e. $2 b c \leq 1$.
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
a+b+c-2 a b c & =a(1-2 b c)+(b+c) \cdot 1 \leq \sqrt{a^{2}+(b+c)^{2}} \sqrt{(1-2 b c)^{2}+1} \\
& =\sqrt{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 b c\right)\left(2-4 b c+4 b^{2} c^{2}\right)} \\
& =\sqrt{(1+2 b c)\left(2-4 b c+4 b^{2} c^{2}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

So it suffices to show that
$$
(1+2 b c)\left(2-4 b c+4 b^{2} c^{2}\right) \leq 2
$$

We have
$$
2-(1+2 b c)\left(2-4 b c+4 b^{2} c^{2}\right)=4 b^{2} c^{2}(1-2 b c) \geq 0
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + abc = 4$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a + b + c \geq C.
$$
solution:
Let
$$
f(a, b, c)=a+b+c, g(a, b, c)=a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b c-4
$$
and
$$
L=f-\lambda g=a+b+c-\lambda\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b c-4\right) .
$$

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial a}=1-\lambda a-\lambda b c=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{1}{2 a+b c} \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial b}=1-\lambda b-\lambda a c=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{1}{2 b+a c} \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial c}=1-\lambda c-\lambda a b=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{1}{2 c+a b}
\end{aligned}
$$

So
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{2 a+b c}=\frac{1}{2 b+a c} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-b)(2-c)=0 
\end{equation*}
$$

In the same way we obtain
$$
\begin{equation*}
(b-c)(2-a)=0 
\end{equation*}
$$
and
$$
\begin{equation*}
(c-a)(2-b)=0 
\end{equation*}
$$

If $a=b=2$ then since $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b c=4$ we get $c=-2$, and therefore $a+b+c=2$.

If $a=b=c \neq 2$ then from the given condition we deduce that
$$
3 a^{2}+a^{3}=4 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-1)(a+2)^{2}=0
$$
and therefore $a=b=c=1$ or $a=b=c=-2$, i.e. $a+b+c=3$ or $a+b+c=-6$.
Thus $\min \{a+b+c\}=-6$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a+b}{b+c}+\frac{b+c}{c+a}+\frac{c+a}{a+b}+3 \frac{a b+b c+c a}{(a+b+c)^{2}} \geq C
$$
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $c=\min \{a, b, c\}$.
Now we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a+b}{b+c}+\frac{b+c}{c+a}+\frac{c+a}{a+b}-3= & \frac{1}{(a+c)(b+c)}(a-b)^{2} \\
& +\frac{1}{(a+b)(b+c)}(a-c)(b-c)
\end{aligned}
$$
and
$$
3\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(a+b+c)^{2}}-1=-\frac{1}{(a+b+c)^{2}}(a-b)^{2}-\frac{1}{(a+b+c)^{2}}(a-c)(b-c)
$$

The given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{equation*}
M(a-b)^{2}+N(a-c)(b-c) \geq 0 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$
where $M=\frac{1}{(a+c)(b+c)}-\frac{1}{(a+b+c)^{2}}$ and $N=\frac{1}{(a+b)(b+c)}-\frac{1}{(a+b+c)^{2}}$.
We can easily prove that $M, N \geq 0$, and since $c=\min \{a, b, c\}$ we get inequality (1).

problem:
Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n} \in (0, \pi)$. Find the minimum constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$:
$$
\sin x_{1} \cos x_{2}+\sin x_{2} \cos x_{3}+\cdots+\sin x_{n} \cos x_{1} \leq C.
$$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $x, y, z \geq 0$ be real numbers such that $x + y + z = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
C\left(x^{2} y^{2} + y^{2} z^{2} + z^{2} x^{2}\right)\left(x^{3} + y^{3} + z^{3}\right) \leq x y + y z + z x
$$
solution:
Let $p=x+y+z=1, q=x y+y z+z x, r=x y z$.
By $I_{2}$ and $I_{3}$ we have
$$
x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}=p\left(p^{2}-3 q\right)+3 r=1-3 q+3 r
$$
and
$$
x^{2} y^{2}+y^{2} z^{2}+z^{2} x^{2}=q^{2}-2 p r=q^{2}-2 r
$$

Clearly $q \leq \frac{1}{3}$.
So the given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{equation*}
12(1-3 q+3 r)\left(q^{2}-2 r\right) \leq q \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Suppose that $q \geq \frac{1}{4}$.
By $N_{3}: p q-9 r \geq 0$ it follows that $r \leq \frac{q}{9}$, i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
0 \leq r \leq \frac{q}{9} \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since $q \leq \frac{1}{3}$ we have
$$
\begin{equation*}
(1-3 q+3 r) r \geq 0 \tag{3}
\end{equation*}
$$

We'll prove that
$$
\begin{equation*}
12\left(1-3 q+3 \frac{q}{9}\right) q^{2} \leq q \tag{4}
\end{equation*}
$$
from which, together with (2) and (3), we'll have
$$
12(1-3 q+3 r)\left(q^{2}-2 r\right) \leq 12(1-3 q+3 r) q^{2} \leq 12\left(1-3 q+3 \frac{q}{9}\right) q^{2} \leq q
$$

Hence
$$
\begin{align*}
q & \geq 12\left(1-3 q+3 \frac{q}{9}\right) q^{2} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad 1 \geq 12\left(1-3 q+\frac{q}{3}\right) q \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad 1 \geq 12 q-32 q^{2} 
\end{align*}
$$

Let $f(q)=12 q-32 q^{2}$. Then $f^{\prime}(q)=12-64 q$.

Since $q \geq \frac{1}{4}$ we deduce that $f^{\prime}(q)=12-64 q \leq 12-\frac{64}{4}=-4<0$, so it follows that $f$ decreases on the interval $[1 / 4,1 / 3]$, i.e. we have
$$
f(q) \leq f\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)=12 \frac{1}{4}-32 \frac{1}{16}=3-2=1
$$
and inequality (2) follows.
Now let us suppose that $0 \leq q \leq \frac{1}{4}$.
Let's rewrite inequality as follows
$$
\begin{equation*}
q \geq 12 q^{2}(1-3 q)+12 r\left(3 q^{2}+6 q-2\right)-72 r^{2} 
\end{equation*}
$$

Since
$$
12 q(1-3 q)=4 \cdot 3 q(1-3 q) \leq 4\left(\frac{3 q+(1-3 q)}{2}\right)^{2}=1
$$
it follows that
$$
\begin{equation*}
12 q^{2}(1-3 q) \leq q \tag{5}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since $0 \leq q \leq \frac{1}{4}$ we get
$$
\begin{equation*}
3 q^{2}+6 q-2 \leq 3 \frac{1}{16}+6 \frac{1}{4}-2<0 \tag{6}
\end{equation*}
$$

By (5) and (6) we obtain
$$
12 q^{2}(1-3 q)+12 r\left(3 q^{2}+6 q-2\right)-72 r^{2} \leq 12 q^{2}(1-3 q) \leq q
$$
as required.

Theorem 72.Theorem:
Let $x, y, z \geq 0$, and $p=x+y+z, q=x y+y z+z x, r=x y z$.
Then we have the following inequalities:
$$
\begin{array}{ll}
N_{3}: p q-9 r \geq 0, & N_{9}: p^{4}+3 q^{2} \geq 4 p^{2} q \\
N_{4}: p^{2} \geq 3 q, & N_{10}: 2 p^{3}+9 r^{2} \geq 7 p q r \\
N_{5}: p^{3} \geq 27 r, & N_{11}: p^{2} q+3 p r \geq 4 q^{2} \\
N_{6}: q^{3} \geq 27 r^{2}, & N_{12}: q^{3}+9 r^{2} \geq 4 p q r \\
N_{7}: q^{2} \geq 3 p r, & N_{13}: p q^{2} \geq 2 p^{2} r+3 q r \\
N_{8}: 2 p^{3}+9 r \geq 7 p q, &
\end{array}
$$

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers such that $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=n$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that for every natural number $k$, the following inequality holds:
$$
a_{1}^{k}+a_{2}^{k}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k} \geq C(a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1}).
$$
solution:
Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
(k-1) a_{i}^{k}+1=\underbrace{a_{i}^{k}+a_{i}^{k}+\cdots+a_{i}^{k}}_{k-1}+1 \geq k \sqrt[k]{a_{i}^{k(k-1)}}=k a_{i}^{k-1}
$$
and if we add these inequalities for $i=1,2, \ldots, n$ we obtain
$$
\begin{equation*}
(k-1)\left(a_{1}^{k}+a_{2}^{k}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k}\right)+n \geq k\left(a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1}\right) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

We'll show that
$$
\begin{equation*}
a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1} \geq n \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

One more application of $A M \geq G M$ gives us
$$
a_{i}^{k-1}+(k-2)=a_{i}^{k-1}+\underbrace{1+\cdots+1}_{k-2} \geq(k-1) \sqrt[k-1]{a_{i}^{k-1}}=(k-1) a_{i}
$$
and adding the previous inequalities for $i=1,2, \ldots, n$ we get
$\left(a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1}\right)+n(k-2) \geq(k-1)\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)=n(k-1)$,
from which we deduce
$$
a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1} \geq n
$$

So we are done with (2).
Now from (1) and (2) we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (k-1)\left(a_{1}^{k}+a_{2}^{k}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k}\right)+n \geq k\left(a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1}\right) \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad(k-1)\left(a_{1}^{k}+a_{2}^{k}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k}\right)+n \\
& \geq(k-1)\left(a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1}\right)+\left(a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1}\right) \\
& \geq(k-1)\left(a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1}\right)+n \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad a_{1}^{k}+a_{2}^{k}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k} \geq a_{1}^{k-1}+a_{2}^{k-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{k-1},
\end{aligned}
$$
as desired.
Equality holds iff $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}=1$.
Remark The given inequality immediately follows by Chebishev's inequality.

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}, b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers between 1001 and 2002, inclusively, such that $a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}=b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a_{i}$ and $b_{i}$:

$$
\frac{a_{1}^{3}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{3}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{3}}{b_{n}} \leq C\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)
$$
solution:
The key ideas are that $\frac{a_{i}}{b_{i}} \in\left[\frac{1}{2}, 2\right]$ for any $i$ and that for all $x \in\left[\frac{1}{2}, 2\right]$ we have the inequality $x^{2}+1 \leq \frac{5}{2} x$. Consequently, we have

$$
\frac{5}{2} \cdot \frac{a_{i}}{b_{i}} \geq 1+\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{b_{i}^{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{5}{2} a_{i} b_{i} \geq a_{i}^{2}+b_{i}^{2}
$$

and also

$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{5}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}^{2}+b_{i}^{2}\right)=2 \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Now, the observation that $\frac{a_{i}^{2}}{b_{i}^{2}}=\frac{\frac{a_{i}^{3}}{b_{i}}}{a_{i} \cdot b_{i}}$ and the inequality $\frac{5}{2} \cdot \frac{a_{i}}{b_{i}} \geq 1+\frac{a_{i}^{2}}{b_{i}^{2}}$ allow us to write $\frac{5}{2} a_{i}^{2} \geq \frac{a_{i}^{3}}{b_{i}}+a_{i} b_{i}$ and adding up these inequalities yields

$$
\frac{5}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2} \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{a_{i}^{3}}{b_{i}}+a_{i} b_{i}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a_{i}^{3}}{b_{i}}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$

Using (1) and (2) we find that

$$
\frac{a_{1}^{3}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{3}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{3}}{b_{n}} \leq \frac{17}{10}\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)
$$

which is the desired inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $a b c + a + c = b$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{2}{a^{2}+1}-\frac{2}{b^{2}+1}+\frac{3}{c^{2}+1} \leq C.
$$
solution:
The given condition is equivalent to $b=\frac{a+c}{1-a c}$.
This suggest the substitutions:
$$
a=\tan \alpha, \quad b=\tan \beta, \quad c=\tan \gamma
$$
where $\tan \beta=\tan (\alpha+\gamma)$ and $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(-\pi / 2, \pi / 2)$, so we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & =\frac{2}{a^{2}+1}-\frac{2}{b^{2}+1}+\frac{3}{c^{2}+1}=\frac{2}{\tan ^{2} \alpha+1}-\frac{2}{\tan ^{2}(\alpha+\gamma)+1}+\frac{3}{\tan ^{2} \gamma+1} \\
& =2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-2 \cos ^{2}(\alpha+\gamma)+3 \cos ^{2} \gamma \\
& =\left(2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-1\right)-\left(2 \cos ^{2}(\alpha+\gamma)-1\right)+3 \cos ^{2} \gamma \\
& =\cos 2 \alpha-\cos (2 \alpha+2 \gamma)+3 \cos ^{2} \gamma \\
& =2 \sin (2 \alpha+\gamma) \sin \gamma+3 \cos ^{2} \gamma
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $x=|\sin \gamma|$. Then we have
$$
A \leq 2 x+3\left(1-x^{2}\right)=-3 x^{2}+2 x+3=-3\left(x-\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2}+\frac{10}{3} \leq \frac{10}{3}
$$

Equality holds if and only if $\sin (2 \alpha+\gamma)=1$ and $\sin \gamma=\frac{1}{3}$, from which we deduce $(a, b, c)=(\sqrt{2} / 2, \sqrt{2}, \sqrt{2} / 4)$.

problem:
Let $x, y$ be non-negative real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{+}_0$:
$$
C\left(x^{9}+y^{9}\right) \geq\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\left(x^{3}+y^{3}\right)\left(x^{4}+y^{4}\right)
$$

Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
x y(x+y-z)+y z(y+z-x)+z x(z+x-y) \geq C \sqrt{x^{3} y^{3}+y^{3} z^{3}+z^{3} x^{3}}
$$

Theorem 32.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c$ and $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers. Then
$$
\frac{x}{y+z}(b+c)+\frac{y}{z+x}(c+a)+\frac{z}{x+y}(a+b) \geq \sqrt{3(a b+b c+c a)}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a-b}{b+c}+\frac{b-c}{c+d}+\frac{c-d}{d+a}+\frac{d-a}{a+b} \geq C.
$$
solution:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a-b}{b+c} & +\frac{b-c}{c+d}+\frac{c-d}{d+a}+\frac{d-a}{a+b}=\frac{a+c}{b+c}+\frac{b+d}{c+d}+\frac{c+a}{d+a}+\frac{d+b}{a+b}-4= \\
& =(a+c)\left(\frac{1}{b+c}+\frac{1}{d+a}\right)+(b+d)\left(\frac{1}{c+d}+\frac{1}{a+b}\right)-4
\end{aligned}
$$

Since

$$
\frac{1}{b+c}+\frac{1}{d+a} \geq \frac{4}{(b+c)+(d+a)}, \frac{1}{c+d}+\frac{1}{a+b} \geq \frac{4}{(c+d)+(a+b)}
$$

we get

$$
\frac{a-b}{b+c}+\frac{b-c}{c+d}+\frac{c-d}{d+a}+\frac{d-a}{a+b} \geq \frac{4(a+c)}{(b+c)+(d+a)}+\frac{4(b+d)}{(c+d)+(a+b)}-4=0
$$

Equality holds for $a=c$ and $b=d$.
Conjecture (Vasile Crtoaje)
If $a, b, c, d, e$ are positive real numbers, then

$$
\frac{a-b}{b+c}+\frac{b-c}{c+d}+\frac{c-d}{d+e}+\frac{d-e}{e+a}+\frac{e-a}{a+b} \geq 0
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the side lengths, and $h_{a}, h_{b}, h_{c}$ be the altitudes, respectively, of a triangle. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all valid side lengths and corresponding altitudes of a triangle:
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{h_{b}^{2}+h_{c}^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{h_{a}^{2}+h_{c}^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{h_{a}^{2}+h_{b}^{2}} \geq C
$$
solution:
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a^{2}}{h_{b}^{2}+h_{c}^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{h_{a}^{2}+h_{c}^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{h_{a}^{2}+h_{b}^{2}} & =\frac{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}{4 P^{2}\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}+\frac{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}{4 P^{2}\left(a^{2}+c^{2}\right)}+\frac{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}{4 P^{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)} \\
& =\frac{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}{4 P^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{a^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Also
$$
a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}=16 P^{2} R^{2}
$$
and
$$
\frac{1}{b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{a^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}} \geq \frac{9}{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)} \quad(\text { since } A M \geq H M)
$$

Therefore
$\frac{a^{2}}{h_{b}^{2}+h_{c}^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{h_{a}^{2}+h_{c}^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{h_{a}^{2}+h_{b}^{2}} \geq \frac{16 P^{2} R^{2}}{4 P^{2}} \cdot \frac{9}{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}=\frac{18 R^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}} \geq 2$,
where the last inequality is true since $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \leq 9 R^{2}$.
Equality holds iff the triangle is equilateral.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
ab + bc + ca \leq abc + C
$$
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$.
Let $f(a, b, c)=a b+b c+c a-a b c$.
We have
$$
\begin{align*}
& f(a, b, c)-f\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}, \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}, c\right) \\
& \quad=a b+b c+c a-a b c-\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}-2 c \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}+c \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2} \\
& \quad=\left(a b-\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}\right)+c\left((a+b)-\sqrt{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)}\right)-c\left(a b-\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}\right) \\
& \quad=\frac{-(a-b)^{2}}{2}-\frac{c(a-b)^{2}}{(a+b)+\sqrt{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)}}+\frac{c(a-b)^{2}}{2} \\
& \quad=(a-b)^{2}\left(\frac{c}{2}-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{c}{(a+b)+\sqrt{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)}}\right) \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

Notice that since $a \geq b \geq c$ we must have $c^{2} \leq 1$, i.e. $c \leq 1$ and $a^{2}+b^{2} \geq 2$.
By $A M \leq Q M$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{c}{2}-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{c}{(a+b)+\sqrt{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)}} & \leq \frac{c}{2}-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{2 \cdot\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)}} \\
& \leq \frac{c}{2}-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{2 \cdot\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}}
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{c}{2}-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{6}} \leq \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{6}} \\
& \leq-\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{6}} \leq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence by (1) we get that
$$
f(a, b, c)-f\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}, \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}, c\right) \leq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
f(a, b, c) \leq f\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}, \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}, c\right)
$$

According to the SMV theorem we need to prove that $f(t, t, c) \leq 2$, when $2 t^{2}+$ $c^{2}=3$.

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(t, t, c) \leq 2 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad t^{2}+2 c t-t^{2} c \leq 2 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 2 t^{2}+4 c t \leq 2 t^{2} c+4 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 4 c t \leq 2 t^{2} c+3-2 t^{2}+1 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 4 c t \leq 2 t^{2} c+c^{2}+1
\end{aligned}
$$
which is true due to $A M \geq G M$, i.e.
$$
2 t^{2} c+c^{2}+1=t^{2} c+c^{2}+1+t^{2} c \geq 4 \sqrt[4]{t^{2} c \cdot c^{2} \cdot t^{2} c}=4 c t
$$

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
