problem:
Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
C\left(x^{2} y+y^{2} z+z^{2} x\right)\left(x y^{2}+y z^{2}+z x^{2}\right) \geq x y z(x+y+z)^{3}.
$$
solution:
Using the AM-GM Inequality, we find that
$\frac{1}{3}+\frac{y^{2} z}{y^{2} z+z^{2} x+x^{2} y}+\frac{x y^{2}}{y z^{2}+z x^{2}+x y^{2}} \geq \frac{3 y \sqrt[3]{x y z}}{\sqrt[3]{3 \cdot\left(y^{2} z+z^{2} x+x^{2} y\right) \cdot\left(y z^{2}+z x^{2}+x y^{2}\right)}}$
and two other similar relations
$\frac{1}{3}+\frac{z^{2} x}{y^{2} z+z^{2} x+x^{2} y}+\frac{y z^{2}}{y z^{2}+z x^{2}+x y^{2}} \geq \frac{3 z \sqrt[3]{x y z}}{\sqrt[3]{3 \cdot\left(y^{2} z+z^{2} x+x^{2} y\right) \cdot\left(y z^{2}+z x^{2}+x y^{2}\right)}}$
$\frac{1}{3}+\frac{x^{2} y}{y^{2} z+z^{2} x+x^{2} y}+\frac{z x^{2}}{y z^{2}+z x^{2}+x y^{2}} \geq \frac{3 x \sqrt[3]{x y z}}{\sqrt[3]{3 \cdot\left(y^{2} z+z^{2} x+x^{2} y\right) \cdot\left(y z^{2}+z x^{2}+x y^{2}\right)}}$
Then, adding up the three relations, we find exactly the desired inequality.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2 = 4$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:
$$
\frac{1}{5-a} + \frac{1}{5-b} + \frac{1}{5-c} + \frac{1}{5-d} \leq C.
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{1}{5-a}-\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{5-b}-\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{5-c}-\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{5-d}-\frac{1}{4} \leq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a-1}{5-a}+\frac{b-1}{5-b}+\frac{c-1}{5-c}+\frac{d-1}{5-d} \leq 0
$$

Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c \geq d$.
Then we have $a^{2}-1 \geq b^{2}-1 \geq c^{2}-1 \geq d^{2}-1$.
We'll show that $\frac{1}{4 a-a^{2}+5} \leq \frac{1}{4 b-b^{2}+5}$.
We have
$$
4 a-a^{2}+5 \geq 4 b-b^{2}+5 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad a+b \leq 4
$$
which is obviously true since $a^{2}+b^{2} \leq 4$.
So we have
$$
\frac{1}{4 a-a^{2}+5} \leq \frac{1}{4 b-b^{2}+5} \leq \frac{1}{4 c-c^{2}+5} \leq \frac{1}{4 d-d^{2}+5}
$$

Now by Chebishev's inequality we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3\left(\frac{a^{2}-1}{4 a-a^{2}+5}+\frac{b^{2}-1}{4 b-b^{2}+5}+\frac{a^{2}-1}{4 c-c^{2}+5}+\frac{a^{2}-1}{4 d-d^{2}+5}\right) \\
& \quad \leq \sum_{\mathrm{cyc}}\left(a^{2}-1\right) \sum_{\mathrm{cyc}}\left(\frac{1}{4 a-a^{2}+5}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus
$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & \geq \frac{a^{2}-1}{4 a-a^{2}+5}+\frac{b^{2}-1}{4 b-b^{2}+5}+\frac{a^{2}-1}{4 c-c^{2}+5}+\frac{a^{2}-1}{4 d-d^{2}+5} \\
& =\frac{a-1}{5-a}+\frac{b-1}{5-b}+\frac{c-1}{5-c}+\frac{d-1}{5-d}
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c=d=1$.

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 1$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{(a+1)^{2}(b+c)}+\frac{1}{(b+1)^{2}(c+a)}+\frac{1}{(c+1)^{2}(a+b)} \leq C.
$$
solution:
Let $a=x^{2}, b=y^{2}, c=z^{2}$. The given inequality becomes
$$
\frac{1}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)}+\frac{1}{\left(y^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(z^{2}+x^{2}\right)}+\frac{1}{\left(z^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)} \leq \frac{3}{8}
$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\sqrt{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)} \geq x y+z=\frac{1}{z}+z=\frac{z^{2}+1}{z}
$$
and
$$
\sqrt{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+y^{2}\right)} \geq x z+y=\frac{1}{y}+y=\frac{y^{2}+1}{y}
$$

Multiplying these two inequalities we get
$$
\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+y^{2}\right) \geq \frac{\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right)}{y z}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(z^{2}+y^{2}\right) \geq \frac{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right)}{y z}
$$

Hence
$$
\frac{1}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)} \leq \frac{y z}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right)}
$$

Similarly we obtain
$$
\frac{1}{\left(y^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(z^{2}+x^{2}\right)} \leq \frac{z x}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right)}
$$
and
$$
\frac{1}{\left(z^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)} \leq \frac{x y}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right)}
$$

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)}+\frac{1}{\left(y^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(z^{2}+x^{2}\right)}+\frac{1}{\left(z^{2}+1\right)^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)} \\
& \quad \leq \frac{x y+y z+z x}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$
and it suffices to prove that
$$
\frac{x y+y z+z x}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right)} \leq \frac{3}{8}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right) \geq \frac{8}{3}(x y+y z+z x)
$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sqrt{\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(1+y^{2}\right)} \geq x+y, \quad \sqrt{\left(z^{2}+1\right)\left(1+x^{2}\right)} \geq z+x \quad \text { and } \\
& \sqrt{\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(1+z^{2}\right)} \geq y+z
\end{aligned}
$$

Multiplying these three inequalities gives us
$$
\begin{equation*}
\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right) \geq(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

By the well-known inequality
$$
(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq \frac{8}{9}(x+y+z)(x y+y z+z x)
$$
and the $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
\begin{equation*}
(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq \frac{8}{9}(x+y+z)(x y+y z+z x) \geq \frac{8}{3}(x y+y z+z x) . \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

By (1) and (2) we obtain
$$
\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(y^{2}+1\right)\left(z^{2}+1\right) \geq(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq \frac{8}{3}(x y+y z+z x)
$$
as required.
Equality occurs iff $x=y=z=1$ i.e. $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle with circumradius $r = \frac{1}{2}$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a^{4}}{b+c-a}+\frac{b^{4}}{a+c-b}+\frac{c^{4}}{a+b-c} \geq C
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 81.Theorem: Let $a, b, c$ be the sides of a triangle. Then the area of the triangle is given by $A=\sqrt{s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)}$, where $s=\frac{a+b+c}{2}$ is the semiperimeter of the triangle.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $xyz = x + y + z + 2$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
xy + yz + zx \geq C(x + y + z).
$$
solution:
The initial condition $x y z=x+y+z+2$ can be rewritten as follows

$$
\frac{1}{1+x}+\frac{1}{1+y}+\frac{1}{1+z}=1
$$

Now, let

$$
\frac{1}{1+x}=a, \frac{1}{1+y}=b, \frac{1}{1+z}=c
$$

Then

$$
x=\frac{1-a}{a}=\frac{b+c}{a}, y=\frac{c+a}{b}, z=\frac{a+b}{c}
$$

We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
x y+y z+z x & \geq 2(x+y+z) \Leftrightarrow \frac{b+c}{a} \cdot \frac{c+a}{b}+\frac{c+a}{b} \cdot \frac{a+b}{c}+\frac{a+b}{c} \cdot \frac{b+c}{a} \geq \\
& \geq 2\left(\frac{b+c}{a}+\cdot \frac{c+a}{b}+\frac{a+b}{c}\right) \Leftrightarrow a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+3 a b c \geq \\
& \geq a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)+c a(c+a) \Leftrightarrow \sum a(a-b)(a-c) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

which is exactly Schur's Inequality.

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $abc = 1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a}{a^{2}+2}+\frac{b}{b^{2}+2}+\frac{c}{c^{2}+2} \leq C
$$
solution:
By the well-known inequality $x^{2}+1 \geq 2 x, \forall x \in \mathbb{R}$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a}{a^{2}+2}+\frac{b}{b^{2}+2}+\frac{c}{c^{2}+2} & =\frac{a}{a^{2}+1+1}+\frac{b}{b^{2}+1+1}+\frac{c}{c^{2}+1+1} \\
& \leq \frac{a}{2 a+1}+\frac{b}{2 b+1}+\frac{c}{2 c+1} \\
& =\frac{1}{2+\frac{1}{a}}+\frac{1}{2+\frac{1}{b}}+\frac{1}{2+\frac{1}{c}}=A
\end{aligned}
$$

The inequality $A \leq 1$ is equivalent to
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(2+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(2+\frac{1}{c}\right)+\left(2+\frac{1}{a}\right)\left(2+\frac{1}{c}\right)+\left(2+\frac{1}{a}\right)\left(2+\frac{1}{b}\right) \\
& \quad \leq\left(2+\frac{1}{a}\right)\left(2+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(2+\frac{1}{c}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
4 \leq \frac{1}{a b}+\frac{1}{a c}+\frac{1}{b c}+\frac{1}{a b c}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad 3 \leq \frac{1}{a b}+\frac{1}{a c}+\frac{1}{b c}
$$
which is true since $\frac{1}{a b}+\frac{1}{a c}+\frac{1}{b c} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\left(\frac{1}{a b c}\right)^{3}}=3$.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$ be real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z > 0$:
$$
\frac{x^{2}-z^{2}}{y+z}+\frac{y^{2}-x^{2}}{z+x}+\frac{z^{2}-y^{2}}{x+y} \geq C.
$$
solution:
We need to prove that $\frac{x^{2}}{y+z}+\frac{y^{2}}{z+x}+\frac{z^{2}}{x+y} \geq \frac{z^{2}}{y+z}+\frac{x^{2}}{z+x}+\frac{y^{2}}{x+y}$.
Without loss of generality we may assume that $x \geq y \geq z$ (since the given inequality is cyclic we also will consider the case $z \geq y \geq x$ ).

Then clearly $x^{2} \geq y^{2} \geq z^{2}$ and $\frac{1}{y+z} \geq \frac{1}{z+x} \geq \frac{1}{x+y}$.
By the rearrangement inequality we have
$$
\frac{x^{2}}{y+z}+\frac{y^{2}}{z+x}+\frac{z^{2}}{x+y} \geq \frac{z^{2}}{y+z}+\frac{x^{2}}{z+x}+\frac{y^{2}}{x+y}
$$
as required.
If we assume that $z \geq y \geq x$, then $z^{2} \geq y^{2} \geq x^{2}$ and $\frac{1}{x+y} \geq \frac{1}{x+z} \geq \frac{1}{z+y}$.
By the rearrangement inequality we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{x^{2}}{y+z}+\frac{y^{2}}{z+x}+\frac{z^{2}}{x+y} & =z^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{x+y}+x^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{y+z}+y^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{z+x} \\
& \geq z^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{y+z}+x^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{z+x}+y^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{x+y} \\
& =\frac{z^{2}}{y+z}+\frac{x^{2}}{z+x}+\frac{y^{2}}{x+y}
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $x=y=z$.

Theorem 37.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers and let $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a permutation of $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$. Then
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \geq a_{1} x_{1}+a_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} x_{n}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c, x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $a + x \geq b + y \geq c + z$ and $a + b + c = x + y + z$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, x, y, z$:
$$
a y + b x \geq C(a c + x z).
$$
solution:
We have
$a y+b x-a c-x z=a(y-c)+x(b-z)=a(a+b-x-z)+x(b-z)=a(a-x)+(a+x)(b-z)=$ $=\frac{1}{2}(a-x)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(a^{2}-x^{2}\right)+(a+x)(b-z)=\frac{1}{2}(a-x)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(a+x)(a-x+2 b-2 z)=$ $=\frac{1}{2}(a-x)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(a+x)(b-c+y-z) \geq 0$.
The equality occurs when $a=x, b=z, c=y$ and $2 x \geq y+z$.

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers and let $S$ be a non-empty subset of $\{1,2, \ldots, n\}$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and all non-empty subsets $S$:
$$
\left(\sum_{i \in S} a_{i}\right)^{2} \leq C \sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq n}\left(a_{i}+\ldots+a_{j}\right)^{2}
$$
solution:
First, let us prove a lemma. Lemma

For any $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{2 k+1} \in \mathbb{R}$ we have the inequality

$$
\left(\sum_{i=0}^{k} a_{2 i+1}\right)^{2} \leq \sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq 2 k+1}\left(a_{i}+\cdots+a_{j}\right)^{2}
$$

Proof of the lemma
Let us take $s_{k}=a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}$. We have

$$
\sum_{i=0}^{k} a_{2 i+1}=s_{1}+s_{3}-s_{2}+\cdots+s_{2 k+1}-s_{2 k}
$$

and so the left hand side in the lemma is

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{2 k+1} s_{i}^{2}+2 \sum_{0 \leq i<j \leq k} s_{2 i+1} s_{2 j+1}+2 \sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq k} s_{2 i} s_{2 j}-2 \sum_{\substack{0 \leq i \leq k \\ 1 \leq j \leq k}} s_{2 i+1} s_{2 j}
$$

and the right hand side is just

$$
(2 k+1) \sum_{i=1}^{2 k+1} s_{i}^{2}-2 \sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq 2 k+1} s_{i} s_{j}
$$

Thus, we need to prove that

$$
2 k \sum_{i=1}^{2 k+1} s_{i}^{2} \geq 4 \sum_{0 \leq i<j \leq k} s_{2 i+1} s_{2 j+1}+4 \sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq k} s_{2 i} s_{2 j}
$$

and it comes by adding up the inequalities

$$
2 s_{2 j+1} s_{2 i+1} \leq s_{2 i+1}^{2}+s_{2 j+1}^{2}, 2 s_{2 i} s_{2 j} \leq s_{2 i}^{2}+s_{2 j}^{2}
$$

Now, let us turn back to the solution of the problem. Let us call a succession of $a_{i}$ 's a sequence and call a sequence that is missing from $S$ a gap. We group the successive sequences from $S$ and thus $S$ will look like this

$$
S=\left\{a_{i_{1}}, a_{i_{1}+1}, \ldots, a_{i_{1}+k_{1}}, a_{i_{2}}, a_{i_{2}+1}, \ldots, a_{i_{2}+k_{2}}, \ldots, a_{i_{r}}, \ldots, a_{i_{r}+k_{r}}\right\}
$$

where $i_{j}+k_{j}<i_{j+1}-1$. Thus, we write $S$ as a sequence, followed by a gap, followed by a sequence, then a gap and so on. Now, take $s_{1}=a_{i_{1}}+\cdots+a_{i_{1}+k_{1}}, s_{2}=a_{i_{1}+k_{1}+1}+$ $\cdots+a_{i_{2}-1}, \ldots, s_{2 r-1}=a_{i_{r}}+\cdots+a_{i_{r}+k_{r}}$

Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\sum_{i \in S} a_{i}\right)^{2}=\left(s_{1}+s_{3}+\cdots+s_{2 r-1}\right)^{2} & \leq \\
\sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq 2 r-1}\left(s_{i}+\cdots+s_{j}\right)^{2} & \leq \sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq n}\left(a_{i}+\cdots+a_{j}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

the last inequality being clearly true, because the terms in the left hand side are among those from the right hand side. We will prove the inequality using induction. For $n=2$ and $n=3$ it's easy. Suppose the inequality is true for all $k<n$ and let us prove it for $n$. If $1 \notin S$, then we just apply the inductive step for the numbers $a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, because the right hand side doesn't decrease. Now, suppose $1 \in S$. If $2 \in S$, then we apply the inductive step with the numbers $a_{1}+a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots, a_{n}$. Thus, we may assume that $2 \notin S$. It is easy to see that $(a+b+c)^{2}+c^{2} \geq \frac{(a+b)^{2}}{2} \geq 2 a b$ and thus we have $\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{k}\right)^{2}+$ $\left(a_{2}+a_{3}+\cdots+a_{k-1}\right)^{2} \geq 2 a_{1} a_{k}\left(^{*}\right)$. Also, the inductive step for $a_{3}, \ldots, a_{n}$ shows that

$$
\left(\sum_{i \in S \backslash\{1\}}\right)^{2} \leq \sum_{3 \leq i \leq j \leq n}\left(a_{i}+\cdots+a_{j}\right)^{2}
$$

So, it suffices to show that

$$
a_{1}^{2}+2 a_{1} \sum_{i \in S \backslash\{1\}} a_{i} \leq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{1}+\cdots+a_{i}\right)^{2}+\sum_{i=2}^{n}\left(a_{2}+\cdots+a_{i}\right)^{2}
$$

But this is clear from the fact that $a_{1}^{2}$ appears in the right hand side and by summing up the inequalities from $\left(^{*}\right)$.

Denote $s_{k}=a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}$ for $k=\overline{1, n}$ and also $s_{n+1}=0$. Define now

$$
b_{i}=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \text { if } i \in S \\
0 & , \text { otherwise }
\end{array}\right.
$$

Using Abel's summation we find that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i \in S} a_{i} & =a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}= \\
& =s_{1}\left(b_{1}-b_{2}\right)+s_{2}\left(b_{2}-b_{3}\right)+\cdots+s_{n-1}\left(b_{n-1}-b_{n}\right)+s_{n} b_{n}+s_{n+1}\left(-b_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, put $b_{1}-b_{2}=x_{1}, b_{2}-b_{3}=x_{2}, \ldots, b_{n-1}-b_{n}=x_{n-1}, b_{n}=x_{n}, x_{n+1}=-b_{1}$. So we have

$$
\sum_{i \in S} a_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} x_{i} s_{i}
$$

and also $x_{i} \in\{-1,0,1\}$. Clearly, $\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} x_{i}=0$. On the other hand, using Lagrange identity we find that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq n}\left(a_{i}+\cdots+a_{j}\right)^{2} & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} s_{i}^{2}+\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(s_{j}-s_{i}\right)^{2}= \\
& =\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n+1}\left(s_{j}-s_{i}\right)^{2}=(n+1) \sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i}^{2}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

So we need to prove that

$$
(n+1) \sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i}^{2} \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i} x_{i}\right)^{2}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i}\right)^{2}
$$

But it is clear that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i} x_{i}\right)^{2}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i}\right)^{2} & =\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i}^{2}\left(1+x_{i}^{2}\right) \\
& +2 \sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n+1} s_{i} s_{j}\left(x_{i} x_{j}+1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, using the fact that $2 s_{i} s_{j} \leq s_{i}{ }^{2}+s_{j}^{2}, 1+x_{i} x_{j} \geq 0$, we can write

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
& 2  \sum_{1 \leq i<j n+1} s_{i} s_{j}\left(x_{i} x_{j}+1\right) \leq \sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n+1}\left(s_{i}^{2}+s_{j}^{2}\right)\left(1+x_{i} x_{j}\right)= \\
& n  \left(s_{1}^{2}+\cdots+s_{n+1}^{2}\right)+s_{1}^{2} x_{1}\left(x_{2}+x_{3}+\cdots+x_{n}\right)+\cdots+s_{n}^{2} x_{n}\left(x_{1}+ \right.\\ 
& +  \left.x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n-1}\right)=-s_{1}^{2} x_{1}^{2}-\cdots-s_{n}^{2} x_{n}^{2}+n\left(s_{1}^{2}+\cdots+s_{n}^{2}\right)
\end{array}
$$

So,

$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i} x_{i}\right)^{2}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i}\right)^{2} \leq \sum_{k=1}^{n+1} s_{k}^{2}\left(x_{k}^{2}+1\right)+\sum_{k=1}^{n+1} s_{k}^{2}\left(n-x_{k}^{2}\right)=
$$

$=(n+1) \sum_{k+1}^{n+1} s_{k}^{2}$ and we are done.

So,

$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i} x_{i}\right)^{2}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} s_{i}\right)^{2} \leq \sum_{k=1}^{n+1} s_{k}^{2}\left(x_{k}^{2}+1\right)+\sum_{k=1}^{n+1} s_{k}^{2}\left(n-x_{k}^{2}\right)=
$$

$=(n+1) \sum_{k+1}^{n+1} s_{k}^{2}$ and we are done.

Theorem 1.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ are real or complex numbers, and

$$
S_{i}=a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{i}, i=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

then

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} S_{i}\left(b_{i}-b_{i+1}\right)+S_{n} b_{n}
$$

problem:
Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n} > 0$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}, n > 1$, such that $x_{1} + x_{2} + \cdots + x_{n} = 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$:
$$
\frac{x_{1}}{\sqrt{1-x_{1}}} + \frac{x_{2}}{\sqrt{1-x_{2}}} + \cdots + \frac{x_{n}}{\sqrt{1-x_{n}}} \geq C (\sqrt{x_{1}} + \sqrt{x_{2}} + \cdots + \sqrt{x_{n}})
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \geq 0$ such that $a + b + c = 1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a b + b c + c a \leq a^3 + b^3 + c^3 + C a b c
$$
solution:
Let $p=a+b+c=1, q=a b+b c+c a, r=a b c$.
Using $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}=p\left(p^{2}-3 q\right)+3 r=1-3 q+3 r$ we have that inequality equivalent to
$$
q \leq 1-3 q+3 r+6 r \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 9 r+1 \geq 4 q
$$

problem:
For any real numbers $a, b, c, x, y, z$, find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds:
$$
a x+b y+c z+\sqrt{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)} \geq C(a+b+c)(x+y+z)
$$
solution:
Let us denote $t=\sqrt{\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}}$. Using the substitutions $x=t p, y=t q$ and $z=t r$, which imply

$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=p^{2}+q^{2}+r^{2}
$$

The given inequality becomes

$$
\begin{gathered}
a p+b q+c r+a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq \frac{2}{3}(a+b+c)(p+q+r) \\
(a+p)^{2}+(b+q)^{2}+(c+r)^{2} \geq \frac{4}{3}(a+b+c)(p+q+r)
\end{gathered}
$$

Since

$$
4(a+b+c)(p+q+r) \leq[(a+b+c)+(p+q+r)]^{2}
$$

it suffices to prove that

$$
(a+p)^{2}+(b+q)^{2}+(c+r)^{2} \geq \frac{1}{3}[(a+p)+(b+q)+(c+r)]^{2}
$$

This inequality is clearly true.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{3}+b^{3}+a b c}+\frac{b^{3}}{b^{3}+c^{3}+a b c}+\frac{c^{3}}{c^{3}+a^{3}+a b c} \geq C
$$
solution:
Let $x=\frac{b}{a}, y=\frac{c}{b}, z=\frac{a}{c}$. Then clearly $x y z=1$.
Therefore
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{3}+b^{3}+a b c} & =\frac{1}{1+x^{3}+\frac{x}{z}}=\frac{1}{1+x^{3}+x^{2} y}=\frac{x y z}{x y z+x^{3}+x^{2} y} \\
& =\frac{y z}{y z+x^{2}+x y}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly we deduce
$$
\frac{b^{3}}{b^{3}+c^{3}+a b c}=\frac{x z}{x z+y^{2}+z y} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c^{3}}{c^{3}+a^{3}+a b c}=\frac{x y}{x y+z^{2}+x z}
$$

So it suffices to prove that
$$
\frac{y z}{y z+x^{2}+x y}+\frac{x z}{x z+y^{2}+z y}+\frac{x y}{x y+z^{2}+x z} \geq 1
$$

According to the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality (Corollary 4.3, Chap. 4) we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{y z}{y z+x^{2}+x y}+\frac{x z}{x z+y^{2}+z y}+\frac{x y}{x y+z^{2}+x z} \\
& \quad \geq \frac{(x y+y z+z x)^{2}}{y z\left(y z+x^{2}+x y\right)+x z\left(x z+y^{2}+z y\right)+x y\left(x y+z^{2}+x z\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We need to prove that
$$
(x y+y z+z x)^{2} \geq y z\left(y z+x^{2}+x y\right)+x z\left(x z+y^{2}+z y\right)+x y\left(x y+z^{2}+x z\right)
$$
which is in fact an equality.
Equality holds iff $x=y=z$, i.e. $a=b=c$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 29.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers such that $b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}>0$. Then
$$
\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{2}}{b_{n}} \geq \frac{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2}}{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}}
$$
with equality if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\left(C+a_{1}\right)\left(C+a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(C+a_{n}\right) \leq\left(1+\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{a_{2}}\right)\left(1+\frac{a_{2}^{2}}{a_{3}}\right) \cdots\left(1+\frac{a_{n}^{2}}{a_{1}}\right)
$$
solution:
Let $x_{i}=\ln a_{i}$, then given inequality becomes
$$
\left(1+e^{x_{1}}\right)\left(1+e^{x_{2}}\right) \cdots\left(1+e^{x_{n}}\right) \leq\left(1+e^{2 x_{1}-x_{2}}\right)\left(1+e^{2 x_{2}-x_{3}}\right) \cdots\left(1+e^{2 x_{n}-x_{1}}\right)
$$

After taking logarithm on the both sides we obtain
$$
\ln \left(1+e^{x_{1}}\right)+\cdots+\ln \left(1+e^{x_{n}}\right) \leq \ln \left(1+e^{2 x_{1}-x_{2}}\right)+\cdots+\ln \left(1+e^{2 x_{n}-x_{1}}\right)
$$

Let consider the sequences $a: 2 x_{1}-x_{2}, 2 x_{2}-x_{3}, \ldots, 2 x_{n}-x_{1}$ and $b: x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$.

Since $f(x)=\ln \left(1+e^{x}\right)$ is convex function on $\mathbb{R}$ by Karamata's inequality it suffices to prove that $a$ (ordered in some way) majorizes the sequences $b$ (ordered in some way), which can be done exactly as in Exercise 12.13, and therefore is left to the reader.

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) = 8$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a+b+c}{C} \geq \sqrt[27]{\frac{a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}}{3}}
$$

Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a given triangle, and $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be the respective angles (in radians). Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all triangles:
$$
\frac{b+c-a}{\alpha}+\frac{c+a-b}{\beta}+\frac{a+b-c}{\gamma} \geq Cs.
$$
where $s=\frac{a+b+c}{2}$.
solution:
Let $x=b+c-a, y=c+a-b$ and $z=a+b-c$.
Without loss the generality we may assume that $a \leq b \leq c$. Then clearly $\alpha \leq \beta \leq \gamma$.

Also $x \geq y \geq z$ and $\frac{1}{\alpha} \geq \frac{1}{\beta} \geq \frac{1}{\gamma}$.
Chebishev's inequality gives us
$$
(x+y+z)\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\gamma}\right) \leq 3\left(\frac{x}{\alpha}+\frac{y}{\beta}+\frac{z}{\gamma}\right)
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\frac{x}{\alpha}+\frac{y}{\beta}+\frac{z}{\gamma}\right) & \geq \frac{1}{3}(x+y+z)\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\gamma}\right) \\
& \geq \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{9(x+y+z)}{\alpha+\beta+\gamma}=\frac{6 s}{\pi}
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

$$
a^4 b + b^4 c + c^4 a \leq C.
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$ be real numbers. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\sqrt{x^{2}+x y+y^{2}}+\sqrt{y^{2}+y z+z^{2}}+\sqrt{z^{2}+z x+x^{2}} \geq C \sqrt{x y+y z+z x}
$$

Theorem 54.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n} ; m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}$ be three sequences of positive real numbers and let $p>1$. Then
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{b+c}{a}+\frac{c+a}{b}+\frac{a+b}{c} \geq C\left(\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}\right)
$$
solution:
Using the inequality $\frac{1}{x+y} \leq \frac{1}{4 x}+\frac{1}{4 y}$ we infer that

$$
\frac{4 a}{b+c} \leq \frac{a}{b}+\frac{a}{c}, \quad \frac{4 b}{a+c} \leq \frac{b}{a}+\frac{b}{c} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{4 c}{a+b} \leq \frac{c}{a}+\frac{c}{b}
$$

Adding up these three inequalities, the conclusion follows.

problem:
Let $0 < x \leq y \leq z$ and $x + y + z = x y z + 2$. Find the minimal constants $C_1$ and $C_2$ such that the following inequalities hold for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraints:
$$
x^2 y \leq C_1
$$
and
$$
x^3 y^2 \leq C_2.
$$
solution:
We rewrite the relation $x+y+z=x y z+2$ as $(1-x)(1-y)+(1-z)(1-x y)=0$. If $x>1$ then $z \geq y \geq x>1$ and so $(1-x)(1-y)+(1-z)(1-x y)>0$, impossible. So we have $x \leq 1$. Next we distinguish two cases 1) $x y \leq 1$; 2) $x y>1$.

1) $x y \leq 1$. We have $x^{2} y \leq x \leq 1$ and $x^{3} y^{2} \leq x \leq 1<\frac{32}{27}$.
2) $x y>1$. From $y \geq \sqrt{x y}$ we get $y>1$. Next we rewrite the relation $x+y+z=$ $x y z+2$ as $x+y-2=(x y-1) z$. Because $z \geq y$ gives $x+y-2 \geq(x y-1) y$, $(y-1)(2-x-x y) \geq 0$ so $2 \geq x(1+y)$. Using the AM-GM Inequality, we have $1+y \geq 2 \sqrt{y}$ and $1+y=1+\frac{y}{2}+\frac{y}{2} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{1 \cdot \frac{y}{2} \cdot \frac{y}{2}}$. Thus we have $2 \geq 2 x \sqrt{y}$ and $2 \geq 3 x \sqrt[3]{\frac{y^{2}}{4}}$, which means that $x^{2} y \leq 1$ and $x^{3} y^{2} \leq \frac{32}{27}$.

The equality $x^{2} y=1$ takes place when $x=y=1$ and the equality $x^{3} y^{2}=\frac{32}{27}$ takes place when $x=\frac{2}{3}, y=z=2$.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest positive number $C$ such that the inequality below holds for all $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}+\frac{b^{3}}{b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{c^{3}}{c^{2}+d^{2}}+\frac{d^{3}}{d^{2}+a^{2}} \geq C(a+b+c+d)
$$
solution:
Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}=a-\frac{a b^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}} \geq a-\frac{a b^{2}}{2 a b}=a-\frac{b}{2}
$$

Analogously
$$
\frac{b^{3}}{b^{2}+c^{2}} \geq b-\frac{c}{2}, \quad \frac{c^{3}}{c^{2}+d^{2}} \geq c-\frac{d}{2}, \quad \frac{d^{3}}{d^{2}+a^{2}} \geq d-\frac{a}{2}
$$

Adding these inequalities give us the required inequality.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers such that $ab + bc + ca = 1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a^2}{b+c} + \frac{b^2}{c+a} + \frac{c^2}{a+b} \geq C
$$

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers satisfying the condition
$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+2 x y z=1.
$$
Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
x + y + z \leq C.
$$
solution:
Clearly, we must have $x, y, z \in(0,1)$. If we put $s=x+y+z$, we get immediately from the given relation

$$
s^{2}-2 s+1=2(1-x)(1-y)(1-z)
$$

Then, again by the AM-GM Inequality ( $1-x, 1-y, 1-z$ being positive), we obtain

$$
s^{2}-2 s+1 \leq 2\left(\frac{1-x+1-y+1-z}{3}\right)^{3}=2\left(\frac{3-s}{3}\right)^{3}
$$

After some easy calculations this yields

$$
2 s^{3}+9 s^{2}-27 \leq 0 \Leftrightarrow(2 s-3)(s+3)^{2} \leq 0
$$

and the conclusion is plain.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $0 \leq a, b, c \leq 1$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:

$$
\frac{c}{7+a^{3}+b^{3}}+\frac{b}{7+c^{3}+a^{3}}+\frac{a}{7+b^{3}+c^{3}} \leq C.
$$

For any $a, b, c, d > 0$, determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:
$$
C\left(a^{3}+1\right)\left(b^{3}+1\right)\left(c^{3}+1\right)\left(d^{3}+1\right) \geq(1+a b c d)\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+b^{2}\right)\left(1+c^{2}\right)\left(1+d^{2}\right)
$$
solution:
Using Huygens Inequality

$$
\prod\left(1+a^{4}\right) \geq(1+a b c d)^{4}
$$

we notice that it is enough to show that that

$$
2^{4} \prod\left(a^{3}+1\right)^{4} \geq \prod\left(1+a^{4}\right)\left(1+a^{2}\right)^{4}
$$

Of course, it suffices to prove that $2\left(a^{3}+1\right)^{4} \geq\left(a^{4}+1\right)\left(a^{2}+1\right)^{4}$ for any positive real $a$. But $\left(a^{2}+1\right)^{4} \leq(a+1)^{2}\left(a^{3}+1\right)^{2}$ and we are left with the inequality $2\left(a^{3}+1\right)^{2} \geq$ $(a+1)^{2}\left(a^{4}+1\right) \Leftrightarrow 2\left(a^{2}-a+1\right)^{2} \geq a^{4}+1 \Leftrightarrow(a-1)^{4} \geq 0$, which follows.

Theorem 13.Theorem:
If $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ are positive real numbers with $p_{1}+p_{2}+\ldots+p_{n}=1$, then

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p_{i}} \geq \prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p_{i}}+\prod_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p_{i}}
$$

problem:
Find the maximal constant $C$ such that for all $a, b, c \in \left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$, the following inequality holds:
$$
\frac{\sin a \cdot \sin (a-b) \cdot \sin (a-c)}{\sin (b+c)}+\frac{\sin b \cdot \sin (b-c) \cdot \sin (b-a)}{\sin (c+a)}+\frac{\sin c \cdot \sin (c-a) \cdot \sin (c-b)}{\sin (a+b)} \geq C.
$$
solution:
Let $x=\sin a, y=\sin b, z=\sin c$. Then we have $x, y, z>0$. It is easy to see that the following relations are true:

$$
\sin a \cdot \sin (a-b) \cdot \sin (a-c) \cdot \sin (a+b) \cdot \sin (a+c)=x\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-z^{2}\right)
$$

Using similar relations for the other terms, we have to prove that:

$$
\sum x\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right) \geq 0
$$

With the substitution $x=\sqrt{u}, y=\sqrt{v}, z=\sqrt{w}$ the inequality becomes $\sum \sqrt{u}(u-$ $v)(u-w) \geq 0$. But this follows from Schur's Inequality.

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a^3 + abc}{(b+c)^2} + \frac{b^3 + abc}{(c+a)^2} + \frac{c^3 + abc}{(a+b)^2} \geq C
$$

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

Theorem 63.Theorem:
Let $x, y, z$ and $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a \geq$ $b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$. Then we have
$$
a(x-y)(x-z)+b(y-x)(y-z)+c(z-x)(z-y) \geq 0
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
If the equation $x^{4}+a x^{3}+2 x^{2}+b x+1=0$ has at least one real root, determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2} \geq C
$$
solution:
Let $x$ be the real root of the equation. Using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality we infer that

$$
a^{2}+b^{2} \geq \frac{\left(x^{4}+2 x^{2}+1\right)^{2}}{x^{2}+x^{6}} \geq 8
$$

because the last inequality is equivalent to $\left(x^{2}-1\right)^{4} \geq 0$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{b(a+b)}+\frac{1}{c(b+c)}+\frac{1}{a(c+a)} \geq \frac{C}{(a+b+c)^{2}}
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$:
$$
a^{n}+b^{n}+c^{n} \geq\left(\frac{a+2 b}{C}\right)^{n}+\left(\frac{b+2 c}{C}\right)^{n}+\left(\frac{c+2 a}{C}\right)^{n}
$$
solution:
By the power mean inequality for any $a, b, c\in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ and, $n \in \mathbb{N}$, we have
$$
\frac{a^{n}+b^{n}+c^{n}}{3} \geq\left(\frac{a+b+c}{3}\right)^{n}
$$

So it follows that
$$
\frac{a^{n}+b^{n}+b^{n}}{3} \geq\left(\frac{a+b+b}{3}\right)^{n}=\left(\frac{a+2 b}{3}\right)^{n}
$$

Similarly we obtain
$$
\frac{b^{n}+c^{n}+c^{n}}{3} \geq\left(\frac{b+2 c}{3}\right)^{n} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c^{n}+a^{n}+a^{n}}{3} \geq\left(\frac{c+2 a}{3}\right)^{n}
$$

After adding these we get the required inequality.

Theorem 59.Theorem:
Let $a=\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, and let $m=\left(m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ also be a sequence of positive real numbers such that $m_{1}+m_{2}+\cdots+m_{n}=1$.
Then for each $r \leq s$ we have
$$
M_{r}^{m}(a) \leq M_{s}^{m}(a)
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{r}+m_{2} a_{2}^{r}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}} \leq\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{s}+m_{2} a_{2}^{s}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{s}\right)^{\frac{1}{s}}
$$

problem:
Let $\alpha_{i} \in\left[\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{5 \pi}{4}\right]$, for $i=1,2, \ldots, n$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $\alpha_i$ in the given range:
$$
\left(\sin \alpha_{1}+\sin \alpha_{2}+\cdots+\sin \alpha_{n}+C\right)^{2} \geq\left(\cos \alpha_{1}+\cos \alpha_{2}+\cdots+\cos \alpha_{n}\right)
$$

Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\sqrt[4]{5 a^2 + 4(b + c) + 3} + \sqrt[4]{5 b^2 + 4(c + a) + 3} + \sqrt[4]{5 c^2 + 4(a + b) + 3} \leq C.
$$

Theorem 59.Theorem:
Let $a=\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, and let $m=\left(m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ also be a sequence of positive real numbers such that $m_{1}+m_{2}+\cdots+m_{n}=1$.
Then for each $r \leq s$ we have
$$
M_{r}^{m}(a) \leq M_{s}^{m}(a)
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{r}+m_{2} a_{2}^{r}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}} \leq\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{s}+m_{2} a_{2}^{s}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{s}\right)^{\frac{1}{s}}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the triangle inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \leq C \left( \frac{1}{a+b-c}+\frac{1}{b+c-a}+\frac{1}{c+a-b} \right)
$$
solution:
Since $A M \geq H M$ we have
$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{a+b-c}+\frac{1}{b+c-a}\right) \geq \frac{2}{a+b-c+b+c-a}=\frac{1}{b}
$$

Similarly we deduce
$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{a+b-c}+\frac{1}{c+a-b}\right) \geq \frac{1}{a} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{b+c-a}+\frac{1}{c+a-b}\right) \geq \frac{1}{c}
$$

Adding these inequalities we get the required inequality.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c$.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a + b + c + d = 1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$:
$$
a b c + b c d + c d a + d a b \leq \frac{1}{27} + C a b c d
$$
solution:
Let $f=a b c+b c d+c d a+d a b-\frac{176}{27} a b c d$.
We'll prove that
$$
f \leq \frac{1}{27}
$$

Define $g=a+b+c+d-1$ and
$$
L=f-\lambda g=a b c+b c d+c d a+d a b-\frac{176}{27} a b c d-\lambda(a+b+c+d-1)
$$

For the first partial derivatives we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial a}=b c+c d+d b-\frac{176}{27} b c d-\lambda=0 \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial b}=a c+c d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a c d-\lambda=0 \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial c}=a b+b d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a b d-\lambda=0 \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial d}=b c+a c+a b-\frac{176}{27} a b c-\lambda=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore
$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda & =b c+c d+d b-\frac{176}{27} b c d=a c+c d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a c d \\
& =a b+b d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a b d=b c+a c+a b-\frac{176}{27} a b c
\end{aligned}
$$

Since
$$
b c+c d+d b-\frac{176}{27} b c d=a c+c d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a c d
$$
we deduce that
$$
(b-a)\left(c+d-\frac{176}{27} c d\right)=0
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (b-c)\left(a+d-\frac{176}{27} a d\right)=0 \\
& (b-d)\left(a+c-\frac{176}{27} a c\right)=0 \\
& (a-c)\left(b+d-\frac{176}{27} b d\right)=0 \\
& (a-d)\left(c+b-\frac{176}{27} c b\right)=0 \\
& (c-d)\left(a+b-\frac{176}{27} a b\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

By solving these equations we must have $a=b=c=d$, and since $a+b+c+d=1$ it follows that $a=b=c=d=1 / 4$.

Then
$$
f(1 / 4,1 / 4,1 / 4,1 / 4)=1 / 27
$$
and we are done.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
3 + a + b + c + \frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} + \frac{a}{b} + \frac{b}{c} + \frac{c}{a} \geq C \frac{(a+1)(b+1)(c+1)}{1 + a b c}
$$
solution:
The inequality is equivalent to the following one

$$
\sum a+\sum \frac{1}{a}+\sum \frac{a}{b} \geq 3 \frac{\sum a b+\sum a}{a b c+1}
$$

or

$$
a b c \sum a+\sum \frac{1}{a}+\sum a^{2} c+\sum \frac{a}{b} \geq 2\left(\sum a+\sum a b\right)
$$

But this follows from the inequalities

$$
a^{2} b c+\frac{b}{c} \geq 2 a b, b^{2} c a+\frac{c}{a} \geq 2 b c, c^{2} a b+\frac{a}{b} \geq 2 c a
$$

and

$$
a^{2} c+\frac{1}{c} \geq 2 a, b^{2} a+\frac{1}{a} \geq 2 b, c^{2} b+\frac{1}{b} \geq 2 c
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be real numbers such that $a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+d^{4}=16$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^{5}+b^{5}+c^{5}+d^{5} \leq C
$$
solution:
We have $a^{4} \leq a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+d^{4}=16$, i.e. $a \leq 2$ from which it follows that $a^{4}(a-2) \leq 0$, i.e. $a^{5} \leq 2 a^{4}$.

Similarly we obtain $b^{5} \leq 2 b^{4}, c^{5} \leq 2 c^{4}$ and $d^{5} \leq 2 d^{4}$.

Hence
$$
a^{5}+b^{5}+c^{5}+d^{5} \leq 2\left(a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+d^{4}\right)=32 \text {. }
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=2, b=c=d=0$ (up to permutation).

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 8$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a-2}{a+1}+\frac{b-2}{b+1}+\frac{c-2}{c+1} \leq C
$$
solution:
Rewrite the given inequality as follows
$$
\frac{a+1-3}{a+1}+\frac{b+1-3}{b+1}+\frac{c+1-3}{c+1} \leq 0
$$
or
$$
\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1} \geq 1
$$

Let $a=\frac{2 x}{y}, b=\frac{2 y}{z}, c=\frac{2 z}{x}$.
Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1} & =\frac{1}{\frac{2 x}{y}+1}+\frac{1}{\frac{2 y}{z}+1}+\frac{1}{\frac{2 z}{x}+1} \\
& =\frac{y}{2 x+y}+\frac{z}{2 y+z}+\frac{x}{2 z+x}
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{y^{2}}{2 x y+y^{2}}+\frac{z^{2}}{2 y z+z^{2}}+\frac{x^{2}}{2 z x+x^{2}} \\
& \geq \frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{2 x y+y^{2}+2 y z+z^{2}+2 z x+x^{2}}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

In the last step we used the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality (Corollary 4.3).

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 29.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers such that $b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}>0$. Then
$$
\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{2}}{b_{n}} \geq \frac{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2}}{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}}
$$
with equality if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the triangle inequality:
$$
a^{2}(b+c-a)+b^{2}(c+a-b)+c^{2}(a+b-c) \leq C a b c
$$
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$. Then very easily we can verify that
$$
c(a+b-c) \geq b(c+a-b) \geq a(b+c-a)
$$

Applying the rearrangement inequality we obtain the following inequalities
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a^{2}(b+c-a)+b^{2}(c+a-b)+c^{2}(a+b-c) \\
& \quad \leq b a(b+c-a)+c b(c+a-b)+a c(a+b-c)
\end{aligned}
$$
and
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a^{2}(b+c-a)+b^{2}(c+a-b)+c^{2}(a+b-c) \\
& \quad \leq c a(b+c-a)+a b(c+a-b)+b c(a+b-c)
\end{aligned}
$$

Adding the last two inequalities gives us the required result.

Theorem 37.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers and let $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a permutation of $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$. Then
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \geq a_{1} x_{1}+a_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} x_{n}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 a b c+C \geq 2(a b+b c+c a)
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{p^{2}+2 q^{2}}{3}+2 r+1 \geq 2 \frac{1-q^{2}}{3}
$$
i.e.
$$
6 r+3+4 q^{2}-p^{2} \geq 0
$$

If $2 q \geq p$ then we are done.
Therefore suppose that $p \geq 2 q$.
It suffices to prove that
$$
6 r+3+4 q^{2}-p^{2} \geq 6 \frac{(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{27}+3+4 q^{2}-p^{2} \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{align*}
& \frac{2(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{9}+3+4 q^{2}-p^{2} \geq 0 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(p-3)^{2}(2 p+3) \geq 2 q^{2}(2 q+3 p-18) \tag{}
\end{align*}
$$

If $2 p \leq 9$ it follows that $2 q+3 p \leq 4 p \leq 18$, and we are done.

If $2 p \geq 9$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
2 q^{2}(2 q+3 p-18) & \leq 2 q^{2}(p+3 p-18)=4 q^{2}(2 p-9) \\
& \leq p^{2}(2 p-9)=(p-3)^{2}(2 p+3)-27<(p-3)^{2}(2 p+3)
\end{aligned}
$$
so inequality (1) is true, as required.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 74.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a+b+$ $c=p$.
Let $a b+b c+c a=\frac{p^{2}-q^{2}}{3},(q \geq 0)$ and $a b c=r$.
Then
$$
\frac{(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{27} \leq r \leq \frac{(p-q)^{2}(p+2 q)}{27}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c+d=4$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{1}{a^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{c^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{d^{2}+1} \geq C
$$
solution:
We have
$$
\frac{1}{a^{2}+1}=1-\frac{a^{2}}{a^{2}+1} \geq 1-\frac{a^{2}}{2 a}=1-\frac{a}{2}
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\frac{1}{b^{2}+1} \geq 1-\frac{b}{2}, \frac{1}{c^{2}+1} \geq 1-\frac{c}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{d^{2}+1} \geq 1-\frac{d}{2}
$$

After adding these inequalities we obtain
$$
\frac{1}{a^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{c^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{d^{2}+1} \geq 4-\frac{a+b+c+d}{2}=4-2=2
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Determine the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all positive integers $n$:
$$
1+\frac{1}{2^{2}}+\frac{1}{3^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n^{2}} < C
$$
solution:
For each $k \geq 2$ we have
$$
\frac{1}{k^{2}}<\frac{1}{k(k-1)}=\frac{1}{k-1}-\frac{1}{k}
$$

So
$$
\begin{aligned}
1+\frac{1}{2^{2}}+\frac{1}{3^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n^{2}} & <1+\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right)+\cdots+\left(\frac{1}{n-1}-\frac{1}{n}\right) \\
& =2-\frac{1}{n}<2
\end{aligned}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 1$. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{2+a}+\frac{1}{2+b}+\frac{1}{2+c} \leq C
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Determine the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c+\frac{1}{a}\right) \geq C.
$$
solution:
Applying $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
a+\frac{1}{b} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{a}{b}}, \quad b+\frac{1}{c} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{b}{c}}, \quad c+\frac{1}{a} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{c}{a}}
$$

Therefore
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c+\frac{1}{a}\right) \geq 8 \sqrt{\frac{a}{b}} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{b}{c}} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{c}{a}}=8
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=\frac{1}{b}, b=\frac{1}{c}, c=\frac{1}{a}$ i.e. $a=\frac{1}{b}=c=\frac{1}{a}$, from which we deduce that $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a c \geq 12$ and $b c \geq 8$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
S = a + b + c + 2\left(\frac{1}{a b} + \frac{1}{b c} + \frac{1}{c a}\right) + \frac{8}{a b c} \geq C.
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \geq 0$ be real numbers such that $a+b+c=1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \geq 0$ with $a+b+c=1$:
$$
\sqrt[3]{a+b}+\sqrt[3]{b+c}+\sqrt[3]{c+a} \leq C.
$$
solution:
Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\sqrt[3]{a+b}=\sqrt[3]{(a+b) \cdot 1 \cdot 1} \leq \frac{a+b+1+1}{3}=\frac{a+b+2}{3}
$$

Similarly
$$
\sqrt[3]{b+c} \leq \frac{b+c+2}{3} \quad \text { and } \quad \sqrt[3]{c+a} \leq \frac{c+a+2}{3}
$$

Thus it follows that
$$
A \leq \frac{a+b+2}{3}+\frac{b+c+2}{3}+\frac{c+a+2}{3}=\frac{2(a+b+c)}{3}+2=\frac{8}{3}
$$
with equality iff $a+b=b+c=c+a=1$, i.e. $a=b=c=1 / 2$.
But then $a+b+c=3 / 2 \neq 1$, a contradiction.
Since $A$ is symmetrical expression in $a, b, c$, we estimate that the minimum (maximum) will occur at the point of incidence $a=b=c$, i.e. $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Clearly $a+b=b+c=c+a=2 / 3$.

Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\sqrt[3]{a+b}=\sqrt[3]{(a+b) \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{2}{3}} \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{a+b+\frac{2}{3}+\frac{2}{3}}{3}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{3(a+b)+4}{9}
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\sqrt[3]{b+c} \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{3(b+c)+4}{9} \quad \text { and } \quad \sqrt[3]{c+a} \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{3(c+a)+4}{9}
$$

Adding the last three inequalities gives us
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot\left(\frac{3(a+b)+4}{9}+\frac{3(b+c)+4}{9}+\frac{3(c+a)+4}{9}\right) \\
& =\sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{6(a+b+c)+12}{9}=\sqrt[3]{18}
\end{aligned}
$$

So $\max A=\sqrt[3]{18}$, and it occurs iff $a+b=b+c=c+a=2 / 3$, i.e. $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}_0$:
$$
\sqrt{\frac{a b+b c+c a}{C}} \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{8}}
$$
solution:
The given inequality is homogenous, so we may assume that $a b+b c+$ $c a=3$.

Then clearly
$$
(a+b+c)^{2} \geq 3(a b+b c+c a)=9, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad a+b+c \geq 3
$$
and
$$
1=\frac{a b+b c+c a}{3} \geq \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad a b c \leq 1
$$

So we need to prove that
$$
\sqrt[3]{\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{8}} \geq 1, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \geq 8
$$

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) & =(a+b+c)(a b+b c+c a)-a b c \\
& =3(a+b+c)-a b c \geq 9-1=8
\end{aligned}
$$
and we are done.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c$.

$$
\frac{a b+4 b c+c a}{a^{2}+b c}+\frac{b c+4 c a+a b}{b^{2}+c a}+\frac{c a+4 a b+b c}{c^{2}+a b} \geq C
$$

Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\sqrt{\frac{2 a}{b+c}}+\sqrt{\frac{2 b}{c+a}}+\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{a+b}} \leq C
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c = 1$. Find the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
a \sqrt{b} + b \sqrt{c} + c \sqrt{a} \leq C.
$$
solution:
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{equation*}
(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(a+b+c)=a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

One more use of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality for
$$
\begin{array}{lcc}
A_{1}=\sqrt{a}, & A_{2}=\sqrt{b}, & A_{3}=\sqrt{c} \text { and } \\
B_{1}=\sqrt{a b}, & B_{2}=\sqrt{b c}, & B_{3}=\sqrt{c a}
\end{array}
$$
gives us
$$
(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq(a+b+c)(a b+b c+c a)=a b+b c+c a
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
2(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq 2(a b+b c+c a) \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

By adding (1) and (2) we get
$$
3(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2(a b+b c+c a)
$$
i.e.
$$
3(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq(a+b+c)^{2}=1
$$
i.e.
$$
a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a} \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $\alpha, x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x y z = 1$ and $\alpha \geq 1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{x^{\alpha}}{y+z}+\frac{y^{\alpha}}{z+x}+\frac{z^{\alpha}}{x+y} \geq C
$$
solution:
We may of course assume that $x \geq y \geq z$. Then we have

$$
\frac{x}{y+z} \geq \frac{y}{z+x} \geq \frac{z}{x+y}
$$

and $x^{\alpha-1} \geq y^{\alpha-1} \geq z^{\alpha-1}$. Using Chebyshev's Inequality we infer that

$$
\sum \frac{x^{\alpha}}{y+z} \geq \frac{1}{3} \cdot\left(\sum x^{\alpha-1}\right) \cdot\left(\sum \frac{x}{y+z}\right)
$$

Now, all we have to do is to observe that this follows from the inequalities $\sum x^{\alpha-1} \geq 3$ (from the AM-GM Inequality) and $\sum \frac{x}{y+z} \geq \frac{3}{2}$

According to the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality, we have:
$[(x(y+z)+y(z+x)+z(x+y)]]\left(\frac{x^{\alpha}}{y+z}+\frac{y^{\alpha}}{z+x}+\frac{z^{\alpha}}{x+y}\right) \geq\left(x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}\right)^{2}$.
Thus it remains to show that

$$
\left(x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}\right)^{2} \geq 3(x y+y z+z x)
$$

Since $(x+y+z)^{2} \geq 3(x y+y z+z x)$, it is enough to prove that

$$
x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}} \geq x+y+z
$$

From Bernoulli's Inequality, we get

$$
x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}=[1+(x-1)]^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}} \geq 1+\frac{1+\alpha}{2}(x-1)=\frac{1-\alpha}{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2} x
$$

and, similarly,

$$
y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}} \geq \frac{1-\alpha}{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2} y, z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}} \geq \frac{1-\alpha}{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2} z
$$

Thus

$$
x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}-(x+y+z) \geq \frac{3(1-\alpha)}{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2}(x+y+z)-(x+y+z)=
$$

$$
\frac{\alpha-1}{2}(x+y+z-3) \geq \frac{\alpha-1}{2}(3 \sqrt[3]{x y z}-3)=0
$$

Equality holds for $x=y=z=1$.
Remark:
Using the substitution $\beta=\alpha+1(\beta \geq 2)$ and $x=\frac{1}{a}, y=\frac{1}{b}, z=\frac{1}{c}(a b c=1)$ the inequality becomes as follows

$$
\frac{1}{a^{\beta}(b+c)}+\frac{1}{b^{\beta}(c+a)}+\frac{1}{c^{\gamma}(a+b)} \geq \frac{3}{2}
$$

For $\beta=3$, we obtain one of the problems of IMO 1995 (proposed by Russia).

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a b c d = 1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c, d$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}+a b+a c+a d+b c+b d+c d \geq C
$$
solution:
Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}+a b+a c+a d+b c+b d+c d \geq 10 \sqrt[10]{a^{5} b^{5} c^{5} d^{5}}=10
$$

Equality holds if and only if $a=b=c=d=1$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers. Find the smallest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{a b c}{a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}} + C \geq \frac{a b + b c + c a}{a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2}}
$$
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to the following one
$$
\begin{aligned}
F= & a b c\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+\frac{2}{3}\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \\
& -\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)(a b+b c+c a) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

The polynomial $F$ is of third degree so it will achieves it's minimum when
$$
(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0 \quad \text { or } a b c=0
$$

If $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$, then without loss of generality we may assume that $a=c$ and the given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a^{2} b}{2 a^{3}+b^{3}}+\frac{2}{3} \geq \frac{a^{2}+2 a b}{2 a^{2}+b^{2}} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-b)^{2}\left(\frac{1}{2 a^{2}+b^{2}}-\frac{2 a+b}{3\left(2 a^{3}+b^{3}\right)}\right) \geq 0 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-b)^{4}(a+b) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
which is obvious.
If $a b c=0$ then without loss of generality we may assume that $c=0$ and the given inequality becomes
$$
\frac{2}{3} \geq \frac{a b}{a^{2}+b^{2}} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad a^{2}+b^{2}+3(a-b)^{2} \geq 0
$$
which is true. And we are done.

Theorem 77.Theorem: If the function $f(a b c, a b+b c+c a, a+b+c)$ is a concave function then it achieves it's maximum and minimum values on $\mathbb{R}$ when $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$, and on $\mathbb{R}^{+}$when $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$ or $a b c=0$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $\frac{1}{a+b+1}+\frac{1}{b+c+1}+\frac{1}{c+a+1} \geq 1$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
a+b+c \geq C(a b+b c+c a)
$$
solution:
We'll use the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.
We have
$$
(a+b+1)\left(a+b+c^{2}\right) \geq(a+b+c)^{2}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \frac{1}{a+b+1} \leq \frac{a+b+c^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}
$$

Analogously
$$
\frac{1}{b+c+1} \leq \frac{b+c+a^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{c+a+1} \leq \frac{c+a+b^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}
$$

By the given condition we have
$1 \leq \frac{1}{a+b+1}+\frac{1}{b+c+1}+\frac{1}{c+a+1} \leq \frac{a+b+c^{2}+b+c+a^{2}+c+a+b^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}$, i.e.
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2(a+b+c) \geq(a+b+c)^{2}-\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad a+b+c \geq a b+b c+c a
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\frac{1}{a(1+b)}+\frac{1}{b(1+c)}+\frac{1}{c(1+a)} \geq \frac{C}{1+abc}
$$
solution:
We can easily check the following identities
$$
\frac{1+a b c}{a(1+b)}=\frac{1+a}{a(1+b)}+\frac{b(1+c)}{1+b}-1, \quad \frac{1+a b c}{b(1+c)}=\frac{1+b}{b(1+c)}+\frac{c(1+a)}{1+c}-1
$$
and
$$
\frac{1+a b c}{a(1+b)}=\frac{1+c}{c(1+a)}+\frac{a(1+b)}{1+a}-1
$$

Adding these identities we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1+a b c}{a(1+b)}+\frac{1+a b c}{b(1+c)}+\frac{1+a b c}{c(1+a)} \\
& \quad=\left(\frac{1+a}{a(1+b)}+\frac{a(1+b)}{1+a}\right)+\left(\frac{1+b}{b(1+c)}+\frac{b(1+c)}{1+b}\right) \\
& \quad+\left(\frac{1+c}{c(1+a)}+\frac{c(1+a)}{1+c}\right)-3 \geq 2+2+2-3=3
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{1}{a(1+b)}+\frac{1}{b(1+c)}+\frac{1}{c(1+a)} \geq \frac{3}{1+a b c}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 11.Theorem:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Given a function $f$ of $n$ variables, define the cyclic sum of variables $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{c y c} f\left(x_{1}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+f\left(x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}, x_{1}\right) \\
+\ldots+f\left(a_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n-1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $ab + bc + ca \geq 3$. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a}{\sqrt{a+b}} + \frac{b}{\sqrt{b+c}} + \frac{c}{\sqrt{c+a}} \geq C
$$
solution:
By Hlder's inequality we have
$$
\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{a+b}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{b+c}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{c+a}}\right)^{2 / 3}(a(a+b)+b(b+c)+c(c+a))^{1 / 3} \geq a+b+c
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{a+b}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{b+c}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{c+a}}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{(a+b+c)^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a}
$$

It is enough to show that
$$
\frac{(a+b+c)^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a} \geq \frac{9}{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
2(a+b+c)^{3} \geq 9\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a\right) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Let $p=a+b+c$ and $q=a b+b c+c a$.
Using the initial condition we have $q \geq 3$, and then inequality (1) is equivalent to
$$
2 p^{3} \geq 9\left(p^{2}-2 q+q\right) \quad \text { or } \quad 2 p^{3}+9 q \geq 9 p^{2}
$$

Applying $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
2 p^{3}+9 q \geq 2 p^{3}+27=p^{3}+p^{3}+27 \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{27 p^{6}}=9 p^{2}
$$
as required.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$ be real numbers such that $x+y+z=1$. Determine the minimal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $x, y, z$:
$$
\sqrt{6x+1}+\sqrt{6y+1}+\sqrt{6z+1} \leq C.
$$
solution:
Let $\sqrt{6 x+1}=a, \sqrt{6 y+1}=b, \sqrt{6 z+1}=c$.
Then
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=6(x+y+z)+3=9
$$

Therefore
$$
(a+b+c)^{2} \leq 3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)=27 \text {, i.e. } a+b+c \leq 3 \sqrt{3}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a^{2}+b c}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}+c a}{(c+a)^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}+a b}{(a+b)^{2}} \geq C
$$

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

Theorem 63.Theorem:
Let $x, y, z$ and $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a \geq$ $b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$. Then we have
$$
a(x-y)(x-z)+b(y-x)(y-z)+c(z-x)(z-y) \geq 0
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers such that $ab + bc + ca = 1$ and $a, b, c \neq 1$. Find the maximal constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$ satisfying the given constraint:
$$
\frac{a}{1-a^{2}}+\frac{b}{1-b^{2}}+\frac{c}{1-c^{2}} \geq C
$$
solution:
Since $a b+b c+c a=1$ (Case 3) we take:
$$
a=\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}, \quad b=\tan \frac{\beta}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad c=\tan \frac{\gamma}{2}
$$
where $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$ and $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$.
Using the well-known identity $\frac{\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}}{\tan ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}-1}=\tan \alpha$, we get that the given inequality is equivalent to $\tan \alpha+\tan \beta+\tan \gamma \geq 3 \sqrt{3}$, which is $N_{16}$.

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1 / \sqrt{3}$.

Theorem 45.Theorem:
Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$. Then $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle if and only if
$$
\sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\beta}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\gamma}{2}+2 \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\gamma}{2}=1
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Find the smallest positive number $C$ such that the inequality below holds for all $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$:
$$
\frac{a b}{a+b+2 c}+\frac{b c}{b+c+2 a}+\frac{c a}{c+a+2 b} \leq C(a+b+c)
$$
solution:
Because the inequality is homogeneous we can consider without loss of generality that $a+b+c=1$ and so the inequality is equivalent to

$$
\sum \frac{1}{a(a+1)} \leq \frac{1}{4 a b c}
$$

We have $\frac{1}{t(t+1)}=\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+1}$, so the inequality is equivalent to

$$
\sum \frac{1}{a} \leq \sum \frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{4 a b c}
$$

We will prove now the following intercalation:

$$
\sum \frac{1}{a} \leq \frac{9}{4}+\frac{1}{4 a b c} \leq \sum \frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{4 a b c}
$$

The inequality in the right follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality:

$$
\left(\sum \frac{1}{a+1}\right)\left(\sum(a+1)\right) \geq 9
$$

and the identity $\sum(a+1)=4$. The inequality in the left can be written as $\sum a b \leq$ $\frac{1+9 a b c}{4}$, which is exactly Schur's Inequality.

We have the following chain of inequalities

$$
\sum \frac{a b}{a+b+2 c}=\sum \frac{a b}{a+c+b+c} \leq \sum \frac{a b}{4}\left(\frac{1}{a+c}+\frac{1}{b+c}\right)=\frac{a+b+c}{4}
$$

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c \geq 1$. Determine the largest constant $C$ such that the following inequality holds for all $a, b, c$:
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{a+1}\right)\left(b+\frac{1}{b+1}\right)\left(c+\frac{1}{c+1}\right) \geq C.
$$
solution:
By the inequality $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\frac{a+1}{4}+\frac{1}{a+1} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{a+1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{a+1}}=1 \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{3 a}{4}+\frac{3}{4} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{3 a}{4} \cdot \frac{3}{4}}=\frac{3}{2} \sqrt{a}
$$

Adding these two inequalities we get
$$
a+\frac{1}{a+1} \geq \frac{3}{2} \sqrt{a}
$$

Analogously we obtain
$$
b+\frac{1}{b+1} \geq \frac{3}{2} \sqrt{b} \quad \text { and } \quad c+\frac{1}{c+1} \geq \frac{3}{2} \sqrt{c}
$$

Multiplying the last three inequalities gives us
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{a+1}\right)\left(b+\frac{1}{b+1}\right)\left(c+\frac{1}{c+1}\right) \geq \frac{27}{8} \sqrt{a b c} \geq \frac{27}{8}
$$
as required.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
