Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x + y + z = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
x y + y z + z x \quad () \quad 9 x y z .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Applying $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
x y+y z+z x=(x y+y z+z x)(x+y+z) \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(x y)(y z)(z x)} \cdot 3 \sqrt[3]{x y z}=9 x y z
$$

Equality occur if and only if $x=y=z=\frac{1}{3}$.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=3$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\sqrt[3]{a^{2}+b c}+\sqrt[3]{b^{2}+c a}+\sqrt[3]{c^{2}+a b} \quad () \quad 3 \sqrt[3]{2}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since we have a symmetrical expression we estimate that the maximum value will occur at the point of incidence $a=b=c=1$. Then we have $a^{2}+b c=2$.

By the inequality $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\sqrt[3]{a^{2}+b c}=\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}} \cdot \sqrt[3]{\left(a^{2}+b c\right) \cdot 2 \cdot 2} \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}\left(\frac{a^{2}+b c+4}{3}\right)
$$

Similarly we obtain
$$
\sqrt[3]{b^{2}+c a} \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}\left(\frac{b^{2}+c a+4}{3}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \sqrt[3]{c^{2}+a b} \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}\left(\frac{c^{2}+a b+4}{3}\right)
$$

Adding the last three inequalities gives us
$$
\begin{aligned}
\sqrt[3]{a^{2}+b c}+\sqrt[3]{b^{2}+c a}+\sqrt[3]{c^{2}+a b} & \leq \frac{1}{3 \sqrt[3]{4}}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a+12\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{3 \sqrt[3]{4}}\left(2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+12\right)=\frac{18}{3 \sqrt[3]{4}}=3 \sqrt[3]{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers such that $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=12$. Consider the following expression:
$$
A = a \sqrt[3]{b^{2}+c^{2}} + b \sqrt[3]{c^{2}+a^{2}} + c \sqrt[3]{a^{2}+b^{2}}.
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank:
$$
A \quad () \quad 12.
$$

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $A$ is a symmetrical expression with respect to $a, b$ and $c, \max A$ occurs when $a=b=c>0$, i.e. $a=b=c=2$.

Hence
$$
2 a^{2}=2 b^{2}=2 c^{2}=8
$$
and
$$
b^{2}+c^{2}=c^{2}+a^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}=8
$$

By $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
a \sqrt[3]{b^{2}+c^{2}} & =\sqrt[3]{a^{3}\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}=\sqrt[6]{a^{6}\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt[6]{\left(2 a^{2}\right)^{3} \cdot\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2} \cdot 8} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \sqrt[6]{8\left(2 a^{2}\right)\left(2 a^{2}\right)\left(2 a^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8+6 a^{2}+2\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}{6}=\frac{4+3 a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly
$$
b \sqrt[3]{c^{2}+a^{2}} \leq \frac{4+a^{2}+3 b^{2}+c^{2}}{6} \quad \text { and } \quad c \sqrt[3]{a^{2}+b^{2}} \leq \frac{4+a^{2}+b^{2}+3 c^{2}}{6}
$$

After adding the last three inequalities we get
$$
A \leq \frac{12+5\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)}{6}=\frac{12+5 \cdot 12}{6}=12
$$
with equality if and only if $a=b=c=2$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c=1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}+\frac{6}{a+b+c} \quad () \quad 5
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$.
Let $f(a, b, c)=\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}+\frac{6}{a+b+c}$.
We'll prove that
$$
f(a, b, c) \geq f(a, \sqrt{b c}, \sqrt{b c})
$$

We have
$$
\begin{align*}
f(a, b, c) & \geq f(a, \sqrt{b c}, \sqrt{b c}) \\
\Leftrightarrow & \quad \frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}+\frac{6}{a+b+c} \geq \frac{2}{\sqrt{b c}}+\frac{6}{a+2 \sqrt{b c}} \\
\Leftrightarrow & c(a+b+c)(a+2 \sqrt{b c})+b(a+b+c)(a+2 \sqrt{b c})+6 b c(a+2 \sqrt{b c}) \\
& \geq 2 \sqrt{b c}(a+b+c)(a+2 \sqrt{b c})+6 b c(a+b+c) \\
\Leftrightarrow & (\sqrt{b}-\sqrt{c})^{2}((a+b+c)(a+2 \sqrt{b c})-6 b c) \geq 0 \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

Since $a \geq b \geq c$ we have $a \geq \frac{b+c}{2} \geq \sqrt{b c}$.
Thus
$$
(a+b+c)(a+2 \sqrt{b c}) \geq(\sqrt{b c}+2 \sqrt{b c})(\sqrt{b c}+2 \sqrt{b c})=9 b c \geq 6 b c
$$

So due to (1) and the last inequality we have
$$
f(a, b, c) \geq f(a, \sqrt{b c}, \sqrt{b c})
$$

According to the SMV theorem we need to prove that $f(a, t, t) \geq 5$, with $a t^{2}=1$.
We have
$$
f(a, t, t) \geq 5 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{1}{a}+\frac{2}{t}+\frac{6}{a+2 t} \geq 5
$$
which is equivalent to
$$
(t-1)^{2}\left(2 t^{4}+4 t^{3}-4 t^{2}-t+2\right) \geq 0
$$
which is true since $2 t^{4}+4 t^{3}-4 t^{2}-t+2>0$ for $t>0$.

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a b c = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a^{3} c}{(b+c)(c+a)}+\frac{b^{3} a}{(c+a)(a+b)}+\frac{c^{3} b}{(a+b)(b+c)} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{4} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Clearing denominators gives us
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 4\left(a^{4} c+b^{4} a+c^{4} a+a^{3} c b+b^{3} a c+c^{3} b a\right) \\
& \quad \geq 3\left(a^{2} b+a^{2} c+b^{2} a+b^{2} c+c^{2} a+c^{2} b+2 a b c\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$4\left(a^{4} c+b^{4} a+c^{4} a+a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \geq 3\left(a^{2} b+a^{2} c+b^{2} a+b^{2} c+c^{2} a+c^{2} b+2\right)$.
By $A M \geq G M$ and $a b c=1$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 4\left(a^{4} c+b^{4} a+c^{4} a+a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \\
& =\left(a^{4} c+a^{2}+b^{4} a\right)+\left(b^{4} a+b^{2}+c^{4} b\right)+\left(c^{4} b+c^{2}+a^{4} c\right)+\left(a^{4} c+a^{2}+c^{2}\right) \\
& +\left(b^{4} a+b^{2}+a^{2}\right)+\left(c^{4} b+c^{2}+b^{2}\right)+\left(a^{4} c+b^{4} a+c^{4} b\right)+\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \\
& \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a^{6} b^{3}}+3 \sqrt[3]{b^{6} c^{3}}+3 \sqrt[3]{c^{6} a^{3}}+3 \sqrt[3]{a^{6} c^{3}}+3 \sqrt[3]{c^{6} b^{3}}+3 \sqrt[3]{a^{5} b^{5} c^{5}} \\
& +3 \sqrt[3]{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}} \\
& =3\left(a^{2} b+a^{2} c+b^{2} a+b^{2} c+c^{2} a+c^{2} b+2\right),
\end{aligned}
$$
and we are done.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $x \geq 3$ be a real number. Consider the following expression:
$$
x + \frac{1}{x} \quad () \quad \frac{10}{3}.
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
In this case we cannot directly use the inequality $A M \geq G M$ since the point $x=1$ doesn't belongs to the domain $[3,+\infty)$.

We can easily show that the function $f(x)=x+\frac{1}{x}$ is an increasing function on $[3,+\infty)$, so it follows that $\min \left\{x+\frac{1}{x}\right\}=3+\frac{1}{3}=\frac{10}{3}$.

Now we will show how we can use $A M \geq G M$.
Since we have equality in $A M \geq G M$ if and only if all variables are equal, we deduce that we cannot use this inequality for the numbers $x$ and $\frac{1}{x}$ at the point of incidence $x=3$ since $3 \neq \frac{1}{3}$.

Assume that $A M \geq G M$ is used for the couple $\left(\frac{x}{\alpha}, \frac{1}{x}\right)$ such that at the point of incidence $x=3$, equality occurs, i.e. $\frac{x}{\alpha}=\frac{1}{x}$.

So it follows that $\alpha=x^{2}=3^{2}=9$.
According to this we transform $x+\frac{1}{x}$ as follows
$$
A=x+\frac{1}{x}=\frac{x}{9}+\frac{1}{x}+\frac{8}{9} x \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{x}{9} \cdot \frac{1}{x}}+\frac{8}{9} x=\frac{2}{3}+\frac{8}{9} \cdot 3=\frac{10}{3}
$$

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be pairwise distinct positive integers. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \quad () \quad \frac{2 n+1}{3}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right) .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Without loss of generality, we may assume that $a_{1}<a_{2}<\cdots<a_{n}$ and hence $a_{i} \geq i$ for all $i$. Thus, we may take $b_{i}=a_{i}-i \geq 0$ and the inequality becomes

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}+2 \sum_{i=1}^{n} i b_{i}+\frac{n(n+1)(2 n+1)}{6} \geq \frac{2 n+1}{3} \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}+\frac{n(n+1)(2 n+1)}{6}
$$

Now, using the fact that $a_{i+1}>a_{i}$ we infer that $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq \cdots \leq b_{n}$ and from Chebyshev's Inequality we deduce that

$$
2 \sum_{i=1}^{n} i b_{i} \geq(n+1) \sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i} \geq \frac{2 n+1}{3} \sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}
$$

and the conclusion is immediate. Also, from the above relations we can see immediately that we have equality if and only if $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ is a permutation of the numbers $1,2, \ldots, n$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be distinct non-negative real numbers. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{1}{(x-y)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(y-z)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(z-x)^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{4}{x y+y z+z x}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
If $a, b>0$, then $\frac{1}{(a-b)^{2}}+\frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}} \geq \frac{4}{a b}$.
The last inequality is true since
$$
\frac{1}{(a-b)^{2}}+\frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}-\frac{4}{a b}=\frac{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}-3 a b\right)^{2}}{a^{2} b^{2}(a-b)^{2}}
$$

Without loss of generality we may assume that $z=\min \{x, y, z\}$.
By the previous inequality for $a=x-z$ and $b=y-z$ we get
$$
\frac{1}{(x-y)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(y-z)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(z-x)^{2}} \geq \frac{4}{(x-z)(y-z)}
$$

So it suffices to show that
$$
\frac{4}{(x-z)(y-z)} \geq \frac{4}{x y+y z+z x}
$$
i.e.
$$
x y+y z+z x \geq(x-z)(y-z)
$$
i.e.
$$
2 z(y+x) \geq z^{2}
$$
which is true since $z=\min \{x, y, z\}$.

Theorem 11.Theorem:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Given a function $f$ of $n$ variables, define the cyclic sum of variables $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{c y c} f\left(x_{1}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+f\left(x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}, x_{1}\right) \\
+\ldots+f\left(a_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n-1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{3} = 3$ and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{5} = 5$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{2} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We'll use Hlder's inequality:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$and $p, q \in(0,1), 1 / p+1 / q=1$ then we have
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

We have
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{3}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} a_{i}^{2} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{5 / 3}\right)^{3 / 5}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}^{2}\right)^{5 / 2}\right)^{2 / 5}
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
3 \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{5 / 3}\right)^{3 / 5} \cdot 5^{2 / 5} \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \frac{3}{5^{2 / 5}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{5 / 3}\right)^{3 / 5} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

We'll show that
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{5 / 3} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)^{5 / 3}
$$

Let $S=\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}$.
Since $0<\frac{a_{i}}{S} \leq 1$ and $\frac{5}{3}>1$ we have that $\left(\frac{a_{i}}{S}\right)^{5 / 3} \leq \frac{a_{i}}{S}=1$ from which we deduce
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{a_{i}}{S}\right)^{5 / 3} \leq \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a_{i}}{S}=1
$$

So
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{5 / 3} \leq S^{5 / 3}=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)^{5 / 3}
$$
since $2^{5}>5^{2}, 2>5^{2 / 5}$ and by (1) we obtain the required inequality.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a_{1}^{3}}{a_{2}}+\frac{a_{2}^{3}}{a_{3}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{3}}{a_{1}} \quad () \quad a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $x_{i}=\ln a_{i}$. Then the given inequality becomes
$$
e^{3 x_{1}-x_{2}}+e^{3 x_{2}-x_{3}}+\cdots+e^{3 x_{n}-x_{1}} \geq e^{2 x_{1}}+e^{2 x_{2}}+\cdots+e^{2 x_{n}}
$$

Let us consider the sequences $a: 3 x_{1}-x_{2}, 3 x_{2}-x_{3}, \ldots, 3 x_{n}-x_{1}$ and $b$ : $2 x_{1}, 2 x_{2}, \ldots, 2 x_{n}$.

Since $f(x)=e^{x}$ is a convex function on $\mathbb{R}$ by Karamata's inequality it suffices to prove that $a$ (ordered in some way) majorizes the sequences $b$ (ordered in some way).

For that purpose, let us assume that
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3 x_{m_{1}}-x_{m_{1}+1} \geq 3 x_{m_{2}}-x_{m_{2}+1} \geq \cdots \geq 3 x_{m_{n}}-x_{m_{n}+1} \quad \text { and } \\
& 2 x_{k_{1}} \geq 2 x_{k_{2}} \geq \cdots \geq 2 x_{k_{n}}
\end{aligned}
$$
for some indexes $m_{i}, k_{i} \in\{1,2, \ldots, n\}$
Clearly
$$
3 x_{m_{1}}-x_{m_{1}+1} \geq 3 x_{k_{1}}-x_{k_{1}+1} \geq 2 x_{k_{1}}
$$
and
$\left(3 x_{m_{1}}-x_{m_{1}+1}\right)+\left(3 x_{m_{2}}-x_{m_{2}+1}\right) \geq\left(3 x_{k_{1}}-x_{k_{1}+1}\right)+\left(3 x_{k_{2}}-x_{k_{2}+1}\right) \geq 2 x_{k_{1}}+2 x_{k_{2}}$.
Analogously the sum of the first $s$ terms of (a) is not less than the sum of an arbitrary $s$ terms of (a), hence it is not less than $\left(3 x_{k_{1}}-x_{k_{1}+1}\right)+\left(3 x_{k_{2}}-x_{k_{2}+1}\right)+\cdots+$ ( $3 x_{k_{s}}-x_{k_{s}+1}$ ), which, on the other hand, is not less than $2 x_{k_{1}}+2 x_{k_{2}}+\cdots+2 x_{k_{s}}$.

So $a \succ b$, and we are done.

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a+b+c=3$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b(2 c+a)}+\frac{b^{3}}{c(2 a+b)}+\frac{c^{3}}{a(2 b+c)} \quad () \quad 1 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We'll show that
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b(2 c+a)}+\frac{b^{3}}{c(2 a+b)}+\frac{c^{3}}{a(2 b+c)} \geq \frac{a+b+c}{3}
$$
from which, with the initial condition, will follow the desired inequality.
Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\frac{9 a^{3}}{b(2 c+a)}+3 b+(2 c+a) \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{9 a^{3}}{b(2 c+a)} \cdot 3 b \cdot(2 c+a)}=9 a
$$

Analogously we have
$$
\frac{9 b^{3}}{c(2 a+b)}+3 c+(2 a+b) \geq 3 b \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{9 c^{3}}{a(2 b+c)}+3 a+(2 b+c) \geq 3 c
$$

Adding the last three inequalities we obtain
$$
9\left(\frac{a^{3}}{b(2 c+a)}+\frac{b^{3}}{c(2 a+b)}+\frac{c^{3}}{a(2 b+c)}\right)+6(a+b+c) \geq 9(a+b+c)
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b(2 c+a)}+\frac{b^{3}}{c(2 a+b)}+\frac{c^{3}}{a(2 b+c)} \geq \frac{a+b+c}{3}=\frac{3}{3}=1
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers

& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in (0,1)$ be positive real numbers such that $a b + b c + c a = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a}{1-a^{2}}+\frac{b}{1-b^{2}}+\frac{c}{1-c^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{1-a^{2}}{a}+\frac{1-b^{2}}{b}+\frac{1-c^{2}}{c}\right)
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $a b+b c+c a=1$ and by Case 3, we use the following substitutions
$$
a=\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}, \quad b=\tan \frac{\beta}{2}, \quad c=\tan \frac{\gamma}{2}
$$
where $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle.
Since $a, b, c \in(0,1)$, it follows that $\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}, \tan \frac{\beta}{2}, \tan \frac{\gamma}{2} \in(0,1)$, i.e. it follows that $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of an acute triangle.

Also we have
$$
\frac{a}{1-a^{2}}=\frac{\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}}{1-\tan ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}}=\frac{\sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{\alpha}{2}}{\cos \alpha}=\frac{\sin \alpha}{2 \cos \alpha}=\frac{\tan \alpha}{2}
$$

Similarly
$$
\frac{b}{1-b^{2}}=\frac{\tan \beta}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c}{1-c^{2}}=\frac{\tan \gamma}{2}
$$

Therefore the given inequality becomes
$$
\frac{\tan \alpha+\tan \beta+\tan \gamma}{2} \geq \frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{2}{\tan \alpha}+\frac{2}{\tan \beta}+\frac{2}{\tan \gamma}\right)
$$
or
$$
\begin{equation*}
\tan \alpha+\tan \beta+\tan \gamma \geq 3\left(\frac{1}{\tan \alpha}+\frac{1}{\tan \beta}+\frac{1}{\tan \gamma}\right)
\end{equation*}
$$

By $I_{6}$ we have that $\tan \alpha+\tan \beta+\tan \gamma=\tan \alpha \cdot \tan \beta \cdot \tan \gamma$. Thus it suffices to show that
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (\tan \alpha+\tan \beta+\tan \gamma)^{2} \geq 3(\tan \alpha \tan \beta+\tan \beta \tan \gamma+\tan \gamma \tan \alpha) \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{1}{2}\left((\tan \alpha-\tan \beta)^{2}+(\tan \beta-\tan \gamma)^{2}+(\tan \gamma-\tan \alpha)^{2}\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

We are done.

Theorem 45.Theorem:
Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$. Then $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle if and only if
$$
\sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\beta}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\gamma}{2}+2 \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\gamma}{2}=1
$$

problem:
Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}, \cdots > 0$ be a sequence of positive numbers such that $x_{k+1} \geq x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{k}$ for any $k$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\sqrt{x_{1}}+\sqrt{x_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{x_{n}} \quad () \quad (1+\sqrt{2}) \sqrt{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
First, let us see what happens if $x_{k+1}$ and $x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{k}$ are close for any $k$. For example, we can take $x_{k}=2^{k}$, because in this case we have $x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{k}=x_{k+1}-2$. Thus, we find that

$$
c \geq \frac{\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sqrt{2}^{k}}{\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{n} 2^{k}}}
$$

for any $n$. Taking the limit, we find that $c \geq 1+\sqrt{2}$. Now, let us prove that $1+\sqrt{2}$ works. We will prove the inequality

$$
\sqrt{x_{1}}+\sqrt{x_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{x_{n}} \leq(1+\sqrt{2}) \sqrt{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}
$$

by induction. For $n=1$ or $n=2$ it is clear. Suppose it is true for $n$ and we will prove that $\sqrt{x_{1}}+\sqrt{x_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{x_{n}}+\sqrt{x_{n+1}} \leq(1+\sqrt{2}) \sqrt{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}+x_{n+1}}$. Of course, it is enough to prove that

$$
\sqrt{x_{n+1}} \leq(1+\sqrt{2})\left(\sqrt{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n+1}}-\sqrt{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}\right)
$$

which is equivalent to

$$
\sqrt{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}+\sqrt{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n+1}} \leq(1+\sqrt{2}) \sqrt{x_{n+1}}
$$

But this one follows because

$$
x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n} \leq x_{n+1}
$$

Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have

T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x y + y z + z x = 5$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
3 x^{2} + 3 y^{2} + z^{2} \quad () \quad 10
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Using the inequality $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
4 x^{2}+z^{2} \geq 4 x z, \quad 4 y^{2}+z^{2} \geq 4 y z \quad \text { and } \quad 2 x^{2}+2 y^{2} \geq 4 x y
$$

Adding these inequalities and using $x y+y z+z x=5$ we get the required inequality.
Equality occurs iff $x=y=1, z=2$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle with area $P$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \quad () \quad 4 \sqrt{3} P
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
After setting $a=x+y, b=y+z, c=z+x$ where $x, y, z>0$, the given inequality becomes
$$
\left((x+y)^{2}+(y+z)^{2}+(z+x)^{2}\right)^{2} \geq 48 x y z(x+y+z)
$$

From $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\begin{equation*}
\left((x+y)^{2}+(y+z)^{2}+(z+x)^{2}\right)^{2} \geq(4 x y+4 y z+4 z x)^{2}=16(x y+y z+z x)^{2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since for every $p, q, r \in \mathbb{R}$ we have $(p+q+r)^{2} \geq 3(p q+q r+r p)$, by (1) we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left((x+y)^{2}+(y+z)^{2}+(z+x)^{2}\right)^{2} \\
& \quad \geq 16(x y+y z+z x)^{2} \\
& \quad \geq 16 \cdot 3((x y)(y z)+(y z)(z x)+(z x)(x y))=48 x y z(x+y+z)
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.
Equality holds iff $x=y=z$, i.e. iff $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that
$$
(a+b+c)(x+y+z)=4
$$
and
$$
\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)=4.
$$

Consider the following inequality:
$$
a b c x y z \quad () \quad \frac{1}{36}.
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Using the AM-GM Inequality, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
4(a b+b c+c a)(x y+y z+z x)=\left[(a+b+c)^{2}-\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\right]\left[(x+y+z)^{2}-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\right]= \\
=20-(a+b+c)^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)-\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(x+y+z)^{2} \leq \\
\leq 20-2 \sqrt{(a+b+c)^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(x+y+z)^{2}}=4
\end{gathered}
$$

therefore

$$
\begin{equation*}
(a b+b c+c a)(x y+y z+z a) \leq 1 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

By multiplying the well-known inequalities

$$
(a b+b c+c a)^{2} \geq 3 a b c(a+b+c), \quad(x y+y z+z x)^{2} \geq 3 x y z(x+y+z)
$$

it follows that

$$
(a b+b c+c a)^{2}(x y+y z+z x)^{2} \geq 9 a b c x y z(a+b+c)(x+y+z)
$$

or

$$
\begin{equation*}
(a b+b c+c a)(x y+y z+z x) \geq 36 a b c x y z \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

From (1) and (2), we conclude that

$$
1 \leq(a b+b c+c a)(x y+y z+z x) \geq 36 a b c x y z
$$

therefore $1 \leq 36 a b c x y z$.
To have $1=36 a b c x y z$, the equalities $(a b+b c+c a)^{2}=3 a b c(a+b+c)$ and $(x y+y z+z x)^{2}=3 x y z(x+y+z)$ are necessary. But these conditions imply $a=b=c$ and $x=y=z$, which contradict the relations $(a+b+c)(x+y+z)=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+\right.$ $\left.c^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)=4$. Thus, it follows that $1>36 a b c x y z$.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b + b c + a c = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{1 + a^{2} b^{2}}{(a + b)^{2}} + \frac{1 + b^{2} c^{2}}{(b + c)^{2}} + \frac{1 + c^{2} a^{2}}{(c + a)^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{5}{2} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{c y c} \frac{(a b+b c+a c)^{2}+a^{2} b^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}} \geq \frac{5}{2}(a b+b c+a c) \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad 2 \sum_{c y c} \frac{2 a b(a b+b c+a c)+(b c+c a)^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}} \geq 5(a b+b c+a c) \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad 4(a b+b c+c a)\left(\frac{a b}{(a+b)^{2}}+\frac{b c}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{c a}{(c+a)^{2}}\right) \\
& \quad+2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \geq 5(a b+b c+a c) \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad(a b+b c+c a)\left(\frac{4 a b}{(a+b)^{2}}+\frac{4 b c}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{4 c a}{(c+a)^{2}}-3\right) \\
& \quad+2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-a b-b c-c a\right) \geq 0 \\
& \Leftrightarrow-(a b+b c+c a)\left(\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}}+\frac{(b-c)^{2}}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{(c-a)^{2}}{(c+a)^{2}}\right) \\
& \quad+\left((a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
\Leftrightarrow \quad & \left(1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(a+b)^{2}}\right)(a-b)^{2}+\left(1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(b+c)^{2}}\right)(b-c)^{2} \\
& +\left(1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(c+a)^{2}}\right)(c-a)^{2} \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Let
$$
\begin{aligned}
& S_{a}=1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(b+c)^{2}}, \quad S_{b}=1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(c+a)^{2}} \quad \text { and } \\
& S_{c}=1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(a+b)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$, and then clearly $S_{a} \leq$ $S_{b} \leq S_{c}$.

We have
$$
S_{c}=1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(a+b)^{2}}=\frac{a^{2}+(a+b)(b-c)}{(a+b)^{2}}>0
$$
and it follows that $S_{b} \geq S_{c}>0$.
Also we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{2} S_{b}+b^{2} S_{a} & =a^{2}\left(1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(c+a)^{2}}\right)+b^{2}\left(1-\frac{a b+b c+c a}{(b+c)^{2}}\right) \\
& =a^{2} \frac{c^{2}+(c+a)(a-b)}{(c+a)^{2}}+b^{2} \frac{c^{2}+(b+c)(b-a)}{(b+c)^{2}} \\
& =c^{2}\left(\frac{a^{2}}{(c+a)^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{(b+c)^{2}}\right)+(a-b)\left(\frac{a^{2}}{c+a}-\frac{b^{2}}{b+c}\right) \\
& =c^{2}\left(\frac{a^{2}}{(c+a)^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{(b+c)^{2}}\right)+(a-b)^{2} \frac{a b+b c+c a}{(c+a)(b+c)}>0
\end{aligned}
$$
and we are done.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$.

Theorem 78.Theorem:
Consider the expression $S=S_{a}(b-c)^{2}+$ $S_{b}(a-c)^{2}+S_{c}(a-b)^{2}$, where $S_{a}, S_{b}, S_{c}$ are functions of $a, b, c$.
$1^{\circ}$ If $S_{a}, S_{b}, S_{c} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$2^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$ and $S_{b}, S_{b}+S_{a}, S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$3^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$ and $S_{a}, S_{c}, S_{a}+2 S_{b}, S_{c}+2 S_{b} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$4^{\circ}$ If $a \geq b \geq c$ and $S_{b}, S_{c}, a^{2} S_{b}+b^{2} S_{a} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.
$5^{\circ}$ If $S_{a}+S_{b} \geq 0$ or $S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0$ or $S_{c}+S_{a} \geq 0\left(S_{a}+S_{b}+S_{c} \geq 0\right)$ and $S_{a} S_{b}+S_{b} S_{c}+S_{c} S_{a} \geq 0$ then $S \geq 0$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{4}{c}+\frac{16}{d} \quad () \quad \frac{64}{a+b+c+d} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We obtain
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{4}{c}+\frac{16}{d} \geq \frac{(1+1+2+4)^{2}}{a+b+c+d}=\frac{64}{a+b+c+d}
$$
as required.

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 29.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers such that $b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}>0$. Then
$$
\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{2}}{b_{n}} \geq \frac{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2}}{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}}
$$
with equality if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = x y z$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
x y + y z + z x \quad () \quad 27
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
x y z=x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(x y z)^{2}}, \text { i.e. }(x y z)^{3} \geq 27(x y z)^{2}
$$
which implies
$$
x y z \geq 27
$$
By $A M \geq G M$ we get $x y+y z+z x \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(x y z)^{2}} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{27^{2}}=27$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $n \geq 2$ and $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}$ be positive real numbers satisfying
$$
\frac{1}{x_{1}+1998}+\frac{1}{x_{2}+1998}+\ldots+\frac{1}{x_{n}+1998}=\frac{1}{1998}
$$

Consider the following expression:
$$
\frac{\sqrt[n]{x_{1} x_{2} \ldots x_{n}}}{n-1} \quad () \quad 1998
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above

Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
(x+y+z)^{2}(x y+y z+z x)^{2} \quad () \quad 3\left(x^{2}+x y+y^{2}\right)\left(y^{2}+y z+z^{2}\right)\left(z^{2}+z x+x^{2}\right)
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have
$$
x^{2}+x y+y^{2}=\frac{3}{4}(x+y)^{2}+\frac{1}{4}(x-y)^{2} \geq \frac{3}{4}(x+y)^{2}
$$
similarly
$$
y^{2}+y z+z^{2} \geq \frac{3}{4}(y+z)^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad z^{2}+z x+x^{2} \geq \frac{3}{4}(z+x)^{2}
$$

Hence
$$
\begin{aligned}
3\left(x^{2}+x y+y^{2}\right)\left(y^{2}+y z+z^{2}\right)\left(z^{2}+z x+x^{2}\right) & \geq 3\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{3}(x+y)^{2}(y+z)^{2}(z+x)^{2} \\
& =\frac{81}{64}((x+y)(y+z)(z+x))^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

We'll show that
$$
\frac{81}{64}((x+y)(y+z)(z+x))^{2} \geq(x+y+z)^{2}(x y+y z+z x)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{9}{8}(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq(x+y+z)(x y+y z+z x)
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
9(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq 8(x+y+z)(x y+y z+z x) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$
from which we'll obtain the desired inequality.
Let's note that
$$
(x+y)(y+z)(z+x)=(x+y+z)(x y+y z+z x)-x y z .
$$

Now by (1) we get
$$
9(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq 8((x+y)(y+z)(z+x)+x y z)
$$
i.e.
$$
(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq 8 x y z
$$
which is clearly true since
$$
x+y \geq 2 \sqrt{x y}, \quad y+z \geq 2 \sqrt{y z}, \quad z+x \geq 2 \sqrt{z x} .
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $x=y=z$.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be the angles of a triangle. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\sin \alpha + \sin \beta + \sin \gamma \quad () \quad \sin 2\alpha + \sin 2\beta + \sin 2\gamma .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Applying the sine law we obtain
$$
\sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma=\frac{a+b+c}{2 R}=\frac{P}{r R}
$$

Also
$$
\begin{aligned}
\sin 2 \alpha+\sin 2 \beta+\sin 2 \gamma & =2(\sin \alpha \cos \alpha+\sin \beta \cos \beta+\sin \gamma \cos \gamma) \\
& =\frac{1}{R}(a \cos \alpha+b \cos \beta+c \cos \gamma)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since
$$
a \cos \alpha+b \cos \beta+c \cos \gamma=\frac{2 P}{R}
$$
we have
$$
\sin 2 \alpha+\sin 2 \beta+\sin 2 \gamma=\frac{2 P}{R^{2}}
$$

Therefore
$$
\frac{\sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma}{\sin 2 \alpha+\sin 2 \beta+\sin 2 \gamma}=\frac{R}{2 r} \geq 1
$$

Equality holds if and only if the triangle is equilateral.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{c}{a+3 b}+\frac{d}{b+3 c}+\frac{a}{c+3 d}+\frac{b}{d+3 a} \quad () \quad 1 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $L=\frac{c^{2}}{a c+3 b c}+\frac{d^{2}}{b d+3 c d}+\frac{a^{2}}{c a+3 d a}+\frac{b^{2}}{b d+3 a b}$.
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& ((a c+3 b c)+(b d+3 c d)+(c a+3 d a)+(b d+3 a b)) \cdot L \geq(a+b+c+d)^{2} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad L \geq \frac{(a+b+c+d)^{2}}{2 a c+2 b d+3 b c+3 c d+3 a d+3 a b}
\end{aligned}
$$

It suffices to prove that
$$
\begin{gathered}
(a+b+c+d)^{2} \geq 2 a c+2 b d+3 b c+3 c d+3 a d+3 a b \\
\quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-b)^{2}+(a-d)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-d)^{2} \geq 0
\end{gathered}
$$
which is clearly true.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c=d$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $0 < x < \frac{\pi}{2}$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\tan x \quad () \quad x .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $f(x)=\tan x, g(x)=x$ where $x \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
We have
$$
f(0)=0=g(0) \quad \text { and } \quad f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} x}>1=g^{\prime}(x), \quad \text { for all } x \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)
$$

According to Theorem 13.2, we have $f(x)>g(x)$, i.e. $\tan x>x$ for all $x \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a}{\sqrt{7+b+c}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{7+c+a}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{7+a+b}} \quad () \quad 1
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let us denote
$$
A=\frac{a}{\sqrt{7+b+c}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{7+c+a}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{7+a+b}}
$$
and
$$
B=a(7+b+c)+b(7+c+a)+c(7+a+b)
$$

By Hlder's inequality we obtain
$$
A^{2} B \geq(a+b+c)^{3} .
$$

It remains to prove that
$$
(a+b+c)^{3} \geq B=7(a+b+c)+2(a b+b c+c a)
$$

Since $A M \geq G M$ we deduce that
$$
a+b+c \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a b c}=3
$$
so it follows that
$$
\begin{aligned}
(a+b+c)^{3} \geq 3(a+b+c)^{2} & =\frac{7}{3}(a+b+c)^{2}+\frac{2}{3}(a+b+c)^{2} \\
& \geq \frac{7}{3} \cdot 3(a+b+c)+2(a b+b c+c a) \\
& =7(a+b+c)+2(a b+b c+c a)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 54.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n} ; m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}$ be three sequences of positive real numbers and let $p>1$. Then
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\left(a^{5}-a^{2}+3\right)\left(b^{5}-b^{2}+3\right)\left(c^{5}-c^{2}+3\right) \quad () \quad (a+b+c)^{3} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We start with the inequality $a^{5}-a^{2}+3 \geq a^{3}+2 \Leftrightarrow\left(a^{2}-1\right)\left(a^{3}-1\right) \geq 0$. Thus, it remains to show that

$$
\prod\left(a^{3}+2\right) \geq\left(\sum a\right)^{3}
$$

Using the AM-GM Inequality, one has

$$
\frac{a^{3}}{a^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{b^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{c^{3}+2} \geq \frac{3 a}{\sqrt[3]{\prod\left(a^{3}+2\right)}}
$$

We write two similar inequalities and then add up all these relations. We will find that

$$
\prod\left(a^{3}+2\right) \geq\left(\sum a\right)^{3}
$$

which is what we wanted.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $21 a b+2 b c+8 c a \leq 12$. Consider the following expression:
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{2}{b}+\frac{3}{c} \quad () \quad \frac{15}{2}
$$
where $k$ is a constant. Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We use the same substitution and reduce the problem to finding the minimum value of $x+y+z$ when $2 x y z \geq 2 x+4 y+7 z$. Applying the weighted the AM-GM Inequality we find that

$$
x+y+z \geq\left(\frac{5 x}{2}\right)^{\frac{2}{5}}(3 y)^{\frac{1}{3}}\left(\frac{15 z}{4}\right)^{\frac{4}{15}}
$$

And also $2 x+4 y+7 z \geq 10^{\frac{1}{5}} \cdot 12^{\frac{1}{3}} \cdot 5^{\frac{7}{15}} \cdot x^{\frac{1}{5}} \cdot y^{\frac{1}{3}} \cdot z^{\frac{7}{15}}$. This means that $(x+$ $+y+z)^{2}(2 x+4 y+7 z) \geq \frac{225}{2} x y z$. Because $2 x y z \geq 2 x+4 y+7 z$, we will have

$$
(x+y+z)^{2} \geq \frac{225}{4} \Rightarrow x+y+z \geq \frac{15}{2}
$$

with equality for $x=3, y=\frac{5}{2}, z=2$.,Let $\frac{1}{a}=x, \frac{2}{b}=y, \frac{3}{c}=z$. Then it is easy to check that the condition of the problem becomes $2 x y z \geq 2 x+4 y+7 z$. And we need to minimize $x+y+z$. But

$$
z(2 x y-7) \geq 2 x+4 y \Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{r}
2 x y>7 \\
z \geq \frac{2 x+4 y}{2 x y-7}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Now, we transform the expression so that after one application of the AM-GM Inequality the numerator $3 x y-7$ should vanish $x+y+z \geq x+y+\frac{2 x+4 y}{2 x y-7}=$ $x+\frac{11}{2 x}+y-\frac{7}{2 x}+\frac{2 x+\frac{14}{x}}{2 x y-7} \geq x+\frac{11}{2 x}+2 \sqrt{1+\frac{7}{x^{2}}}$. But, it is immediate to prove that $2 \sqrt{1+\frac{7}{x^{2}}} \geq \frac{3+\frac{7}{x}}{2}$ and so $x+y+z \geq \frac{3}{2}+x+\frac{9}{x} \geq \frac{15}{2}$. We have equality for $x=3, y=\frac{5}{2}, z=2$. Therefore, in the initial problem the answer is $\frac{15}{2}$, achieved for $a=\frac{1}{3}, b=\frac{4}{5}, c=\frac{3}{2}$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers such that $(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)=1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a b + b c + c a \quad () \quad \frac{3}{4} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We homogenize as follows
$$
\begin{equation*}
(a b+b c+c a)^{3} \leq \frac{27}{64}(a+b)^{2}(b+c)^{2}(c+a)^{2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since inequality (1) is homogenous, we may assume that $a b+b c+c a=1$.
Now, we can use the substitutions
$$
a=\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}, \quad b=\tan \frac{\beta}{2}, \quad c=\tan \frac{\gamma}{2}
$$
where $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$ and $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$.
Then
$$
a+b=\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}+\tan \frac{\beta}{2}=\frac{\sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\beta}{2}+\cos \frac{\alpha}{2} \sin \frac{\beta}{2}}{\cos \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\beta}{2}}=\frac{\sin \frac{\alpha+\beta}{2}}{\cos \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\beta}{2}}=\frac{\cos \frac{\gamma}{2}}{\cos \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\beta}{2}}
$$

Similarly
$$
b+c=\frac{\cos \frac{\alpha}{2}}{\cos \frac{\beta}{2} \cos \frac{\gamma}{2}} \quad \text { and } \quad c+a=\frac{\cos \frac{\beta}{2}}{\cos \frac{\gamma}{2} \cos \frac{\alpha}{2}}
$$
i.e. we obtain
$$
(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)=\frac{1}{\cos \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\beta}{2} \cos \frac{\gamma}{2}}
$$

Therefore inequality (1) becomes
$$
\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos ^{2} \frac{\beta}{2} \cos ^{2} \frac{\gamma}{2}} \geq \frac{64}{27}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \cos \frac{\alpha}{2} \cos \frac{\beta}{2} \cos \frac{\gamma}{2} \leq \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{8}
$$

problem:
Let $x \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Consider the following expression:
$$
\frac{x^{2}+1}{x+1} \quad () \quad 1 .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above

Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ be positive real numbers such that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{1+x_{i}}=1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{x_{i}} \quad () \quad (n-1) \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{\sqrt{x_{i}}} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $\frac{1}{1+x_{i}}=a_{i}$. The inequality becomes

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{1-a_{i}}{a_{i}}} \geq(n-1) \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{a_{i}}{1-a_{i}}} \Leftrightarrow \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{\sqrt{a_{i}\left(1-a_{i}\right)}} \geq \\
\geq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{a_{i}}{1-a_{i}}} \Leftrightarrow n \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{a_{i}}{1-a_{i}}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{\sqrt{a_{i}\left(1-a_{i}\right)}}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

But the last inequality is a consequence of Chebyshev's Inequality for the $n$-tuples $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and

$$
\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{a_{1}\left(1-a_{1}\right)}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{a_{2}\left(1-a_{2}\right)}}, \ldots, \frac{1}{\sqrt{a_{n}\left(1-a_{n}\right)}}\right)
$$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c=3$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{c^{2}+a+b}+\frac{1}{a^{2}+b+c}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+c+a} \quad () \quad 1
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Observe that
$$
\frac{1}{a^{2}+b+c}-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{1}{a^{2}-a+3}-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{a(1-a)}{3\left(a^{2}-a+3\right)}
$$

Analogously
$$
\frac{1}{b^{2}+c+a}-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{b(1-b)}{3\left(b^{2}-b+3\right)} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{c^{2}+a+b}-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{c(1-c)}{3\left(c^{2}-c+3\right)}
$$

Now the given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{a(a-1)}{a^{2}-a+3}+\frac{b(b-1)}{b^{2}-b+3}+\frac{c(c-1)}{c^{2}-c+3} \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a-1}{a-1+3 / a}+\frac{b-1}{b-1+3 / b}+\frac{c-1}{c-1+3 / c} \geq 0
$$

Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$.

Then clearly $a-1 \geq b-1 \geq c-1$ and since $a+b+c=3$ it follows that $a b, b c, c a \leq 3$. Now we can easily show that
$$
\frac{1}{a-1+3 / a} \geq \frac{1}{b-1+3 / b} \geq \frac{1}{c-1+3 / c}
$$

Applying Chebishev's inequality we obtain
$$
(a-1+b-1+c-1)\left(\frac{1}{a-1+3 / a}+\frac{1}{b-1+3 / b}+\frac{1}{c-1+3 / c}\right) \leq 3 A
$$
i.e.
$$
A \geq 0
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z \in[-1,1]$ be real numbers such that $x+y+z+x y z=0$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\sqrt{x+1}+\sqrt{y+1}+\sqrt{z+1} \quad () \quad 3
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\sqrt{x+1}+\sqrt{y+1}+\sqrt{z+1} \leq \sqrt{3(x+y+z+3)}
$$

If $x+y+z \leq 0$ then $\sqrt{x+1}+\sqrt{y+1}+\sqrt{z+1} \leq 3$, and the given inequality clearly holds.

So let us assume that $x+y+z>0$. Then we have $x y z=-(x+y+z)<0$. Without loss of generality we may assume that $z<0$ and then it's clear that $x, y \in$ $(0,1]$.

Applying once more, the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we obtain
$$
\sqrt{x+1}+\sqrt{y+1}+\sqrt{z+1} \leq \sqrt{2 x+2 y+4}+\sqrt{z+1}
$$

So it suffices to show that
$$
\sqrt{2 x+2 y+4}+\sqrt{z+1} \leq 3
$$

We have
$$
\begin{align*}
& \sqrt{2 x+2 y+4}+\sqrt{z+1} \leq 3 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \sqrt{2 x+2 y+4}-2 \leq 1-\sqrt{z+1} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{2(x+y)}{\sqrt{2 x+2 y+4}+2} \leq \frac{-z}{\sqrt{z+1}+1} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{-2 z(1+x y)}{\sqrt{2 x+2 y+4}+2} \leq \frac{-z}{\sqrt{z+1}+1} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad 2(1+x y)(1+\sqrt{1+z}) \leq \sqrt{2 x+2 y+4}+2 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 2 x y+2(1+x y) \sqrt{1+z} \leq \sqrt{2 x+2 y+4} . \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

We can easily deduce that $1+z=\frac{(1-x)(1-y)}{1+x y}$, and then inequality (1) is equivalent to
$$
x y+\sqrt{(1-x)(1-y)(1+x y)} \leq \sqrt{1+\frac{x+y}{2}}
$$

Finally, using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
x y+\sqrt{(1-x)(1-y)(1+x y)} & =\sqrt{x} \sqrt{x y^{2}}+\sqrt{1-x} \sqrt{1+x y-y-x y^{2}} \\
& \leq \sqrt{(x+1-x)\left(x y^{2}+1+x y-y-x y^{2}\right)} \\
& =\sqrt{1+y(1-x)} \leq 1 \leq \sqrt{1+\frac{x+y}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$
as desired.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
In the triangle $ABC$, $\overline{AC}^{2}$ is the arithmetic mean of $\overline{BC}^{2}$ and $\overline{AB}^{2}$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\cot^{2} \beta \quad () \quad \cot \alpha \cdot \cot \gamma
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $\overline{B C}=a, \overline{A C}=b, \overline{A B}=c$. Then we have $2 b^{2}=a^{2}+c^{2}$. By the law of sines and cosines we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \cot \beta=\frac{\cos \beta}{\sin \beta}=\frac{\frac{a^{2}+c^{2}-b^{2}}{2 a c}}{\frac{b}{2 R}}=\frac{\left(a^{2}+c^{2}-b^{2}\right) R}{a b c} \\
& \cot \alpha=\frac{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}\right) R}{a b c} \quad \text { and } \quad \cot \gamma=\frac{\left(b^{2}+a^{2}-c^{2}\right) R}{a b c}
\end{aligned}
$$

So we need to prove that
$$
\frac{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}\right) R}{a b c} \cdot \frac{\left(b^{2}+a^{2}-c^{2}\right) R}{a b c} \leq \frac{\left(a^{2}+c^{2}-b^{2}\right)^{2} R^{2}}{(a b c)^{2}}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}\right) \cdot\left(b^{2}+a^{2}-c^{2}\right) \leq\left(a^{2}+c^{2}-b^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Applying $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\left(b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}\right) \cdot\left(b^{2}+a^{2}-c^{2}\right) \leq\left(\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}+b^{2}+a^{2}-c^{2}}{2}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}\right) \cdot\left(b^{2}+a^{2}-c^{2}\right) \leq\left(b^{2}\right)^{2}=\left(2 b^{2}-b^{2}\right)^{2}=\left(a^{2}+c^{2}-b^{2}\right)^{2}
$$
as required.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x + y + z = 4$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{2 x y + x z + y z} + \frac{1}{x y + 2 x z + y z} + \frac{1}{x y + x z + 2 y z} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{x y z}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By $A M \geq H M$ we have that $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b} \geq \frac{4}{a+b}$, for any $a, b \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$.
Therefore
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2 x y+x z+y z} & =\frac{1}{(x y+x z)+(x y+y z)} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{1}{x y+x z}+\frac{1}{x y+y z}\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{1}{x y}+\frac{1}{x z}\right)+\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{1}{x y}+\frac{1}{y z}\right)\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{16}\left(\frac{2}{x y}+\frac{1}{x z}+\frac{1}{y z}\right)=\frac{2 z+y+x}{16 x y z}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly,
$$
\frac{1}{x y+2 x z+y z} \leq \frac{z+2 y+x}{16 x y z} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{x y+x z+2 y z} \leq \frac{z+y+2 x}{16 x y z}
$$

Adding the three inequalities yields that
$$
\frac{1}{2 x y+x z+y z}+\frac{1}{x y+2 x z+y z}+\frac{1}{x y+x z+2 y z} \leq \frac{1}{16}\left(\frac{4(x+y+z)}{x y z}\right)=\frac{1}{x y z}
$$

Equality occurs iff $x=y=z=4 / 3$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{c^{2}+a^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above

$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b+c+d}+\frac{b^{3}}{a+c+d}+\frac{c^{3}}{b+d+a}+\frac{d^{3}}{b+c+a} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{3} .

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
27+\left(2+\frac{a^{2}}{b c}\right)\left(2+\frac{b^{2}}{c a}\right)\left(2+\frac{c^{2}}{a b}\right) \quad () \quad 6(a+b+c)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution: By expanding the two sides, the inequality is equivalent to $2 a b c\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+\right.$ $\left.3 a b c-a^{2} b-a^{2} c-b^{2} a-b^{2} c-c^{2} a-c^{2} b\right)+\left(a^{3} b^{3}+b^{3} c^{3}+c^{3} a^{3}+3 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}-a^{3} b^{2} c-\right.$ $\left.a^{3} b c^{2}-a b^{3} c^{2}-a b^{2} c^{3}-a^{2} b^{3} c-a^{2} b c^{3}\right) \geq 0$. But this is true from Schur's Inequality applied for $a, b, c$ and $a b, b c, c a$.

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $b$ and $c$ be the lengths of two sides of an arbitrary $n$-gon $(n \geq 3)$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{b}{c} \quad () \quad 2 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relations to fill in the blanks.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be the lengths of the sides of the given $n$-gon.
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a_{1} \geq a_{2} \geq \cdots \geq a_{n}$.
Suppose that such a side does not exist, i.e. let us suppose that for any two sides $b$ and $c$ we have $\frac{b}{c} \geq 2(b>c)$, i.e. let us suppose that for every $i \in\{1,2, \ldots, n-1\}$ we have $\frac{a_{i}}{a_{i+1}} \geq 2$.

So it follows that
$$
a_{2} \leq \frac{a_{1}}{2}, \quad a_{3} \leq \frac{a_{2}}{2} \leq \frac{a_{1}}{4}, \ldots, \quad a_{n} \leq \frac{a_{n-1}}{2} \leq \frac{a_{1}}{2^{n-1}}
$$

If we add these inequalities we obtain
$$
a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} \leq a_{1}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}\right)=a_{1}\left(1-\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}\right)<a_{1}
$$
which is impossible.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{1}{1+a+b}+\frac{1}{1+b+c}+\frac{1}{1+c+a} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{2+a}+\frac{1}{2+b}+\frac{1}{2+c}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $x=a+b+c$ and $y=a b+a c+b c$.
Clearly $x, y \geq 3$ (these are immediate consequences of $A M \geq G M$ ).
Now the given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{3+4 x+y+x^{2}}{2 x+y+x^{2}+x y} \leq \frac{12+4 x+y}{9+4 x+2 y}
$$
i.e.
$$
3 x^{2} y+x y^{2}+6 x y-5 x^{2}-y^{2}-24 x-3 y-27 \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(3 x^{2} y-5 x^{2}-12 x\right)+\left(x y^{2}-y^{2}-3 x-3 y\right)+(6 x y-9 x-27) \geq 0
$$
which is true since $x, y \geq 3$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in (1,2)$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{b \sqrt{a}}{4 b \sqrt{c}-c \sqrt{a}}+\frac{c \sqrt{b}}{4 c \sqrt{a}-a \sqrt{b}}+\frac{a \sqrt{c}}{4 a \sqrt{b}-b \sqrt{c}} \quad () \quad 1
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above

Let \(a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}\). Consider the following inequality:
$$
(a+b+c)^{6} \quad () \quad 27\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(a b+b c+c a)^{2} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Denote $x=a+b+c, y=a b+b c+c a$.
Then we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{6} & \geq 27\left(x^{2}-2 y\right) y^{2} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad x^{6} \geq 27 x^{2} y^{2}-54 y^{3} \\
& \Leftrightarrow \quad\left(x^{2}-3 y\right)\left(x^{4}+3 x^{2} y-18 y^{2}\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
which is true, since
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{2} & =(a+b+c)^{2} \geq 3(a b+b c+c a)=3 y, \quad x^{4} \geq 9 y^{2} \quad \text { and } \\
3 x^{2} y & \geq 3 \cdot 3 y \cdot y=9 y^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e. we have
$$
x^{2}-3 y \geq 0 \quad \text { and } \quad x^{4}+3 x^{2} y-18 y^{2} \geq 9 y^{2}+9 y^{2}-18 y^{2}=0
$$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
(n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n} \quad () \quad \left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right).
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Again, we will use induction to prove this inequality, but the proof of the inductive step will be again highly non-trivial. Indeed, suppose the inequality is true for $n$ numbers and let us prove it for $n+1$ numbers.

Due to the symmetry and homogeneity of the inequality, it is enough to prove it under the conditions $a_{1} \geq a_{2} \geq \cdots \geq a_{n+1}$ and $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=1$. We have to prove that
$n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n+1}+n a_{n+1}^{n+1}+n a_{n+1} \cdot \prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}+a_{n+1} \cdot \prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}-\left(1+a_{n+1}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}+a_{n+1}^{n}\right) \geq 0$.
But from the inductive hypothesis we have

$$
(n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n} \geq a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}
$$

and so

$$
n a_{n+1} \prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq a_{n+1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1}-(n-1) a_{n+1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}
$$

Using this last inequality, it remains to prove that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n+1}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}\right)-a_{n+1}\left(n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1}\right)+ \\
+a_{n+1}\left(\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}+(n-1) a_{n+1}^{n}-a_{n+1}^{n-1}\right) \geq 0
\end{gathered}
$$

Now, we will break this inequality into

$$
a_{n+1}\left(\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}+(n-1) a_{n+1}^{n}-a_{n+1}^{n-1}\right) \geq 0
$$

and

$$
\left(n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n+1}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}\right)-a_{n+1}\left(n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1}\right) \geq 0
$$

Let us justify these two inequalities. The first one is pretty obvious

$$
\begin{gathered}
\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}+(n-1) a_{n+1}^{n}-a_{n+1}^{n-1}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}-a_{n+1}+a_{n+1}\right)+(n-1) a_{n+1}^{n}-a_{n+1}^{n-1} \geq \\
\geq a_{n+1}^{n}+a_{n+1}^{n-1} \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}-a_{n+1}\right)+(n-1) a_{n+1}^{n}-a_{n+1}^{n-1}=0
\end{gathered}
$$

Now, let us prove the second inequality. It can be written as

$$
n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n+1}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n} \geq a_{n+1}\left(n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1}\right)
$$

Because $n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1} \geq 0$ (using Chebyshev's Inequality) and $a_{n+1} \leq \frac{1}{n}$, it is enough to prove that

$$
n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n+1}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n} \geq \frac{1}{n}\left(n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{n-1}\right)
$$

but this one follows, because $n a_{i}^{n+1}+\frac{1}{n} a_{i}^{n-1} \geq a_{i}^{n}$ for all $i$. Thus, the inductive step is proved.

Theorem 19.Theorem:
For any nonnegative real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$

$$
(n-1) \sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{n}+n \prod_{k=1}^{n} a_{k} \geq\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}\right) \cdot\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{n-1}\right)
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a^{2}+b c}{b+c}+\frac{b^{2}+c a}{c+a}+\frac{c^{2}+a b}{a+b} \quad () \quad a+b+c .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Assume $a \geq b \geq c$. Then clearly $a^{2} \geq b^{2} \geq c^{2}$ and $\frac{1}{b+c} \geq \frac{1}{c+a} \geq \frac{1}{a+b}$.
According to the rearrangement inequality we have
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{b+c}+\frac{b^{2}}{c+a}+\frac{c^{2}}{a+b} \geq \frac{b^{2}}{b+c}+\frac{c^{2}}{c+a}+\frac{a^{2}}{a+b}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a^{2}+b c}{b+c}+\frac{b^{2}+c a}{c+a}+\frac{c^{2}+a b}{a+b} \geq \frac{b^{2}+b c}{b+c}+\frac{c^{2}+c a}{c+a}+\frac{a^{2}+a b}{a+b}=a+b+c
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $x + y + z = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{x^{2} + y^{2}}{z} + \frac{y^{2} + z^{2}}{x} + \frac{z^{2} + x^{2}}{y} \quad () \quad 2
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x^{2}+y^{2}}{z}+\frac{y^{2}+z^{2}}{x}+\frac{z^{2}+x^{2}}{y} \\
& \geq 2 \frac{x y}{z}+2 \frac{y z}{x}+2 \frac{z x}{y}=2\left(\frac{x y}{z}+\frac{y z}{x}+\frac{z x}{y}\right) \\
& =2\left(\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x y}{z}+\frac{y z}{x}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x y}{z}+\frac{z x}{y}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{y z}{x}+\frac{z x}{y}\right)\right) \\
& \geq 2\left(\sqrt{y^{2}}+\sqrt{x^{2}}+\sqrt{z^{2}}\right)=2(x+y+z)=2
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that
$$
\frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+c^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{c^{2}+a^{2}+1} \geq 1 .
$$

Consider the following inequality:
$$
a b + b c + c a \quad () \quad 3 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality gives us
$$
\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+1\right)\left(1+1+c^{2}\right) \geq(a+b+c)^{2}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}+1} \leq \frac{2+c^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}
$$

Analogous we obtain
$$
\frac{1}{b^{2}+c^{2}+1} \leq \frac{2+a^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{c^{2}+a^{2}+1} \leq \frac{2+b^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}
$$

So we have
$$
1 \leq \frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+c^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{c^{2}+a^{2}+1} \leq \frac{6+a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}
$$
i.e.
$$
6+a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq(a+b+c)^{2}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad a b+b c+c a \leq 3
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $\frac{1}{a+1} + \frac{1}{b+1} + \frac{1}{c+1} = 2$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{1}{4ab+1} + \frac{1}{4bc+1} + \frac{1}{4ca+1} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{2}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $p=a+b+c, q=a b+b c+c a, r=a b c$.
From $\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1}=2$ we deduce
$$
\begin{equation*}
(a+1)(b+1)+(b+1)(c+1)+(c+1)(a+1)=2(a+1)(b+1)(c+1) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

(1) is equivalent to
$$
3+2 p+q=2(1+p+q+r)
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
q+2 r=1 \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$
We have
$(4 a b+1)(4 b c+1)+(4 b c+1)(4 c a+1)+(4 c a+1)(4 a b+1)=64 p r+8 q+3$
and
$$
(4 a b+1)(4 b c+1)(4 c a+1)=64 r^{2}+16 p r+4 q+1
$$

We need to show that
$$
64 p r+8 q+3 \geq \frac{3}{2}\left(64 r^{2}+16 p r+4 q+1\right)
$$
or
$$
32 p r+16 q+6 \geq 192 r^{2}+48 p r+12 q+3
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
192 r^{2}+16 p r-4 q-3 \leq 0 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

$q^{2} \geq 3 p r$ , it follows that $p r \leq \frac{q^{2}}{3}$.
Now since $q=1-2 r$ we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
192 r^{2}+16 p r-4 q-3 & \leq 192 r^{2}+16 \frac{q^{2}}{3}-4 q-3 \\
& =192 r^{2}+16 \frac{(1-2 r)^{2}}{3}-4(1-2 r)-3
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{align*}
& =\frac{5}{3}\left(128 r^{2}-8 r-1\right) \\
& =\frac{5}{3} \cdot 128\left(r-\frac{1}{8}\right)\left(r+\frac{1}{16}\right) \tag{2}
\end{align*}
$$

From (2) and $r \leq \frac{1}{8}$ it follows that $192 r^{2}+16 p r-4 q-3 \leq 0$, which means that inequality (1), i.e. inequality holds.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a+\sqrt{a b}+\sqrt[3]{a b c}}{3} \quad () \quad \sqrt[3]{a \cdot \frac{a+b}{2} \cdot \frac{a+b+c}{3}}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have that

$$
a+\sqrt{a b}+\sqrt[3]{a b c} \leq a+\sqrt[3]{a b \frac{a+b}{2}}+\sqrt[3]{a b c}
$$

Now we will prove that

$$
a+\sqrt[3]{a b \frac{a+b}{2}}+\sqrt[3]{a b c} \leq \sqrt[3]{a \cdot \frac{a+b}{2} \cdot \frac{a+b+c}{3}}
$$

By the AM-GM Inequality, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sqrt[3]{1 \cdot \frac{2 a}{a+b} \cdot \frac{3 a}{a+b+c}} \leq \frac{1+\frac{2 a}{a+b}+\frac{3 a}{a+b+c}}{3} \\
\sqrt[3]{1 \cdot 1 \cdot \frac{3 b}{a+b+c}} \leq \frac{2+\frac{3 b}{a+b+c}}{3} \\
\sqrt[3]{1 \cdot \frac{2 b}{a+b} \cdot \frac{3 c}{a+b+c}} \leq \frac{1+\frac{2 b}{a+b}+\frac{3 c}{a+b+c}}{3}
\end{gathered}
$$

Now, just add them up and we have the desired inequality. The equality occurs when $a=b=c$.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \geq 0$ be real numbers such that $a + b + c + d = 4$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a b c + b c d + c d a + d a b + (a b c)^{2} + (b c d)^{2} + (c d a)^{2} + (d a b)^{2} \quad () \quad 8 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let us denote
$$
f(a, b, c, d)=a b c+b c d+c d a+d a b+(a b c)^{2}+(b c d)^{2}+(c d a)^{2}+(d a b)^{2}
$$

Because of symmetry we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c \geq d$.
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right)-f(a, b, c, d) \\
& \quad=\left(\frac{a-c}{2}\right)^{2}\left((b+d)+\left(\left(\frac{a+c}{2}\right)^{2}+a c\right)\left(b^{2}+d^{2}\right)-2 b^{2} d^{2}\right) \\
& \quad \geq\left(\frac{a-c}{2}\right)^{2}\left(4 a b c d-2 b^{2} d^{2}\right) \geq 0 \quad\left(a b c d \geq b^{2} d^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

So
$$
f\left(\frac{a+c}{2}, b, \frac{a+c}{2}, d\right) \geq f(a, b, c, d)
$$

According to the SMV theorem it suffices to show that
$$
f(t, t, t, d) \leq 8
$$
where $3 t+d=4$ and clearly $0 \leq t \leq \frac{4}{3}$.
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(t, t, t, d) \leq 8 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad t^{3}+3 t^{2}(3-3 t)+3 t^{4}(4-3 t)^{2}+t^{6} \leq 8 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(t-1)^{2}\left(28 t^{4}-16 t^{3}-12 t^{2}-8\right) \leq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

So it is enough to show that $28 t^{4}-16 t^{3}-12 t^{2}-8 \leq 0$, which is easy to prove for $0 \leq t \leq \frac{4}{3}$.

Equality holds iff $a=b=c=d=1$.

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers such that $a b + b c + c a = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{1}{1+a} + \frac{1}{1+b} + \frac{1}{1+c} \quad () \quad \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{3}+1}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b^{2}}+\frac{b^{3}}{c^{2}}+\frac{c^{3}}{a^{2}} \quad () \quad a+b+c .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Using $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b^{2}}+2 b=\frac{a^{3}}{b^{2}}+b+b \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{a^{3}}{b^{2}} \cdot b \cdot b}=3 a
$$

Analogously we have
$$
\frac{b^{3}}{c^{2}}+2 c \geq 3 b \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c^{3}}{a^{2}}+2 a \geq 3 c
$$

Adding these three inequalities we obtain
$$
\frac{a^{3}}{b^{2}}+\frac{b^{3}}{c^{2}}+\frac{c^{3}}{a^{2}}+2(a+b+c) \geq 3(a+b+c)
$$
as required. Equality holds iff $a=b=c$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
