a(x-y)(x-z)+b(y-x)(y-z)+c(z-x)(z-y) \geq 0
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
If the equation $x^{4}+a x^{3}+2 x^{2}+b x+1=0$ has at least one real root, then consider the following expression:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2} \quad () \quad 8
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $x$ be the real root of the equation. Using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality we infer that

$$
a^{2}+b^{2} \geq \frac{\left(x^{4}+2 x^{2}+1\right)^{2}}{x^{2}+x^{6}} \geq 8
$$

because the last inequality is equivalent to $\left(x^{2}-1\right)^{4} \geq 0$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a^{n}+b^{n}+c^{n} \quad () \quad \left(\frac{a+2 b}{3}\right)^{n}+\left(\frac{b+2 c}{3}\right)^{n}+\left(\frac{c+2 a}{3}\right)^{n} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By the power mean inequality for any $a, b, c\in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ and, $n \in \mathbb{N}$, we have
$$
\frac{a^{n}+b^{n}+c^{n}}{3} \geq\left(\frac{a+b+c}{3}\right)^{n}
$$

So it follows that
$$
\frac{a^{n}+b^{n}+b^{n}}{3} \geq\left(\frac{a+b+b}{3}\right)^{n}=\left(\frac{a+2 b}{3}\right)^{n}
$$

Similarly we obtain
$$
\frac{b^{n}+c^{n}+c^{n}}{3} \geq\left(\frac{b+2 c}{3}\right)^{n} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c^{n}+a^{n}+a^{n}}{3} \geq\left(\frac{c+2 a}{3}\right)^{n}
$$

After adding these we get the required inequality.

Theorem 59.Theorem:
Let $a=\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, and let $m=\left(m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ also be a sequence of positive real numbers such that $m_{1}+m_{2}+\cdots+m_{n}=1$.
Then for each $r \leq s$ we have
$$
M_{r}^{m}(a) \leq M_{s}^{m}(a)
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{r}+m_{2} a_{2}^{r}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}} \leq\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{s}+m_{2} a_{2}^{s}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{s}\right)^{\frac{1}{s}}
$$

Theorem 59.Theorem:
Let $a=\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, and let $m=\left(m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ also be a sequence of positive real numbers such that $m_{1}+m_{2}+\cdots+m_{n}=1$.
Then for each $r \leq s$ we have
$$
M_{r}^{m}(a) \leq M_{s}^{m}(a)
$$
i.e.

\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{r}+m_{2} a_{2}^{r}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}} \leq\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{s}+m_{2} a_{2}^{s}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{s}\right)^{\frac{1}{s}}

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{a+b-c}+\frac{1}{b+c-a}+\frac{1}{c+a-b}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $A M \geq H M$ we have
$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{a+b-c}+\frac{1}{b+c-a}\right) \geq \frac{2}{a+b-c+b+c-a}=\frac{1}{b}
$$

Similarly we deduce
$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{a+b-c}+\frac{1}{c+a-b}\right) \geq \frac{1}{a} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{b+c-a}+\frac{1}{c+a-b}\right) \geq \frac{1}{c}
$$

Adding these inequalities we get the required inequality.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c$.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a + b + c + d = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a b c + b c d + c d a + d a b \quad () \quad \frac{1}{27} + \frac{176}{27} a b c d .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $f=a b c+b c d+c d a+d a b-\frac{176}{27} a b c d$.
We'll prove that
$$
f \leq \frac{1}{27}
$$

Define $g=a+b+c+d-1$ and
$$
L=f-\lambda g=a b c+b c d+c d a+d a b-\frac{176}{27} a b c d-\lambda(a+b+c+d-1)
$$

For the first partial derivatives we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial a}=b c+c d+d b-\frac{176}{27} b c d-\lambda=0 \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial b}=a c+c d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a c d-\lambda=0 \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial c}=a b+b d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a b d-\lambda=0 \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial d}=b c+a c+a b-\frac{176}{27} a b c-\lambda=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore
$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda & =b c+c d+d b-\frac{176}{27} b c d=a c+c d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a c d \\
& =a b+b d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a b d=b c+a c+a b-\frac{176}{27} a b c
\end{aligned}
$$

Since
$$
b c+c d+d b-\frac{176}{27} b c d=a c+c d+d a-\frac{176}{27} a c d
$$
we deduce that
$$
(b-a)\left(c+d-\frac{176}{27} c d\right)=0
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (b-c)\left(a+d-\frac{176}{27} a d\right)=0 \\
& (b-d)\left(a+c-\frac{176}{27} a c\right)=0 \\
& (a-c)\left(b+d-\frac{176}{27} b d\right)=0 \\
& (a-d)\left(c+b-\frac{176}{27} c b\right)=0 \\
& (c-d)\left(a+b-\frac{176}{27} a b\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

By solving these equations we must have $a=b=c=d$, and since $a+b+c+d=1$ it follows that $a=b=c=d=1 / 4$.

Then
$$
f(1 / 4,1 / 4,1 / 4,1 / 4)=1 / 27
$$
and we are done.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
3 + a + b + c + \frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} + \frac{a}{b} + \frac{b}{c} + \frac{c}{a} \quad () \quad 3 \frac{(a+1)(b+1)(c+1)}{1 + a b c}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
The inequality is equivalent to the following one

$$
\sum a+\sum \frac{1}{a}+\sum \frac{a}{b} \geq 3 \frac{\sum a b+\sum a}{a b c+1}
$$

or

$$
a b c \sum a+\sum \frac{1}{a}+\sum a^{2} c+\sum \frac{a}{b} \geq 2\left(\sum a+\sum a b\right)
$$

But this follows from the inequalities

$$
a^{2} b c+\frac{b}{c} \geq 2 a b, b^{2} c a+\frac{c}{a} \geq 2 b c, c^{2} a b+\frac{a}{b} \geq 2 c a
$$

and

$$
a^{2} c+\frac{1}{c} \geq 2 a, b^{2} a+\frac{1}{a} \geq 2 b, c^{2} b+\frac{1}{b} \geq 2 c
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be real numbers such that $a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+d^{4}=16$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a^{5}+b^{5}+c^{5}+d^{5} \quad () \quad 32
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have $a^{4} \leq a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+d^{4}=16$, i.e. $a \leq 2$ from which it follows that $a^{4}(a-2) \leq 0$, i.e. $a^{5} \leq 2 a^{4}$.

Similarly we obtain $b^{5} \leq 2 b^{4}, c^{5} \leq 2 c^{4}$ and $d^{5} \leq 2 d^{4}$.

Hence
$$
a^{5}+b^{5}+c^{5}+d^{5} \leq 2\left(a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+d^{4}\right)=32 \text {. }
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=2, b=c=d=0$ (up to permutation).

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 8$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a-2}{a+1}+\frac{b-2}{b+1}+\frac{c-2}{c+1} \quad () \quad 0
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Rewrite the given inequality as follows
$$
\frac{a+1-3}{a+1}+\frac{b+1-3}{b+1}+\frac{c+1-3}{c+1} \leq 0
$$
or
$$
\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1} \geq 1
$$

Let $a=\frac{2 x}{y}, b=\frac{2 y}{z}, c=\frac{2 z}{x}$.
Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1} & =\frac{1}{\frac{2 x}{y}+1}+\frac{1}{\frac{2 y}{z}+1}+\frac{1}{\frac{2 z}{x}+1} \\
& =\frac{y}{2 x+y}+\frac{z}{2 y+z}+\frac{x}{2 z+x}
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{y^{2}}{2 x y+y^{2}}+\frac{z^{2}}{2 y z+z^{2}}+\frac{x^{2}}{2 z x+x^{2}} \\
& \geq \frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{2 x y+y^{2}+2 y z+z^{2}+2 z x+x^{2}}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

In the last step we used the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality (Corollary 4.3).

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 29.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers such that $b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}>0$. Then
$$
\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{2}}{b_{n}} \geq \frac{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2}}{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}}
$$
with equality if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a^{2}(b+c-a)+b^{2}(c+a-b)+c^{2}(a+b-c) \quad () \quad 3 a b c
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$. Then very easily we can verify that
$$
c(a+b-c) \geq b(c+a-b) \geq a(b+c-a)
$$

Applying the rearrangement inequality we obtain the following inequalities
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a^{2}(b+c-a)+b^{2}(c+a-b)+c^{2}(a+b-c) \\
& \quad \leq b a(b+c-a)+c b(c+a-b)+a c(a+b-c)
\end{aligned}
$$
and
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a^{2}(b+c-a)+b^{2}(c+a-b)+c^{2}(a+b-c) \\
& \quad \leq c a(b+c-a)+a b(c+a-b)+b c(a+b-c)
\end{aligned}
$$

Adding the last two inequalities gives us the required result.

Theorem 37.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers and let $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a permutation of $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$. Then
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \geq a_{1} x_{1}+a_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} x_{n}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 a b c+1 \quad () \quad 2(a b+b c+c a) .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{p^{2}+2 q^{2}}{3}+2 r+1 \geq 2 \frac{1-q^{2}}{3}
$$
i.e.
$$
6 r+3+4 q^{2}-p^{2} \geq 0
$$

If $2 q \geq p$ then we are done.
Therefore suppose that $p \geq 2 q$.
It suffices to prove that
$$
6 r+3+4 q^{2}-p^{2} \geq 6 \frac{(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{27}+3+4 q^{2}-p^{2} \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{align*}
& \frac{2(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{9}+3+4 q^{2}-p^{2} \geq 0 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(p-3)^{2}(2 p+3) \geq 2 q^{2}(2 q+3 p-18) \tag{}
\end{align*}
$$

If $2 p \leq 9$ it follows that $2 q+3 p \leq 4 p \leq 18$, and we are done.

If $2 p \geq 9$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
2 q^{2}(2 q+3 p-18) & \leq 2 q^{2}(p+3 p-18)=4 q^{2}(2 p-9) \\
& \leq p^{2}(2 p-9)=(p-3)^{2}(2 p+3)-27<(p-3)^{2}(2 p+3)
\end{aligned}
$$
so inequality (1) is true, as required.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 74.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a+b+$ $c=p$.
Let $a b+b c+c a=\frac{p^{2}-q^{2}}{3},(q \geq 0)$ and $a b c=r$.
Then
$$
\frac{(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{27} \leq r \leq \frac{(p-q)^{2}(p+2 q)}{27}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c+d=4$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{a^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{c^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{d^{2}+1} \quad () \quad 2
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have
$$
\frac{1}{a^{2}+1}=1-\frac{a^{2}}{a^{2}+1} \geq 1-\frac{a^{2}}{2 a}=1-\frac{a}{2}
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\frac{1}{b^{2}+1} \geq 1-\frac{b}{2}, \frac{1}{c^{2}+1} \geq 1-\frac{c}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{d^{2}+1} \geq 1-\frac{d}{2}
$$

After adding these inequalities we obtain
$$
\frac{1}{a^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{c^{2}+1}+\frac{1}{d^{2}+1} \geq 4-\frac{a+b+c+d}{2}=4-2=2
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

problem:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Consider the following inequality:
$$
1+\frac{1}{2^{2}}+\frac{1}{3^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n^{2}} \quad () \quad 2 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
For each $k \geq 2$ we have
$$
\frac{1}{k^{2}}<\frac{1}{k(k-1)}=\frac{1}{k-1}-\frac{1}{k}
$$

So
$$
\begin{aligned}
1+\frac{1}{2^{2}}+\frac{1}{3^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n^{2}} & <1+\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right)+\cdots+\left(\frac{1}{n-1}-\frac{1}{n}\right) \\
& =2-\frac{1}{n}<2
\end{aligned}
$$

\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.

\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c+\frac{1}{a}\right) \quad () \quad 8
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Applying $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
a+\frac{1}{b} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{a}{b}}, \quad b+\frac{1}{c} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{b}{c}}, \quad c+\frac{1}{a} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{c}{a}}
$$

Therefore
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c+\frac{1}{a}\right) \geq 8 \sqrt{\frac{a}{b}} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{b}{c}} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{c}{a}}=8
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=\frac{1}{b}, b=\frac{1}{c}, c=\frac{1}{a}$ i.e. $a=\frac{1}{b}=c=\frac{1}{a}$, from which we deduce that $a=b=c=1$.

H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}

Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \geq 0$ be real numbers such that $a+b+c=1$. Consider the following expression:
$$
\sqrt[3]{a+b} + \sqrt[3]{b+c} + \sqrt[3]{c+a} \quad()\quad \sqrt[3]{18}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\sqrt[3]{a+b}=\sqrt[3]{(a+b) \cdot 1 \cdot 1} \leq \frac{a+b+1+1}{3}=\frac{a+b+2}{3}
$$

Similarly
$$
\sqrt[3]{b+c} \leq \frac{b+c+2}{3} \quad \text { and } \quad \sqrt[3]{c+a} \leq \frac{c+a+2}{3}
$$

Thus it follows that
$$
A \leq \frac{a+b+2}{3}+\frac{b+c+2}{3}+\frac{c+a+2}{3}=\frac{2(a+b+c)}{3}+2=\frac{8}{3}
$$
with equality iff $a+b=b+c=c+a=1$, i.e. $a=b=c=1 / 2$.
But then $a+b+c=3 / 2 \neq 1$, a contradiction.
Since $A$ is symmetrical expression in $a, b, c$, we estimate that the minimum (maximum) will occur at the point of incidence $a=b=c$, i.e. $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Clearly $a+b=b+c=c+a=2 / 3$.

Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\sqrt[3]{a+b}=\sqrt[3]{(a+b) \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{2}{3}} \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{a+b+\frac{2}{3}+\frac{2}{3}}{3}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{3(a+b)+4}{9}
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\sqrt[3]{b+c} \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{3(b+c)+4}{9} \quad \text { and } \quad \sqrt[3]{c+a} \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{3(c+a)+4}{9}
$$

Adding the last three inequalities gives us
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & \leq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot\left(\frac{3(a+b)+4}{9}+\frac{3(b+c)+4}{9}+\frac{3(c+a)+4}{9}\right) \\
& =\sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{4}} \cdot \frac{6(a+b+c)+12}{9}=\sqrt[3]{18}
\end{aligned}
$$

So $\max A=\sqrt[3]{18}$, and it occurs iff $a+b=b+c=c+a=2 / 3$, i.e. $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\sqrt{\frac{a b+b c+c a}{3}} \quad () \quad \sqrt[3]{\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{8}}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
The given inequality is homogenous, so we may assume that $a b+b c+$ $c a=3$.

Then clearly
$$
(a+b+c)^{2} \geq 3(a b+b c+c a)=9, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad a+b+c \geq 3
$$
and
$$
1=\frac{a b+b c+c a}{3} \geq \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad a b c \leq 1
$$

So we need to prove that
$$
\sqrt[3]{\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{8}} \geq 1, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \geq 8
$$

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) & =(a+b+c)(a b+b c+c a)-a b c \\
& =3(a+b+c)-a b c \geq 9-1=8
\end{aligned}
$$
and we are done.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a \sqrt{b} + b \sqrt{c} + c \sqrt{a} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{equation*}
(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(a+b+c)=a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

One more use of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality for
$$
\begin{array}{lcc}
A_{1}=\sqrt{a}, & A_{2}=\sqrt{b}, & A_{3}=\sqrt{c} \text { and } \\
B_{1}=\sqrt{a b}, & B_{2}=\sqrt{b c}, & B_{3}=\sqrt{c a}
\end{array}
$$
gives us
$$
(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq(a+b+c)(a b+b c+c a)=a b+b c+c a
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
2(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq 2(a b+b c+c a) \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

By adding (1) and (2) we get
$$
3(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2(a b+b c+c a)
$$
i.e.
$$
3(a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a})^{2} \leq(a+b+c)^{2}=1
$$
i.e.
$$
a \sqrt{b}+b \sqrt{c}+c \sqrt{a} \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $\alpha, x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x y z = 1$ and $\alpha \geq 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{x^{\alpha}}{y+z}+\frac{y^{\alpha}}{z+x}+\frac{z^{\alpha}}{x+y} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{2}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We may of course assume that $x \geq y \geq z$. Then we have

$$
\frac{x}{y+z} \geq \frac{y}{z+x} \geq \frac{z}{x+y}
$$

and $x^{\alpha-1} \geq y^{\alpha-1} \geq z^{\alpha-1}$. Using Chebyshev's Inequality we infer that

$$
\sum \frac{x^{\alpha}}{y+z} \geq \frac{1}{3} \cdot\left(\sum x^{\alpha-1}\right) \cdot\left(\sum \frac{x}{y+z}\right)
$$

Now, all we have to do is to observe that this follows from the inequalities $\sum x^{\alpha-1} \geq 3$ (from the AM-GM Inequality) and $\sum \frac{x}{y+z} \geq \frac{3}{2}$

According to the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality, we have:
$[(x(y+z)+y(z+x)+z(x+y)]]\left(\frac{x^{\alpha}}{y+z}+\frac{y^{\alpha}}{z+x}+\frac{z^{\alpha}}{x+y}\right) \geq\left(x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}\right)^{2}$.
Thus it remains to show that

$$
\left(x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}\right)^{2} \geq 3(x y+y z+z x)
$$

Since $(x+y+z)^{2} \geq 3(x y+y z+z x)$, it is enough to prove that

$$
x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}} \geq x+y+z
$$

From Bernoulli's Inequality, we get

$$
x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}=[1+(x-1)]^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}} \geq 1+\frac{1+\alpha}{2}(x-1)=\frac{1-\alpha}{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2} x
$$

and, similarly,

$$
y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}} \geq \frac{1-\alpha}{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2} y, z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}} \geq \frac{1-\alpha}{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2} z
$$

Thus

$$
x^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+y^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}+z^{\frac{1+\alpha}{2}}-(x+y+z) \geq \frac{3(1-\alpha)}{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2}(x+y+z)-(x+y+z)=
$$

$$
\frac{\alpha-1}{2}(x+y+z-3) \geq \frac{\alpha-1}{2}(3 \sqrt[3]{x y z}-3)=0
$$

Equality holds for $x=y=z=1$.
Remark:
Using the substitution $\beta=\alpha+1(\beta \geq 2)$ and $x=\frac{1}{a}, y=\frac{1}{b}, z=\frac{1}{c}(a b c=1)$ the inequality becomes as follows

$$
\frac{1}{a^{\beta}(b+c)}+\frac{1}{b^{\beta}(c+a)}+\frac{1}{c^{\gamma}(a+b)} \geq \frac{3}{2}
$$

For $\beta=3$, we obtain one of the problems of IMO 1995 (proposed by Russia).

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a b c d = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}+a b+a c+a d+b c+b d+c d \quad () \quad 10 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}+a b+a c+a d+b c+b d+c d \geq 10 \sqrt[10]{a^{5} b^{5} c^{5} d^{5}}=10
$$

Equality holds if and only if $a=b=c=d=1$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a b c}{a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}}+\frac{2}{3} \quad () \quad \frac{a b+b c+c a}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to the following one
$$
\begin{aligned}
F= & a b c\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+\frac{2}{3}\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \\
& -\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)(a b+b c+c a) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

The polynomial $F$ is of third degree so it will achieves it's minimum when
$$
(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0 \quad \text { or } a b c=0
$$

If $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$, then without loss of generality we may assume that $a=c$ and the given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a^{2} b}{2 a^{3}+b^{3}}+\frac{2}{3} \geq \frac{a^{2}+2 a b}{2 a^{2}+b^{2}} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-b)^{2}\left(\frac{1}{2 a^{2}+b^{2}}-\frac{2 a+b}{3\left(2 a^{3}+b^{3}\right)}\right) \geq 0 \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(a-b)^{4}(a+b) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
which is obvious.
If $a b c=0$ then without loss of generality we may assume that $c=0$ and the given inequality becomes
$$
\frac{2}{3} \geq \frac{a b}{a^{2}+b^{2}} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad a^{2}+b^{2}+3(a-b)^{2} \geq 0
$$
which is true. And we are done.

Theorem 77.Theorem: If the function $f(a b c, a b+b c+c a, a+b+c)$ is a concave function then it achieves it's maximum and minimum values on $\mathbb{R}$ when $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$, and on $\mathbb{R}^{+}$when $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$ or $a b c=0$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $\frac{1}{a+b+1}+\frac{1}{b+c+1}+\frac{1}{c+a+1} \geq 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a+b+c \quad () \quad a b+b c+c a .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We'll use the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.
We have
$$
(a+b+1)\left(a+b+c^{2}\right) \geq(a+b+c)^{2}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \frac{1}{a+b+1} \leq \frac{a+b+c^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}
$$

Analogously
$$
\frac{1}{b+c+1} \leq \frac{b+c+a^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{c+a+1} \leq \frac{c+a+b^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}
$$

By the given condition we have
$1 \leq \frac{1}{a+b+1}+\frac{1}{b+c+1}+\frac{1}{c+a+1} \leq \frac{a+b+c^{2}+b+c+a^{2}+c+a+b^{2}}{(a+b+c)^{2}}$, i.e.
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2(a+b+c) \geq(a+b+c)^{2}-\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad a+b+c \geq a b+b c+c a
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{a(1+b)}+\frac{1}{b(1+c)}+\frac{1}{c(1+a)} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{1+a b c}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We can easily check the following identities
$$
\frac{1+a b c}{a(1+b)}=\frac{1+a}{a(1+b)}+\frac{b(1+c)}{1+b}-1, \quad \frac{1+a b c}{b(1+c)}=\frac{1+b}{b(1+c)}+\frac{c(1+a)}{1+c}-1
$$
and
$$
\frac{1+a b c}{a(1+b)}=\frac{1+c}{c(1+a)}+\frac{a(1+b)}{1+a}-1
$$

Adding these identities we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1+a b c}{a(1+b)}+\frac{1+a b c}{b(1+c)}+\frac{1+a b c}{c(1+a)} \\
& \quad=\left(\frac{1+a}{a(1+b)}+\frac{a(1+b)}{1+a}\right)+\left(\frac{1+b}{b(1+c)}+\frac{b(1+c)}{1+b}\right) \\
& \quad+\left(\frac{1+c}{c(1+a)}+\frac{c(1+a)}{1+c}\right)-3 \geq 2+2+2-3=3
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{1}{a(1+b)}+\frac{1}{b(1+c)}+\frac{1}{c(1+a)} \geq \frac{3}{1+a b c}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 11.Theorem:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Given a function $f$ of $n$ variables, define the cyclic sum of variables $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{c y c} f\left(x_{1}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+f\left(x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n}, x_{1}\right) \\
+\ldots+f\left(a_{n}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n-1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b + b c + c a \geq 3$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a}{\sqrt{a+b}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{b+c}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{c+a}} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{\sqrt{2}} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By Hlder's inequality we have
$$
\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{a+b}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{b+c}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{c+a}}\right)^{2 / 3}(a(a+b)+b(b+c)+c(c+a))^{1 / 3} \geq a+b+c
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{a+b}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{b+c}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{c+a}}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{(a+b+c)^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a}
$$

It is enough to show that
$$
\frac{(a+b+c)^{3}}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a} \geq \frac{9}{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
2(a+b+c)^{3} \geq 9\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a\right) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Let $p=a+b+c$ and $q=a b+b c+c a$.
Using the initial condition we have $q \geq 3$, and then inequality (1) is equivalent to
$$
2 p^{3} \geq 9\left(p^{2}-2 q+q\right) \quad \text { or } \quad 2 p^{3}+9 q \geq 9 p^{2}
$$

Applying $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
2 p^{3}+9 q \geq 2 p^{3}+27=p^{3}+p^{3}+27 \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{27 p^{6}}=9 p^{2}
$$
as required.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$ be real numbers such that $x + y + z = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\sqrt{6 x + 1} + \sqrt{6 y + 1} + \sqrt{6 z + 1} \quad () \quad 3 \sqrt{3}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $\sqrt{6 x+1}=a, \sqrt{6 y+1}=b, \sqrt{6 z+1}=c$.
Then
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=6(x+y+z)+3=9
$$

Therefore
$$
(a+b+c)^{2} \leq 3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)=27 \text {, i.e. } a+b+c \leq 3 \sqrt{3}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a^{2}+b c}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}+c a}{(c+a)^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}+a b}{(a+b)^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{2} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

Theorem 63.Theorem:
Let $x, y, z$ and $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a \geq$ $b \geq c$ or $a \leq b \leq c$. Then we have
$$
a(x-y)(x-z)+b(y-x)(y-z)+c(z-x)(z-y) \geq 0
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c (a, b, c \neq 1)$ be non-negative real numbers such that $a b + b c + c a = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a}{1-a^{2}}+\frac{b}{1-b^{2}}+\frac{c}{1-c^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $a b+b c+c a=1$ (Case 3) we take:
$$
a=\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}, \quad b=\tan \frac{\beta}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad c=\tan \frac{\gamma}{2}
$$
where $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$ and $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$.
Using the well-known identity $\frac{\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}}{\tan ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}-1}=\tan \alpha$, we get that the given inequality is equivalent to $\tan \alpha+\tan \beta+\tan \gamma \geq 3 \sqrt{3}$, which is $N_{16}$.

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=1 / \sqrt{3}$.

Theorem 45.Theorem:
Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$. Then $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle if and only if
$$
\sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\beta}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\gamma}{2}+2 \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\gamma}{2}=1
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a b}{a+b+2 c}+\frac{b c}{b+c+2 a}+\frac{c a}{c+a+2 b} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{4}(a+b+c) .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Because the inequality is homogeneous we can consider without loss of generality that $a+b+c=1$ and so the inequality is equivalent to

$$
\sum \frac{1}{a(a+1)} \leq \frac{1}{4 a b c}
$$

We have $\frac{1}{t(t+1)}=\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+1}$, so the inequality is equivalent to

$$
\sum \frac{1}{a} \leq \sum \frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{4 a b c}
$$

We will prove now the following intercalation:

$$
\sum \frac{1}{a} \leq \frac{9}{4}+\frac{1}{4 a b c} \leq \sum \frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{4 a b c}
$$

The inequality in the right follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality:

$$
\left(\sum \frac{1}{a+1}\right)\left(\sum(a+1)\right) \geq 9
$$

and the identity $\sum(a+1)=4$. The inequality in the left can be written as $\sum a b \leq$ $\frac{1+9 a b c}{4}$, which is exactly Schur's Inequality.

We have the following chain of inequalities

$$
\sum \frac{a b}{a+b+2 c}=\sum \frac{a b}{a+c+b+c} \leq \sum \frac{a b}{4}\left(\frac{1}{a+c}+\frac{1}{b+c}\right)=\frac{a+b+c}{4}
$$

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c \geq 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{a+1}\right)\left(b+\frac{1}{b+1}\right)\left(c+\frac{1}{c+1}\right) \quad () \quad \frac{27}{8} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By the inequality $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\frac{a+1}{4}+\frac{1}{a+1} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{a+1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{a+1}}=1 \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{3 a}{4}+\frac{3}{4} \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{3 a}{4} \cdot \frac{3}{4}}=\frac{3}{2} \sqrt{a}
$$

Adding these two inequalities we get
$$
a+\frac{1}{a+1} \geq \frac{3}{2} \sqrt{a}
$$

Analogously we obtain
$$
b+\frac{1}{b+1} \geq \frac{3}{2} \sqrt{b} \quad \text { and } \quad c+\frac{1}{c+1} \geq \frac{3}{2} \sqrt{c}
$$

Multiplying the last three inequalities gives us
$$
\left(a+\frac{1}{a+1}\right)\left(b+\frac{1}{b+1}\right)\left(c+\frac{1}{c+1}\right) \geq \frac{27}{8} \sqrt{a b c} \geq \frac{27}{8}
$$
as required.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\sqrt{a+b-c}+\sqrt{c+a-b}+\sqrt{b+c-a} \quad () \quad \sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We'll use Ravi's substitutions, i.e. let $a=x+y, b=y+z, c=z+x$, where $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$.

Now the given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\sqrt{2 x}+\sqrt{2 y}+\sqrt{2 z} \leq \sqrt{x+y}+\sqrt{y+z}+\sqrt{z+x}
$$

By $Q M \geq A M$ we have $\sqrt{\frac{x+y}{2}} \geq \frac{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}}{2}$, from which we deduce that
$$
\sqrt{x+y} \geq \frac{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}}{\sqrt{2}}
$$

Analogously we get
$$
\sqrt{y+z} \geq \frac{\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{z}}{\sqrt{2}} \text { and } \quad \sqrt{z+x} \geq \frac{\sqrt{z}+\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{2}}
$$

After adding these three inequalities we obtain
$$
\sqrt{x+y}+\sqrt{y+z}+\sqrt{z+x} \geq 2 \frac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{2}}+2 \frac{\sqrt{y}}{\sqrt{2}}+2 \frac{\sqrt{z}}{\sqrt{2}}
$$
i.e.
$$
\sqrt{x+y}+\sqrt{y+z}+\sqrt{z+x} \geq \sqrt{2 x}+\sqrt{2 y}+\sqrt{2 z}
$$
as required.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{3 a}{b+c}+\frac{4 b}{c+a}+\frac{5 c}{a+b} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{2}(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{4}+\sqrt{5})^{2}-12
$$
where $k$ is the minimal value of the expression. Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{3 a}{b+c}+\frac{4 b}{c+a}+\frac{5 c}{a+b}+(3+4+5) \\
& \quad=(a+b+c)\left(\frac{3}{b+c}+\frac{4}{c+a}+\frac{5}{a+b}\right) \\
& \quad=\frac{1}{2}((b+c)+(c+a)+(a+b))\left(\frac{3}{b+c}+\frac{4}{c+a}+\frac{5}{a+b}\right) \\
& \geq \frac{1}{2}(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{4}+\sqrt{5})^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence
$$
\frac{3 a}{b+c}+\frac{4 b}{c+a}+\frac{5 c}{a+b} \geq \frac{1}{2}(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{4}+\sqrt{5})^{2}-12
$$

So the minimal value of the expression is $\frac{1}{2}(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{4}+\sqrt{5})^{2}-12$, and it is reached if and only if $\frac{b+c}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{c+a}{2}=\frac{a+b}{\sqrt{5}}$.

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \geq 0$ be real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 1$. Consider the expression
$$
A = a + b + c + \frac{1}{abc}.
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation for the minimal value of $A$.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
A=a+b+c+\frac{1}{a b c} \geq 4 \sqrt[4]{a b c \cdot \frac{1}{a b c}}=4
$$
with equality iff $a=b=c=\frac{1}{a b c}$, i.e. $a=b=c=1$.
Thus $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=3 \neq 1$, a contradiction.
Since $A$ is a symmetrical expression in $a, b$ and $c$, we estimate that $\min A$ occurs at the incidence point $a=b=c$, i.e. $a=b=c=1 / \sqrt{3}$.

Hence at the incidence point we have $a=b=c=\frac{1}{\alpha a b c}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$, and it follows that $\alpha=\frac{1}{a^{2} b c}=\frac{1}{(1 / \sqrt{3})^{4}}=9$.

Therefore
$$
\begin{align*}
A & =a+b+c+\frac{1}{a b c}=a+b+c+\frac{1}{9 a b c}+\frac{8}{9 a b c} \\
& \geq 4 \sqrt[4]{a b c \cdot \frac{1}{9 a b c}}+\frac{8}{9 a b c}=4 \sqrt[4]{\frac{1}{9}}+\frac{8}{9 a b c} \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

By $Q M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a b c}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad \sqrt{\frac{1}{3}} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a b c}
$$

Hence
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{a b c} \geq 3 \sqrt{3} \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

By (1) and (2) we get
$$
A \geq \frac{4}{\sqrt{3}}+3 \sqrt{3} \cdot \frac{8}{9}=4 \sqrt{3}
$$

So $\min A=4 \sqrt{3}$, and it occurs iff $a=b=c=1 / \sqrt{3}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ with $a + b + c = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a^{2}+b}{b+c}+\frac{b^{2}+c}{c+a}+\frac{c^{2}+a}{a+b} \quad () \quad 2
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality, we find that

$$
\sum \frac{a^{2}+b}{b+c} \geq \frac{\left(\sum a^{2}+1\right)^{2}}{\sum a^{2}(b+c)+\sum a^{2}+\sum a b}
$$

And so it is enough to prove that

$$
\frac{\left(\sum a^{2}+1\right)^{2}}{\sum a^{2}(b+c)+\sum a^{2}+\sum a b} \geq 2 \Leftrightarrow 1+\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2} \geq 2 \sum a^{2}(b+c)+2 \sum a b
$$

The last inequality can be transformed as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2} & \geq 2 \sum a^{2}(b+c)+2 \sum a b \Leftrightarrow 1+\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2} \geq \\
& \geq 2 \sum a^{2}-2 \sum a^{3}+2 \sum a b \Leftrightarrow\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2}+2 \sum a^{3} \geq \sum a^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and it is true, because

$$
\sum a^{3} \geq \frac{\sum a^{2}}{3}(\text { Chebyshev's Inequality })
$$

and

$$
\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{\sum a^{2}}{3}
$$

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = x y z$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
x y + y z + z x \quad () \quad 2(x + y + z) + 9
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Note that $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=x y z$ implies $x^{2}<x y z$, i.e. $x<y z$; analogously $y<z x$ and $z<x y$.

So $x y<y z \cdot z x$, i.e. $z^{2}>1$, from which we deduce that $z>1$; analogously $x>1$ and $y>1$. So all three numbers are greater than 1 .

Let's denote $a=x-1, b=y-1, c=z-1$. Then $a, b, c>0$ and clearly $x=$ $a+1, y=b+1, z=c+1$.

Now the initial condition $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=x y z$ becomes
$$
\begin{equation*}
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a+b+c+2=a b c+a b+b c+c a \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

If we set $q=a b+b c+c a$ we have
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq q, \quad a+b+c \geq \sqrt{3 q} \quad \text { and } \quad a b c \leq\left(\frac{q}{3}\right)^{3 / 2}=\frac{(3 q)^{3 / 2}}{27}
$$

Finally by (1) and the last three inequalities we obtain
$$
q+\sqrt{3 q}+2 \leq a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a+b+c+2=a b c+a b+b c+c a \leq \frac{(3 q)^{3 / 2}}{27}+q
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\sqrt{3 q}+2 \leq \frac{(3 q)^{3 / 2}}{27} \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Denote $\sqrt{3 q}=A$. Then inequality (2) is equivalent to
$$
A+2 \leq \frac{A^{3}}{27} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(A-6)(A+3)^{2} \geq 0
$$
from which we deduce that we must have $\sqrt{3 q}=A \geq 6$, i.e. $q \geq 12$.

Hence
$a b+b c+c a \geq 12 \Leftrightarrow(x-1)(y-1)+(y-1)(z-1)+(z-1)(x-1) \geq 12$,
from which we obtain $x y+y z+z x \geq 2(x+y+z)+9$, and we are done.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c=1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\sqrt{a+b c}+\sqrt{b+c a}+\sqrt{c+a b} \quad () \quad 2 .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $a+b+c=1$ we have $a+b c=a(a+b+c)+b c=(a+b)(a+c)$ i.e.
$$
\sqrt{a+b c}=\sqrt{(a+b)(a+c)} \leq \frac{(a+b)+(a+c)}{2}=\frac{2 a+b+c}{2}
$$

Similarly we obtain
$$
\sqrt{b+c a} \leq \frac{2 b+c+a}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \sqrt{c+a b} \leq \frac{2 c+a+b}{2}
$$

After adding the last three inequalities, we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
\sqrt{a+b c}+\sqrt{b+c a}+\sqrt{c+a b} & \leq \frac{2 a+b+c}{2}+\frac{2 b+c+a}{2}+\frac{2 c+a+b}{2} \\
& =2(a+b+c)=2
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $x + y + z = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{2}+\left(1-y^{2}\right)^{2}+\left(1-z^{2}\right)^{2} \quad () \quad (1+x)(1+y)(1+z)
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $p=x+y+z=1, q=x y+y z+z x, r=x y z$.
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
3-2\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4} \leq(1+x)(1+y)(1+z)
$$

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} & =p^{2}-2 q=1-2 q \\
x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4} & =\left(p^{2}-2 q\right)^{2}-2\left(q^{2}-2 p r\right)=(1-2 q)^{2}-2\left(q^{2}-2 r\right) \\
(1+x)(1+y)(1+z) & =1+p+q+r=2+q+r
\end{aligned}
$$

So we need to show that
$$
3-2(1-2 q)+(1-2 q)^{2}-2\left(q^{2}-2 r\right) \leq 2+q+r
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3-2+4 q+1-4 q+4 q^{2}-2 q^{2}+4 r \leq 2+q+r \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 2 q^{2}-q+3 r \leq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

We have
$$
\begin{equation*}
3 q \leq p^{2}=1, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad q \leq \frac{1}{3} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$
and
$$
\begin{equation*}
p q \geq 9 r, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad q \geq 9 r, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad r \leq \frac{q}{9} \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

By (2) we have
$$
2 q^{2}-q+3 r \leq 2 q^{2}-q+3 \frac{q}{9}=2 q\left(q-\frac{1}{3}\right) \leq 0
$$

The last inequality is true due to (1) and the fact that $q \geq 0$, so we are done.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \geq 0$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\sqrt{a^{4}+a^{2} b^{2}+b^{4}}+\sqrt{b^{4}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{4}}+\sqrt{c^{4}+c^{2} a^{2}+a^{4}} \quad () \quad a \sqrt{2 a^{2}+b c}+b \sqrt{2 b^{2}+c a}+c \sqrt{2 c^{2}+a b}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We start from $\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right)^{2} \geq 0$. We rewrite it as $4 a^{4}+4 a^{2} b^{2}+4 b^{4} \geq 3 a^{4}+6 a^{2} b^{2}+3 b^{4}$. It follows that $\sqrt{a^{4}+a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2}} \geq \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)$.

Using this observation, we find that

$$
\left(\sum \sqrt{a^{4}+a^{2} b^{2}+b^{4}}\right)^{2} \geq 3\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

But using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality we obtain

$$
\left(\sum a \sqrt{2 a^{2}+b c}\right)^{2} \leq\left(\sum a^{2}\right)\left(\sum\left(2 a^{2}+b c\right)\right) \leq 3\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

and the inequality is proved.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
3\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)^{2} \quad () \quad \left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{3}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By Hlder's inequality we obtain
$$
\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)(1+1+1) \geq\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{3}
$$
i.e.
$$
3\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)^{2} \geq\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{3}
$$

Theorem 54.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n} ; m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}$ be three sequences of positive real numbers and let $p>1$. Then
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{p} m_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be non-negative real numbers such that $x + y + z = 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
x y + y z + z x - 2 x y z \quad () \quad \frac{7}{27}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $f(x, y, z)=x y+y z+z x-2 x y z$.
Without loss of generality we may assume that $0 \leq x \leq y \leq z \leq 1$.
Since $x+y+z=1$ we have
$$
\begin{equation*}
3 x \leq x+y+z=1, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad x \leq \frac{1}{3}
\end{equation*}
$$

Furthermore we have
$$
f(x, y, z)=(1-3 x) y z+x y+z x+x y z \stackrel{(1)}{\geq} 0
$$
and we are done with the left inequality.
It remains to prove the right inequality.
Since $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
y z \leq\left(\frac{y+z}{2}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{1-x}{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Since $1-2 x>0$ we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x, y, z) & =x(y+z)+y z(1-2 x) \leq x(1-x)+\left(\frac{1-x}{2}\right)^{2}(1-2 x) \\
& =\frac{-2 x^{3}+x^{2}+1}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

We'll show that
$$
f(x)=\frac{-2 x^{3}+x^{2}+1}{4} \leq \frac{7}{27}, \quad \text { for all } x \in\left[0, \frac{1}{3}\right]
$$

We have
$$
f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{-6 x^{2}+2 x}{4}=\frac{3 x}{2}\left(\frac{1}{3}-x\right) \geq 0, \quad \text { for all } x \in\left[0, \frac{1}{3}\right]
$$

Thus $f$ is an increasing function on $\left[0, \frac{1}{3}\right]$, so it follows that
$$
f(x) \leq f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)=\frac{7}{27}, \quad x \in\left[0, \frac{1}{3}\right]
$$
as required.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 a b c+3 \quad () \quad (1+a)(1+b)(1+c)
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $f(a, b, c)=a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b c+2-a-b-c-a b-b c-c a$. We have to prove that all values of $f$ are nonnegative. If $a, b, c>3$, then we clearly have $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}<1$, which means that $f(a, b, c)>a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2-a-b-c>0$. So, we may assume that $a \leq 3$ and let $m=\frac{b+c}{2}$. Easy computations show that $f(a, b, c)-f(a, m, m)=$ $\frac{(3-a)(b-c)^{2}}{4} \geq 0$ and so it remains to prove that $f(a, m, m) \geq 0$, which is the same as

$$
(a+1) m^{2}-2(a+1) m+a^{2}-a+2 \geq 0
$$

This is clearly true, because the discriminant of the quadratic equation is $-4(a+$ 1) $(a-1)^{2} \leq 0$.

problem:
Let $x > 0$ be a real number. Consider the following expressions:
$$
x - \frac{x^2}{2} \quad () \quad \ln(x+1)
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let us consider the functions
$$
f(x)=\ln (x+1) \quad \text { and } \quad g(x)=x-\frac{x^{2}}{2} \quad \text { on the interval }[0, \alpha), \text { where } \alpha \in \mathbb{R}
$$

We have
$$
f(0)=0=g(0) \quad \text { and } \quad f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{1+x}, \quad g^{\prime}(x)=1-x
$$

For $x \in(0, \alpha)$ it follows that $\frac{1}{1+x}>1-x$, i.e.
$$
f^{\prime}(x)>g^{\prime}(x), \quad \text { for all } x \in(0, \alpha)
$$

According to Theorem 13.2 we have $f(x)>g(x)$, for all $x \in(0, \alpha)$ i.e.
$$
\ln (x+1)>x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}, \quad x \in(0, \alpha)
$$

Since $\alpha$ is arbitrary we conclude that $\ln (x+1)>x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}$, for all $x \in(0, \infty)$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{(2 a+b+c)^{2}}{2 a^{2}+(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{(2 b+a+c)^{2}}{2 b^{2}+(a+c)^{2}}+\frac{(2 c+a+b)^{2}}{2 c^{2}+(a+b)^{2}} \quad () \quad 8 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Because the inequality is homogeneous, we can assume that $a+b+c=3$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{(2 a+b+c)^{2}}{2 a^{2}+(b+c)^{2}} & =\frac{a^{2}+6 a+9}{3 a^{2}-6 a+9}=\frac{1}{3}\left(1+2 \cdot \frac{4 a+3}{2+(a-1)^{2}}\right) \leq \\
& \leq \frac{1}{3}\left(1+2 \cdot \frac{4 a+3}{2}\right)=\frac{4 a+4}{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus

$$
\sum \frac{(2 a+b+c)^{2}}{2 a^{2}+(b+c)^{2}} \leq \frac{1}{3} \sum(4 a+4)=8
$$

Denote $x=\frac{b+c}{a}, y=\frac{c+a}{b}, z=\frac{a+b}{c}$. We have to prove that

$$
\sum \frac{(x+2)^{2}}{x^{2}+2} \leq 8 \Leftrightarrow \sum \frac{2 x+1}{x^{2}+2} \leq \frac{5}{2} \Leftrightarrow \sum \frac{(x-1)^{2}}{x^{2}+2} \geq \frac{1}{2}
$$

But, from the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality, we have

$$
\sum \frac{(x-1)^{2}}{x^{2}+2} \geq \frac{(x+y+z-3)^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+6}
$$

It remains to prove that

$$
\begin{gathered}
2\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+2 x y+2 y z+2 z x-6 x-6 y-6 z+9\right) \geq x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+6 \Leftrightarrow \\
\Leftrightarrow x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+4(x y+y z+z x)-12(x+y+z)+12 \geq 0
\end{gathered}
$$

Now $x y+y z+z x \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{x^{2} y^{2} z^{2}} \geq 12$ (because $x y z \geq 8$ ), so we still have to prove that $(x+y+z)^{2}+24-12(x+y+z)+12 \geq 0$, which is equivalent to $(x+y+z-6)^{2} \geq 0$, clearly true.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{x^{2}+x y+y^{2}}+\frac{1}{y^{2}+y z+z^{2}}+\frac{1}{z^{2}+z x+x^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{9}{(x+y+z)^{2}} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
It is true that $x^{2}+x y+y^{2}=(x+y+z)^{2}-(x y+y z+z x)-(x+y+z) z$.
Now we have
$$
\frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{x^{2}+x y+y^{2}}=\frac{1}{1-\frac{x y+y z+z x}{(x+y+z)^{2}}-\frac{z}{x+y+z}}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{x^{2}+x y+y^{2}}=\frac{1}{1-(a b+b c+c a)-c}
$$
where $a=\frac{x}{x+y+z}, b=\frac{y}{x+y+z}, c=\frac{z}{x+y+z}$.
The given inequality can be written in the form
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{1-d-c}+\frac{1}{1-d-b}+\frac{1}{1-d-a} \geq 9 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$
where $a, b, c$ are positive real numbers such that
$$
a+b+c=1 \quad \text { and } \quad d=a b+b c+c a
$$

After clearing the denominators, inequality (1) becomes
$$
9d^{3}-6 d^{2}-3 d+1+9 a b c \geq 0 \quad \text { or } \quad d(3 d-1)^{2}+(1-4 d+9 a b c) \geq 0
$$
which is true since $1-4 d+9 a b c \geq 0$ (the last inequality is a direct consequences of Schur's inequality).

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c = 2$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \quad () \quad a \sqrt{b+c}+b \sqrt{c+a}+c \sqrt{a+b}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have

$$
a \sqrt{b+c}+b \sqrt{c+a}+c \sqrt{a+b} \leq \sqrt{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(a+b+c)}
$$

Using Chebyshev Inequality, we infer that

$$
\sqrt{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(a+b+c)} \leq \sqrt{6\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}
$$

and so it is enough to prove that $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \geq 3 a b c$, which is true by the AM-GM Inequality. We have equality if $a=b=c=\sqrt[3]{2}$.

$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{3^{3}}+\frac{b^{2}}{4^{3}}+\frac{c^{2}}{5^{3}} \quad () \quad \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{6^{3}} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Note that $3^{3}+4^{3}+5^{3}=6^{3}$.
Taking
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{1}=\frac{a}{\sqrt{3^{3}}}, \quad a_{2}=\frac{b}{\sqrt{4^{3}}}, \quad a_{3}=\frac{c}{\sqrt{5^{3}}} ; \\
& b_{1}=\sqrt{3^{3}}, \quad b_{2}=\sqrt{4^{3}}, \quad b_{3}=\sqrt{5^{3}},
\end{aligned}
$$
by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we obtain
$$
\left(\frac{a^{2}}{3^{3}}+\frac{b^{2}}{4^{3}}+\frac{c^{2}}{5^{3}}\right)\left(3^{3}+4^{3}+5^{3}\right) \geq(a+b+c)^{2}
$$
as required.

Theorem 30.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be non-negative real numbers, and let $n$ be a positive integer. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (n-1)\left(a_{1}^{n}+a_{2}^{n}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n}\right)+n a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n} \\
& \quad \geq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(a_{1}^{n-1}+a_{2}^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > -1$ be real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1+x^{2}}{1+y+z^{2}}+\frac{1+y^{2}}{1+z+x^{2}}+\frac{1+z^{2}}{1+x+y^{2}} \quad () \quad 2 .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let us observe that $y \leq \frac{1+y^{2}}{2}$ and $1+y+z^{2}>0$, so

$$
\frac{1+x^{2}}{1+y+z^{2}} \geq \frac{1+x^{2}}{1+z^{2}+\frac{1+y^{2}}{2}}
$$

and the similar relations. Setting $a=1+x^{2}, b=1+y^{2}, c=1+z^{2}$, it is sufficient to prove that

$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{a}{2 c+b}+\frac{b}{2 a+c}+\frac{c}{2 b+a} \geq 1 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

for any $a, b, c>0$. Let $A=2 c+b, B=2 a+c, C=2 b+a$. Then $a=\frac{C+4 B-2 A}{9}$, $b=\frac{A+4 C-2 B}{9}, c=\frac{B+4 A-2 C}{9}$ and the inequality (1) is rewritten as

$$
\frac{C}{A}+\frac{A}{B}+\frac{B}{C}+4\left(\frac{B}{A}+\frac{C}{B}+\frac{A}{C}\right) \geq 15
$$

Because $A, B, C>0$, we have from the AM-GM Inequality that

$$
\frac{C}{A}+\frac{A}{B}+\frac{B}{C} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{A}{B} \cdot \frac{B}{C} \cdot \frac{C}{A}}=3
$$

and $\frac{B}{A}+\frac{C}{B}+\frac{A}{C} \geq 3$ and the conclusion follows.
An alternative solution for (1) is by using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality:

$$
\frac{a}{2 c+b}+\frac{b}{2 a+c}+\frac{c}{2 b+a}=\frac{a^{2}}{2 a c+a b}+\frac{b^{2}}{2 a b+c b}+\frac{c^{2}}{2 b c+a c} \geq \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{3(a b+b c+c a)} \geq 1
$$

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c = \sqrt{a b c}$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a b + b c + c a \quad () \quad 9(a + b + c)
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By the inequality $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\sqrt{a b c}=a+b+c \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a b c}
$$
which implies
$$
\begin{equation*}
a b c \geq 3^{6} \quad \text { and } \quad a+b+c=\sqrt{a b c} \geq \sqrt{3^{6}}=3^{3} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Once more, the inequality $A M \geq G M$ gives us
$$
a b+b c+c a \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}}
$$
i.e.
$$
(a b+b c+c a)^{3} \geq 3^{3}(a b c)^{2}=3^{3}(a+b+c)^{4} \stackrel{(1)}{\geq} 3^{6}(a+b+c)^{3}
$$

Hence
$$
a b+b c+c a \geq 9(a+b+c)
$$
as required.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=9$.

Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4} \quad () \quad a b c(a+b+c) .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have that: If $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}$ then
$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} \geq x y+y z+z x
$$

Therefore
$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4} & \geq a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}=(a b)^{2}+(b c)^{2}+(c a)^{2} \\
& \geq(a b)(b c)+(b c)(c a)+(c a)(a b)=a b c(a+b+c)
\end{aligned}
$$

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{x}{x+\sqrt{(x+y)(x+z)}}+\frac{y}{y+\sqrt{(y+z)(y+x)}}+\frac{z}{z+\sqrt{(z+x)(z+y)}} \quad () \quad 1 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Rewrite the given inequality as follows
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{\frac{(x+y)(x+z)}{x^{2}}}}+\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{\frac{(y+z)(y+x)}{y^{2}}}}+\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{\frac{(z+x)(z+y)}{z^{2}}}} \leq 1 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since this is homogenous we may take $x y+y z+z x=1$.
Therefore by Case 3, we can take
$$
a=\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}, \quad b=\tan \frac{\beta}{2}, \quad c=\tan \frac{\gamma}{2}
$$
where $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle.
We have
$$
\frac{(x+y)(x+z)}{x^{2}}=\frac{\left(\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}+\tan \frac{\beta}{2}\right)\left(\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}+\tan \frac{\gamma}{2}\right)}{\tan ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}}=\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}}
$$

Similarly
$$
\frac{(y+z)(y+x)}{y^{2}}=\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \frac{\beta}{2}} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{(z+x)(z+y)}{z^{2}}=\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \frac{\gamma}{2}}
$$

Thus inequality ( 1 ) becomes
$$
\frac{\sin \frac{\alpha}{2}}{1+\sin \frac{\alpha}{2}}+\frac{\sin \frac{\beta}{2}}{1+\sin \frac{\beta}{2}}+\frac{\sin \frac{\gamma}{2}}{1+\sin \frac{\gamma}{2}} \leq 1
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\alpha}{2}}+\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\beta}{2}}+\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\gamma}{2}} \geq 2 \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since $A M \geq H M$ we obtain
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\alpha}{2}}+\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\beta}{2}}+\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\gamma}{2}} \geq \frac{9}{3+\sin \frac{\alpha}{2}+\sin \frac{\beta}{2}+\sin \frac{\gamma}{2}} \tag{3}
\end{equation*}
$$

According to $N_{3}$, we have that $\sin \frac{\alpha}{2}+\sin \frac{\beta}{2}+\sin \frac{\gamma}{2} \leq \frac{3}{2}$.
Finally, by the previous inequality and (3) we obtain
$$
\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\alpha}{2}}+\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\beta}{2}}+\frac{1}{1+\sin \frac{\gamma}{2}} \geq \frac{9}{3+\frac{3}{2}}=2
$$
as required.

Theorem 45.Theorem:
Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi)$. Then $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are the angles of a triangle if and only if
$$
\sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\beta}{2}+\sin ^{2} \frac{\gamma}{2}+2 \sin \frac{\alpha}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\beta}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\gamma}{2}=1
$$

problem:
Given are positive real numbers $a, b, c$ and $x, y, z$, for which $a + x = b + y = c + z = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
(a b c + x y z) \left( \frac{1}{a y} + \frac{1}{b z} + \frac{1}{c x} \right) \quad () \quad 3
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let us observe that $a b c+x y z=(1-b)(1-c)+a c+a b-a$. Thus,

$$
\frac{1-c}{a}+\frac{c}{1-b}-1=\frac{a b c+x y z}{a(1-b)}
$$

Using these identities we deduce immediately that
$3+(x y z+a b c)\left(\frac{1}{a y}+\frac{1}{b z}+\frac{1}{c x}\right)=\frac{a}{1-c}+\frac{b}{1-a}+\frac{c}{1-b}+\frac{1-c}{a}+\frac{1-a}{b}+\frac{1-b}{c}$.
Now, all we have to do is apply the AM-GM Inequality

$$
\frac{a}{1-c}+\frac{b}{1-a}+\frac{c}{1-b}+\frac{1-c}{a}+\frac{1-a}{b}+\frac{1-b}{c} \geq 6
$$

problem:
Let $x, y, z \leq 1$ be real numbers such that $x + y + z = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{1+x^{2}}+\frac{1}{1+y^{2}}+\frac{1}{1+z^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{27}{10} .

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(C) $=$

(F) None of the above

Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}+d^{4}+2 a b c d \quad () \quad a^{2} b^{2}+a^{2} c^{2}+a^{2} d^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+b^{2} d^{2}+c^{2} d^{2} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Because of symmetry without loss of generality we can assume $a \geq b \geq$ $c \geq d$.

Let $x=\ln a, y=\ln b, z=\ln c, t=\ln d$; then clearly $x \geq y \geq z \geq t$ and given inequality becomes
$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{4 x} & +e^{4 y}+e^{4 z}+e^{4 t}+e^{x+y+z+t}+e^{x+y+z+t} \\
& \geq e^{2(x+y)}+e^{2(x+z)}+e^{2(x+t)}+e^{2(y+z)}+e^{2(y+t)}+e^{2(z+t)}
\end{aligned}
$$

The function $f(x)=e^{x}$ is a convex on $\mathbb{R}$, so according to Karamata's inequality it suffices to prove that $(4 x, 4 y, 4 z, 4 t, x+y+z+t, x+y+z+t)$ (ordered in some way) majorizes the sequences $(2(x+y), 2(x+z), 2(x+t), 2(y+z), 2(y+t)$, $2(z+t)$ ) (ordered in some way).

Clearly $4 x \geq 4 y \geq 4 z$ and $4 x \geq x+y+z+t \geq 4 t$.
We need to consider four cases:
If $4 z \geq x+y+z+t$ then we can easily show that
$$
2(x+y) \geq 2(x+z) \geq 2(y+z) \geq 2(x+t) \geq 2(y+t) \geq 2(z+t)
$$
and we can check that the sequence $(4 x, 4 y, 4 z, x+y+z+t, x+y+z+t, 4 t)$ majorize the sequence $(2(x+y), 2(x+z), 2(y+z), 2(x+t), 2(y+t), 2(z+t))$.

The cases when $x+y+z+t \geq 4 z, 4 y \geq x+y+z+t$ or $x+y+z+t \geq 4 y$ are analogous as the first case and therefore are left to the reader.

Theorem 68.Theorem:
Let $f: I \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on the interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and let $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n},\left(b_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$, where $a_{i}, b_{i} \in I, i=$ $1,2, \ldots, n$, are two sequences, such that $\left(a_{i}\right) \succ\left(b_{i}\right)$. Then
$$
f\left(a_{1}\right)+f\left(a_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(a_{n}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}\right)+f\left(b_{2}\right)+\cdots+f\left(b_{n}\right)
$$

problem:

$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

(A) $\leq$

(C) $=$

Theorem 48.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $p, q>1$ be such that $1 / p+1 / q=1$.
Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}=1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n}} \quad () \quad a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Applying $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
\frac{\sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n}}}{n} \geq \sqrt[n]{\sqrt{a_{1}} \sqrt{a_{2}} \cdots \sqrt{a_{n}}}=1
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n}} \geq n \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Now we'll use the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.
We have
$$
\left(\sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n}}\right)^{2} \leq\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)(1+1+\cdots+1)
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\left(\sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n}}\right)^{2} \leq n\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right) \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Using (1) and (2) gives us
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n}}\right)^{2} \leq & n\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right) \leq\left(\sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n}}\right) \\
& \times\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
\sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n}} \leq a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}
$$
as required.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n}$ be real numbers such that $x_{1}^{2}+\cdots+x_{n}^{2}=1$ and $y_{1}^{2}+\cdots+y_{n}^{2}=1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\left(x_{1} y_{2}-x_{2} y_{1}\right)^{2} \quad () \quad 2\left(1-\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k} y_{k}\right)
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We clearly have the inequality

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(x_{1} y_{2}-x_{2} y_{1}\right)^{2} \leq \sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n}\left(x_{i} y_{j}-x_{j} y_{i}\right)^{2} & =\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} y_{i}^{2}\right)-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i} y_{i}\right)^{2}= \\
& =\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i} y_{i}\right)\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i} y_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Because we also have $\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i} y_{i}\right| \leq 1$, we find immediately that

$$
\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i} y_{i}\right)\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i} y_{i}\right) \leq 2\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i} y_{i}\right)
$$

and the problem is solved.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c + d = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
16(a b c + b c d + c d a + d a b) \quad () \quad 1 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We'll show that
$$
16(a b c+b c d+c d a+d a b) \leq(a+b+c+d)^{3}
$$

Applying $A M \geq G M$ gives us
$$
\begin{aligned}
16(a b c+b c d+c d a+d a b) & =16 a b(c+d)+16 c d(a+b) \\
& \leq 4(a+b)^{2}(c+d)+4(c+d)^{2}(a+b) \\
& =4(c+d)(a+b)(a+b+c+d) \\
& \leq(a+b+c+d)^{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

It is obvious that equality holds if and only if $a=b=c=d=1 / 4$.
