problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c+1=4 a b c$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{a^{4}+b+c}+\frac{1}{b^{4}+c+a}+\frac{1}{c^{4}+a+b} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{a+b+c} .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\frac{1}{a^{4}+b+c}=\frac{1+b^{3}+c^{3}}{\left(a^{4}+b+c\right)\left(1+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)} \leq \frac{1+b^{3}+c^{3}}{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}}
$$

Similarly we get
$$
\frac{1}{b^{4}+c+a} \leq \frac{1+c^{3}+b^{3}}{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{c^{4}+a+b} \leq \frac{1+a^{3}+b^{3}}{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}}
$$

After adding the last three inequalities we obtain
$$
\frac{1}{a^{4}+b+c}+\frac{1}{b^{4}+c+a}+\frac{1}{c^{4}+a+b} \leq \frac{3+2\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}}
$$
so it suffices to prove that
$$
\frac{3+2\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}} \leq \frac{3}{a+b+c}
$$
i.e.
$$
3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2} \geq(a+b+c)\left(3+2\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)\right)
$$

Let $a+b+c=p, a b+b c+c a=q$ and $a b c=r$.
Then since $a+b+c+1=4 a b c$, by $A M \geq G M$ it follows that
$$
4 r=a+b+c+1 \geq 4 \sqrt[4]{r}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad r \geq 1
$$

Now we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & =3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}-(a+b+c)\left(3+2\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)\right) \\
& =3\left(p^{2}-2 q\right)^{2}-p\left(3+2 p\left(p^{2}-3 q\right)+6 r\right) \\
& =3\left(p^{2}-2 q\right)^{2}-3 p-2 p^{2}\left(p^{2}-3 q\right)-6 p r \\
& =3 p^{4}-12 p^{2} q+12 q^{2}-3 p-2 p^{4}+6 p^{2} q-6 p r \\
& =p^{4}-6 p^{2} q+12 q^{2}-3 p-6 p r \\
& =\left(p^{2}-3 q\right)^{2}+q^{2}-3 p+2\left(q^{2}-3 p r\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $r \geq 1$ we have $q^{2}-3 p \geq q^{2}-3 p r$ and it follows that
$$
A=\left(p^{2}-3 q\right)^{2}+q^{2}-3 p+2\left(q^{2}-3 p r\right) \geq\left(p^{2}-3 q\right)^{2}+3\left(q^{2}-3 p r\right)
$$

According to $N_{7}: q^{2}-3 p r \geq 0$ we deduce that
$$
A \geq\left(p^{2}-3 q\right)^{2}+3\left(q^{2}-3 p r\right) \geq 0
$$
as required.

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b c(a+b+c)=3$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \quad () \quad 8 .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & =(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)=\left(a b+a c+b^{2}+b c\right)(c+a) \\
& =(b(a+b+c)+a c)(c+a)=\left(\frac{3}{a c}+a c\right)(c+a)
\end{aligned}
$$

By $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & =\left(\frac{3}{a c}+a c\right)(c+a)=\left(\frac{1}{a c}+\frac{1}{a c}+\frac{1}{a c}+a c\right)(c+a) \\
& \geq 4 \sqrt[4]{\frac{a c}{(a c)^{3}}} \cdot 2 \sqrt{a c}=4 \frac{1}{\sqrt{a c}} \cdot 2 \sqrt{a c}=8
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality occurs iff $a=c$ and $\frac{1}{a c}=a c$, i.e. $a=c=1$, and then we easily get $b=1$.

problem:
Let $n > 3$ and $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n} > 0$ have product 1. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{1+x_{1}+x_{1} x_{2}}+\frac{1}{1+x_{2}+x_{2} x_{3}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{1+x_{n}+x_{n} x_{1}} \quad () \quad 1
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We use a similar form of the classical substitution $x_{1}=\frac{a_{2}}{a_{1}}, x_{2}=\frac{a_{3}}{a_{2}}, \ldots, x_{n}=\frac{a_{1}}{a_{n}}$. In this case the inequality becomes

$$
\frac{a_{1}}{a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}}+\frac{a_{2}}{a_{2}+a_{3}+a_{4}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{a_{n}+a_{1}+a_{2}}>1
$$

and it is clear, because $n>3$ and $a_{i}+a_{i+1}+a_{i+2}<a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}$ for all $i$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d > 0$ be real numbers. Consider the following expression:
$$
A=\left(1+\frac{2 a}{3 b}\right)\left(1+\frac{2 b}{3 c}\right)\left(1+\frac{2 c}{3 d}\right)\left(1+\frac{2 d}{3 a}\right)
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation between $A$ and its minimal value.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
A \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{2 a}{3 b}} \cdot 2 \sqrt{\frac{2 b}{3 c}} \cdot 2 \sqrt{\frac{2 c}{3 d}} \cdot 2 \sqrt{\frac{2 d}{3 a}}=8
$$
with equality if and only if $\frac{2 a}{3 b}=\frac{2 b}{3 c}=\frac{2 c}{3 d}=\frac{2 d}{3 a}=1$.
Hence $2(a+b+c+d)=3(a+b+c+d)$, i.e. $2=3$, which is impossible.
Since $A$ is a symmetrical expression in $a, b, c$ and $d$, the minimum (maximum) occurs at the incidence point $a=b=c=d>0$, and then
$$
A=\left(1+\frac{2}{3}\right)^{4}=\frac{625}{81}
$$

We have
$$
1+\frac{2 a}{3 b}=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{3}+\frac{a}{3 b}+\frac{a}{3 b} \geq 5 \sqrt[5]{\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{3}\left(\frac{a}{3 b}\right)^{2}}=\frac{5}{3}\left(\frac{a}{b}\right)^{2 / 5}
$$

Similarly we get
$$
1+\frac{2 b}{3 c} \geq \frac{5}{3}\left(\frac{b}{c}\right)^{2 / 5}, \quad 1+\frac{2 c}{3 d} \geq \frac{5}{3}\left(\frac{c}{d}\right)^{2 / 5} \quad \text { and } \quad 1+\frac{2 d}{3 a} \geq \frac{5}{3}\left(\frac{d}{a}\right)^{2 / 5}
$$

If we multiply the above inequalities we obtain $A \geq \frac{625}{81}$.
Equality holds if and only if $a=b=c=d>0$.

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c=6$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\sqrt[3]{a b+b c}+\sqrt[3]{b c+c a}+\sqrt[3]{c a+a b} \quad () \quad 6
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
The given inequality is equivalent to
$$
\sqrt[3]{b(a+c)}+\sqrt[3]{c(b+a)}+\sqrt[3]{a(c+b)} \leq 6
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\sqrt[3]{b(6-b)}+\sqrt[3]{c(6-c)}+\sqrt[3]{a(6-a)} \leq 6 \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since at the point of incidence $a=b=c=2$ we have $2 a=6-a=4$ by $A M \geq G M$ we deduce
$$
\sqrt[3]{a(6-a)}=\frac{\sqrt[3]{2 a \cdot(6-a) \cdot 4}}{2} \leq \frac{2 a+6-a+4}{6}=\frac{a+10}{6}
$$

Analogously we obtain
$$
\sqrt[3]{b(6-b)} \leq \frac{b+10}{6} \quad \text { and } \sqrt[3]{c(6-c)} \leq \frac{c+10}{6}
$$

After adding the last three inequalities we get
$$
\sqrt[3]{b(6-b)}+\sqrt[3]{c(6-c)}+\sqrt[3]{a(6-a)} \leq \frac{a+b+c+30}{6}=\frac{36}{6}=6
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c=2$.

Since we have a symmetrical expression we estimate that the maximum value of $\sqrt[3]{a b+b c}+\sqrt[3]{b c+c a}+\sqrt[3]{c a+a b}$ will occur at the point of incidence $a=b=c=2$ and then clearly we have $a b+b c=8$.

By the inequality $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\sqrt[3]{a b+b c}=\frac{\sqrt[3]{(a b+b c) \cdot 8 \cdot 8}}{4} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{(a b+b c)+8+8}{3}\right)
$$

Similarly we obtain
$\sqrt[3]{b c+c a} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{(b c+c a)+8+8}{3}\right) \quad$ and $\quad \sqrt[3]{c a+a b} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{(c a+a b)+8+8}{3}\right)$.
Adding the last three inequalities gives us
$$
\begin{equation*}
\sqrt[3]{a b+b c}+\sqrt[3]{b c+c a}+\sqrt[3]{c a+a b} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{2(a b+b c+c a)+48}{3}\right) \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since $a b+b c+c a \leq \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{3}=12$ by (1) we get
$$
\sqrt[3]{a b+b c}+\sqrt[3]{b c+c a}+\sqrt[3]{c a+a b} \leq \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{24+48}{3}\right)=6
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a b+b c=b c+c a=c a+a b=8$, i.e. $a=b=c=2$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{2} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $f(a, b, c)=\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}$.
We have
$$
\begin{align*}
& f(a, b, c)-f\left(\frac{a+b}{2}, \frac{a+b}{2}, c\right) \\
& \quad=\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}-\left(\frac{a+b}{a+b+2 c}+\frac{a+b}{a+b+2 c}+\frac{c}{a+b}\right) \\
& \quad=\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}-\frac{2(a+b)}{a+b+2 c}=\frac{a^{3}+c a^{2}+c b^{2}+b^{3}-2 a b c-a b^{2}-a^{2} b}{(b+c)(a+c)(a+b+2 c)} \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

Since $A M \geq G M$ we obtain
$$
\begin{align*}
a^{3}+c a^{2}+c b^{2}+b^{3}= & \frac{a^{3}+a^{3}+b^{3}}{3}+\frac{a^{3}+b^{3}+b^{3}}{3} \\
& +c a^{2}+c b^{2} \geq a^{2} b+a b^{2}+2 a b c \tag{2}
\end{align*}
$$

From (1) and (2) it follows that
$$
f(a, b, c)-f\left(\frac{a+b}{2}, \frac{a+b}{2}, c\right) \geq 0
$$
i.e.
$$
f(a, b, c) \geq f\left(\frac{a+b}{2}, \frac{a+b}{2}, c\right)
$$

Therefore by the SMV theorem it suffices to prove that $f(t, t, c) \geq \frac{3}{2}$.
We have
$$
f(t, t, c) \geq \frac{3}{2} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{t}{t+c}+\frac{t}{t+c}+\frac{c}{2 t} \geq \frac{3}{2} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad 2(t-c)^{2} \geq 0
$$
which is obviously true.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c$.

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d > 0$ be real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\left(\frac{1}{a b}+\frac{1}{a c}+\frac{1}{a d}+\frac{1}{b c}+\frac{1}{b d}+\frac{1}{c d}\right) \quad () \quad \frac{3}{8}\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}+\frac{1}{d}\right)^{2}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
If we multiply both sides by $(a b c d)^{2}$ the above inequality becomes
$$
a b c d(c d+b d+b c+a d+a c+a b) \leq \frac{3}{8}(b c d+a c d+a b d+a b c)^{2}
$$

$\Leftrightarrow \quad a b c d\left(\frac{c d+b d+b c+a d+a c+a b}{6}\right) \leq\left(\frac{b c d+a c d+a b d+a b c}{4}\right)^{2}$
$\Leftrightarrow \quad p_{4} p_{2} \leq p_{3}^{2}$.
The last inequality is true, due to Newton's inequality.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=d$.

Theorem 61.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}>0$. Then
$$
p_{1} \geq p_{2}^{\frac{1}{2}} \geq \cdots \geq p_{k}^{\frac{1}{k}} \geq \cdots \geq p_{n}^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

Theorem 60.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}>0$ be arbitrary real numbers. Then for each $k=1,2, \ldots, n-1$, we have
$$
p_{k-1} p_{k+1} \leq p_{k}^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:

$$

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+3 a b c \quad () \quad a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)+c a(c+a) .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since the above inequality is homogenous, we may assume that $a+b+$ $c=1$.

Then clearly $q \in[0,1]$ and the given inequality becomes
$$
27 r+4 q^{2}-1 \geq 0
$$

If $q \geq \frac{1}{2}$, then we are done.
If $q \leq \frac{1}{2}$, by Theorem 15.1, we have
$$
27 r+4 q^{2}-1 \geq 27 \frac{(1+q)^{2}(1-2 q)}{27}+4 q^{2}-1=q^{2}(1-2 q) \geq 0
$$
as required.
Equality occurs iff $(a, b, c)=(t, t, t)$ or $(a, b, c)=(t, t, 0)$, where $t \geq 0$ is an arbitrary real number (up to permutation).

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

Theorem 74.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a+b+$ $c=p$.
Let $a b+b c+c a=\frac{p^{2}-q^{2}}{3},(q \geq 0)$ and $a b c=r$.
Then
$$
\frac{(p+q)^{2}(p-2 q)}{27} \leq r \leq \frac{(p-q)^{2}(p+2 q)}{27}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)=0$.

Theorem 73.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a+b+c=1$ and let
$$
a b+b c+c a=\frac{1-q^{2}}{3} \quad(q \geq 0)
$$

Then we have the following inequalities
$$
\frac{(1+q)^{2}(1-2 q)}{27} \leq a b c \leq \frac{(1-q)^{2}(1+2 q)}{27}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
a^{5}+b^{5}+c^{5} \quad () \quad a^{4} b+b^{4} c+c^{4} a \text {. }
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$, and then clearly $a^{4} \geq b^{4} \geq c^{4}$ (since the given inequality is cyclic we also need to consider the case when $c \geq b \geq a$, which is analogous).

Now by the rearrangement inequality we get the required inequality. Equality occurs iff $a=b=c$.

Since $A M \geq G M$ we obtain the following inequalities:
$$
\begin{array}{r}
a^{5}+a^{5}+a^{5}+a^{5}+b^{5} \geq 5 a^{4} b \\
b^{5}+b^{5}+b^{5}+b^{5}+c^{5} \geq 5 b^{4} c \\
c^{5}+c^{5}+c^{5}+c^{5}+a^{5} \geq 5 c^{4} a
\end{array}
$$
and adding the previous three inequalities yields required inequality. Equality occurs iff $a=b=c$.

Theorem 37.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers and let $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a permutation of $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$. Then
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \geq a_{1} x_{1}+a_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} x_{n}
$$

problem:
Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ be positive real numbers with product 1. Consider the following inequality:
$$
n^{n} \cdot \prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}^{n}+1\right) \quad () \quad \left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x_{i}}\right)^{n}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Using the AM-GM Inequality, we deduce that

$$
\frac{x_{1}^{n}}{1+x_{1}^{n}}+\frac{x_{2}^{n}}{1+x_{2}^{n}}+\cdots+\frac{x_{n-1}^{n}}{1+x_{n-1}^{n}}+\frac{1}{1+x_{n}^{n}} \geq \frac{n}{x_{n} \cdot \sqrt[n]{\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+x_{i}^{n}\right)}}
$$

and

$$
\frac{1}{1+x_{1}^{n}}+\frac{1}{1+x_{2}^{n}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{1+x_{n-1}^{n}}+\frac{x_{n}^{n}}{1+x_{n}^{n}} \geq \frac{n \cdot x_{n}}{\sqrt[n]{\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+x_{i}^{n}\right)}}
$$

Thus, we have

$$
\sqrt[n]{\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+x_{i}^{n}\right)} \geq x_{n}+\frac{1}{x_{n}}
$$

Of course, this is true for any other variable, so we can add all these inequalities to obtain that

$$
n \sqrt[n]{\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(1+x_{i}^{n}\right)} \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x_{i}}
$$

which is the desired inequality.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Consider the following inequality for any real number $x$:
$$
x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1 \quad () \quad 0 .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We consider two cases: $x<1$ and $x \geq 1$.
(1) Let $x<1$. We have
$$
x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1=x^{12}+\left(x^{4}-x^{9}\right)+(1-x)
$$

Since $x<1$ we have $1-x>0$ and $x^{4}>x^{9}$, i.e. $x^{4}-x^{9}>0$, so in this case
$$
x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1>0
$$
i.e. the desired inequality holds.
(2) For $x \geq 1$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1 & =x^{8}\left(x^{4}-x\right)+\left(x^{4}-x\right)+1 \\
& =\left(x^{4}-x\right)\left(x^{8}+1\right)+1=x\left(x^{3}-1\right)\left(x^{8}+1\right)+1
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $x \geq 1$ we have $x^{3} \geq 1$, i.e. $x^{3}-1 \geq 0$.
Therefore
$$
x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1>0
$$
and the problem is solved.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{1}{2-a} + \frac{1}{2-b} + \frac{1}{2-c} \quad () \quad 3
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Rewrite the given inequality as follows
$$
\frac{a}{2-a}+\frac{b}{2-b}+\frac{c}{2-c} \geq 3
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{2 a-a^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{2 b-b^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{2 c-c^{2}} \geq 3
$$

Clearly $a, b, c \in(0, \sqrt{3})$, so $2 a-a^{2}, 2 b-b^{2}, 2 c-c^{2}>0$.
Now by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality (Corollary 4.3 ) we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a^{2}}{2 a-a^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{2 b-b^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{2 c-c^{2}} & \geq \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{2(a+b+c)-\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)} \\
& =\frac{9}{2(a+b+c)-3}
\end{aligned}
$$

So it remains to prove that
$$
\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{2(a+b+c)-3} \geq 3
$$
which is equivalent to $(a+b+c-3)^{2} \geq 0$, and clearly holds.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 29.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers such that $b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}>0$. Then
$$
\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{2}}{b_{n}} \geq \frac{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2}}{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}}
$$
with equality if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the side lengths of a given triangle. Consider the following expressions:
$$
8(a+b-c)(b+c-a)(c+a-b) \quad () \quad (a+b)(b+c)(c+a)
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \geq 2 \sqrt{a b} 2 \sqrt{b c} 2 \sqrt{c a}=8 a b c
$$

So, it suffices to show that
$$
8 a b c \geq 8(a+b-c)(b+c-a)(c+a-b)
$$
i.e.
$$
a b c \geq(a+b-c)(b+c-a)(c+a-b)
$$
which is true by Exercise 3.4.
Equality occurs if and only if $a=b=c$.

Theorem 23.Theorem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, and let us denote
$$
\begin{aligned}
Q M & =\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{3}}, \quad A M=\frac{a+b+c}{3}, \quad G M=\sqrt[3]{a b c} \text { and } \\
H M & =\frac{3}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}

$$

Then
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a=b=c$.

Theorem 59.Theorem:
Let $a=\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, and let $m=\left(m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}\right)$ also be a sequence of positive real numbers such that $m_{1}+m_{2}+\cdots+m_{n}=1$.
Then for each $r \leq s$ we have
$$
M_{r}^{m}(a) \leq M_{s}^{m}(a)
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{r}+m_{2} a_{2}^{r}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{r}} \leq\left(m_{1} a_{1}^{s}+m_{2} a_{2}^{s}+\cdots+m_{n} a_{n}^{s}\right)^{\frac{1}{s}}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$ be real numbers such that $a+b+c>0$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \quad () \quad \left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}+3 a b c .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
If we define
$$
x=\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}}, \quad y=\frac{b}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}}, \quad z=\frac{c}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}}
$$
then the given inequality becomes
$$
x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3} \leq\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}+3 x y z, \quad \text { with } x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=1
$$

So it suffices to prove that
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \leq\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}+3 a b c, \quad \text { with condition } a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1
$$
i.e.
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \leq 1+3 a b c, \quad \text { with } a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1
$$

Let us define
$$
f=a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-3 a b c, \quad g=a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-1
$$
and
$$
L=f-\lambda g=a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-3 a b c-\lambda\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-1\right)
$$

We obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial a}=3 a^{2}-3 b c-2 \lambda a=0 \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial b}=3 b^{2}-3 a c-2 \lambda b=0 \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial c}=3 c^{2}-3 a b-2 \lambda c=0
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
\lambda=\frac{3\left(a^{2}-b c\right)}{2 a}=\frac{3\left(b^{2}-a c\right)}{2 b}=\frac{3\left(c^{2}-a b\right)}{2 c}
$$

Thus
$$
\frac{3\left(a^{2}-b c\right)}{2 a}=\frac{3\left(b^{2}-a c\right)}{2 b} \Leftrightarrow(a-b)(a b+b c+c a)=0
$$

Similarly we deduce
$$
(b-c)(a b+b c+c a)=0 \quad \text { and } \quad(c-a)(a b+b c+c a)=0
$$

By solving these equations we deduce that we must have $a=b=c$ or $a b+b c+$ $c a=0$.

If $a=b=c$ then $f(a, a, a)=0<1$.
If $a b+b c+c a=0$ then
$$
(a+b+c)^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2(a b+b c+c a)=1
$$
and since $a+b+c>0$ we obtain $a+b+c=1$.
Therefore
$f(a, b, c)=a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-3 a b c=(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-a b-b c-c a\right)=1$, and the problem is solved.

Then the maximum or minimum values of $f$ with the conditions $g_{i}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots\right.$, $\left.x_{m}\right)=0, i=1,2, \ldots, k$, occur at the bounds of the interval $I$ or occur at the points at which the partial derivatives (according to the variables $\left.x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)$ of the function $L=f-\sum_{i=1}^{k} \lambda_{i} g_{i}$, are all zero.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be real numbers such that $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=1$. Consider the following expression:
$$
x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}-3 x y z \quad () \quad 1.
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $t=x y+y z+z x$. Let us observe that

$$
\left(x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}-3 x y z\right)^{2}=(x+y+z)^{2}(1-x y-y z-z x)^{2}=(1+2 t)(1-t)^{2}
$$

We also have $-\frac{1}{2} \leq t \leq 1$. Thus, we must find the maximum value of the expression $(1+2 t)(1-t)^{2}$, where $-\frac{1}{2} \leq t \leq 1$. In this case we clearly have $(1+2 t)(t-1)^{2} \leq 1 \Leftrightarrow$ $t^{2}(3-2 t) \geq 0$ and thus $\left|x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}-3 x y z\right| \leq 1$. We have equality for $x=1, y=z=0$ and thus the maximum value is 1 .

\end{aligned}

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a b c = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{a^{3}+b^{3}+1}+\frac{1}{b^{3}+c^{3}+1}+\frac{1}{c^{3}+a^{3}+1} \quad () \quad 1
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have
$$
\frac{1}{a^{3}+b^{3}+1}=\frac{1}{(a+b)\left((a-b)^{2}+a b\right)+1} \leq \frac{1}{(a+b) a b+1}
$$
and since $a b=\frac{1}{c}$ we deduce
$$
\frac{1}{a^{3}+b^{3}+1} \leq \frac{1}{(a+b) a b+1}=\frac{c}{a+b+c}
$$

Similarly
$$
\frac{1}{b^{3}+c^{3}+1} \leq \frac{a}{a+b+c} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{c^{3}+a^{3}+1} \leq \frac{b}{a+b+c}
$$

Adding the last three inequalities we obtain the required inequality.
Equality holds if and only if $a=b=c=1$.

problem:
If $x, y, z$ are positive real numbers, consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{x^{2}+x y+y^{2}}+\frac{1}{y^{2}+y z+z^{2}}+\frac{1}{z^{2}+z x+z^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{9}{(x+y+z)^{2}} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Considering the relation

$$
x^{2}+x y+y^{2}=(x+y+z)^{2}-(x y+y z+z x)-(x+y+z) z
$$

we get

$$
\frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{x^{2}+x y+y^{2}}=\frac{1}{1-\frac{x y+y z+z x}{(x+y+z)^{2}}-\frac{z}{x+y+z}}
$$

or

$$
\frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{x^{2}+x y+y^{2}}=\frac{1}{1-(a b+b c+c a)-c}
$$

where $a=\frac{x}{x+y+z}, b=\frac{y}{x+y+z}, c=\frac{z}{x+y+z}$. The inequality can be rewritten as

$$
\frac{1}{1-d-c}+\frac{1}{1-d-b}+\frac{1}{1-d-a} \geq 9
$$

where $a, b, c$ are positive reals with $a+b+c=1$ and $d=a b+b c+c a$. After making some computations the inequality becomes

$$
9 d^{3}-6 d^{2}-3 d+1+9 a b c \geq 0
$$

or

$$
d(3 d-1)^{2}+(1-4 d+9 a b c) \geq 0
$$

which is Schur's Inequality.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\sqrt{a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}}+\sqrt{a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}} \quad () \quad \sqrt{a^{3} b+b^{3} c+c^{3} a}+\sqrt{a b^{3}+b c^{3}+c a^{3}} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
It is clear that it suffices to prove the following inequalities

$$
\sum a^{4}+\sum a^{2} b^{2} \geq \sum a^{3} b+\sum a b^{3}
$$

and

$$
\left(\sum a^{4}\right)\left(\sum a^{2} b^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum a^{3} b\right)\left(\sum a b^{3}\right)
$$

The first one follows from Schur's Inequality

$$
\sum a^{4}+a b c \sum a \geq \sum a^{3} b+\sum a b^{3}
$$

and the fact that

$$
\sum a^{2} b^{2} \geq a b c \sum a
$$

The second one is a simple consequence of the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a^{3} b+b^{3} c+c^{3} a\right)^{2} \leq\left(a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}\right)\left(a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}\right) \\
& \left(a b^{3}+b c^{3}+c a^{3}\right)^{2} \leq\left(a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}\right)\left(a^{4}+b^{4}+c^{4}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c=3$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{a+2 b^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{b+2 c^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{c+2 a^{2}} \quad () \quad 1
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Applying $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{a+2 b^{2}}=a-\frac{2 a b^{2}}{a+2 b^{2}} \geq a-\frac{2 a b^{2}}{3 \sqrt[3]{a b^{4}}}=a-\frac{2(a b)^{2 / 3}}{3}
$$

Analogously we obtain
$$
\frac{b^{2}}{b+2 c^{2}} \geq b-\frac{2(b c)^{2 / 3}}{3} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{c^{2}}{c+2 a^{2}} \geq c-\frac{2(c a)^{2 / 3}}{3}
$$

Adding these three inequalities gives us
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{a+2 b^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{b+2 c^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{c+2 a^{2}} \geq(a+b+c)-\frac{2}{3}\left((a b)^{2 / 3}+(b c)^{2 / 3}+(c a)^{2 / 3}\right)
$$

So it is enough to show that
$$
(a+b+c)-\frac{2}{3}\left((a b)^{2 / 3}+(b c)^{2 / 3}+(c a)^{2 / 3}\right) \geq 1
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
(a b)^{2 / 3}+(b c)^{2 / 3}+(c a)^{2 / 3} \leq 3 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Applying $A M \geq G M$ we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
(a b)^{2 / 3}+(b c)^{2 / 3}+(c a)^{2 / 3} & \leq \frac{(a+a b+b)+(b+b c+c)+(c+c a+a)}{3} \\
& =\frac{2(a+b+c)+(a b+b c+c a)}{3} \\
& \leq \frac{2(a+b+c)+(a+b+c)^{2} / 3}{3}=\frac{2 \cdot 3+3^{2} / 3}{3}=3
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e. we have proved (1), and we are done.

Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 29.Theorem:

$$
with equality if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers satisfying the condition
$$
x^{2} + y^{2} + z^{2} + 2 x y z = 1.
$$
Consider the following expressions:
$$
x y + x z + y z \quad () \quad \frac{3}{4}.
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
These inequalities are simple consequences of a) and b):

$$
x y+x z+y z \leq \frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{3} \leq \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{9}{4}=\frac{3}{4}
$$

and

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=1-2 x y z \geq 1-2 \cdot \frac{1}{8}=\frac{3}{4}
$$

Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n} ; m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}$ be three sequences of positive real numbers and let $p>1$. Then

Then

\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{q}\right)^{\frac{1}{q}}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\frac{a_{1}^{p}}{b_{1}^{q}}=\frac{a_{2}^{p}}{b_{2}^{q}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}^{p}}{b_{n}^{q}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ be real numbers. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{c^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $\frac{a}{b}=x, \frac{b}{c}=y, \frac{c}{a}=z$. Then it is clear that $x y z=1$, and the given inequality becomes
$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} \geq x+y+z
$$

From $Q M \geq A M$ we have
$$
\sqrt{\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{3}} \geq \frac{x+y+z}{3}
$$
i.e.
$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} \geq \frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{3} \geq \frac{3 \sqrt[3]{x y z}(x+y+x)}{3}=x+y+z
$$

are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have

problem:
Suppose that $a_{1}<a_{2}<\ldots<a_{n}$ are real numbers for some integer $n \geq 2$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
a_{1} a_{2}^{4}+a_{2} a_{3}^{4}+\ldots+a_{n} a_{1}^{4} \quad () \quad a_{2} a_{1}^{4}+a_{3} a_{2}^{4}+\ldots+a_{1} a_{n}^{4}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution: A quick look shows that as soon as we prove the inequality for $n=3$, it will be proved by induction for larger $n$. Thus, we must prove that for any $a<b<c$ we have $a b\left(b^{3}-a^{3}\right)+b c\left(c^{3}-b^{3}\right) \geq c a\left(c^{3}-a^{3}\right) \Leftrightarrow\left(c^{3}-b^{3}\right)(a c-b c) \leq\left(b^{3}-a^{3}\right)(a b-a c)$. Because $a<b<c$, the last inequality reduces to $a\left(b^{2}+a b+a^{2}\right) \leq c\left(c^{2}+b c+b^{2}\right)$. And this last inequality is equivalent to $(c-a)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+a b+b c+c a\right) \geq 0$, which is clear.

Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ be a sequence of non-negative real numbers and let $\left(\alpha_{i}\right)$ and $\left(\beta_{i}\right)$ be sequences of positive real numbers such that $\left(\beta_{i}\right) \prec\left(\alpha_{i}\right)$. Then

Theorem 62.Theorem:
Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\beta>0$. Then we have
$$
T[\alpha+2 \beta, 0,0]+T[\alpha, \beta, \beta] \geq 2 T[\alpha+\beta, \beta, 0]
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers such that $a b + b c + c a = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a^{2}}{1+a}+\frac{b^{2}}{1+b}+\frac{c^{2}}{1+c} \quad () \quad \frac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{3}+1} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above

Let $a, b, c$ be the lengths of the sides of a given triangle, and $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be the respective angles (in radians). Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{b+c-a}{a \alpha}+\frac{c+a-b}{b \beta}+\frac{a+b-c}{c \gamma} \quad () \quad \frac{9}{\pi} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $x=\frac{b+c-a}{a}, y=\frac{c+a-b}{b}$ and $z=\frac{a+b-c}{c}$.
Without loss the generality we may assume $a \leq b \leq c$. Then $\alpha \leq \beta \leq \gamma$.
Also $x \geq y \geq z$ and $\frac{1}{\alpha} \geq \frac{1}{\beta} \geq \frac{1}{\gamma}$.
Chebishev's inequality gives us
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\frac{x}{\alpha}+\frac{y}{\beta}+\frac{z}{\gamma}\right) & \geq \frac{1}{3}(x+y+z)\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\gamma}\right) \\
& \geq \frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{b+c-a}{a}+\frac{c+a-b}{b}+\frac{a+b-c}{c}\right) \cdot \frac{9}{\pi} \\
& =\frac{3}{\pi}\left(\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a}+\frac{a}{c}+\frac{c}{a}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{b}-3\right) \geq \frac{3}{\pi}(2+2+2-3)=\frac{9}{\pi}
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
For a given $n>2$, let $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} > 0$ have product 1. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a_{1} a_{2}}{\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}\right)\left(a_{2}^{2}+a_{1}\right)}+\frac{a_{2} a_{3}}{\left(a_{2}^{2}+a_{3}\right)\left(a_{3}^{2}+a_{2}\right)}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n} a_{1}}{\left(a_{n}^{2}+a_{1}\right)\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{n}\right)} \quad () \quad n-2
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let us take first $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n-1}=x, a_{n}=\frac{1}{x^{n-1}}$. We infer that

$$
k_{n} \geq \frac{2 x^{2 n-1}}{\left(x^{n+1}+1\right)\left(x^{2 n-1}+1\right)}+\frac{n-2}{(1+x)^{2}}>\frac{n-2}{(1+x)^{2}}
$$

for all $x>0$. Clearly, this implies $k_{n} \geq n-2$. Let us prove that $n-2$ is a good constant and the problem will be solved.

First, we will prove that $\left(x^{2}+y\right)\left(y^{2}+x\right) \geq x y(1+x)(1+y)$. Indeed, this is the same as $(x+y)(x-y)^{2} \geq 0$. So, it suffices to prove that

$$
\frac{1}{\left(1+a_{1}\right)\left(1+a_{2}\right)}+\frac{1}{\left(1+a_{2}\right)\left(1+a_{3}\right)}+\cdots+\frac{1}{\left(1+a_{n}\right)\left(1+a_{1}\right)} \leq n-2
$$

Now, we take $a_{1}=\frac{x_{1}}{x_{2}}, \ldots, a_{n}=\frac{x_{n}}{x_{1}}$ and the above inequality becomes

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(1-\frac{x_{k+1} x_{k+2}}{\left(x_{k}+x_{k+1}\right)\left(x_{k+1}+x_{k+2}\right)}\right) \geq 2
$$

which can be also written in the following from

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{x_{k}}{x_{k}+x_{k+1}}+\frac{x_{k+1}^{2}}{\left(x_{k}+x_{k+1}\right)\left(x_{k+1}+x_{k+2}\right)} \geq 2
$$

Clearly,

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{x_{k}}{x_{k}+x_{k+1}} \geq \sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{x_{k}}{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}=1
$$

So, we have to prove the inequality

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{x_{k+1}^{2}}{\left(x_{k}+x_{k+1}\right)\left(x_{k+1}+x_{k+2}\right)} \geq 1
$$

Using the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality, we infer that

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{x_{k+1}^{2}}{\left(x_{k}+x_{k+1}\right)\left(x_{k+1}+x_{k+2}\right)} \geq \frac{\left(\sum_{k+1}^{n} x_{k}\right)^{2}}{\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(x_{k}+x_{k+1}\right)\left(x_{k+1}+x_{k+2}\right)}
$$

and so it suffices to prove that

$$
\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k}\right)^{2} \geq \sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k}^{2}+2 \sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k} x_{k+1}+\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k} x_{k+2}
$$

But this one is equivalent to

$$
2 \sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n} x_{i} x_{j} \geq 2 \sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k} x_{k+1}+\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k} x_{k+2}
$$

and it is clear. Thus, $k_{n}=n-2$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a b + b c + c a = \frac{1}{3}$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a}{a^{2} - b c + 1} + \frac{b}{b^{2} - c a + 1} + \frac{c}{c^{2} - a b + 1} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{a + b + c}
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a}{a^{2}-b c+1}+\frac{b}{b^{2}-c a+1}+\frac{c}{c^{2}-a b+1} \\
& \quad=\frac{a^{2}}{a^{3}-a b c+a}+\frac{b^{2}}{b^{3}-a b c+b}+\frac{c^{2}}{c^{3}-a b c+c} \\
& \quad \geq \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+a+b+c-3 a b c}
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, since
$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-3 a b c & =(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-a b-b c-c a\right) \\
& =(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-1 / 3\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+a+b+c-3 a b c} & =\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+1-1 / 3\right)} \\
& =\frac{a+b+c}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2 / 3} \\
& =\frac{a+b+c}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2(a b+b c+c a)} \\
& =\frac{1}{a+b+c},
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c+d=4$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a}{b^{2}+b}+\frac{b}{c^{2}+c}+\frac{c}{d^{2}+d}+\frac{d}{a^{2}+a} \quad () \quad \frac{8}{(a+c)(b+d)} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Denote $A=\frac{a}{b^{2}+b}+\frac{b}{c^{2}+c}+\frac{c}{d^{2}+d}+\frac{d}{a^{2}+a}$.
Consider the function $f(x)=\frac{1}{x(x+1)}$. Then $f$ is convex for $x>0$.
According to Jensen's inequality, we have
$$
\frac{a}{4} \cdot f(b)+\frac{b}{4} \cdot f(c)+\frac{c}{4} \cdot f(d)+\frac{d}{4} \cdot f(a) \geq f\left(\frac{a b+b c+c d+d a}{4}\right)
$$
i.e.
$$
A \geq \frac{64}{(a b+b c+c d+d a)^{2}+4(a b+b c+c d+d a)}
$$

So it remains to prove that
$$
\frac{64}{(a b+b c+c d+d a)^{2}+4(a b+b c+c d+d a)} \geq \frac{8}{(a+c)(b+d)}
$$
i.e.
$$
a b+b c+c d+d a \leq 4
$$
i.e.
$$
(a-b+c-d)^{2} \geq 0
$$
which is obviously true. Equality holds iff $a=b=c=d=1$.

problem:
For positive real numbers $a, b, c$ such that $a b c \leq 1$, consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a} \quad () \quad a+b+c
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
If $a b+b c+c a \leq a+b+c$, then the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality solves the problem:

$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}=\frac{a^{2} c+b^{2} a+c^{2} b}{a b c} \geq \frac{\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}}}{a b c} \geq a+b+c
$$

Otherwise, the same inequality gives

$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}=\frac{a^{2} c+b^{2} a+c^{2} b}{a b c} \geq \frac{\frac{(a b+b c+c a)^{2}}{a+b+c}}{a b c} \geq a+b+c
$$

(here we have used the fact that $a b c \leq 1$ ).

Using the AM-GM Inequality, we deduce that

$$
\frac{2 a}{b}+\frac{b}{c} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{a^{2}}{b c}} \geq 3 a
$$

Similarly, $\frac{2 b}{c}+\frac{c}{a} \geq 3 b$ and $\frac{2 c}{a}+\frac{a}{b} \geq 3 c$. Adding these three inequalities, the conclusion is immediate.

Let $x=\sqrt[9]{\frac{a b^{4}}{c^{2}}}, y=\sqrt[9]{\frac{c a^{4}}{b^{2}}}, z=\sqrt[9]{\frac{b c^{4}}{a^{2}}}$. Consequently, $a=x y^{2}, b=z x^{2}, c=y z^{2}$, and also $x y z \leq 1$. Thus, using the Rearrangement Inequality, we find that

$$
\sum \frac{a}{b}=\sum \frac{x^{2}}{y z} \geq x y z \sum \frac{x^{2}}{y z}=\sum x^{3} \geq \sum x y^{2}=\sum a
$$

Replacing $a, b, c$ by $t a, t b, t c$ with $t=\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{a b c}}$ preserves the value of the quantity in the left-hand side of the inequality and increases the value of the right-hand side and makes $a t \cdot b t \cdot c t=a b c t^{3}=1$. Hence we may assume without loss of generality that $a b c=1$. Then there exist positive real numbers $x, y, z$ such that $a=\frac{y}{x}, b=\frac{z}{y}, c=\frac{x}{z}$. The Rearrangement Inequality gives

$$
x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3} \geq x^{2} y+y^{2} z+z^{2} x
$$

Thus

$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}=\frac{x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}}{x y z} \geq \frac{x^{2} y+y^{2} z+z^{2} x}{x y z}=a+b+c
$$

as desired.

Theorem 2.Theorem:
If $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are nonnegative real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} \geq\left(a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}$. This inequality is a special case of the Power Mean Inequality.

problem:
Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{2004}$ be real numbers in the interval $[-1,1]$ such that $x_{1}^{3}+x_{2}^{3}+\ldots+x_{2004}^{3}=0$. Consider the following expression:
$$
x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{2004} \quad () \quad  \sqrt[3]{223} \cdot \sqrt[3]{1781^{2}}-223.
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let us take $a_{i}=x_{i}^{3}$ and the function $f:[-1,1] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, f(x)=x^{\frac{1}{3}}$. We will prove first the following properties of $f$ :

1. $f(x+y+1)+f(-1) \geq f(x)+f(y)$ if $-1<x, y<0$.
2. $f$ is convex on $[-1,0]$ and concave on $[0,1]$.
3. If $x>0$ and $y<0$ and $x+y<0$ then $f(x)+f(y) \leq f(-1)+f(x+y+1)$ and if $x+y>0$ then $f(x)+f(y) \leq f(x+y)$. The proofs of these results are easy. Indeed, for the first one we make the substitution $x=-a^{3}, y=-b^{3}$ and it comes down to $1>a^{3}+b^{3}+(1-a-b)^{3} \Leftrightarrow 1>(a+b)\left(a^{2}-a b+b^{2}\right)+1-3(a+b)+3(a+b)^{2}-(a+b)^{3} \Leftrightarrow$ $\Leftrightarrow 3(a+b)(1-a)(1-b)>0$, which follows. The second statement is clear and the third one can be easily deduced in the same manner as 1.

From these arguments we deduce that if $\left(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{2004}\right)=t$ is the point where the maximum value of the function $g: A=\left\{x \in[-1,1]^{2004} \mid x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}=0\right\} \rightarrow$ $\rightarrow \mathbb{R}, g\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{2004}\right)=\sum_{k=1}^{2004} f\left(x_{k}\right)$ (this maximum exists because this function is defined on a compact) is attained then we have that all positive components of $t$ are equal to each other and all negative ones are $-1$ . So, suppose we have $k$ components equal to $-1$ and $2004- k$ components equal to a number $a$. Because $t_{1}+t_{2}+\cdots+t_{2004}=$ 0 we find that $a=\frac{k}{2004-k}$ and the value of $g$ in this point is $(2004-k) \sqrt[3]{\frac{k}{2004-k}}-k$. Thus we have to find the maximum value of $(2004-k) \sqrt[3]{\frac{k}{2004-k}}-k$, when $k$ is in the set $\{0,1, \ldots, 2004\}$. A short analysis with derivatives shows that the maximum is attained when $k=223$ and so the maximum value is $\sqrt[3]{223} \cdot \sqrt[3]{1781^{2}}-223$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the side-lengths of a triangle. Consider the following expressions:
$$
\frac{a}{3a-b+c} + \frac{b}{3b-c+a} + \frac{c}{3c-a+b} \quad () \quad 1
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{4 a}{3 a-b+c}+\frac{4 b}{3 b-c+a}+\frac{4 c}{3 c-a+b} \\
& \quad=3+\frac{a+b-c}{3 a-b+c}+\frac{b+c-a}{3 b-c+a}+\frac{c+a-b}{3 c-a+b}
\end{aligned}
$$

So it remains to show that
$$
\frac{a+b-c}{3 a-b+c}+\frac{b+c-a}{3 b-c+a}+\frac{c+a-b}{3 c-a+b} \geq 1
$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a+b-c}{3 a-b+c}+\frac{b+c-a}{3 b-c+a}+\frac{c+a-b}{3 c-a+b} \\
& \quad=\frac{(a+b-c)^{2}}{(3 a-b+c)(a+b-c)}+\frac{(b+c-a)^{2}}{(3 b-c+a)(b+c-a)} \\
& \quad+\frac{(c+a-b)^{2}}{(3 c-a+b)(c+a-b)} \\
& \quad \geq \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{(3 a-b+c)(a+b-c)+(3 b-c+a)(b+c-a)+(3 c-a+b)(c+a-b)} \\
& \quad=1
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.
Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

Theorem 29.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers such that $b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}>0$. Then
$$
\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{2}}{b_{n}} \geq \frac{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2}}{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}}
$$
with equality if and only if $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $x, y, z > 0$ be real numbers such that $x + y + z = x y z$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
(x-1)(y-1)(z-1) \quad () \quad 6 \sqrt{3} - 10 .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since $x<x y z$ we have $y z>1$ and analogously $x z>1$ and $x y>1$. At most one of $x, y, z$ can be less than 1 .

Let $x \leq 1, y \geq 1, z \geq 1$. Then we have $(x-1)(y-1)(z-1) \leq 0$, so the given inequality holds.

So it's enough to consider the case when $x \geq 1, y \geq 1, z \geq 1$.
Let $x-1=a, y-1=b, z-1=c$.
Then $a, b, c$ are non-negative and since $x=a+1, y=b+1, z=c+1$ we obtain
$$
\begin{align*}
a+1+b+1+c+1 & =(a+1)(b+1)(c+1), \quad \text { i.e. } \\
a b c+a b+b c+c a & =2 \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

Let $x=\sqrt[3]{a b c}$, so we have
$$
\begin{equation*}
a b+b c+c a \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}}=3 x^{2} \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Combine (1) and (2) we have
$$
x^{3}+3 x^{2} \leq a b c+a b+b c+c a=2 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad(x+1)\left(x^{2}+2 x-2\right) \leq 0
$$
so we must have $x^{2}+2 x-2 \leq 0$ and we easily deduce that $x \leq \sqrt{3}-1$, i.e. we get
$$
x^{3} \leq(\sqrt{3}-1)^{3}=6 \sqrt{3}-10
$$
and we are done.

problem:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{x^{3}}{y z}+\frac{y^{3}}{z x}+\frac{z^{3}}{x y} \quad () \quad x+y+z .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Since the given inequality is symmetric we may assume that $x \geq y \geq z$.
Then
$$
x^{3} \geq y^{3} \geq z^{3} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{y z} \geq \frac{1}{z x} \geq \frac{1}{x y}
$$

By the rearrangement inequality we have
$$
\begin{align*}
\frac{x^{3}}{y z}+\frac{y^{3}}{z x}+\frac{z^{3}}{x y} & =x^{3} \cdot \frac{1}{y z}+y^{3} \cdot \frac{1}{z x}+z^{3} \cdot \frac{1}{x y} \\
& \geq x^{3} \cdot \frac{1}{x y}+y^{3} \cdot \frac{1}{y z}+z^{3} \cdot \frac{1}{z x}=\frac{x^{2}}{y}+\frac{y^{2}}{z}+\frac{z^{2}}{x} \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

We will prove that
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{x^{2}}{y}+\frac{y^{2}}{z}+\frac{z^{2}}{x} \geq x+y+z \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Let $x \geq y \geq z$.
Then $x^{2} \geq y^{2} \geq z^{2}$ and $\frac{1}{z} \geq \frac{1}{y} \geq \frac{1}{x}$ (since inequality (6.4) is cyclic we also need to consider the case $z \geq y \geq x$ ).

By the rearrangement inequality we obtain
$$
\frac{x^{2}}{y}+\frac{y^{2}}{z}+\frac{z^{2}}{x} \geq \frac{x^{2}}{x}+\frac{y^{2}}{y}+\frac{z^{2}}{z}=x+y+z
$$

The case when $z \geq y \geq x$ is analogous to the previous case.
Now by (1) and (2) we obtain
$$
\frac{x^{3}}{y z}+\frac{y^{3}}{z x}+\frac{z^{3}}{x y} \geq x+y+z
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $x=y=z$.

Theorem 37.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers and let $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a permutation of $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$. Then
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \geq a_{1} x_{1}+a_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} x_{n}
$$

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $\max \{a, b, c\} - \min \{a, b, c\} \leq 1$. Consider the following expressions:
$$
1 + a^3 + b^3 + c^3 + 6abc \quad () \quad 3a^2b + 3b^2c + 3c^2a .
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution: Clearly, we may assume that $a=\min \{a, b, c\}$ and let us write $b=a+x, c=a+y$, where $x, y \in[0,1]$. It is easy to see that $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-3 a b c=3 a\left(x^{2}-x y+y^{2}\right)+x^{3}+y^{3}$ and $a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a-3 a b c=a\left(x^{2}-x y+y^{2}\right)+x^{2} y$. So, the inequality becomes $1+x^{3}+y^{3} \geq 3 x^{2} y$. But this follows from the fact that $1+x^{3}+y^{3} \geq 3 x y \geq 3 x^{2} y$, because $0 \leq x, y \leq 1$.

Theorem 28.Theorem:
Let $a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq \cdots \leq a_{n}$ and $b_{1} \leq b_{2} \leq$ $\cdots \leq b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leq n \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right) \leq n\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$ or $b_{1}=b_{2}=\cdots=b_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers such that $a+b+c=1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{a b}{c+1}+\frac{b c}{a+1}+\frac{c a}{b+1} \quad () \quad \frac{1}{4} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
If one of $a, b, c$ is equal to zero then it is easy to show that the given inequality is true. Equality in this case occurs iff one of $a, b, c$ is zero, and the other two numbers are equal to $1 / 2$.

Because of this we can assume that $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$.
From $a+b+c=1$ it follows that at least one of the numbers $a, b, c$ is less then $4 / 9$. In the opposite case, if all of them are greater then $4 / 9$, we will have
$$
a+b+c>3 \cdot \frac{4}{9}=\frac{4}{3}>1
$$
a contradiction.
So we can assume that
$$
\begin{equation*}
c<4 / 9 \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

Let $A=\frac{a b}{c+1}+\frac{b c}{a+1}+\frac{c a}{b+1}$.
Then
$$
\begin{equation*}
A=a b c\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}-\frac{1}{a+1}-\frac{1}{b+1}-\frac{1}{c+1}\right) \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

Since
$$
\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1}=\frac{1}{4}((a+1)+(b+1)+(c+1))\left(\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1}\right)
$$
applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{align*}
& \frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1} \\
& \quad=\frac{1}{4}((a+1)+(b+1)+(c+1))\left(\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1}\right) \\
& \quad \geq \frac{1}{4}(1+1+1)^{2}=\frac{9}{4} \tag{3}
\end{align*}
$$

Now using (2) and (3) we obtain
$$
\begin{align*}
A & =a b c\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}-\left(\frac{1}{a+1}+\frac{1}{b+1}+\frac{1}{c+1}\right)\right) \\
& \leq a b c\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}-\frac{9}{4}\right)=a b+a c+b c-\frac{9 a b c}{4} \tag{4}
\end{align*}
$$

On the other hand, we have
$$
(1-c)^{2}=(a+b)^{2} \geq 4 a b
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
a b \leq \frac{(1-c)^{2}}{4} \tag{5}
\end{equation*}
$$
and using (4) we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& A-\frac{1}{4} \leq a b+a c+b c-\frac{9 a b c}{4}-\frac{1}{4}=a b+c(a+b)-\frac{9 a b c}{4}-\frac{1}{4} \\
&=a b\left(1-\frac{9 c}{4}\right)+c(1-c)-\frac{1}{4} \\
& \stackrel{(1),(5)}{\leq} \frac{(1-c)^{2}}{4}\left(1-\frac{9 c}{4}\right)+c(1-c)-\frac{1}{4} \\
&=\frac{1}{16}\left(-9 c^{3}+6 c^{2}-c\right)=\frac{-c}{16}\left(9 c^{2}-6 c+1\right)=\frac{-c(3 c-1)^{2}}{16} \leq 0
\end{aligned}
$$
as required.
Equality occurs iff $a=b=c=1 / 3$.

Theorem 26.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ be real numbers. Then we have
$$
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right) \geq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \geq\left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
$$

Equality occurs if and only if the sequences $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right.$, $\ldots, b_{n}$ ) are proportional, i.e. $\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}=\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be the side lengths, $h_{a}, h_{b}, h_{c}$ be the altitudes, respectively, and $r$ be the inradius of a triangle. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{h_{a}-2 r}+\frac{1}{h_{b}-2 r}+\frac{1}{h_{c}-2 r} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{r} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
By $\frac{1}{h_{a}}+\frac{1}{h_{b}}+\frac{1}{h_{c}}=\frac{1}{r}$ we obtain
$$
\frac{h_{a}-2 r}{h_{a}}+\frac{h_{b}-2 r}{h_{b}}+\frac{h_{c}-2 r}{h_{c}}=1
$$

Applying $A M \geq H M$ we get
$$
\left(\frac{h_{a}-2 r}{h_{a}}+\frac{h_{b}-2 r}{h_{b}}+\frac{h_{c}-2 r}{h_{c}}\right)\left(\frac{h_{a}}{h_{a}-2 r}+\frac{h_{b}}{h_{b}-2 r}+\frac{h_{c}}{h_{c}-2 r}\right) \geq 9
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{h_{a}}{h_{a}-2 r}+\frac{h_{b}}{h_{b}-2 r}+\frac{h_{c}}{h_{c}-2 r} \geq 9
$$

Therefore
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{2 r}{h_{a}-2 r}+\frac{2 r}{h_{b}-2 r}+\frac{2 r}{h_{c}-2 r} \\
& \quad=\frac{h_{a}-\left(h_{a}-2 r\right)}{h_{a}-2 r}+\frac{h_{b}-\left(h_{b}-2 r\right)}{h_{b}-2 r}+\frac{h_{c}-\left(h_{c}-2 r\right)}{h_{c}-2 r} \\
& \quad=\frac{h_{a}}{h_{a}-2 r}+\frac{h_{b}}{h_{b}-2 r}+\frac{h_{c}}{h_{c}-2 r}-3 \geq 9-3=6
\end{aligned}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{1}{h_{a}-2 r}+\frac{1}{h_{b}-2 r}+\frac{1}{h_{c}-2 r} \geq \frac{3}{r}
$$

Theorem 35.Theorem:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers. The numbers
$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q M=\sqrt{\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}}{n}}, \quad A M=\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} \\
& G M=\sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad H M=\frac{n}{\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$
are called the quadratic, arithmetic, geometric and harmonic mean for the numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$, respectively, and we have
$$
Q M \geq A M \geq G M \geq H M
$$

Equalities occur if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a+b+c=3$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{2+a^{2}+b^{2}}+\frac{1}{2+b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{2+c^{2}+a^{2}} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{4} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Without loss of generality we may assume that $a \geq b \geq c$.
Let $f(a, b, c)=\frac{1}{2+a^{2}+b^{2}}+\frac{1}{2+b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{2+c^{2}+a^{2}}$.
We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(a & \left., \frac{b+c}{2}, \frac{b+c}{2}\right)-f(a, b, c) \\
& =\left(b^{2}+c^{2}-\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{2}\right) \\
& \times\left(\frac{1}{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}+2\right)\left(2+\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{2}\right)}-\frac{1}{\left(4+2 a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(4+2 a^{2}+\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{2}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since
$$
\begin{aligned}
b^{2}+c^{2} & \geq \frac{(b+c)^{2}}{2}, \quad 4+2 a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq b^{2}+c^{2}+2 \quad \text { and } \\
4+2 a^{2}+\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{2} & \geq 2+\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$
we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
f\left(a, \frac{b+c}{2}, \quad \frac{b+c}{2}\right)-f(a, b, c) & \geq 0, \quad \text { i.e. } \\
f\left(a, \frac{b+c}{2}, \frac{b+c}{2}\right) & \geq f(a, b, c)
\end{aligned}
$$

According to SMV theorem it suffices to prove that $f(a, t, t) \leq \frac{3}{4}$, when $a+2 t=3$.

We have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(a, t, t) \leq \frac{3}{4} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{2}{2+a^{2}+t^{2}}+\frac{1}{2+2 t^{2}} \leq \frac{3}{4} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{8}{8+4 a^{2}+(2 t)^{2}}+\frac{2}{4+(2 t)^{2}} \leq \frac{3}{4} \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{8}{8+4 a^{2}+(3-a)^{2}}+\frac{2}{4+(3-a)^{2}} \leq \frac{3}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$
which can be easily transformed to $(a-1)^{2}\left(15 a^{2}-78 a+111\right) \geq 0$, and clearly holds.

Equality holds iff $a=b=c=1$.

Theorem 79.Theorem:
Let $F: I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symmetric, continuous, function satisfying $F\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \geq F\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$, where the sequence $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$ is a sequence obtained from the sequence $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\right)$ by some predefined transformation ( $a \Delta$-transformation).
Then we have $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \geq F(x, x, \ldots, x)$, with $x=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}$.

problem:
Let $x$ and $y$ be positive real numbers. Consider the following expressions:
$$
x^{y} + y^{x} \quad () \quad 1
$$
Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution: We will prove that $a^{b} \geq \frac{a}{a+b-a b}$ for any $a, b \in(0,1)$. Indeed, from Bernoulli Inequality it follows that $a^{1-b}=(1+a-1)^{1-b} \leq 1+(a-1)(1-b)=a+b-a b$ and thus the conclusion. Now, it $x$ or $y$ is at least 1 , we are done. Otherwise, let $0<x, y<1$. In this case we apply the above observation and find that $x^{y}+y^{x} \geq$ $\frac{x}{x+y-x y}+\frac{y}{x+y-x y}>\frac{x}{x+y}+\frac{y}{x+y}=1$.

problem:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that $a+b+c=a b c$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+b^{2}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+c^{2}}} \quad () \quad \frac{3}{2} .
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
After taking $a=\tan \alpha, b=\tan \beta, c=\tan \gamma$ where $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in(0, \pi / 2)$, the given inequality becomes
$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{\sin ^{2} \alpha}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{\sin ^{2} \beta}{\cos ^{2} \beta}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{\sin ^{2} \gamma}{\cos ^{2} \gamma}}} \leq \frac{3}{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\cos \alpha+\cos \beta+\cos \gamma \leq \frac{3}{2}
$$

Also
$$
\begin{aligned}
\tan (\alpha+\beta+\gamma) & =\frac{\tan \alpha+\tan \beta+\tan \gamma-\tan \alpha \tan \beta \tan \gamma}{1-\tan \alpha \tan \beta-\tan \beta \tan \gamma-\tan \gamma \tan \alpha} \\
& =\frac{a+b+c-a b c}{1-a b-b c-c a}=0
\end{aligned}
$$
which means $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=\pi$.
The function $f(x)=-\cos x$ is convex on $[0, \pi / 2]$.
So by Jensen's inequality we have
$$
\frac{\cos \alpha+\cos \beta+\cos \gamma}{3} \leq \cos \frac{\alpha+\beta+\gamma}{3}=\frac{1}{2}
$$
i.e. we get
$$
\cos \alpha+\cos \beta+\cos \gamma \leq \frac{3}{2}
$$
as required.,Let $a=\frac{1}{x}, b=\frac{1}{y}, c=\frac{1}{z}$.
The constraint $a+b+c=a b c$ becomes $x y+y z+z x=1$, and the given inequality becomes equivalent to
$$
\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}}+\frac{y}{\sqrt{y^{2}+1}}+\frac{z}{\sqrt{z^{2}+1}} \leq \frac{3}{2}
$$
i.e.
$$
\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+x y+y z+z x}}+\frac{y}{\sqrt{y^{2}+x y+y z+z x}}+\frac{z}{\sqrt{z^{2}+x y+y z+z x}} \leq \frac{3}{2},
$$
i.e.
$$
\begin{equation*}
\frac{x}{\sqrt{(x+y)(x+z)}}+\frac{y}{\sqrt{(y+z)(y+x)}}+\frac{z}{\sqrt{(z+x)(z+y)}} \leq \frac{3}{2} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}
$$

By $A M \geq G M$ we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{x}{\sqrt{(x+y)(x+z)}} & =\frac{x \sqrt{(x+y)(x+z)}}{(x+y)(x+z)} \leq \frac{x((x+y)+(x+z))}{2(x+y)(x+z)} \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x}{x+y}+\frac{x}{x+z}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Analogously we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{y}{\sqrt{(y+z)(y+x)}} \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{y}{y+z}+\frac{y}{y+x}\right) \text { and } \\
& \frac{z}{\sqrt{(z+x)(z+y)}} \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{z}{z+x}+\frac{z}{z+y}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Adding these three inequalities we get inequality (1).

problem:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a + b + c = 1$. Consider the following inequality:
$$
\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}+a^{2}\right) \quad () \quad 8\left(a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Determine the correct inequality relation to fill in the blank.

Options:

(A) $\leq$ 

(B) $\geq$

(C) $=$ 

(D) $<$

(E) $>$

(F) None of the above
solution:
Let $x=\frac{1}{a}, y=\frac{1}{b}, z=\frac{1}{c}$. We find the equivalent form if $\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=1$ then

$$
\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\left(z^{2}+x^{2}\right) \geq 8\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

We will prove the following inequality

$$
\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\left(z^{2}+x^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}\right)^{2} \geq 8\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

for any positive numbers $x, y, z$.
Write $x^{2}+y^{2}=2 c, y^{2}+z^{2}=2 a, z^{2}+x^{2}=2 b$. Then the inequality becomes

$$
\sum \sqrt{\frac{a b c}{b+c-a}} \geq \sum a
$$
